Więzi transatlantyckie są tak silne, jak nigdy wcześniej. Jak w ciągu ostatnich siedmiu lat wyglądały, a jak będą wyglądać stosunki Europy ze Stanami Zjednoczonymi? To pytanie jest bardzo złożone.

title: Andrzej Duda w Londynie: Musimy zniechęcić każdego, kto chciałby zmienić świat siłą
authors: Euractiv.pl Euractiv.pl,Autor Barbara Bodalska,Almar Latour,Andrzej Duda,Podcast Europejski
description: Prezydent Andrzej Duda oświadczył wczoraj w Londynie, że po to, żeby przywrócić na świecie ład, którego podstawą są wspólne wartości, trzeba wspólnie odpowiedzieć na agresję i zniechęcić każdego, kto chciałby spróbować zmienić świat siłą. Dwudniową wizytę w Wielkiej Brytanii Andrzej Duda rozpoczął we wtorek (23 maja) od wystąpienia w czasie Londyńskiej Konferencji ws. Obronności.

title: Opinion | Press Freedom Is Your Freedom
description: The imprisonment of Journal reporter Evan Gerskhovich is a reminder of the fight we’re in. May 2, 2023 2:35 pm ETIf you’ve worn a “Free Evan” button, you know that most everyone who crosses your path will take note and signal that they support its cause. They usually say they want a pin for themselves, for their neighbors, colleagues and friends. Ambassadors, lawmakers, CEOs, store clerks and journalists alike all have asked to get their hands on one and join the campaign.

title: Opinion | Press Freedom Is Your Freedom
description: If you’ve worn a “Free Evan” button, you know that most everyone who crosses your path will take note and signal that they support its cause. They usually say they want a pin for themselves, for their neighbors, colleagues and friends. Ambassadors, lawmakers, CEOs, store clerks and journalists alike all have asked to get their hands on one and join the campaign.

title: Opinion | A Report to Our Readers
description: Dec. 12, 2022 10:24 am ETListen to article(2 minutes)Dear Reader: We’re pleased to announce Emma Tucker has been named the next editor in chief of The Wall Street Journal and Dow Jones Newswires. She will succeed Matt Murray, who will be taking on a new senior role at News Corp reporting to Chief Executive Robert Thomson.

title: Opinion | At Soccer’s World Cup, an American and Dutch Treat
description: Members of the U.S. team at the FIFA World Cup in Doha, Qatar, Nov. 30. The moment the U.S. beat Iran 1-0 in Qatar, pundits feverishly declared that “the most politically charged” soccer game of the 2022 World Cup was behind us. But clearly this judgment was rash. Another game with profound geopolitical undercurrents will take place Saturday: the U.S. against the Netherlands.

title: Opinion | The Tragic Site of Salman Rushdie’s Stabbing
description: It’s a bitter irony that Salman Rushdie was about to discuss the need to protect persecuted writers when he was brutally assaulted in Western New York Friday. The symbolic nature of the tragic event comes into even sharper relief because of the assault’s exact location: the Chautauqua Institution. Founded in 1874 as an educational experiment, Chautauqua is a nonprofit organization and a summer resort.

title: Opinion | A Report to Our Readers
description: Dear Readers: The Wall Street Journal headquarters have been quiet in the past year, but our journalism is quite the opposite. The usual cacophony—phones ringing, reporters interviewing sources, editors discussing the latest news developments and screens flashing headlines and statistics—has been replaced, at least temporarily, with utter silence as most colleagues are again working from home amid the latest Covid-19 spike.

title: Alicia Kirchner quiere tener su propio observatorio de medios en Santa Cruz
description: LA NACION | Política | Actualidad La gobernadora Alicia Kirchner envió un proyecto de ley que pretende unificar el control de los medios públicos de Santa Cruz Fuente: Archivo - Crédito: Silvana Colombo EL CALAFATE.- La gobernadora Alicia Kirchner quiere tener su propio Observatorio Provincial de Medios para lo cual envió un proyecto de ley a la legislatura santacruceña que establece una nueva organización para los medios públicos de Santa Cruz, bajo la nominación de Sistema Integral de...

title: Christchurch Hit by Multiple Earthquakes
authors: Geoffrey Rogow,Lucy Craymer,Almar Latour,The Wall Street Journal
description: By Geoffrey Rogow, Lucy Craymer And Almar Latour Updated Dec. 23, 2011 5:00 am ET CHRISTCHURCH—Two days before Christmas, New Zealand's second-largest city Christchurch was rocked by earthquakes including a 5.8-magnitude tremor that forced the temporary evacuation of the airport, triggered rock falls and caused further damage in the downtown area.

title: A field guide to insulting gestures the Dutch and American teams could employ in the Women’s World Cup final
description: When the U.S. faced England on the football pitch earlier this week, the outcome was perhaps unsurprising: The U.S. was on its way to the women’s World Cup finals — and the English on their way home What was arguably more stunning, however, was the reaction to star U.S. striker Alex Morgan’s tea-drinking pantomime in celebrating the go-ahead goal in American’s 2-1 victory against England.

title: Reported facts, weaponized in service of action
description: Sometimes democracies die in bright daylight. Despite the work of journalists globally, the slide into authoritarianism is gathering pace in many parts of the world, including a few Central European nations. And despite the urgency of generation-defining issues — from climate change to trade wars, from AI and designer babies to the growing gulf between rich and poor — we’ll increasingly find that the mere reporting of facts is not enough. There often is a vacuum between facts and action.

title: Guests Can't Seem toResistSouvenir From Nobel Dinner
description: STOCKHOLM -- Alfred Nobel, the shy Swedish inventor of dynamite and the creator of the Nobel Prizes, couldn't have anticipated what a wingding the dinner after the awards ceremony has become. These days, it's an annual white-tie extravaganza with a million dollars in crystal that is used just once a year, flag-waving students in white hats, elaborate seating protocol and dining etiquette intricate enough to stump the world's best brains, some of whom are present.

title: World Cup 2014: Why the U.S. Should Support the Netherlands for the Rest of the World Cup
description: A Dutch fan cheers on his team at the World Cup. Associated Press By Updated July 7, 2014 6:23 pm ET Dear American Soccer Fan, Now that Team USA has exited the World Cup following a truly amazing performance, you may be tempted to stop watching the World Cup altogether as there is no one for whom to cheer. But there's a remedy: You can throw your support behind another country. And let me be the first to suggest the fine nation of the Netherlands.

title: Conquering calm " Nieman Journalism Lab
description: At a recent business dinner, one executive did something unexpected: He pulled out a Nokia phone that looked like it belonged in the late 1990s. He explained that he had adopted the “dumb phone” to fight information overload from his now-discarded smartphone, which until recently had barraged him with alerts, headlines, emails, social media, and everything else we see every day. His reasoning: He now had fewer distractions and more time to think. It’s an understandable move.

title: Bitcoin Is the World’s Hottest Currency, but No One’s Using It
description: As businesses accepting bitcoin payments find few takers, the virtual currency is a long way from its traditional counterparts.

title: Here’s One Investor Who Dumped Stocks on the Flynn News (The Wall Street Journal)
description: Can Mike Flynn derail one of history's biggest bull markets? At least one investor thinks so.

title: There will be 24 billion IoT devices installed on Earth by 2020 (Business Insider)
description: BII By 2020, more than 24 billion internet-connected devices will be installed globally — that's more than 4 devices for every human on earth. The Internet of Things first came to us on PCs. Then i...

title: Uber built a fake city in Pittsburgh with roaming mannequins to test its self-driving cars (Business Insider)
description: Uber Uber is testing its self-driving cars in a fake city it built in Pittsburgh called the ALMONO. The fake city has a giant roundabout, fake cars, and roaming mannequins that jump out into the s...

title: Thanks, #fakenews
description: The intrusion of fake news into the media ecosystem has been met with fear and outrage. Yet fake news might trigger a good thing,? too: A reminder of the extraordinary value of truth and perhaps a realization that, after much agonizing over the viability of the news business, there is a raison d’être beyond the accumulation of digital eyeballs. Journalism is often at its best during periods of genuine turmoil or uncertainty.

title: From walls to canals
description: Competition is the merciless propelling force of this new era of journalism — and in the year ahead that will only intensify. It’s a beautiful thing, though of course not everyone will win. To spot future winners and losers, watch the following issues:The “Chinese wall” cannot be the only concept governing relations between newsrooms and business. Yes, there should be clear principles and rules in place that prevent advertising or other special interests from influencing news coverage.

title: Thanks for going Dutch, America
description: Many of you are probably busy eating chunks of Gouda cheese while brushing up on your Dutch language skills to better express your emotions during today’s World Cup semifinal between Holland and Argentina. The enormous outpouring of support for the Oranje by U.S. fans in the last week has left me to conclude that my plea to you to throw your support behind the Netherlands was most persuasive.

title: Dutch to the Yanks: Thanks!
description: Dear American voetbal fans: Many of you are probably busy eating chunks of Gouda cheese while brushing up on your Dutch language skills to better express your emotions during the upcoming World Cup semifinal of Holland vs. Argentina. The enormous outpouring of support for Oranje by U.S.

title: The only World Cup team left to root for
description: Now that Team USA has exited the World Cup following a truly amazing performance, you may be tempted to stop watching the World Cup altogether as there is no one for whom to cheer. But there’s a remedy: you can throw your support behind another country. And let me be the first to suggest the fine nation of the Netherlands. Sure, Dutch people may be the object of Dr. Evil’s hatred in Austin Powers. But don’t write us off. We actually we have a lot in common with Americans.

title: World Cup 2014: Why the U.S. Should Support the Netherlands For the Rest of the World Cup
description: A Dutch fan cheers on his team at the World Cup.

title: In This Profession, Everyone Moves Up, Some Fall Down
description: SAN ANTONIO -- Digging the metal pins on his shoes deep into a wooden pole, Pete Luna gave a big heave and hoisted himself a few feet higher. He was sweating but there was no time for a breather.

title: Humacyte Shares Rise After FDA Grants Priority Review to Vascular Trauma Treatment
description: By Kailyn Rhone Shares of Humacyte rose after the U.S. Food and Drug Administration granted priority review to its vascular trauma treatment in development. The stock was up almost 13% to $3.53 on Friday. Shares are up 21% in the past 12 months.

title: Humacyte Shares Rise After FDA Grants Priority Review to Vascular Trauma Treatment
description: By Kailyn Rhone Shares of Humacyte rose after the U.S. Food and Drug Administration granted priority review to its vascular trauma treatment in development. The stock was up almost 13% to $3.53 on Friday. Shares are up 21% in the past 12 months.

title: Humacyte Shares Rise After FDA Grants Priority Review to Vascular Trauma Treatment
description: Humacyte Shares Rise After FDA Grants Priority Review to Vascular Trauma TreatmentHUMAShares of Humacyte rose after the U.S. Food and Drug Administration granted priority review to its vascular trauma treatment in development. The stock was up almost 13% to $3.53 on Friday. Shares are up 21% in the past 12 months.

title: Humacyte Shares Rise After FDA Grants Priority Review to Vascular Trauma Treatment
description: By Kailyn Rhone Shares of Humacyte rose after the U.S. Food and Drug Administration granted priority review to its vascular trauma treatment in development. The stock was up almost 13% to $3.53 on Friday. Shares are up 21% in the past 12 months.

title: AMC Networks Shares Drop 19% Amid Subscriber Slump
description: By Kailyn Rhone Shares of AMC Networks fell on Friday after the company reported declining revenue in the fourth quarter due to a steep drop in content licensing. The stock dropped almost 19% to $13.86 in morning trading. The stock is down 25% since the start of the year. The entertainment company said its fourth-quarter content licensing revenues fell 68% to $96 million due to timing and availability of deliveries.

title: Paylocity Holding Shares Drop After Cut to Sales Outlook
description: By Kailyn Rhone Shares of Paylocity Holding fell on Thursday after the company lowered its sales outlook for the year. The stock fell 7% to $159.90 in after-hours trading. The stock is down almost 23% over the last year. The payroll provider said it expected total revenue of roughly $1.38 billion for the full year, down from its prior outlook for around $1.4 billion. The reduced view came after the company reported better-than-expected second-quarter results.

title: Motorola Solutions Posts Higher 4Q Sales on Strong Demand
description: By Kailyn Rhone Motorola Solutions posted higher revenue and earnings in the fourth quarter helped by acquisitions and strong demand for its software and services. The communications company on Thursday logged earnings of $595 million, or $3.47 a share, for the fourth quarter ended Dec. 31, compared with $589 million, or $3.43 a share, a year earlier. Adjusted earnings were $3.90 a share, above/below analysts' estimates of $3.63 a share. Sales rose to $2.8 billion from $2.7 billion.

title: Oscar Health Shares Rise 22% After Reporting Narrower Loss
description: By Kailyn Rhone Shares of Oscar Health rose after the company posted a narrower loss than expected in the fourth quarter. The stock was up about 22%, to $16.43, after hitting a 52-week high of $17.55 earlier in Thursday's session. Shares are up about 83% since the start of the year. The healthcare technology company posted a loss for the three months ended Dec. 31 of $150 million, or 66 cents a share, compared with a loss of $226 million, or $1.05 a share, for the same period a year earlier.

title: Insperity Shares Drop to 52-Week Low After 4Q Earnings Results Miss
description: By Kailyn Rhone Insperity shares were down 18% to $92.81 after the company reported fourth-quarter earnings that missed analysts' expectations. The stock hit its 52-week low of $90.80 earlier in Thursday's session, and is down 17% in the past 12 months. The human resources service company posted quarterly earnings of $19.6 million, or 52 cents a share, compared with $38.2 million, or 99 cents a share, in the same quarter last year. Adjusted earnings were 75 cents a share.

title: U-Haul Posts Lower 3Q Earnings on Slow Moving Activity
description: By Kailyn Rhone U-Haul Holding reported a decline in quarterly earnings and revenue as moving activity remained lower compared to last year. The Reno, Nev.-based company, known for its moving and storage businesses, on Wednesday said earnings available to shareholders fell to $99.2 million, or 46 cents a share, for the third quarter ended Dec. 31, from $198.9 million, or 98 cents a share, in the same period a year earlier. Revenue declined to $1.34 billion from $1.38 billion.

title: Cirrus Logic Shares Up 15% After 3Q Earnings Beat Expectations
description: By Kailyn Rhone Shares of Cirrus Logic rose Wednesday after the company reported third-quarter earnings that beat analysts' estimates. The stock was recently up almost 15% to $90. Shares are up about 8.5% since the start of the year. The Austin, Texas-based semiconductor supplier late Tuesday posted quarterly earnings of $138.7 million, or $2.50 a share, in the quarter ended Dec. 30, up from earnings of $103.5 million, or $1.83 a share, in the same quarter last year.

title: Aviat Networks Shares Jump 20% After Raising FY24 Guidance
description: By Kailyn Rhone Shares of Aviat Networks rose sharply after the wireless transport provider improved its second-quarter sales and raised its full-year guidance. The stock was up almost 20% to $36 on Wednesday, and have risen 10.3% since the start of the year. The Austin, Texas-based company said it now expects revenue of $425 million to $432 million for the year, compared with its previous outlook of $367 million to $374 million. In the second quarter ended Dec.

title: Omnicom Group 4Q Profit Down on Higher Expenses
description: By Kailyn Rhone Omnicom Group posted lower profit for the fourth quarter, as expenses rose at a faster pace than revenue. The New York-based advertising holding company on Tuesday reported a profit of $425.7 million, or $2.13 a share, compared with a profit of $429.8 million, or $2.09 a share, in the same period a year earlier. Adjusted earnings came in at $2.20 a share. Analysts polled by FactSet expected $2.17 a share. Revenue rose 5% to $4.06 billion.

title: Avis Shares Rise 7% After Rival Hertz Reports 4Q Loss
description: By Kailyn Rhone Shares of Avis Budget Group rose after rival rental car company Hertz Global Holdings reported a fourth-quarter loss. The stock was up almost 7% to $166.73 on Tuesday after hitting a 52-week low of $153.07 a day prior. Shares are down 27.3% in the past 12 months. Hertz posted a loss for the three months ended Dec. 31 of $348 million, or $1.14 a share, compared with a profit of $116 million, and a loss of 1 cent a share, for the same period a year earlier.

title: Symbotic 1Q Loss Narrows as Revenue Improves
description: By Kailyn Rhone Symbotic said its first-quarter loss narrowed and revenue rose as the company initiated five system deployments and completed three systems. The robotics warehouse automation company had a loss for the three months ended Dec. 30 of $1.93 million, or 2 cents a share, compared with a loss of $7.19 million, or 12 cents a share, for the same period a year earlier. Revenue rose to $368.5 million from $206.3 million last year.

title: Graham Shares Jump 13% After Raising FY24 Outlook
description: By Kailyn Rhone Shares of Graham rose after the pumping equipment company improved its third-quarter sales and raised its full-year outlook. The stock was up almost 13% to $22.28 on Monday after earlier hitting a 52-week high of $23.50. Shares are up 96.5% in the past 12 months. The Batavia, NY.-based company said it now expects revenue of $175 million to $185 million for the year ending March 31, compared with previous outlook of $170 million to $180 million. In the third quarter ended Dec.

title: Houlihan Lokey Shares Up 4% After 3Q Earnings Beat
description: By Kailyn Rhone Shares of Houlihan Lokey rose after the company reported third-quarter earnings that beat analysts' estimates. The stock was up 4% to $126.15 on Friday after earlier hitting a 52-week high of $129.22. Shares are up about 25.7% in the past 12 months. The Los Angeles, Calif.-based investment bank late Thursday posted earnings of $70.8 million, or $1.04 a share, in the quarter ended Dec. 31, up from earnings of $63.1 million, or 90 cents, in the same quarter last year.

title: Tyra Shares Jump After $200 Million Private Placement Funding
description: By Kailyn Rhone Tyra Biosciences shares rose sharply after it announced an agreement to sell securities in a private placement financing that's expected to generate $200 million in proceeds. The biotechnology company's stock jumped 25% to $16.26 Friday. Shares are up 21.5% over the past 12 months. Tyra said it will sell 15.4 million shares of its common stock at the price of $13.01 a share. The sale is expected to close Tuesday.

title: Schneider National Records Lower 4Q Revenue, Profit
description: By Kailyn Rhone Schneider National reported declining earnings in the fourth quarter as the company faced lower freight demand and two recent accident claims. The Green Bay, Wis.-based trucking company posted a profit of $27.4 million, or 15 cents a share, down from $110.1 million, or 62 cents a share, in the same quarter a year ago. Stripping out one-time items, adjusted earnings were 16 cents a share. Analysts polled by FactSet had been expecting 20 cents a share.

title: Fortune Brands Innovations Logs Higher 4Q Revenue, Boosted by Acquisitions
description: By Kailyn Rhone Fortune Brands Innovations recorded higher revenue in the fourth quarter, boosted by recent acquisitions. The Deerfield, Ill.-based maker of Master Lock security products, Moen faucets and other home goods reported a profit of $81.3 million, or 64 cents a share, down from a profit of $109.9 million, or 85 cents a share, in the same quarter a year ago. Stripping out one-time items, earnings were 95 cents a share. Analysts polled by FactSet had been expecting 93 cents a share.

title: Crane Posts Higher 4Q Revenue, Lower Profit
description: By Kailyn Rhone Industrial products manufacturer Crane reported lower fourth-quarter profit and higher revenue as the company saw stronger demand and a record backlog. The Stamford, Conn.-based company logged net income of $49.4 million, or 86 cents a share, compared with a loss of $1.71, or $97.2 million a share, for the same period a year earlier. Analysts polled by FactSet expected adjusted earnings of 83 cents per share.

title: Books to Curl Up with During the Holidays
description: New York City, NY — As the holiday season unfolds and the cold weather settles in, there is no better place to warm up but nestled in a good book. Whether you’re curled up by the fireplace or sun-soaked on the beach, there are many books to read to transport you to a different world and add a magical touch to your holidays.

title: Eco-friendly Practices for a Green Holiday Season
description: New York City, NY — Amidst celebrating the holiday season with loved ones, exchanging gifts and indulging in festive traditions, it is important to consider the environmental impact of these celebrations. Here are four different ways to enjoy the holidays while also staying sustainable, and green. Green Gift Giving Choose presents with a purpose and purchase sustainable gifts crafted from recycled or upcycled materials by local businesses and artisans.

title: Tips for Connecting From Afar for Holiday Celebrations
description: New York City, NY — There was once a time when it seemed impossible to connect with loved ones during the holiday season if you were living in a different city, state, or country. However, after the beginning stages of COVID-19, there have been many new ways implemented where one can be with family and friends even if you are thousands of miles away. Here are five different ways you can share and feel the warmth of the holiday season despite being miles apart.

title: NYU Announces Creation of Center for the Study of Antisemitism
description: New York City, NY — New York University announced it will create a center for the study of antisemitism set to open in the fall 2024 semester following tensions over the Israel-Hamas conflict on its campus. The center will focus on the history of antisemitism and include programs addressing other forms of discrimination and prejudice. The center will be funded by a seven-figure anonymous donation, according to an announcement from university president Linda Mills.

title: Is it Too Late to Change Your Major?
description: New York City, NY — On college campuses, where every building echoes dreams and ambition, there exists a moment that many students fear: the realization that their major may not be the right path. Around one-third of students enrolled in bachelor's degree programs changed their majors at least once, according to a report by The U.S. Dept. of Education.

title: How to Nail Your First Job Negotiation
description: New York City, NY — Gen Z is stepping into the professional world with a unique set of skills and a determination to make a lasting impact. As Gen Z, negotiating your first job can be exhilarating yet challenging as mastering negotiation is not just a skill learned overnight.  So, how does Gen Z seize the opportunity and confidently secure the best deal for them? Let's uncover how to successfully negotiate your first job in five steps.

title: Best Ways to Prepare for Holiday Spending as a College Student
description: New York City, NY — As the holiday season quickly approaches, it is unfortunately the time of the year when many worry about giving the best gifts to loved ones — and how much money it’ll take out of their pockets. For students, balancing festive celebrations on a college budget can be challenging. However, there are many ways to enjoy the holidays without breaking the brand with smart financial planning. Here are the five best ways for students to prepare for holiday spending this year.

title: Navigating Personal Loans as a College Student
description: New York City, NY — College often brings several financial challenges, causing many students to contemplate the idea of taking out a personal loan. As it can be helpful financially, it’s hard to tell when or if it's a wise move. Around one-third (33.1%) of college students carry personal loan debt as it is the most common debt among students, according to The State University of New York’s (SUNY) blog. Therefore, it is essential to consider all possibilities before committing to borrow money.

title: YouTube Superstar MrBeast Surpasses 200M Subscribers
description: New York City, NY — YouTube giant Jimmy Donaldson, famously known as MrBeast, recently hit a major milestone of surpassing 200 million subscribers. Donaldson now holds the title of the world’s second most popular YouTube channel as it took him nearly a decade to get to the first 100 million, and 15 months to grow to 200 million.

title: TikTok Users Hack Starbucks App for Cheaper Drinks - YR Media
description: New York City, NY — TikTokers are showing Starbucks lovers how to hack its app to save money on premium drinks. One user got her drink down to around 50% on a venti iced coffee using the hack on the mobile app. “It feels illegal that I just bought this coffee for $3,” said TikToker user @sophiacelentano48 in a video. The hack starts by ordering an iced triple espresso, which costs $3.35 and includes a creamer chosen by the user.

title: How ‘Girl Dinner’ is an Escape from Mental Overload - YR Media
description: New York City, NY — The popular TikTok trend “girl dinner” may be an escape from current troubles or anxiety.  The trend, which started in May, is about how women will eat anything they have around from cheese plates and wine to leftover takeouts. It comes from TikTok creator Olivia Maher who jokingly shared a video of her dinner, bread, cheese, grapes and cornichons.

title: Gen Z Craves Mentorship in the Workplace - YR Media
description: New York City, NY — More Gen Z report that having a mentor at work is “crucial for their career,” according to a survey by Springtide Research Institute via The 74th News. As many have reported feelings of burnout compared to all other generations, they find it essential to have a mentor to help guide them through workplace issues, like Morgan Sanner.

title: 7 Popular Halloween Costumes of 2023 - YR Media
description: New York City, NY — From Barbie to Beyoncé’s Renaissance Tour, Blockbuster movies and musical artists are driving this year’s trendy Halloween costumes. Halloween, the annual celebration of spooky, has always been about dressing up in the scariest costumes. However, things look a little different this year, according to Google's Frightgeist site. Here is a look at the seven most popular Halloween costumes of 2023.

title: Should You Post Your Resume on LinkedIn? - YR Media
description: New York City, NY — As job hunting can be tough, especially post-pandemic, many early-career professionals are posting their resumes on LinkedIn to gain a further reach and more opportunities. With the recent trend of posting resumes on the professional networking platform, some experts argue that posting resumes broadly is a no-go as resumes should be tailored towards a specific company that fits one’s skillset.

title: More Students to Receive Free School Meals - YR Media
description: New York City, NY — Millions of more students will receive free school meals under an expanded federal program for schools serving low-income communities. The U.S. Dept. of Agriculture recently announced that nearly 3,000 added school districts serving more than five million students will be eligible for free breakfast and lunch at no cost.

title: TikTok Users ask ChatGPT for Outfit Styles - YR Media
description: New York City, NY — Most of the younger generation went to Pinterest or Instagram for outfit ideas. Now, many TikTok users are asking ChatGPT, an artificial intelligence (AI) chatbot, to style their outfits for a day as it has become a popular trend on the platform and YouTube. The trend sparked over the summer and now has more than 4 billion views on the search “Chat GPT fashion” as many creators test to see if the tool is helpful for outfit inspiration.

title: Students Face Pressure to Have an Internship Every Semester - YR Media
description: New York City, NY — A growing number of students feel overwhelmed with the expectation to have multiple internships throughout their college career as more students now seek fall or spring opportunities — in addition to the summer when most usually are interns. As students face many demands, from paying college tuition to taking exams, they also have the added pressure of securing an internship to gain experience outside the classroom or find a post-graduation job.

title: Should Schools Nationwide Implement the Clear Bookbag Policy? - YR Media
description: New York City, NY — An increasing number of schools across the country now require students to wear transparent backpacks due to security concerns. Many people question whether schools nationwide should adopt the policy. The clear backpack policy mandates children at middle schools and high schools to wear transparent, see-through bookbags as a safety measure as mass shootings remain a growing problem within the school district.

title: 今年の米新学期消費、過去最高予想 学生ローン返済再開でも活況
description: ［１日 ロイター］ - 米国の「新学期消費」が好調だ。新型コロナウイルス禍で停止していた学生ローンの返済が１０月から再開されるため、家計の負担は重いはずだが、今年の支出額は過去最高を記録するとみられている。 米国の「新学期消費」が好調だ。新型コロナウイルス禍で停止していた学生ローンの返済が１０月から再開されるため、家計の負担は重いはずだが、今年の支出額は過去最高を記録するとみられている。写真は米カリフォルニア州で２０２０年７月撮影（２０２３年 ロイター/Mike Blake） 全米小売業協会（ＮＲＦ）によると、今年の新学期関連消費は昨年を２４０億ドル以上上回り１３５０億ドルを超える見込み。 「経済的に厳しいにもかかわらず、消費者は欲しい商品やサービスを購入する方法を見つけている」とベリキャストの小売・消費者行動専門家、チップ・ウェスト氏は指摘する。 小売り大手ウォルマートでは、新学期関連商品が５─７月期に計画以上の売れ行きだったという。...

title: 今年の米新学期消費、過去最高予想 学生ローン返済再開でも活況
description: ［１日 ロイター］ - 米国の「新学期消費」が好調だ。新型コロナウイルス禍で停止していた学生ローンの返済が１０月から再開されるため、家計の負担は重いはずだが、今年の支出額は過去最高を記録するとみられている。 全米小売業協会（ＮＲＦ）によると、今年の新学期関連消費は昨年を２４０億ドル以上上回り１３５０億ドルを超える見込み。 「経済的に厳しいにもかかわらず、消費者は欲しい商品やサービスを購入する方法を見つけている」とベリキャストの小売・消費者行動専門家、チップ・ウェスト氏は指摘する。 小売り大手ウォルマートでは、新学期関連商品が５─７月期に計画以上の売れ行きだったという。 ベストバイのマシュー・ビルナス最高財務責任者（ＣＦＯ）は８月２９日、電子製品への需要が予想をやや上回っており、新学期関連の消費が若干長期化していると述べた。 ＮＲＦの８月の調査では、約７０％がラップトップＰＣ（パソコン）やＰＣ関連製品を購入する予定と答えた。 ＜「ジョーツ」、透けるバックパックが人気＞...

title: From 'jorts' to clear backpacks, US back-to-school spending to hit record high this year
description: FILE PHOTO: Back to school suppiles for sale in U.S. department storesBy Kailyn Rhone(Reuters) - See-through backpacks and jean shorts are among the popular last-minute purchases ahead of the new school year, several retailers said, as heat waves sweep the U.S. and security concerns grow at many middle- and high schools. Though U.S. student debt repayments will resume on Oct. 1, straining many Americans' budgets, 2023 is expected to be the most expensive back-to-school shopping season yet.

Though U.S. student debt repayments will resume on Oct. 1, straining many Americans’ budgets, 2023 is expected to be the most expensive back-to-school shopping season yet.

title: Blue-State Residents Streamed Into South Carolina. Here's Why It Stayed Ruby Red.
description: GREER, S.C.—Fed up with pandemic restrictions, Sandy Zal uprooted her family from Schenectady, N.Y., three years ago and moved here because of its Republican tilt. She and her husband named their new company Freedom Window Tinting, a nod to South Carolina’s ethos. “We knew that we’d have freedom to make choices for our kids and our family that were taken away in New York,” said Zal, 47 years old.

title: Blue-State Residents Streamed Into South Carolina. Here’s Why It Stayed Ruby Red
authors: Eliza Collins,Paul Overberg,Anthony DeBarros,The Wall Street Journal
description: Cookies, device or similar online identifiers (e.g. login-based identifiers, randomly assigned identifiers, network based identifiers) together with other information (e.g. browser type and information, language, screen size, supported technologies etc.) can be stored or read on your device to recognise it each time it connects to an app or to a website, for one or several of the purposes presented here.

title: These Voters Will Decide the 2024 Election. They Don’t Like What They See.
authors: Ken Thomas,Catherine Lucey,Eliza Collins,Paul Overberg,South Florida Reporter
description: Tony Grauslys, a 56-year-old merchandiser from Hudson, N.H., is upset that lawmakers focus on other countries’ problems when America can’t fix its own. Marvin Jenkins, 60, a retired state trooper in Saginaw Township, Mich., worries that both leading presidential candidates are too old. Juliet Will-Robinson, 38, a graduate student from Freemansburg, Pa., wishes there was a viable third-party alternative.

title: U.S. Population Growth Continues Slow Recovery From Pandemic
authors: Alyssa Lukpat,Paul Overberg,The Wall Street Journal
description: The U.S. population grew 0.5% this year, according to Census Bureau estimates released Tuesday, as the pandemic’s effects on births, deaths and immigration continued to fade. The increase for the year that ended June 30 was similar to the previous year, when the population grew 0.4%. The new estimate shows the population has grown to 334.9 million, up 1.6 million people in the past year. In the decade before the pandemic, the U.S. grew by an average of 2.1 million people a year.

title: 人口普查数据显示美国人口到2100年料将缩减
link: https://cn.wsj.com/articles/人口普查数据显示美国人口到2100年料将缩减-5515b8fe
description: 美国人口长期持续增长的势头料将终结。 美国人口普查局(Census Bureau)周四公布的预测显示，在最有可能的情况下，美国人口将在2080年停止增长，到2100年将略有减少。 这是美国人口普查局首次在对未来几十年的主要展望中预测人口下降。美国唯一一次出现人口下降的记录是在1918，当时流感大流行和超过100万的海外驻军造成了估计人口的小幅下降。 人口增长放缓将使美国人口在近3.7亿的规模达到峰值，然后在本世纪最后几年降至3.66亿。这些预测（自2018年以来首次发布）反映了多年来出生率的下降、人口老龄化导致的死亡率上升以及越发依赖移民实现人口增长的状况。 这一转变将对美国经济及其地缘政治地位产生影响。随着赡养老人的年轻劳动力减少，社会安全福利(Social Security)和美国联邦医疗保险(Medicare)等福利计划将面临更大的压力。人口减少可能会广泛地改变美国社会的方向，直到20世纪的很长时间里，美国社会都呈爆炸式增长。...

title: America’s Population Projected to Shrink by 2100, Census Figures Show
authors: Paul Overberg,Rosie Ettenheim,The Wall Street Journal
description: She contends the reason is ‘racial animus,’ not plagiarism. Is DEI vulnerable to sudden collapse? Believers come out of the shadows after congressional hearings. “We’re not the people with the tinfoil hats anymore.”Singapore-based Asia Partners’ second fund closes even as the rout in the market for IPOs and venture-capital fundraising continues. At an annual gathering, academic economists are surprised and relieved over soft landing, but worry about what comes next.

title: Montana Has Had It With Rich Outsiders. Will That Help Jon Tester Win Re-Election?
authors: Eliza Collins,Paul Overberg,The Wall Street Journal
description: KALISPELL, Mont.—This state’s rightward shift will make it difficult for Democratic Sen. Jon Tester to win a fourth term next year. Montanans have voted every other Democrat out of statewide office and decisively backed Donald Trump in the past two presidential races. Yet residents share a bipartisan frustration that may be Tester’s best hope for clinching another term.

title: Why No One’s Going Into Accounting
authors: Lindsay Ellis,Paul Overberg,The Wall Street Journal
description: An accounting career, once a launchpad into the upper middle class for hundreds of thousands of Americans, is no longer paying off. Copyright ©2023 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. title: U.S. Incomes Fall For Third Straight Year
authors: Gwynn Guilford,Paul Overberg,The Wall Street Journal
description: Wage growth for the typical worker outstripped inflation starting in December 2022 . Surging inflation gobbled up household income gains last year, making 2022 the third straight year in which Americans saw their living standards eroded by rising prices and pandemic disruptions.

title: Why Democrats Lost Iowa
description: Just about every Republican presidential candidate plans to attend the Iowa State Fair that begins in Des Moines this week. But don’t expect to see President Biden there. Iowa was once a center of gravity for both political parties during presidential elections and a key swing state. In recent years, it has turned so red that Democrats have little political power in the state and the party’s candidates have few reasons to go.

title: Why Democrats Lost Iowa
description: Just about every Republican presidential candidate plans to attend the Iowa State Fair that begins in Des Moines this week. But don’t expect to see President Biden there. Iowa was once a center of gravity for both political parties during presidential elections and a key swing state. In recent years, it has turned so red that Democrats have little political power in the state and the party’s candidates have few reasons to go.

title: Why Democrats Lost Iowa
authors: Catherine Lucey,Paul Overberg,The Wall Street Journal
description: Just about every Republican presidential candidate plans to attend the Iowa State Fair that begins in Des Moines this week. But don’t expect to see President Biden there. Copyright ©2023 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All Rights Reserved. 87990cbe856818d5eddac44c7b1cdeb8

title: Black Americans Are Leaving Cities in the North and West
authors: Jimmy Vielkind,Jon Kamp,Paul Overberg,Jack Gillum,The Wall Street Journal
description: Listen to article(2 minutes)The waves of migration that brought Black Americans to many northern cities are reversing. Copyright ©2023 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All Rights Reserved. 87990cbe856818d5eddac44c7b1cdeb8

title: How America Became an Older Nation in One Decade
description: Thanks to the baby boomers, the age pyramid—where bar graphs of the number of men and women are placed spine to spine—is turning into more of an obelisk. In international context, however, the U.S. is still pretty young for a developed nation. Its median age—37.9 years—is higher than Mexico's 29.4 but lower than Canada's 40.4 and well below Germany's 44.8, Italy's 47.3 and Japan's 48.7.

title: Same-Sex Couples Accounted for 1% of Households in 2020, Census Data Shows
authors: Paul Overberg,Anthony DeBarros,The Wall Street Journal
description: The new data on same-sex couples is the most complete national profile ever compiled. Americans in same-sex marriages and partnerships account for about 1% of households, according to newly released figures from the decennial census that show the changing composition of U.S. families.

title: 米政府、黒人に奴隷の子孫かを尋ねる案を検討
authors: Michelle Hackman,Paul Overberg,The Wall Street Journal (Japan)
description: 米政府は、国勢調査を含む連邦政府の書類で、祖先が奴隷だったかどうかを黒人に尋ねることを検討している。 　バイデン政権は、政府が米国人の人種や民族を調査する方法の更新案で、米国における奴隷の子孫である黒人と、サハラ以南のアフリカやカリブ海諸国などからの移民としてやってきた人々の親族を区別する方法について、一般に意見を求めている。 ...

title: U.S. Mulls Asking Blacks if They Slave Descendants…
description: The U.S. government is considering asking Black Americans on federal forms, including the census, whether their ancestors were enslaved. In a proposed update to how the government tracks Americans’ race and ethnicity, the Biden administration is asking the public for input on how it might go about differentiating Black people who are descendants of slaves in America from those whose families arrived more recently as immigrants from sub-Saharan Africa, the Caribbean or other countries.

title: WSJ News Exclusive | U.S. Considers Asking Black Americans on Census if They Are Slave Descendants
authors: Michelle Hackman,Paul Overberg,The Wall Street Journal
description: March 30, 2023 11:33 am ETListen to article(2 minutes)The U.S. government is considering asking Black Americans on federal forms, including the census, whether their ancestors were enslaved.

title: Exodus From America’s Big Cities Slowed Last Year as Pandemic Receded
authors: Paul Overberg,John McCormick,John Mccormick,Max Rust,The Wall Street Journal
description: San Francisco, like some of the country’s other big cities, saw its population decline slow down from mid-2021 to mid-2022. Big cities lost fewer residents last year as more immigrants moved in, fewer people died and more babies were born there, according to new census data that shows the urban exodus that gained steam early in the pandemic is cooling.

title: Exodus From Americas Big Cities Slowed Last Year as Pandemic Receded
description: New census figures show suburbs and smaller metro areas claimed most U.S. growth

title: Biden Administration Is Gearing Up To Pay Reparations | Blog Posts
description: The Democrats are getting serious about paying “reparations” to blacks, so they are laying the bureaucratic groundwork for the California reparations plan, which distinguishes descendants of slaves from descendants of post-1865 black immigrants. From the Wall Street Journal:On the other hand, this will drive a wedge into the black bloc.

title: Government Proposes Overhaul of Race Categories in Census and Other Surveys
description: Government Proposes Overhaul of Race Categories in Census and Other SurveysThe change would combine queries about race and Hispanic ethnicity and add a category for people from the Middle East and North Africa on census and other government forms

title: U.S. Population Growth Remains Sluggish Despite Uptick This Year
authors: Paul Overberg,John McCormick,The Wall Street Journal
description: America’s population grew 0.4% this year, Census Bureau figures released Thursday show, continuing historically slow growth that has added pressure to a tight labor market. The slight uptick, in the third year of the pandemic, was still greater than the unprecedented low rate of 0.1% recorded in 2021. The U.S. added 1.3 million people in the year that ended July 1 for a total population of 333.3 million.

title: Many Hospitals Get Big Drug Discounts. That Doesn’t Mean Markdowns for Patients.
authors: Anna Wilde Mathews,Paul Overberg,Joseph Walker,Tom McGinty,The Wall Street Journal
description: Many Hospitals Get Big Drug Discounts. That Doesn’t Mean Markdowns for Patients. Through a government program aimed at helping low-income patients, some hospitals buy medications at reduced prices. They can sell them to patients and their insurers for much more.

title: Many Hospitals Get Big Drug Discounts. That Doesn’t Mean Markdowns for Patients.
authors: Anna Wilde Mathews,Paul Overberg,Joseph Walker,Tom McGinty,The Wall Street Journal
description: One participant is the Cleveland Clinic’s flagship hospital, which reported $1.35 billion in net income last year. The hospital doesn’t admit enough Medicaid and low-income Medicare patients to qualify for low-cost drugs under the program’s original requirements. But a quirk in federal law allowed the hospital to qualify as a “rural referral center,” despite its location near the center of Cleveland.

title: Immigration Becomes Key Issue in Competitive Pennsylvania House Race
authors: Tarini Parti,Paul Overberg,The Wall Street Journal
description: WILKES-BARRE, Pa.—More than a thousand miles from the southern U.S. border, the ripple effects of an influx of immigrants into this former coal-mining city could help decide one of the most competitive congressional races in the country next month.

title: New Data Show Broad Shift to Remote Work During Pandemic
authors: Gwynn Guilford,Paul Overberg,The Wall Street Journal
description: The number of Americans working remotely more than tripled in 2021 from 2019, according to new federal data, and the trend shows signs of persisting this year. In 2021, 27.6 million people reported primarily working from home nationwide, up from 9 million in 2019, according to new 2021 American Community Survey estimates released Thursday by the Census Bureau. In percentage terms, that translated to 17.9% of employees who worked mainly remotely in 2021, compared with 5.7% in 2019.

title: 人口普查数据显示去年美国家庭收入中位数同比持平
link: https://cn.wsj.com/articles/人口普查数据显示去年美国家庭收入中位数同比持平-11663115704

title: U.S. Incomes Were Flat Last Year, Census Figures Show
authors: Paul Overberg,John McCormick,The Wall Street Journal
description: Median household income was essentially unchanged last year on an inflation-adjusted basis from the previous year and was recorded as $70,800, the U.S. Census Bureau said Tuesday in its annual report on the nation’s financial well-being. The lack of any significant growth for 2021 follows a decrease in incomes recorded in 2020, the first year of the pandemic.

title: Chicago vs. Dallas: Why the North Lags Behind the South and West in Racial Integration
authors: Paul Overberg,Max Rust,The Wall Street Journal
description: Updated July 16, 2022 9:55 am ETU.S. metropolitan areasacross the South and West show more racial integration than those in the Northeast and Midwest, figures from the latest decennial census show. Using academic research and decades of prior census results, The Wall Street Journal analyzed 2020 census data to see where the homes of whites, Blacks, Latinos and Asians remained most clustered along racial lines, and where they have become more intermixed.

title: 新冠疫情加剧美国大城市人口流失
link: https://cn.wsj.com/articles/新冠疫情加剧美国大城市人口流失-11653640507
description: 根据周四公布的人口普查数据，去年美国大城市人口加速下降，原因是疫情继续驱动美国人寻找更多空间。 据最新估计显示，截至2021年7月1日的一年里，最大城市的居民流失比例高于中小城市。在九个人口超过100万的城市中，居民总数下降1.7%，减少了41.9万人。在这九个城市中只有两个城市人口实现增长：凤凰城和圣安东尼奥。 ...

title: Big U.S. Cities Lost More Residents as Covid-19 Pandemic Stretched On
authors: Paul Overberg,Janet Adamy,The Wall Street Journal
description: New York, the nation’s largest city, lost 3.5% of its residents, or about 305,000 people. The second-largest city, Los Angeles, lost 1%, or 41,000 people, while the third-largest, Chicago, lost 1.6%, or 45,000 people. San Francisco’s population fell 6.3%, a loss of 55,000 people. It and Chicago have lost so many people that their populations have fallen close to their 2010 levels.

title: 2020 Census Undercounted Six States, Overcounted Eight
description: Six states were undercounted in the 2020 census while eight states were overcounted, Census Bureau officials reported Thursday. Census totals for the remaining 36 states and the District of Columbia fell within the estimated ranges produced by a large post-census survey used to check the quality of the decennial count. The survey included more than 160,000 homes chosen randomly. Responses from each were checked against any census response from that home.

title: Newly Released U.S. Census Records Reveal a Time Capsule of Life in 1950
authors: Paul Overberg,Matthew Riva,The Wall Street Journal
description: In 1950, thousands of workers spread out across the country and interviewed Americans for the once-a-decade census. Handwritten line by line, the records capture thumbnail portraits of 151 million people in 43 million homes. Bill Crouch/Oakland Tribune/Getty From April 1 on, genealogy sleuths, historians and the merely curious can dig through those 1950 census forms, the first to be unveiled in a searchable format.

title: U.S. Census Undercounted Blacks, Hispanics in 2020
description: The 2020 census on net missed about 0.24% of the U.S. population, or about three-quarters of a million people, the Census Bureau said Thursday in releasing a key report card on the accuracy of the count. The margin wasn’t statistically significant but many groups were miscounted at significant rates, according to bureau officials. About 3.3% of Black people were missed, as were 5% of Hispanic people and 0.9% of American Indians and Alaska Natives.

title: What Covid-19 Leaves Behind
authors: Jon Kamp,Jennifer Levitz,Brianna Abbott,Paul Overberg,The Wall Street Journal
description: Two years into the Covid-19 pandemic, America’s death toll has surpassed one million. But the disease is also unraveling families and communities in subtler ways. By Jon Kamp, Jennifer Levitz, Brianna Abbott and Paul Overberg Feb. 16, 2022 Tap story Americans have died since the start of the pandemic. That’s roughly a million more deaths than would have been expected in that time.

title: One Million Deaths: The Hole the Pandemic Made in U.S. Society
authors: Jon Kamp,Jennifer Levitz,Brianna Abbott,Paul Overberg,The Wall Street Journal
description: Covid-19 has been directly responsible for most of the fatalities, but the disease is also unraveling families and communities in subtler waysBy Jon Kamp, Jennifer Levitz, Brianna Abbott and Paul OverbergUpdated Jan. 31, 2022 11:50 pm ETTwo years into the Covid-19 pandemic, America’s death toll is closing in on one million. Federal authorities estimate that 987,456 more people have died since early 2020 than would have otherwise been expected, based on long-term trends.

title: Covid-19 Pandemic Drives U.S. Population Growth to Record Low
description: The number of U.S. residents grew by just 0.1% for the 12 months ended July 1 New annual population totals from the Census Bureau were released Tuesday. Photo: caroline brehman/Shutterstock America’s population grew at the lowest rate on record this year, according to Census Bureau figures released Tuesday that show how the pandemic is changing the country’s demographic contours.

title: Coronavirus pandemic a factor as U.S. population grows at record-low pace
description: America's population grew 0.1% this year, the lowest rate on record, according to Census Bureau figures released Tuesday that show how the pandemic is changing the country's demographic contours. The U.S. added just 393,000 people in the year that ended July 1 for a total population of 331.9 million. That included 148,000 more births than deaths, a surplus that has long supplied much of the nation's growth. The other component - which measures movement to and from abroad - grew by 245,000.

title: How to Understand the Data Explosion
description: The Future of Everything covers the innovation and technology transforming the way we live, work and play, with monthly issues on transportation, health, education and more. This month is Data, online starting Dec. 2 and in print Dec. 9. Remember getting your first digital camera? Suddenly you could take (and keep) hundreds of photographs. Today, it’s likely that you’re keeping thousands of photos—as well as video, audio and other files—on the phone in your pocket.

title: Californians Flee the Coast to Inland Cities in a Mass Pandemic-Era Exodus
authors: Christine Mai-Duc,Paul Overberg,Christine Mai Duc,The Wall Street Journal
description: Since moving out of the Los Angeles area, Eva and Randy Fluker say they miss summer weekends at the beach, monthly trips to Disneyland and their favorite Mexican food and ramen joints. They don’t miss trying to squeeze their work life, two stuck-at-home kids and Ms. Fluker’s 98-year-old grandmother into a 1,700 square-foot house in Norwalk, Calif.

title: The Pandemic Hit Cities Hard, but Especially Washington, D.C.
authors: Julie Bykowicz,Paul Overberg,The Wall Street Journal
description: Washington, D.C., underwent one of the most dramatic urban revivals of any U.S. city during the past two decades. Newcomers poured in, businesses expanded and developers transformed the area with high-end condos, entertainment and shopping. The pandemic and rising housing prices began cooling that growth. The city lost a net of nearly 19,000 households to moves in 2020, according to U.S. Postal Service permanent change-of-address data.

title: INCOMES DECLINED LAST YEAR AS VIRUS TOOK TOLL
authors: John McCormick,Paul Overberg,The Wall Street Journal
description: ABSTRACTCensus data show Americans saw their first significant decline in household income in decade in 2020, but government aid kept many people from falling into poverty; median household income fell 2.9% from 2019 to $67,500; graphs (M)

title: YOUNGER GRAPPLE WITH COVID DEATHS
authors: Jon Kamp,Paul Overberg,The Wall Street Journal
description: ABSTRACTSurge in deaths tied to Delta variant of coronavirus is hitting working-age people high as older people are largely vaccinated, highlighting risks for people who are unvaccinated; deaths among people under age 55 have hit 1,800 a week, matching last winterâ€™s surge; photo (M)

title: Census Figures Show Americans’ Incomes Fell in 2020
authors: John McCormick,Paul Overberg,The Wall Street Journal
description: Americans last year saw their first significant decline in household income in nearly a decade, government data showed, with economic pain from the Covid-19 pandemic prompting government aid that helped keep millions from falling into poverty. An annual assessment of the nation’s financial well-being, released Tuesday by the Census Bureau, offered insight into how households fared during the pandemic’s first year.

title: Covid-19 Deaths in Delta Surge Trend Younger in U.S.
authors: Jon Kamp,Paul Overberg,The Wall Street Journal
description: A surge in Covid-19 deaths caused by the highly contagious Delta variant is hitting working-age people hard while highlighting the risks for people who remain unvaccinated. Federal data show Covid-19 deaths among people under 55 have roughly matched highs near 1,800 a week set during last winter’s surge. These data show weekly tallies for overall Covid-19 deaths, meanwhile, remain well under half of the pandemic peak near 26,000 reached in January.

title: PANDEMIC STOKES EXURBS BOOM
authors: Cameron McWhirter,Paul Overberg,The Wall Street Journal
description: ABSTRACTSurging housing costs and remote work amid coronavirus pandemic are driving new residents to fast-growing exurbs of metropolitan areas in Southeast where people used to seek suburbs closer in; photos (M)

title: New Life and Work Choices Turn Sleepy Southeastern Towns Into Booming Exurbs
authors: Cameron McWhirter,Paul Overberg,The Wall Street Journal
description: MURFREESBORO, Tenn.—This bucolic town 30 miles southeast of Nashville, Tenn., was once best known for its nearby Civil War battlefield and state college. Now it is one of the fastest-growing places in the country. Surging housing costs and remote work are sending droves of people to live in new, fast-growing exurbs of metropolitan areas in the Southeast where suburban living has long been concentrated closer to the city.

title: Where Is America Diversifying the Fastest? Small Midwestern Towns.
description: One in seven residents in Columbus, Ind., a city of about 50,000, was born outside the United States. Public school students collectively speak more than 50 languages and dialects at home. Roughly three dozen foreign companies operate in the area.

title: Where Is America Diversifying the Fastest? Small Midwestern Towns.
authors: John McCormick,Paul Overberg,The Wall Street Journal
description: One in seven residents in Columbus, Ind., a city of about 50,000, was born outside the United States. Public school students collectively speak more than 50 languages and dialects at home. Roughly three dozen foreign companies operate in the area.

title: Census Data Show America’s White Population Shrank for the First Time
authors: Paul Overberg,John McCormick,The Wall Street Journal
description: The first detailed results of the 2020 census show a diversifying nation where the total white population shrank for the first time in its history and where large metropolitan areas, especially in the South and Southwest, saw the strongest growth. The non-Hispanic white population dropped 2.6% between 2010 and 2020, a decline that puts that group’s share of the total U.S. population below 60%.

title: Census Data Change to Protect Privacy Rattles Researchers, Minority Groups
description: A plan to protect the confidentiality of Americans’ responses to the 2020 census by injecting small, calculated distortions into the results is raising concerns that it will erode their usability for research and distribution of state and federal funds. The Census Bureau is due to release the first major results of the decennial count in mid-August.

title: The Pandemic Changed Where Americans Live
authors: Arian Campo-Flores,Paul Overberg,Joseph De Avila,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: The pandemic has spurred a burst of mobility that is accelerating changes in where and how Americans live. Some young people are leaving cities earlier than is typical, while some older people are speeding up retirement moves. Fewer newcomers are giving cities a try, meaning the people moving out aren’t being replaced by fresh residents. Suburbs are emerging as the winners from these changes, marking the end of a decadelong growth trend for big cities.

title: South and Mountain West Gain Political Power From Population Growth
authors: Paul Overberg,Kristina Peterson,The Wall Street Journal
description: A YMCA youth ambassador conducts a census 2020 interview at a YMCA location in Los Angeles last August. Photo: Patrick T. Fallon/Bloomberg News The first results of the 2020 census show that political power will shift even more to states in the South and Mountain West and that population growth slowed to almost the lowest rate in history.

title: Infographic: Deaths from COVID-19 are far higher than reported estimates
authors: Daniel Michaels,Jon Kamp,Paul Overberg,Genetic Literacy Project
description: The GLP Needs Your HelpIt is easier than ever for advocacy groups to spread disinformation on pressing science issues, such as the ongoing coronavirus pandemic. No, vaccines are not harmful. Yes, the use of biotechnology, GMOs or gene editing to develop antigens for treatments including vaccines are part of the solution. To inform the public about what’s really going on, we present the facts and challenge those who don't. We can’t do this work without your help.

title: Covid-19 Vaccine Hesitancy Presents Challenge for Herd-Immunity Push
authors: Julie Wernau,Paul Overberg,The Wall Street Journal
description: If everyone in the U.S. who says they definitely plan to get vaccinated gets the shot, it won’t be enough to end the pandemic. That’s because vast numbers of Americans are either unsure about getting the Covid-19 vaccine or say they will never get it, according to new data from the U.S. Census Bureau. The survey of responses from about 68,000 adults conducted Jan. 6-18 provides the most comprehensive picture yet about which Americans are hesitant to get vaccinated—and why.

title: Biden Inherits an Older, Polarized and Financially Insecure Nation
authors: Paul Overberg,Janet Adamy,The Wall Street Journal
description: President-elect Joe Biden is inheriting a country with an aging population that is on shakier economic footing and is more politically polarized than at most points in recent years. Key metrics of financial and social well-being show the challenges Mr. Biden faces as he moves into the White House on Wednesday. The coronavirus pandemic halted the 11-year economic expansion and drove up unemployment just as the typical American household was starting to enjoy sustained income growth.

title: The Covid-19 Death Toll Is Even Worse Than It Looks
authors: Paul Overberg,Jon Kamp,Daniel Michaels,Lindsay Huth,The Wall Street Journal
description: The recorded death count from the Covid-19 pandemic as of Thursday is nearing 2 million. The true extent is far worse. More than 2.8 million people have lost their lives due to the pandemic, according to a Wall Street Journal analysis of data from 59 countries and jurisdictions. This tally offers the most comprehensive view yet of the pandemic’s global impact. Deaths in these places last year surged more than 12% above average levels.

title: New Population Data Suggest Which States Will Win and Lose Seats in Congress
authors: Janet Adamy,Paul Overberg,The Wall Street Journal
description: WASHINGTON—New population estimates show how Southern and Western states are poised to gain political power when the U.S. reshuffles congressional seats and Electoral College votes next year. The Census Bureau on Tuesday released annual state population estimates as of July 1. That data was gathered separately from decennial census responses pegged to April 1, which lawmakers will use in early 2021 to redistribute seats in the House of Representatives.

title: Census Estimates U.S. Population Grew 8% in Last Decade, Slowest Since the 1930s
authors: Janet Adamy,Paul Overberg,The Wall Street Journal
description: A YMCA youth ambassador conducted a census interview in Los Angeles in August. Photo: Patrick T. Fallon/Bloomberg News The U.S. population has grown about 8% over the past decade to more than 332 million people, according to a Census Bureau analysis released before the results of the decennial count. The figures published Tuesday are separate from those gathered by the 2020 census that wrapped up in October.

title: The Census Predicament: Counting Americans by Race
authors: Janet Adamy,Paul Overberg,The Wall Street Journal
description: As director of the U.S. Census Bureau from 1998 to 2001, Kenneth Prewitt oversaw the first decennial count of the new century. When the enormous job of data collection was finally done, he arrived at a stark conclusion: The government should stop asking every American to report their race. “The race question is incoherent because race is incoherent,” said Prof. Prewitt, now a professor of public affairs at Columbia University.

title: Census Snags May Delay Results Beyond Trump Administration
description: Snags in processing the results of the 2020 census may delay its first results long enough to prevent President Trump from carrying out his plan to exclude unauthorized immigrants from the population-based calculation that distributes seats in the House of Representatives and votes in the Electoral College. In a written statement Thursday, Census Bureau Director Steven Dillingham cited “anomalies” discovered in processing, which began after counting ended Oct. 15.

title: Infographic: Well before Trump’s February partial ‘China air ban', COVID had spent January quietly spreading across the US
authors: Joel Eastwood,Paul Overberg,Rob Barry,Genetic Literacy Project
description: The Wall Street Journal interviewed disease detectives and reviewed hundreds of pages of new research to piece together how the coronavirus infiltrated the wealthiest nation on earth. The latest genetic, epidemiological and computational research suggests it was spreading inside the country before anyone started looking. How did this happen? …Jan.

title: Coronavirus Hit the U.S. Long Before We Knew
authors: Rob Barry,Joel Eastwood,Paul Overberg,The Wall Street Journal
description: Coronavirus Hit the U.S. Long Before We KnewMonths before travel bans and lockdowns, Americans were transmitting the virus across the country

title: Coronavirus Hit the U.S. Long Before We Knew
authors: Rob Barry,Joel Eastwood,Paul Overberg,The Wall Street Journal
description: On March 4, California officially recorded its first day with 10 new Covid-19 infections. California daily new Covid-19 cases Jan. 1March 4March 3105001,000 By Jan. 24, there was a greater than 50% chance 10 new people were being infected every day. Likelihood of single day with at least 10 locally transmitted infections 0% 100% In fact, researchers now estimate California reached that mark more than one month earlier. It had spread across America before anyone reacted.

title: Court Fight Over Census Tied to Plan for Excluding Illegal Immigrants
description: A series of court decisions in coming weeks will determine whether state population totals, which shape how many electoral votes each state receives, will be delivered during President Trump’s current term or will stretch into the spring, when a new administration could be in place. After initially asking for extra time to complete the count because of the pandemic, the Trump administration in recent weeks reversed course and is now pushing to give lawmakers the totals in early January.

title: U.S. Incomes Up, Poverty Rate Down in 2019
authors: Janet Adamy,Paul Overberg,The Wall Street Journal
description: WASHINGTON—American incomes rose sharply and poverty fell in the final year of the country’s decadelong economic expansion, according to Census Bureau figures released Tuesday. Median household income was $68,700 in 2019, up 6.8% from the prior year and the highest figure on record. The poverty rate was 10.5%, a drop of 1.3 percentage points from the year before.

title: Court Blocks Trump Plan to Exclude Some Immigrants From 2020 Census to Allocate House Seats
description: A special three-judge panel has blocked President Trump’s plan to exclude immigrants living in the U.S. illegally from the 2020 census count that will be used to redistribute seats in the House of Representatives. Acting on two lawsuits filed in New York by a group of states, cities, counties and civil-rights groups, the judges said Thursday that the plan violates several laws that spell out how the results of the decennial census are to be used for distributing congressional seats. ...

title: Worker Turnover, Shortened Schedule Hamper 2020 Census
description: A high workforce attrition rate and a shortened schedule are making it more difficult for the Census Bureau to complete a decennial count that has been disrupted by the coronavirus pandemic. About 240,000 workers have completed training and are knocking on millions of doors, according to spokesman Michael Cook. The bureau hired 402,000 workers, he said, but tens of thousands dropped out at various stages of clearing a background check, being fingerprinted or completing training. ...

title: Covid-19 Deaths Strike Early for Many Minorities
authors: Paul Overberg,Jon Kamp,The Wall Street Journal
description: Covid-19 is known to be particularly risky for the elderly. For many minorities, the disease is killing them in the prime of their lives. Among people in the U.S. who died between their mid-40s and mid-70s since the pandemic began, the virus is responsible for about 9% of deaths. For Latino people who died in that age range, the virus has killed nearly 25%, according to a Wall Street Journal analysis of death-certificate data collected by federal authorities. ...

title: 2020 Data Fellowship
authors: Elizabeth Lucas,Paul Overberg,Center for Health Journalism
description: The 2020 Center for Health Journalism Data Fellowship was designed for skilled journalists who want to learn to mine data sources to reveal key insights essential to high-impact journalism. The program offered professional reporters an opportunity to learn to acquire, analyze and produce visualizations of data that can help their audiences understand key health and child welfare developments.

title: The Wall Street Journal's Paul Overberg Shares Essential COVID-19 Data Tips
authors: Giles Bruce,Paul Overberg,Center for Health Journalism
description: Over the past several months, data on COVID-19 has been used by governments around the world to order businesses to close and people to stay inside their homes, and has been a bedrock feature of news reports on the pandemic. But that doesn’t mean the numbers are always presented in their proper contexts.

title: Coronavirus Pandemic Led to Surge in Alzheimer’s Deaths
authors: Jon Kamp,Paul Overberg,The Wall Street Journal
description: At least 15,000 more Americans have died in recent months from Alzheimer’s disease and dementia than otherwise would have, health officials believe, pointing to how the coronavirus pandemic has exacted a higher fatality toll than official numbers have shown.

title: Covid-19 Stalks Large Families in Rural America
authors: Ian Lovett,Dan Frosch,Paul Overberg,The Wall Street Journal
description: The Woods family did everything together at the house on Paden Road in Gadsden, Ala. They gathered there before going to high-school football games on Friday nights. They ate there after church on Sundays, when the family matriarch, Barbara Woods, would make chicken and dressing for her children and grandchildren. And this spring, they grew sick there together.

title: Census Bureau Says 60.5% of Households Responded to 2020 Count
description: The Census Bureau reported Monday that it had reached its target to get at least 60.5% of households to respond to the 2020 census, despite disruptions created by the Covid-19 pandemic. The 2020 census ramped up in March, with many households responding quickly by late March. The response rate reached 50% by April 18 and 60% by Memorial Day. The final 2010 census rate was 66.5%.

title: Nearly Half of Adults Live in U.S. Households That Lost Income Since Lockdowns Started
authors: David Harrison,Paul Overberg,The Wall Street Journal
description: Nearly Half of Adults Live in U.S. Households That Lost Income Since Lockdowns StartedCensus Bureau report also shows more than a third expect to lose income over next four weeks in fallout from coronavirus pandemic, despite reopening efforts

title: U.S. Deaths Are Up Sharply, Though Covid-19’s Precise Toll Is Murky
authors: Paul Overberg,Jon Kamp,Brian McGill,The Wall Street Journal
description: In mid-April, 30% more Americans died than was typical in the same period in previous years, a Wall Street Journal examination of federal death-certificate data shows. The increase points to the heavy toll the coronavirus pandemic has had on the U.S., though it doesn’t provide an exact number of deaths from Covid-19, the disease caused by the virus. The coronavirus’s precise toll still isn’t very clear.

title: The Tricky Math Behind Coronavirus Death Predictions
authors: Brianna Abbott,Paul Overberg,The Wall Street Journal
description: The near doubling of coronavirus death predictions in a closely followed model this week underscores a frustrating reality for officials weighing how and when to reopen society: Many basic facts about the new coronavirus remain unknown. Epidemiologists have created many computer models to predict surge capacity in the health-care system and guide policy-making. These seek to predict how many people might be infected, how many will die, and when and how transmission might slow or speed up. ...

title: Why We Don’t Know How Many Americans Are Infected With Coronavirus—and Might Never Know
authors: Joel Eastwood,Paul Overberg,Rob Barry,The Wall Street Journal
description: The number of known infections with the new coronavirus has grown rapidly in the U.S., with more than 270,000 cases as of Friday. More than 7,000 have died. But there are all kinds of holes in those numbers. People who got sick—or died—before testing was widely available don’t show up in the tallies. Even now, many people who want to get tested can’t, and some who could get tested choose not to. Some people are tested more than once.

title: Census Bureau Delays Field Work on 2020 Census Again Over Coronavirus
description: The Census Bureau will extend its suspension of Census 2020 field work until April 15, two weeks longer than originally planned, due to the coronavirus epidemic. The delay, announced Saturday, will further compress the timetable to count all Americans. The process is scheduled to end Aug. 14 to meet a legal deadline that requires results be delivered by Dec. 31. The count was originally scheduled to end July 31. The...

title: Virus Outbreak Forces Census to Delay Head Count
description: WASHINGTON—The Census Bureau will delay the end of its Census 2020 head count by at least two weeks, until Aug. 14, due to the novel coronavirus epidemic. The bureau is checking with state and federal officials daily and will continue to adjust its operations as needed, Al Fontenot, associate director for decennial operations, said in a briefing Friday.

title: U.S. Census Bureau Suspends 2020 Census Field Work
description: WASHINGTON—The Census Bureau is suspending field work on the 2020 census until April 1 to protect thousands of census workers and help slow the spread of the novel coronavirus, the agency said Wednesday. The suspension could slow delivery of census forms being distributed by census workers this week to almost 10 million households. The door-to-door distribution is focused in rural and tribal areas where residents don’t receive mail at their homes. ...

title: College Students’ Dispersal Over Virus Concern Is Expected to Snarl Census
description: The sudden dispersal of college students across the U.S. as schools seek to limit the spread of the novel coronavirus could complicate the Census Bureau’s plan to count students at their school addresses. The 2020 census got under way Thursday. Millions of Americans have received invitations encouraging them to fill out the decennial questionnaire online, by phone or on paper.

title: How America Has Changed Since the Last Census
authors: Danny Dougherty,Renée Rigdon,Paul Overberg,The Wall Street Journal
description: In the 10 years since the last census, the U.S. has added 19 million people, growing more than 6%. The middle of the country has become more diverse, the booming growth of cities has slowed and longer lives and slowing births have resulted in an America that is older than it was a decade ago, according to Census Bureau estimates.

title: 2020 Census to Kick Off This Week
authors: Janet Adamy,Paul Overberg,The Wall Street Journal
description: WASHINGTON—The government’s largest effort to collect data on Americans using the internet gets under way this week when tens of millions of households will be asked to fill out their 2020 census forms online. The count will capture a country that has changed significantly since 2010. A wave of aging baby boomers and a collapse in the fertility...

title: Affluent Americans Still Say ‘I Do.’ More in the Middle Class Don’t.
authors: Janet Adamy,Paul Overberg,The Wall Street Journal
description: Middle-class Americans are forsaking marriage amid financial insecurity, effectively making the institution more of a luxury good enjoyed by prosperous Americans. The middle three-fifths of U.S. earners have experienced the sharpest declines in marriage rates over the past four decades compared with people at the bottom of the income ladder and those at the top, according to a Wall Street Journal analysis of census data from 1980 to 2018, the most recent available.

title: Heart Disease Strikes Back Across the U.S., Even in Healthy Places
authors: Betsy McKay,Paul Overberg,The Wall Street Journal
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo.—Colorado is ranked as one of the nation’s healthiest states. It often doesn’t feel that way to David Rosenbaum. The Colorado Springs cardiologist regularly sees men and women in their 30s and 40s with heart problems, such as high blood pressure, an irregular heart rhythm, heart attacks. A visit from a young patient was rare when he started practicing there 17 years ago. Not anymore.

title: Political Power Set to Continue Shift to Southern States, Data Show
authors: Janet Adamy,Paul Overberg,The Wall Street Journal
description: WASHINGTON—New state census totals show population continuing to shift from the North and Midwest to the South and Southwest in ways that could help states that have voted Republican in recent years. The Census Bureau released on Monday state population estimates for the year ended July 1. Congressional seats and electoral votes are allocated to states based on a census conducted every 10 years.

title: Speed Cameras: The Cities With the Worst Offenders
authors: Scott Calvert,Paul Overberg,Max Rust,The Wall Street Journal
description: NEW ORLEANS—As the Nissan cruised past single-story homes near Holy Cross School in the city’s Gentilly neighborhood, a speed camera clocked the car going 30 mph in a 20 mph zone. The resulting citation in May was the car’s 296th speed-camera ticket in less than two years. In 2018 alone, it racked up 188 tickets totaling $19,080 in fines—and the owner didn’t pay a penny, the city says. SHARE YOUR THOUGHTSHave you gotten a ticket from a speed camera?

title: Census Overhaul Seeks to Avoid Outing Individual Respondent Data
description: The Census Bureau is overhauling its systems after it found anyone with sophisticated data tools could use published results to identify millions of individual census respondents, according to agency officials. The new system would prevent anyone—whether policy makers, marketers or data thieves—from using published data to target people based on what they disclose on the census.

title: Doctors, Once GOP Stalwarts, Now More Likely to Be Democrats
authors: Janet Adamy,Paul Overberg,The Wall Street Journal
description: Oct. 6, 2019 1:38 pm ET Doctors used to be America’s quintessential Republicans. During the 20th century, most were high-earning men who owned their own practices. They liked Republicans’ support for curbing medical malpractice lawsuits and limiting government’s role in health care. When Democrats proposed creating Medicare in the 1960s, the American Medical Association, the largest physician group then and now, opposed the idea with a campaign starring then-actor Ronald Reagan.

title: Millennials Continue to Leave Big Cities
authors: Janet Adamy,Paul Overberg,Greg Ip,Diario La República (Colombia)
description: Census figures show smaller drop in young urban residents than previous years, but many still leaving for cheaper housing, better schoolsThe Wall Street Journal Large U.S. cities lost tens of thousands of millennial and younger Gen X residents last year, according to Census figures released Thursday that offer fresh signs of cooling urban growth.

title: Millennials Continue to Leave Big Cities
authors: Janet Adamy,Paul Overberg,The Wall Street Journal
description: By Janet Adamy and Paul OverbergSept. 26, 2019 12:01 am ETLarge U.S. cities lost tens of thousands of millennial and younger Gen X residents last year, according to Census figures released Thursday that offer fresh signs of cooling urban growth. Cities with more than a half million people collectively lost almost 27,000 residents age 25 to 39 in 2018, according to a Wall Street Journal analysis of the figures.

title: Median U.S. Household Income Showed No Growth in 2018
authors: Janet Adamy,Paul Overberg,The Wall Street Journal
description: WASHINGTON—American incomes remained essentially flat in 2018 after three straight years of growth, according to Census Bureau figures released Tuesday that offer a broad look at U.S. households’ financial well-being. Median household income was $63,179 in 2018, an uptick of 0.9% that census officials said isn’t statistically significant from the prior year based on figures adjusted for inflation.

title: White House Defends Trump’s Decision on Census
