GrimaldiOct. 11, 2022 8:00 am ETThousands of officials across the government’s executive branch reported owning or trading stocks that stood to rise or fall with decisions their agencies made, a Wall Street Journal investigation has found.

title: WWE董事会发现前CEO曾向特朗普基金会捐款500万美元
link: https://cn.wsj.com/articles/wwe董事会发现前ceo曾向特朗普基金会捐款500万美元-11660782552
description: 董事会内部调查发现，Vince McMahon因不当行为指控而从World Wrestling Entertainment Inc. (WWE)卸任前，该公司有1,960万美元的支出未被记录，其中包括2007年和2009年向特朗普(Donald Trump)的慈善机构提供的总额500万美元捐款。 在本月的证券公告中，WWE表示，McMahon花费的上述约2,000万美元本应被披露，因为相关交易对他经营的这家公司有利。虽然这些钱中的大部分支付给了指控McMahon和另一位WWE高管有不当性行为的女性，但该公司在公告中称有500万美元与这些指控无关，不过没有说明用在了哪里。 了解上述调查的人士表示，这500万美元用于向现已解散的特朗普基金会(Donald J. Trump Foundation)进行慈善捐款，在捐款的那两年里，当时还是房地产开发商的特朗普在WWE的电视转播活动中现身过。...

title: WWE internal probe finds ex-CEO Vince McMahon gave $5 million to Trump's charity
description: Contributions totaling $5 million to Donald Trump's charity in 2007 and 2009 were among $19.6 million in unrecorded company expenses Vince McMahon paid out before he stepped down from World Wrestling Entertainment Inc. amid misconduct allegations, an internal board investigation found. In securities filings this month, WWE said that the roughly $20 million that came out of McMahon's pocket should have been disclosed, because the transactions benefited the company he ran.

title: WSJ News Exclusive | WWE’s Board Finds Vince McMahon Paid $5 Million to Donald Trump’s Charity
authors: Joe Palazzolo,Ted Mann,The Wall Street Journal
description: People familiar with the board investigation said the $5 million represented charitable donations to the now-dissolved Donald J. Trump Foundation in the same two years that the then-real-estate developer made appearances at WWE televised events. Mr. McMahon retired as chairman and CEO last month, ending his four-decade tenure as the head of the company that he and his wife, Linda McMahon, built into wrestling’s biggest business.

title: WWE Says Probe of Vince McMahon Is ‘Substantially Complete’
authors: Joe Palazzolo,Ted Mann,The Wall Street Journal
description: The settlements with the women, first reported by The Wall Street Journal, included a $7.5 million pact in 2018 with a former wrestler who alleged Mr. McMahon coerced her into giving him oral sex. She alleged that Mr. McMahon pushed her out after she refused further sexual encounters, according to people familiar with the deal. An attorney representing Mr. McMahon declined to comment.

title: FEDERAL INQUIRIES HASTENED PARTING AT WWE
authors: Ted Mann,Joe Palazzolo,The Wall Street Journal
description: ABSTRACTSEC and federal prosecutors have launched inquiries into payments made by World Wrestling Entertainment’s CEO Vince McMahon to settle claims of sexual misconduct; probes hastened McMahon’s retirement on July 22; photo (M)

title: Sports Media Mailbag
authors: Joe Palazzolo,Ted Mann,Joe Flint,Parker Gabriel,The Athletic
description: Welcome to the 32nd Media Mailbag for The Athletic. Writing a mailbag - as egocentric as it is - is always a fun exercise. Thanks for sending in your questions via the website and app. There were nearly 150 questions, so this will be a two-parter. Part 2 will appear later this week. Note: Questions have been edited for clarity and length. The NFL gets its future players free from the colleges.

title: WSJ News Exclusive | WWE’s Vince McMahon Agreed to Pay $12 Million in Hush Money to Four Women
authors: Joe Palazzolo,Ted Mann,Joe Flint,The Wall Street Journal
description: Vince McMahon, World Wrestling Entertainment Inc.’s longtime leader, agreed to pay more than $12 million over the past 16 years to suppress allegations of sexual misconduct and infidelity, an amount far larger than previously known.

title: WWE Board Investigating Vince McMahon ‘Hush Pact’ For Alleged Affair
description: Vince McMahon is under investigation. Joe Palazzolo and Ted Mann of The Wall Street Journal report that the WWE board is investigating a secret $3 million settlement, or a “hush pact”, that company chairman Vince McMahon reached with a former employee that he allegedly had an affair with, per documents and people familiar with the inquiry.

title: WSJ News Exclusive | WWE Board Probes Secret $3 Million Hush Pact by CEO Vince McMahon, Sources Say
authors: Joe Palazzolo,Ted Mann,The Wall Street Journal
description: By Joe Palazzolo and Ted MannJune 15, 2022 3:52 pm ETThe board of World Wrestling Entertainment is investigating a secret $3 million settlement that longtime chief executive Vince McMahon agreed to pay to a departing employee with whom he allegedly had an affair, according to documents and people familiar with the board inquiry.

title: Federal Judge Replaced in Big Criminal Copyright Case
description: One of the largest criminal copyright cases in U.S. history has a new judge and potentially a new headache for the Justice Department in its decadelong effort to extradite and convict Kim Dotcom, founder of the file-sharing service Megaupload Ltd. Judge Liam O’Grady was replaced this week by Judge Anthony Trenga, according to a notice on the docket in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia.

title: CONGRESS PASSES BILL ON JUDGE DISCLOSURE
authors: James V. Grimaldi,Coulter Jones,Joe Palazzolo,The Wall Street Journal
description: ABSTRACTPres Biden is expected to sign bill prompted by WSJ reporting would require federal judges and Supreme Court justices to make more timely and accessible disclosures of their financial holdings and potential conflicts of interest (M)

title: Judges’ Financial-Disclosure Bill Passes, Heads to President’s Desk
authors: James V. Grimaldi,Coulter Jones,Joe Palazzolo,The Wall Street Journal
description: WASHINGTON—Federal judges and Supreme Court justices must make more timely and accessible disclosures of their financial holdings and potential conflicts of interest under legislation that’s one step closer to becoming law after a voice vote in the House Wednesday. The Courthouse Ethics and Transparency Act, a bill prompted by a Wall Street Journal investigation, passed the Senate in February and now heads to the White House for President Biden’s expected signature.

title: Federal Judiciary Acts to Automate Judges’ Financial Disclosures
authors: James V. Grimaldi,Joe Palazzolo,Coulter Jones,The Wall Street Journal
description: Move comes amid pressure from Congress on new legislationBy James V. Grimaldi, Joe Palazzolo and Coulter JonesMar. 15, 2022 5:13 pm ETWASHINGTON—The federal judiciary’s policy-making body said it would automate the release of financial-disclosure forms of federal judges to improve transparency, but lawmakers said the move falls short of ethics legislation on the verge of final passage.

title: WSJ News Exclusive | IRS Is Audited Over Its Safeguards Against Favored Treatment of Big Business
authors: Joe Palazzolo,Richard Rubin,The Wall Street Journal
description: The Internal Revenue Service’s watchdog is examining how the agency guards against favoring large businesses and global companies in compliance matters as part of a broad audit. The U.S. Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration, or Tigta, has reached out to people inside and outside the IRS for information since starting work on the audit late last year, according to a person familiar with the inquiry.

title: WSJ News Exclusive | Fallout From Judges’ Financial Conflicts Spreads to Appeals Courts
authors: James V. Grimaldi,Joe Palazzolo,Coulter Jones,The Wall Street Journal
description: Federal appeals courts now have to decide whether affected judges’ conflicts were great enough to warrant wiping out their rulings. The Walter E. Hoffman U.S. Courthouse in Norfolk, Va.

title: Federal Judge Steps Aside From High-Profile Amazon Case, Citing Financial Conflict
description: A federal judge removed himself from a nearly two-year-old Amazon.com Inc. case, citing a financial conflict, after a Wall Street Journal report about his family’s Amazon stockholdings. U.S. District Judge Liam O’Grady had ruled in Amazon’s favor during the 20 months he oversaw the civil case, in which the online retailer accuses two former employees of taking kickbacks from a real-estate developer and violating Amazon’s conflict-of-interest policies.

title: An Amazon Suit Encounters a Snag: a Judge With a Conflict of Interest
authors: Joe Palazzolo,Coulter Jones,James V. Grimaldi,The Wall Street Journal
description: For nearly two years, U.S. District Judge Liam O’Grady has handed Amazon.com Inc. a string of court victories in a continuing suit in which it accuses two former employees of taking kickbacks from a real-estate developer and violating Amazon’s conflict-of-interest policies. All that time, Judge O’Grady had a conflict of his own: a financial interest that under federal law barred him from hearing the case in the first place. Throughout the case, Judge O’Grady’s wife owned Amazon stock.

title: Judges Held Off Congress’s Efforts to Impose Ethics Rules-Until Now
authors: James V. Grimaldi,Joe Palazzolo,Coulter Jones,The Wall Street Journal
description: Chief Justice John Roberts wasn’t pleased as lawmakers briefed him and other senior judges about a sweeping judicial-accountability bill they had just introduced. In a wood-paneled conference room at the Supreme Court, Chief Justice Roberts said he had “serious constitutional concerns” about the 2018 House legislation, according to attendees. The room fell quiet.

title: Federal Judge Files Recusal Notices in 138 Cases After WSJ Queries
authors: Coulter Jones,Joe Palazzolo,James V. Grimaldi,The Wall Street Journal
description: One of America’s most prominent federal judges acknowledged in court notices that he may have violated the law in 138 lawsuits identified by The Wall Street Journal between 2011 and 2018 by hearing cases that involved companies in which he or his wife had a financial interest. The admissions by U.S. District Judge Rodney Gilstrap, most made in notices filed Friday by a court clerk, involved some of America’s biggest brand-name stocks including Exxon Mobil Corp. , McDonald’s Corp.   Microsoft Corp.

title: Judiciary Plans New System for Spotting Financial Conflicts After WSJ Report
authors: Joe Palazzolo,James V. Grimaldi,Coulter Jones,The Wall Street Journal
description: The federal judiciary is planning a new electronic financial-disclosure system to spot judges’ conflicts, but the chairwoman of the judiciary’s ethics committee stopped short of promising an end to long delays in getting those reports to the public. “In some cases the release of reports takes too long,” Judge Jennifer Elrod said in written testimony for a House Judiciary subcommittee hearing Tuesday.

title: WSJ News Exclusive | Federal Judges Would Face Tougher Stock-Trading Rules Under Bipartisan Bill
authors: James V. Grimaldi,Coulter Jones,Joe Palazzolo,The Wall Street Journal
description: Federal judges would be required to report stock trades over $1,000 within 45 days and post their financial-disclosure forms online under legislation proposed by a bipartisan group of lawmakers in the Senate and House of Representatives.

title: Federal Judges or Their Brokers Traded Stocks of Litigants During Cases
authors: Coulter Jones,Joe Palazzolo,James V. Grimaldi,The Wall Street Journal
description: This copy is for your personal, non-commercial use only. Distribution and use of this material are governed byour Subscriber Agreement and by copyright law. For non-personal use or to order multiple copies, please contactDow Jones Reprints at 1-800-843-0008 or visit www.djreprints.com. https://www.wsj.com/articles/federal-judges-brokers-traded-stocks-of-litigants-during-cases-walmart-pfizer-11634306192

title: Weekend Reads, Oct. 2-3 - A Wall Street Journal List curated by Todd Olmstead
authors: James V. Grimaldi,Coulter Jones,Joe Palazzolo,Vanessa Fuhrmans,The Wall Street Journal
description: A selection of WSJ articles that published during the week for readers to dive into this weekend. This WSJ investigation found hundreds of instances of judges improperly failing to disqualify themselves from cases. This article is part of WSJ's annual Women in the Workplace report, which I always find to be essential reading.

title: Judge Rodney Gilstrap Sets an Unwanted Record: Most Cases With Financial Conflicts
authors: Joe Palazzolo,James V. Grimaldi,Coulter Jones,The Wall Street Journal
description: No federal judge in America has heard more patent-infringement lawsuits in the past decade than Rodney Gilstrap, who presides over a small courthouse in Marshall, Texas. He also holds another record: Judge Gilstrap has taken on 138 cases since 2011 that involved companies in which he or a family member had a financial interest, more than any other federal judge, a Wall Street Journal investigation shows. The companies included Microsoft Corp. (53 cases), Walmart Inc. (36 cases), Target Corp.

title: Dozens of Federal Judges Had Financial Conflicts: What You Need to Know
authors: Coulter Jones,Joe Palazzolo,James V. Grimaldi,The Wall Street Journal
description: Updated April 27, 2022 7:30 pm ETListen to article(2 minutes)A Wall Street Journal investigation found that 152 federal judges around the nation have violated U.S. law and judicial ethics by overseeing 1,076 court cases involving companies in which they or their family owned stock. Copyright ©2023 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All Rights Reserved. 87990cbe856818d5eddac44c7b1cdeb8

title: How the Journal Found Judges’ Violations of Law on Conflicts
authors: Coulter Jones,James V. Grimaldi,Joe Palazzolo,The Wall Street Journal
description: By Coulter Jones, James V. Grimaldi and Joe PalazzoloSept. 28, 2021 8:56 am ETTo discover recusal violations, The Wall Street Journal reviewed the financial holdings of roughly 700 federal district and appellate judges and compared them against tens of thousands of court cases. The Journal used data provided by the Free Law Project, a nonpartisan legal-research nonprofit, which requested financial-disclosure forms for all federal judges from the Administrative Office of the U.S. Courts.

title: Federal Judges With Financial Conflicts
authors: Andrew Levinson,Coulter Jones,Joe Palazzolo,James V. Grimaldi,The Wall Street Journal
description: The Wall Street Journal analyzed nearly a decade’s worth of legal and financial records and discovered 131 federal judges who unlawfully heard cases where they had a financial interest. Look at U.S. District Judge Brian Martinotti. The New Jersey judge traded Wells Fargo stock while hearing a case where the bank was the defendant, and ruled in its favor. Federal law bars judges from hearing cases in which they or their family hold stocks in the plaintiff or defendant.

title: 131 Federal Judges Broke the Law by Hearing Cases Where They Had a Financial Interest
authors: James V. Grimaldi,Coulter Jones,Joe Palazzolo,The Wall Street Journal
description: By James V. Grimaldi, Coulter Jones and Joe PalazzoloSept. 28, 2021 9:07 am ETCopyright ©2023 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All Rights Reserved. 87990cbe856818d5eddac44c7b1cdeb8

title: A Post-Watergate Law Some Judges Overlook
authors: James V. Grimaldi,Joe Palazzolo,Coulter Jones,The Wall Street Journal
description: Since 1974, federal judges have been prohibited by federal law from hearing cases involving companies in which they hold even a single share of stock. The law, signed by former President Gerald Ford about four months after the resignation of Richard Nixon, created a black-and-white rule: If judges, their spouses or minor children own a “legal or equitable interest, however small,” in a plaintiff or a defendant in their court, they must disqualify themselves from the case.

title: National Enquirer owner, former CEO fined for breaking election law to help Trump in 2016
description: The publisher of the National Enquirer agreed to pay $187,500 as part of a settlement with the Federal Election Commission over a 2016 scheme to buy and suppress the story of a woman who alleged an affair with former President Donald Trump. The May 17 agreement between A360 Media LLC and the FEC characterized the $150,000 payment to model Karen McDougal as an illegal corporate campaign contribution. Federal law prohibits companies from making contributions to candidate committees.

title: National Enquirer Parent Fined for Breaking Election Law in 2016 Campaign
description: David Pecker, former CEO of American Media, told prosecutors in 2018 that he took a story about the alleged affair off the market at the behest of Donald Trump. The publisher of the National Enquirer agreed to pay $187,500 as part of a settlement with the Federal Election Commission over a 2016 scheme to buy and suppress the story of a woman who alleged an affair with former President Donald Trump.

title: National Enquirer Parent, Ex-CEO Fined for Breaking Election Law in 2016 Campaign
description: The May 17 agreement between A360 Media LLC and the FEC characterized the $150,000 payment to model Karen McDougal as an illegal corporate campaign contribution. Federal law prohibits companies from making contributions to candidate committees. A spokesman for A360 Media and David Pecker, the former chief executive of American Media Inc., didn’t have an immediate comment.

title: Cuomo Impeachment Inquiry to Look at Family Covid-19 Testing
authors: Jimmy Vielkind,Joe Palazzolo,The Wall Street Journal
description: ALBANY, N.Y.—The impeachment investigation into New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo will also examine whether members of the Democratic governor’s family were given priority access to coronavirus tests in the first weeks of the pandemic last year, a key state lawmaker said.

title: Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s Office Under Investigation for Nursing Homes’ Covid-19 Liability Immunity
authors: Corinne Ramey,Jimmy Vielkind,Joe Palazzolo,The Wall Street Journal
description: Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn are investigating a push by Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s administration to enact broad protections for nursing homes from lawsuits and criminal prosecution early in the Covid-19 pandemic, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: WSJ News Exclusive | Cuomo Administration Questioned U.S. Health Officials About Nursing-Home Data
authors: Joe Palazzolo,Jimmy Vielkind,The Wall Street Journal
description: When New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s administration learned last year that the federal government was about to release data on Covid-19 deaths in nursing homes, state officials were concerned: Would the federal numbers tell the public a different story than the state’s own?

title: Cuomo advisers got health officials to alter report on COVID-19 nursing-home deaths
description: The Wall Street Journal Published: March 4, 2021 at 9:40 p.m. ET By July report undercounted more than 6,400 deaths New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo speaks in New York City in May 2020. AFP/Getty Images New York Gov.

title: WSJ News Exclusive | Cuomo Advisers Altered Report on Covid-19 Nursing-Home Deaths
authors: Joe Palazzolo,Jimmy Vielkind,Rebecca Davis O’Brien,The Wall Street Journal
description: New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s top advisers successfully pushed state health officials to strip a public report of data showing that more nursing-home residents had died of Covid-19 than the administration had acknowledged, according to people with knowledge of the report’s production.

title: Gov. Cuomo's Administration Hires Criminal Defense Lawyer
description: © seth wenig/Agence France-Presse/Getty Images The administration of New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo has retained a prominent white-collar defense attorney as it grapples with allegations of sexual harassment and Justice Department inquiries into Covid-19 deaths in the state’s nursing homes. Elkan Abramowitz, a one-time federal prosecutor, confirmed he is representing the Executive Chamber—which comprises the governor and his closest aides—in the nursing-home investigation.

title: WSJ News Exclusive | Cuomo Administration Hires Criminal Defense Lawyer
authors: Jimmy Vielkind,Joe Palazzolo,The Wall Street Journal
description: The administration of New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo has retained a prominent white-collar defense attorney as it grapples with allegations of sexual harassment and Justice Department inquiries into Covid-19 deaths in the state’s nursing homes. Elkan Abramowitz, a one-time federal prosecutor, confirmed he was representing the Executive Chamber—which comprises the governor and his closest aides—in both the sexual harassment and nursing-home matters.

title: Most Capitol Riot Suspects Have No Far-Right Group Ties, a Challenge in Fight Against Extremism
authors: Joe Palazzolo,Erin Ailworth,Rebecca Davis O’Brien,The Wall Street Journal
description: Most of the nearly 200 people charged in federal cases in connection with the Capitol riot have no known ties to far-right groups, underscoring the challenge of heading off violent extremism, a Wall Street Journal review found. Authorities say they are ramping up efforts to counter extremism in the wake of the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol, but they are discovering that any charges against people affiliated with organized groups such as the Proud Boys addresses only part of the issue.

title: If you're trying to make sense of the Capitol riot, read these books
authors: Robert Blaemire,Joe Palazzolo,Michael Rothfeld,Elizabeth Holtzman,KION-TV (Salinas, CA)
description: On January 6, the world watched as the US Capitol was attacked by pro-Trump rioters. Since then, each day has been filled with revelations about how it was plotted and carried out. Many are still trying to process the initial shock. While seeing Confederate and Trump 2020 flags draped all over the Capitol was a shocking sight for some, others were not surprised. “It was simply the culmination of the past four years under Trump’s presidency,” said librarian Djaz Zulida.

title: If you're trying to make sense of the Capitol riot, read these books
authors: Sydney Walton,Robert Blaemire,Joe Palazzolo,Michael Rothfeld,WICU-TV / WSEE-TV (Erie, PA)
description: On January 6, the world watched as the US Capitol was attacked by pro-Trump rioters. Since then, each day has been filled with revelations about how it was plotted and carried out. Many are still trying to process the initial shock. While seeing Confederate and Trump 2020 flags draped all over the Capitol was a shocking sight for some, others were not surprised. "It was simply the culmination of the past four years under Trump's presidency," said librarian Djaz Zulida.

title: WSJ News Exclusive | Steve Wynn and Lawyer, United over Trump, Break Ties in Messy Spat
authors: Joe Palazzolo,Aruna Viswanatha,The Wall Street Journal
description: For years, lawyer L. Lin Wood worked closely with Steve Wynn, representing the casino magnate in legal matters and united in their support of President Trump. Mr. Wood crafted sensitive settlement pacts when Mr. Wynn faced accusations of sexual harassment, allegations Mr. Wynn has denied. Mr. Wynn arranged for the Atlanta-based lawyer to visit Mr. Trump’s Florida club as his guest.

title: Trump and His Allies Set the Stage for Riot Well Before January 6
authors: Rebecca Ballhaus,Joe Palazzolo,Andrew Restuccia,The Wall Street Journal
description: It took just a few hours for pro-Trump rioters to storm the U.S. Capitol Wednesday. Before that were weeks of rhetoric and encouragement from the president and a circle of close allies, whose actions are certain to draw closer scrutiny. In the weeks after the election, President Trump and a handful of key, high-level supporters urged in news conferences, speeches and social media posts that followers of the president should rise up against the outcome of a national election they said was rigged.

title: Democrats Continue March Toward Trump Impeachment — Latest Updates - WSJ.com
authors: Kate King,Kristina Peterson,Natalie Andrews,Aaron Zitner,Rebecca Ballhaus,Siobhan Hughes,Joe Palazzolo,John McCormick,Andrew Restuccia,The Wall Street Journal
description: Two men recorded in now notorious images from the Jan. 6 riot in Washington were charged in federal court Saturday for violent entry and disorderly conduct on Capitol grounds. Federal officials said one of the men, 36-year-old Adam Johnson, of Florida, removed Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi’s lectern from its storage spot and was photographed carrying it through the Capitol building. Mr. Johnson couldn’t immediately be reached for comment.

title: Mail Service Deteriorated After Postmaster General Louis DeJoy’s Arrival, Watchdog Found
description: A dramatic and lasting slowdown in mail delivery flowed from actions that Postmaster General Louis DeJoy initiated or which were accelerated after he took office in June, according to an analysis by the U.S. Postal Service’s watchdog.

title: In Worst-Hit Covid State, New York’s Cuomo Called All the Shots
authors: Jimmy Vielkind,Joe Palazzolo,Jacob Gershman,The Wall Street Journal
description: Governor overrode mayor on shutdown timing, faced criticism for nursing home moves; ‘It’s not your call’By Jimmy Vielkind, Joe Palazzolo and Jacob GershmanSep. 11, 2020 11:14 am ETNew York City was locking down. Gov. Andrew Cuomo wanted to say when and how it would happen. After Mayor Bill de Blasio told residents in a March 17 news conference to prepare to “shelter in place,” Mr. Cuomo dismissed the mayor’s plan in a television interview while his aides blitzed City Hall with calls.

title: 160694 2019 E Jean Carroll v Donald J Trump EXHIBIT S 113
description: 160694/2019NYSCEF DOC. NO. 113 Case 1:20-cv-07311 Document 1 Filed 09/08/20 PageRECEIVED 1 of 4 NYSCEF: 09/08/2020 JEFFREY BOSSERT CLARK Acting Assistant Attorney General Civil Division JAMES G. TOUHEY, JR. Director STEPHEN R.

description: JEFFREY BOSSERT CLARKActing Assistant Attorney GeneralCivil DivisionJAMES G. TOUHEY, JR. DirectorSTEPHEN R. title: Coronavirus Takes Financial Toll on New York City’s ‘Safety-Net’ Hospitals
authors: Melanie West,Joe Palazzolo,The Wall Street Journal
description: The hospitals serving New York City’s neediest and most vulnerable patients face a financial reckoning as a result of the new coronavirus outbreak and uncertain stimulus funding from Washington, officials at the institutions say. New York City’s Health + Hospitals system is running with about 18 days of cash on hand, officials say. The 11-hospital system will go lean on cash in June and July if more federal funding doesn’t begin to flow, including from the Federal Emergency Management Agency.

title: Wave of media layoffs continues
description: This story, plus an investigation finds that some news stories were removed from Google search results after questionable copyright complaints, a reporter demonstrates the ease of plagiarizing news sites, and more, all in today’s media headlines.

title: Google Hides News, Tricked by Fake Claims
authors: Andrea Fuller,Kirsten Grind,Joe Palazzolo,The Wall Street Journal
description: A Google search, at one time, could locate a news article on a man accused of attempted child rape, another on someone charged with fraud and still others on Ukrainian politicians facing corruption allegations. Googling certain keywords in March would find an article detailing the movements of two coronavirus-infected British tourists in Vietnam and warning others who visited the same places to take precautions. Then the stories vanished. ...

title: WSJ News Exclusive | Overwhelmed by Coronavirus, New York City Awards Contracts to Unproven Vendors
authors: Andrea Fuller,Joe Palazzolo,The Wall Street Journal
description: About six weeks after the owner of a snowplow and hauling company pleaded guilty to a felony tax crime, his company received an award normally off-limits to people facing jail time: a $14 million contract from New York City. Amid the coronavirus pandemic, city agencies have been conducting more-limited background checks on vendors than usual, balancing due diligence with the need to get supplies quickly, city officials said. A...

title: Young Doctors Struggle to Treat Coronavirus Patients: ‘We Are Horrified and Scared’
authors: Khadeeja Safdar,Joe Palazzolo,Janet Adamy,Shalini Ramachandran,The Wall Street Journal
description: As young doctors training to be psychiatrists, Rita Morales and her co-residents at NewYork-Presbyterian/Columbia hospital filled many days counseling patients and managing their medications. When coronavirus patients flooded in, the hospital said it needed a group of psychiatry residents to help care for the sickest of patients in the intensive-care unit.

title: As Coronavirus Peaks, New York City’s Hospitals Prepare ‘Live or Die’ Guidance
authors: Janet Adamy,Melanie Evans,Joe Palazzolo,The Wall Street Journal
description: A surge in critically ill patients in New York City is forcing major hospitals to make worst-case scenario plans for who will live and die, as the coronavirus peaks and stretches emergency supplies. Some hospitals and state health leaders have drawn up guidelines for which patients get ventilators should hospitals run short, according to interviews with hospital officials and memos viewed by The Wall Street Journal. The...

title: The Coronavirus Crisis in Doctors’ Own Words: ‘A Flood of Death That I Cannot Manage’
authors: Joe Palazzolo,Anthony De Rosa,The Wall Street Journal
description: As doctors, nurses and other health-care professionals face an unrelenting flow of patients through their hospitals, they’ve taken to social media to share their experiences. The raw emotions and visceral descriptions of what they are enduring comes through in countless posts on Twitter, Facebook, Instagram and other platforms. Many call the fight against the new coronavirus unlike any other health crisis they have faced in their careers.

title: WSJ News Exclusive | NYU Langone Tells ER Doctors to ‘Think More Critically’ About Who Gets Ventilators
authors: Shalini Ramachandran,Joe Palazzolo,The Wall Street Journal
description: NYU Langone Health, one of the nation’s top academic medical centers, told emergency-room doctors that they have “sole discretion” to place patients on ventilators and institutional backing to “withhold futile intubations.” A March 28 email from Robert Femia, who heads the New York health center’s department of emergency medicine, underscored the life-or-death decisions placed on the shoulders of bedside physicians as they treat increasing numbers of coronavirus patients with a limited supply...

title: Inside a New York ER as Coronavirus Hits: ‘We Don’t Know How High the Peak Is Going to Be’
description: BROOKLYN, N.Y.—Dr. John Marshall, an N95 mask sealed tightly to his face, hurried through his horseshoe-shaped emergency department on Wednesday, checking on staff dealing with the surge in coronavirus patients. “High-flows coming?” one doctor asked, using hospital shorthand for high-flow oxygen machines,...

title: Coronavirus Cases Strain New York City Hospitals: ‘We’re Getting Pounded’
authors: Shalini Ramachandran,Joe Palazzolo,Melanie West,Melanie Evans,The Wall Street Journal
description: New York City hospitals are already straining under the onslaught of novel coronavirus cases, even as state officials say the real peak of the outbreak is nearly a month and a half away. Doctors at the largest public hospital in New York say equipment shortages have resulted in them wearing the same masks for as long as a week. Emergency-room physicians at another hospital are having to reuse gowns. Some large hospitals already have exceeded the capacity of their intensive-care units. ...

title: LIVE STREAM: Dionne Searcey and Michael Rothfeld with Jennifer Forsyth
description: Join us on Zoom for a conversation with authors and Pulitzer Prize winning reporters Dionne Searcey and Michael Rothfeld. Serving as moderator will be Jennifer Forsyth, Deputy Chief of Investigations at The Wall Street Journal and Searcey and Rothfeld's former editor. The event is free but registration is required. Please click here to register.

title: Bloomberg Releases Woman From Nondisclosure Agreement Over Discrimination Suit
description: A woman who says Michael Bloomberg told her to terminate her pregnancy while she worked for his financial-data company the 1990s has been released from a nondisclosure agreement that prevented her from discussing the allegations, her lawyer said Friday.

title: Amazon’s Jeff Bezos sued for defamation by his girlfriend’s brother
description: Michael Sanchez, the brother of Jeff Bezos’ girlfriend, sued the Amazon.com Inc. AMZN, +7.38%   founder for defamation, alleging his representatives spread false rumors to news outlets that Sanchez provided graphic nude photos of Bezos to the press. The lawsuit, filed Friday in California state court in Los Angeles, also names as a defendant Gavin de Becker, a security consultant hired by Bezos.

title: Leaked texts linked to Bezos girlfriend
description: Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos, right, and his girlfriend Lauren Sanchez, left, pictured as they arrive to attend a company event in Mumbai. Text messages are among materials under review in a probe examining whether publisher America Media Inc. tried to extort Bezos. Picture: AFPFederal prosecutors in Manhattan have evidence indicating Jeff Bezos’ girlfriend provided text messages to her brother that he then sold to the National Enquirer for its article about the Amazon.com Inc.

title: Prosecutors’ evidence indicates brother of Bezos’ girlfriend leaked texts to National Enquirer
description: Manhattan federal prosecutors have evidence indicating Jeff Bezos' girlfriend provided text messages to her brother that he then sold to the National Enquirer for its article about the Amazon.com Inc. founder's affair, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Prosecutors’ evidence indicates brother of Bezos’ girlfriend leaked texts to National Enquirer
description: Manhattan federal prosecutors have evidence indicating Jeff Bezos’ girlfriend provided text messages to her brother that he then sold to the National Enquirer for its article about the Amazon.com Inc. AMZN, -1.22%   founder’s affair, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: WSJ News Exclusive | Prosecutors Have Evidence Bezos’ Girlfriend Gave Texts to Brother Who Leaked to National Enquirer
authors: Joe Palazzolo,Corinne Ramey,The Wall Street Journal
description: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan have evidence indicating Jeff Bezos ’ girlfriend provided text messages to her brother that he then sold to the National Enquirer for its article about the Amazon.com Inc. founder’s affair, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: THE FIXERS by Joe Palazzolo , Michael Rothfeld
description: Be the first to discover new talent! Each week, our editors select the one author and one book they believe to be most worthy of your attention and highlight them in our Pro Connect email alert. Sign up here to receive your FREE alerts. Email address:Please provide an email address.

title: Why Legal Secretaries Can't Find Jobs
authors: Jennifer Smith,Joe Palazzolo,The Wall Street Journal
description: Steve Bryant is still hunting for permanent work more than four years after he was laid off from his legal secretary job at the New York office of Latham & Watkins LLP, which slashed more than 250 staffers at the height of the recession. Mr. Bryant has tried to burnish his résumé, obtaining a college degree and a paralegal certificate from Hunter College in New York. Despite roughly 20 job interviews, and a slew of job applications, he has landed only lower-paying work as a temp.

title: The Bottom-Feeders, Crooked Lawyers, Gossipmongers, and Porn Stars Who Created the 45th President
authors: Jill Filipovic,Joe Palazzolo,Michael Rothfeld,The Washington Post
description: Jill Filipovic is a journalist and the author of “The H-Spot: The Feminist Pursuit of Happiness.”‘The Fixers” is not a particularly enjoyable read.

title: ‘Monday Is Going To Be A Bad Day’: Rosenstein Gave Sessions A Heads Up On 2018 Cohen Raid
description: This article is part of TPM Cafe, TPM’s home for opinion and news analysis. The following is an excerpt from “The Fixers: The Bottom-Feeders, Crooked Lawyers, Gossipmongers and Porn Stars Who Created the 45th President” (Penguin Random House, on sale Jan. 14, 2020). In the predawn hours of Monday, April 9, FBI agents filtered into a side entrance of the Loews Regency Hotel on Manhattan’s Park Avenue and took the service elevator to the seventeenth floor. They knocked on the door to room 1728.

title: The Untold Story of How Trump’s Fixers Silenced Stormy Daniels Just Days Before the 2016 Election
description: This is an adapted excerpt from The Fixers: The Bottom-Feeders, Crooked Lawyers, Gossipmongers, and Porn Stars Who Created the 45th President, by Pulitzer Prize-winning investigative reporters Joe Palazzolo and Michael Rothfeld, to be published Tuesday by Random House. TheAccess Hollywood video changed the math for Stormy Daniels as well as for Donald Trump. Before it emerged, reporters had already focused on allegations of Trump making unwanted sexual advances and objectifying women.

title: The Fixers: The Bottom-Feeders, Crooked Lawyers, Gossipmongers, and Porn Stars Who Created the 45th President
authors: Joe Palazzolo,New York Journal of Books
description: “Donald Trump appears to conceive politics like business and sex—a combat zone contesting personal power, with winning the only pleasure.”  Like a lumbering, retired football lineman, Donald Trump stands 6'3" and weighs 239 pounds, an imposing alpha male. He appears to conceive politics like business and sex—a combat zone contesting personal power, with winning the only pleasure.

title: The Fixers: The Bottom-Feeders, Crooked Lawyers, Gossipmongers, and Porn Stars Who Created the 45th President (Hardcover)
description: $28.00 Not Currently On Our Shelves. Usually Ships in 1-5 Days Description The shocking, definitive account of the lawyers and media tycoons who enabled the rise of Donald Trump, featuring new revelations from a Pulitzer Prize-winning Wall Street Journal teamWith his blunt-force fame and the myths he’s propagated about himself, Donald Trump has always moved in a world of gossip barons, crooked lawyers, and porn stars.

title: The Fixers
description: The First Fixer Donald Trump kept a photo of Roy Cohn on his office desk. If a business meeting wasn’t proceeding as planned, Trump might point to the photo and say, in so many words, You don’t want to mess with me. Just look at this mug. That’s my lawyer. This affinity for the battle had bound the two men, forging one of the defining relationships of both of their lives. It began in the early 1970s, with Trump a few years shy of his thirtieth birthday.

title: The Fall of Donald Trump’s Fixers
authors: Joe Palazzolo,Michael Rothfeld,The Wall Street Journal
description: For decades, Donald Trump has depended on loyalists to take care of especially sensitive and difficult tasks. These guardians of his image—including the Red-baiter Roy Cohn, the tabloid publisher David Pecker and the lawyer Michael Cohen—learned a hard lesson from their service. They pledged fealty to Mr. Trump and dedicated themselves to shielding him. For a while, they became wealthier and more powerful through their association with him.

title: A Businessman’s Second Act Upends Giuliani’s Ukraine Work for Trump
authors: Georgi Kantchev,Rebecca Davis O’Brien,Joe Palazzolo,The Wall Street Journal
description: Years before he worked to help President Trump’s personal attorney try to have Ukraine launch investigations,Igor Fruman brought a first to the Ukrainian port city of Odessa: a condo building with a swimming pool. The project was part of a web of Ukraine businesses—including beach clubs, Jaguar dealerships, and imports of olives and baby food—that Mr. Fruman built or invested in during the 1990s, as the collapse of the Soviet Union presented an opening for luxurious tastes in Eastern Europe.

title: Giuliani Associate Left Trail of Troubled Businesses Before Ukraine Probe Push
authors: Joe Palazzolo,Rebecca Davis O’Brien,The Wall Street Journal
description: Since its inception in 2013, a Florida firm called Fraud Guarantee has attracted no identifiable customers, generated zero returns for investors and—according to Florida court records—defaulted on its office lease years ago after falling behind on rent. And yet the fraud-insurance company and Ukrainian-born founder Lev Parnas scored a major victory in August 2018: a business relationship with Rudy Giuliani, President Trump’s personal attorney. ...

title: Investigative reporters trade secrets, stories at Northeastern’s The Civic Experience
description: / Walter V. Robinson, editor-at-large at The Boston Globe hosts a conversation with Renee Dudley, a technology reporter at ProPublica; David Fahrenthold, a reporter covering the Trump family and its business interests for The Washington Post; Patricia Wen, the editor of The Boston Globe’s Spotlight team; and Joe Palazzolo, a legal affairs reporter for The Wall Street Journal.

title: Giuliani Associates Plead Not Guilty in Campaign-Finance Case
description: Two associates of Rudy Giuliani who aided his efforts to spark investigations in Ukraine that would benefit President Trump politically pleaded not guilty Wednesday to charges tied to an alleged scheme to illegally influence U.S. politicians. The pleas by Igor Fruman and Lev Parnas in federal district court in Manhattan came as U.S. House committees continued their impeachment inquiry into whether Mr. Trump abused his office for personal gain.

title: U.S. Judge Rules Apple Colluded on E-Books
authors: Joe Palazzolo,Ian Sherr,Chad Bray,The Wall Street Journal
description: Apple Inc. colluded with five major U.S. publishers to drive up the prices of e-books, a federal judge ruled Wednesday in a stern rebuke that threatens to limit the technology company's options when negotiating future content deals.

title: Giuliani’s Longtime Business Partner Resigns From Security Firm
authors: Julie Bykowicz,Joe Palazzolo,The Wall Street Journal
description: Rudy Giuliani said the departure of his business partner from their security company had nothing to do with his involvement in the current Ukraine controversy. Photo: shannon stapleton/Reuters By Oct. 11, 2019 5:25 pm ET Rudy Giuliani’s longtime business partner and friend, John Huvane, resigned from their security company in recent weeks, according to several people familiar with the move, which Mr. Giuliani confirmed.

title: Indicted Florida Pair Known for Flashy Style, Claim of Trump Ties
authors: Julie Bykowicz,Joe Palazzolo,Georgi Kantchev,The Wall Street Journal
description: In Ukraine, they were known by business associates for touting their connections to the Trump administration. In the U.S., their flashy style and propensity for name-dropping raised eyebrows. Their business deals at times ended in lawsuits.

title: Court Revives Suit Alleging Foreign Payments to Trump Businesses Violate the Constitution
authors: Jacob Gershman,Joe Palazzolo,The Wall Street Journal
description: A federal appeals court in New York revived a lawsuit that alleges President Trump is unconstitutionally profiting from his presidency. In a 2-1 decision, the Second U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals said on Friday plaintiffs representing hotels and restaurants that compete with Mr. Trump’s businesses have legal standing to bring their claims.

title: Documents Show Efforts by Jeffrey Epstein’s Attorneys to Sway Prosecutors
description: Local prosecutors in Manhattan labeled Jeffrey Epstein a low-level sex offender nearly a decade ago, against the recommendation of a state panel of experts and to the shock of a New York judge.

title: Epstein Scandal Brings Legal Titans to Blows
authors: Joe Palazzolo,Jacob Gershman,The Wall Street Journal
description: The arrest of Jeffrey Epstein is escalating a long-simmering fight between two of the nation’s best-known lawyers, Alan Dershowitz and David Boies. The men were friendly, if not exactly friends, until 2015. That’s when Mr. Dershowitz learned Mr. Boies was representing Virginia Giuffre, a former Florida resident who had alleged Mr. Epstein sexually abused her as a minor and prostituted her to his friends, including Mr. Dershowitz.

title: A Legal Roadmap to the Epstein Prosecution
description: Financier Jeffrey Epstein pleaded not guilty Monday to two counts related to sex-trafficking of minors in an indictment unsealed in federal court in Manhattan. The charges, alleging a yearslong scheme to sexually abuse girls, followed a federal investigation of Mr. Epstein more than a decade ago in Florida that ended in a deal that allowed him to avoid federal convictions.

title: Levin, Grassley Team Up (Again) To Pierce Corporate Veil
description: DOW JONES, A NEWS CORP COMPANY Home World U.S. Politics Economy Business Tech Markets Opinion Life & Arts Real Estate WSJ. Magazine Search

title: Apple Starts E-Book Trial Monday at a Disadvantage
description: Apple Inc. heads to a U.S. federal court Monday to face civil accusations that it conspired with five publishers to drive up the price of electronic books in the weeks leading up to the 2010 introduction of the iPad. The Justice Department will try to prove during the three-week trial in Manhattan that the publishers seized on Apple's entrance into the e-book market as an opportunity to shift from low prices set by Amazon.com Inc. to higher ones set by the publishers themselves. ...

title: Brother of Bezos' lover sold billionaire's texts to US media for $200,000
description: Amazon.com Inc. founder Jeff Bezos and his allies have publicly speculated about how the National Enquirer acquired racy texts he sent to his girlfriend, including at one point hinting Saudi Arabia or the White House may have been involved. The reality is simpler: Michael Sanchez, the brother of Mr. Bezos’ lover, sold the billionaire’s secrets for $200,000 to the Enquirer’s publisher, said people familiar with the matter. The inside story of the deal between American Media LLC and Mr....

authors: Michael Rothfeld,Joe Palazzolo,Alexandra Berzon,The Wall Street Journal
description: Amazon.com Inc. founder Jeff Bezos and his allies have publicly speculated about how the National Enquirer acquired racy texts he sent to his girlfriend, including at one point hinting Saudi Arabia or the White House may have been involved. title: Prosecutors Seek Emails Between Michael Cohen and Lawyer Who Sought Pardon for Him
authors: Joe Palazzolo,Rebecca Ballhaus,The Wall Street Journal
description: Federal prosecutors have requested Michael Cohen’s communications with a New York lawyer who last year sought a pardon on Mr. Cohen’s behalf, the lawyer said. Robert Costello said the Manhattan U.S. attorney’s office last week requested his communications with Mr. Cohen, a former lawyer for President Trump. The prosecutors also provided Mr. Costello with a waiver that Mr. Cohen had signed, allowing Mr. Costello to disclose his conversations with the attorney.

title: How reporters uncovered Trump hush payments
authors: Denise-Marie Ordway,Joe Palazzolo,Michael Rothfeld,Lukas Alpert,Journalist's Resource
description: Editor’s note: On March 12, the Shorenstein Center on Media, Politics and Public Policy will award the 2019 Goldsmith Prize for Investigative Reporting to a stellar investigative report that has had a direct impact on government, politics and policy at the national, state or local levels. Seven reporting teams have been chosen as finalists for the 2019 prize, which carries a $10,000 award for finalists and $25,000 for the winner.

title: Michael Cohen’s lawyer asked about pardon with Trump’s legal team last year
description: An attorney for Michael Cohen, Donald Trump’s former personal lawyer, raised the possibility of a pardon with attorneys for the president after federal agents raided Cohen’s properties in April, according to people familiar with the discussions.

title: Michael Cohen’s lawyer asked about pardon with Trump’s legal team last year
description: An attorney for Michael Cohen, Donald Trump’s former personal lawyer, raised the possibility of a pardon with attorneys for the president after federal agents raided Cohen’s properties in April, according to people familiar with the discussions.

title: Lawyer for Cohen Approached Trump Attorneys About Pardon
authors: Rebecca Ballhaus,Joe Palazzolo,Michael Rothfeld,The Wall Street Journal
description: An attorney for Michael Cohen, Donald Trump’s former personal lawyer, raised the possibility of a pardon with attorneys for the president after federal agents raided Mr. Cohen’s properties in April, according to people familiar with the discussions.

title: New details emerge about Nigerian, Italian pols' visits
description: Welcome to 1100 Pennsylvania, a newsletter devoted to President Donald Trump’s Trump International Hotel Washington, D.C. (and his other companies). President Trump, of course, still owns his businesses and can profit from them. If you like what you see, tell someone—and support this work by paying for a subscription. If you’ve been forwarded this newsletter, subscribe for yourself at zacheverson.substack.com. Questions? Read our FAQ/manifesto. Tips or feedback?

title: Cohen Threatened CNBC That Trump Would Sue After 2014 Poll Disappointment
authors: Joe Palazzolo,Michael Rothfeld,The Wall Street Journal
description: Donald Trump and his then-attorney Michael Cohen pressured CNBC in 2014 to place the real-estate tycoon higher in its list of the country’s top business leaders after Mr. Cohen failed to manipulate the rankings in Mr. Trump’s favor, according to people familiar with the matter. Mr. Cohen called CNBC and threatened that Mr. Trump would sue over his poor standing in the ranking, arguing that the news channel was “ignoring the will of the people,” the people familiar with the matter said.

title: Ex-Trump lawyer Michael Cohen hired an IT firm to rig early CNBC, Drudge polls
description: In early 2015, a man who runs a small technology company showed up at Trump Tower to collect $50,000 for having helped Michael Cohen, then Donald Trump’s personal lawyer, try to rig online polls in his boss’s favor before the presidential campaign.

title: Cohen Hired IT Firm to Rig Early CNBC, Drudge Polls to Favor Trump
authors: Michael Rothfeld,Rob Barry,Joe Palazzolo,The Wall Street Journal
description: In early 2015, a man who runs a small technology company showed up at Trump Tower to collect $50,000 for having helped Michael Cohen , then Donald Trump’s personal lawyer, try to rig online polls in his boss’s favor before the presidential campaign.

title: Prayers at School Board Meetings Test Church-State Divide
description: The U.S. Supreme Court has upheld the constitutionality of prayers during state legislature sessions and town council meetings. Now the justices may be asked to clarify the separation of church and state in a new forum: school board meetings. The high court has long held that prayer in public schools violates the First Amendment, which bars the government from establishing an official religion.

title: Trump understands intricacies of campaign finance laws, old testimony reveals
description: Sworn statements by President Donald Trump dating back several decades indicate he has a deep understanding of campaign-finance laws, legal experts say, which could be critical if investigators ever pursue a case against him over his alleged direction of hush-money payments in the 2016 campaign. Trump’s statements were made as part of a 2000 regulatory investigation into his casino company and in 1988 testimony for a government-integrity commission.

title: Trump Testimony From Decades Ago Indicates Knowledge of Campaign-Finance Laws
authors: Rebecca Ballhaus,Joe Palazzolo,The Wall Street Journal
description: Sworn statements by President Trump dating back several decades indicate he has a deep understanding of campaign-finance laws, legal experts say, which could be critical if investigators ever pursue a case against him over his alleged direction of hush-money payments in the 2016 campaign. Mr. Trump’s statements were made as part of a 2000 regulatory investigation into his casino company and in 1988 testimony for a government-integrity commission.

title: Cohen Describes Trump’s Involvement in Hush-Money Payments
description: Michael Cohen, President Trump’s former personal attorney, gave his fullest public description of Mr. Trump’s involvement in two hush money deals during the 2016 campaign that the Justice Department has said were federal crimes.

title: U.K. Group Sues Law Firm After Failing to Win Back Russian Coal Mine
description: A U.K. investment group has sued Baker McKenzie LLP, one of the largest law firms in the world, for allegedly botching the group’s effort to recover a Siberian coal mine it says is worth more than $170 million. London-based Lehram Capital Investments Ltd., which specializes in distressed assets, filed the lawsuit in November in a state court in Cook County, Ill., where the law firm was founded.

title: Donald Trump Played Central Role in Hush Payoffs to Stormy Daniels and Karen McDougal
authors: Joe Palazzolo,Nicole Hong,Michael Rothfeld,Rebecca Davis O’Brien,The Wall Street Journal
description: By Joe Palazzolo, Nicole Hong, Michael Rothfeld, Rebecca Davis O’Brien and Rebecca BallhausNov. 9, 2018 1:03 pm ETAs a presidential candidate in August 2015, Donald Trump huddled with a longtime friend, media executive David Pecker, in his cluttered 26th floor Trump Tower office and made a request. What can you do to help my campaign? he asked, according to people familiar with the meeting.

title: Judge Dismisses Stormy Daniels’ Defamation Suit Against Trump
authors: Joe Palazzolo,Sara Randazzo,The Wall Street Journal
description: LOS ANGELES—A federal judge in California dismissed a lawsuit brought by Stormy Daniels against President Donald Trump that accused him of defaming her in a tweet. U.S. District Judge S. James Otero in Los Angeles ruled on Monday that the former adult-film star, whose real name is Stephanie Clifford, must pay Mr. Trump’s legal fees in the case.

title: Supreme Court Extends Block of Birth-Control Mandate in Little Sisters Case
description: The Supreme Court on Friday suspended enforcement of the federal health-care law's contraception requirements for Little Sisters of the Poor, an order of Catholic nuns that operates homes for the elderly poor. The order extends an earlier block of the mandate -- which requires employers to provide workers with birth-control coverage at no cost -- while the Little Sisters press their appeal.

title: Trump directed legal action to enforce Stormy Daniels’s hush agreement
description: President Trump personally directed an effort in February to stop Stormy Daniels from publicly describing an alleged sexual encounter with Trump, people familiar with the events say. In a phone call, Trump instructed his then-lawyer Michael Cohen to seek a restraining order against the former adult-film actress, whose real name is Stephanie Clifford, through a confidential arbitration proceeding, one of the people said.

In a phone call, Trump instructed his then-lawyer Michael Cohen to seek a restraining order against the former adult-film actress, whose real name is Stephanie Clifford, through a confidential arbitration proceeding, one of the people said.

In a phone call, Trump instructed his then-lawyer Michael Cohen to seek a restraining order against the former adult-film actress, whose real name is Stephanie Clifford, through a confidential arbitration proceeding, one of the people said.

title: Michael Cohen has reportedly talked about Trump to Mueller investigators
description: Michael Cohen, President Donald Trump’s former lawyer, has met multiple times with special counsel Robert Mueller’s investigators, including within the past month, according to people familiar with the matter. As part of the meetings, investigators asked Cohen questions about Trump, including about the president’s business dealings with Russia, one of the people said.

title: Mueller Team Has Interviewed Michael Cohen Multiple Times
authors: Rebecca Ballhaus,Joe Palazzolo,The Wall Street Journal
description: Michael Cohen Has Met Multiple Times with Special Counsel Robert Mueller’s Investigators in Recent Weeks, Sources SayInvestigators Asked Cohen Questions about President Trump and Mr. Trump’s Business Dealings with RussiaCohen Pleaded Guilty in Manhattan Federal Court Last Month, Faces Sentencing Later This Year

title: Korte.pdf | Standing (Law) | Government
description: requires employe rs to provide coverage for contraception and sterilization procedures in their employee health-care plans on penalties and the risk of enforcement actions. The plaintiffs are two Catholic families and their closely the other a manufacturing firm in Indiana. T he businesse secular and for profit, but they operate in conformity with the faith commitments of the families that own and manage them. The plaintiffs object for religious reasons to providing the mandated coverage.

title: Michael Cohen seeks to rescind nondisclosure agreement with Stormy Daniels
description: Michael Cohen told a federal judge in Los Angeles on Friday that he has agreed to rescind the nondisclosure agreement that legally requires former adult-film star Stephanie Clifford to keep silent about an alleged sexual encounter with President Trump. The filling came in a lawsuit that Clifford, known professionally as Stormy Daniels, filed in March against the shell company Cohen, Trump’s former lawyer, had used to pay her $130,000 for signing the agreement in October 2016.

title: Michael Cohen Seeks to Rescind Nondisclosure Agreement With Stormy Daniels
description: Michael Cohen told a federal judge in Los Angeles on Friday that he has agreed to rescind the nondisclosure agreement that legally requires former adult-film star Stephanie Clifford to keep silent about an alleged sexual encounter with President Trump. The filling came in a lawsuit that Ms. Clifford, known professionally as Stormy Daniels, filed in March against the shell company Mr. Cohen, Mr. Trump’s former lawyer, had used to pay her $130,000 for signing the agreement in October 2016.

title: Why Michael Cohen Agreed to Plead Guilty—And Implicate the President
authors: Rebecca Davis O’Brien,Nicole Hong,Joe Palazzolo,The Wall Street Journal
description: Michael Cohen had many reasons to play ball last weekend when his legal team sat down to talk to federal prosecutors. The Manhattan U.S. Attorney’s office had testimony from Mr. Cohen’s accountant and business partners, along with bank records, tax filings and loan applications that implicated not only Mr. Cohen in potential criminal activity, but also his wife, who filed taxes jointly with her husband.

title: Michael Cohen Pleads Guilty, Says Trump Told Him to Pay Off Women
authors: Nicole Hong,Rebecca Ballhaus,Rebecca Davis O’Brien,Joe Palazzolo,The Wall Street Journal
description: NEW YORK— Michael Cohen , the president’s former personal lawyer, told a federal judge that Donald Trump had directed him during the 2016 campaign to buy the silence of two women who said they had affairs with Mr. Trump. Mr. Cohen made the statement as he pleaded guilty Tuesday to eight criminal charges, including campaign-finance violations.

title: Michael Cohen changed his mind on Stormy Daniels payment after ‘Access Hollywood’ tape surfaced
description: Michael Cohen initially balked at the idea of buying the silence of a former adult-film star who says she had sex with Donald Trump, but he did an about-face after a video of Trump talking about groping women became public in October 2016.

title: Michael Cohen changed his mind on Stormy Daniels payment after ‘Access Hollywood’ tape surfaced
authors: Joe Palazzolo,Nicole Hong,Rebecca Davis O’Brien,Rebecca Ballhaus,MarketWatch
description: Michael Cohen initially balked at the idea of buying the silence of a former adult-film star who says she had sex with Donald Trump, but he did an about-face after a video of Trump talking about groping women became public in October 2016. A day after the recording surfaced of outtakes of Trump speaking to a host of NBC’s “Access Hollywood,” Cohen, then Trump’s senior counsel, told a representative for the performer that he was open to a deal, according to a person familiar with the conversation.

title: Michael Cohen changed his mind on Stormy Daniels payment after ‘Access Hollywood’ tape surfaced
authors: Joe Palazzolo,Nicole Hong,Rebecca Davis O’Brien,Rebecca Ballhaus,MarketWatch
description: Michael Cohen initially balked at the idea of buying the silence of a former adult-film star who says she had sex with Donald Trump, but he did an about-face after a video of Trump talking about groping women became public in October 2016. title: As ‘Access Hollywood’ Tape Surfaced, Michael Cohen Changed Tune on Paying Stormy Daniels
description: Trying to understand the events involving President Trump, Michael Cohen and Stormy Daniels​ and the potential impact on the presidency? WSJ’s Michael Rothfeld and Joe Palazzolo are here to focus on what's important: the money trail. Photo: Getty ImagesMichael Cohen initially balked at the idea of buying the silence of a former adult-film star who says she had sex with Donald Trump, but he did an about-face after a video of Mr. Trump talking about groping women became public in October 2016.

title: Details revealed in ex-Playboy model’s lawsuit against Republican fundraiser
description: A California court unsealed a lawsuit filed by a former Playboy centerfold claiming that a GOP fundraiser reneged on a 2017 agreement to pay her $1.6 million to keep quiet about an affair and pregnancy. The unsealing of the complaint Tuesday in Los Angeles County Superior Court sheds more light on the $1.6 million deal between Shera Bechard and Elliott Broidy, who has acknowledged their affair and subsequent agreement.

title: Details revealed in ex-Playboy model’s lawsuit against Republican fundraiser
description: A California court unsealed a lawsuit filed by a former Playboy centerfold claiming that a GOP fundraiser reneged on a 2017 agreement to pay her $1.6 million to keep quiet about an affair and pregnancy. The unsealing of the complaint Tuesday in Los Angeles County Superior Court sheds more light on the $1.6 million deal between Shera Bechard and Elliott Broidy, who has acknowledged their affair and subsequent agreement.

title: Deal Between GOP Fundraiser and Ex-Playboy Model Detailed in Unsealed Suit
description: A California court unsealed a lawsuit filed by a former Playboy centerfold claiming that a GOP fundraiser reneged on a 2017 agreement to pay her $1.6 million to keep quiet about an affair and pregnancy. The unsealing of the complaint Tuesday in Los Angeles County Superior Court sheds more light on the $1.6 million deal between Shera Bechard and Elliott Broidy, who has acknowledged their affair and subsequent agreement.

title: National Enquirer’s Yearslong Dealings With Trump Lawyer Fall Under Federal Scrutiny
authors: Michael Rothfeld,Joe Palazzolo,Lukas Alpert,Rebecca Davis O’Brien,The Wall Street Journal
description: Michael Cohen and the publisher of the National Enquirer forged an alliance over the years, looking out for the interests of Donald Trump and each other. Now, federal investigators are examining those ties as part of a wide-ranging probe into Mr. Cohen’s personal business dealings and his self-described role as Mr. Trump’s fixer.

title: Trump’s Former Lawyer Michael Cohen Recorded Conversation About Stormy Daniels Payment With News Anchor
authors: Rebecca Ballhaus,Michael Rothfeld,Joe Palazzolo,The Wall Street Journal
description: Michael Cohen recorded a conversation he had with a reporter this year in which he said he arranged “on my own” a $130,000 payment in 2016 to a former adult-film star who alleged an affair with Donald Trump, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Michael Cohen and Trump discussed buying rights to Playmate’s story in taped conversation
description: MIchael Cohen taped a conversation in person with Donald Trump in which the two men discussed buying the rights to a former Playboy Playmate’s story that she had an affair with Trump more than a decade ago, according to people familiar with the matter. The conversation, between the then-GOP presidential nominee and his longtime personal lawyer, took place in September 2016, the people said.

title: Michael Cohen and Trump discussed buying rights to Playmate’s story in taped conversation
description: MIchael Cohen taped a conversation in person with Donald Trump in which the two men discussed buying the rights to a former Playboy Playmate’s story that she had an affair with Trump more than a decade ago, according to people familiar with the matter. The conversation, between the then-GOP presidential nominee and his longtime personal lawyer, took place in September 2016, the people said.

The conversation, between the then-GOP presidential nominee and his longtime personal lawyer, took place in September 2016, the people said.

title: Novartis Played Down Ties to Trump Lawyer Michael Cohen, Report Says
description: Novartis AG made misleading statements playing down its 2017 relationship with President Donald Trump’s then-personal lawyer, according to a report released Friday by Democratic senators that shed new light on the company’s consulting contract with the lawyer, Michael Cohen. The report also reveals Mr. Cohen’s advocacy for another pharmaceutical company, one the report says has ties to an investment firm associated with Viktor Vekselberg, a wealthy Russian businessman now under U.S. sanctions....

title: Ex-Playmate sues GOP donor Elliott Broidy over $1.6 million hush-money deal
description: A former Playboy centerfold model has sued a prominent Republican fundraiser, her former lawyer and the lawyer for former adult-film star Stephanie Clifford in connection with the breakdown of a $1.6 million hush-money agreement, according to court documents filed Friday.

title: Top GOP Fundraiser to Stop Hush Payments Over Affair
authors: Michael Rothfeld,Joe Palazzolo,The Wall Street Journal
description: A top Republican fundraiser will stop making payments to a former mistress who signed a hush-money agreement that was negotiated last year by Michael Cohen, President Donald Trump’s longtime lawyer.

title: Top GOP fundraiser Elliott Broidy to end hush payments over affair
description: A top Republican fundraiser will stop making payments to a former mistress who signed a hush-money agreement that was negotiated last year by Michael Cohen, President Donald Trump’s longtime lawyer.

title: Abortion Foes to Take New Aim at Roe v. Wade
authors: Joe Palazzolo,Nicole Hong,The Wall Street Journal
description: The retirement of Justice Anthony Kennedy has created what abortion opponents view as a once-in-a-generation opportunity to establish a 5-4 majority on the Supreme Court that favors their side. Justice Kennedy, nominated to the bench by President Ronald Reagan in 1987, more often aligned with the conservative wing of the court in his rulings, but supporters of abortion rights considered him a firewall when it came to Roe v.

title: Ex-Playmate Alleging Trump Affair to Get Men’s Journal Cover
authors: Joe Palazzolo,Nicole Hong,Lukas Alpert,Michael Rothfeld,The Wall Street Journal
description: The publisher accused of buying and then suppressing a Playboy model’s claim she had an affair with Donald Trump ordered one of its magazines to feature the woman on its cover without her cooperation, people familiar with the matter said. Current and former employees of publisher American Media Inc. said they believe Karen McDougal’s planned appearance on the cover of September’s issue of Men’s Journal is intended to protect the company from a federal criminal investigation in New York.

title: Report: Prosecutors Subpoena National Enquirer Records in Michael Cohen Investigation
authors: Nicole Hong,Joe Palazzolo,Michael Rothfeld,Rebecca Davis O’Brien,Black Christian News Network
description: Federal authorities have subpoenaed the publisher of the National Enquirer for records related to its $150,000 payment to a former Playboy model for the rights to her story alleging an affair with Donald Trump, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Publisher of National Enquirer Subpoenaed in Michael Cohen Probe
authors: Nicole Hong,Joe Palazzolo,Michael Rothfeld,Rebecca Davis O’Brien,The Wall Street Journal
description: Federal authorities have subpoenaed the publisher of the National Enquirer for records related to its $150,000 payment to a former Playboy model for the rights to her story alleging an affair with Donald Trump, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Publisher of National Enquirer subpoenaed in Michael Cohen probe, report says
authors: Nicole Hong,Joe Palazzolo,Michael Rothfeld,Rebecca Davis O’Brien,Fox News
description: Federal authorities have subpoenaed the publisher of the National Enquirer for records related to its $150,000 payment to a former Playboy model for the rights to her story alleging an affair with Donald Trump, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: National Enquirer publisher subpoenaed as part of Michael Cohen probe
authors: Nicole Hong,Joe Palazzolo,Michael Rothfeld,Rebecca Davis O’Brien,MarketWatch
description: Federal authorities have subpoenaed the publisher of the National Enquirer for records related to its $150,000 payment to a former Playboy model for the rights to her story alleging an affair with Donald Trump, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Michael Cohen Called in Loan While Seeking Funds to Pay Stormy Daniels
authors: Mark Maremont,Joe Palazzolo,Rebecca Davis O’Brien,The Wall Street Journal
description: Michael Cohen took aggressive steps to collect on a multimillion-dollar debt in October 2016, at the time he was seeking to come up with $130,000 to pay a former adult-film star for agreeing to keep quiet about an alleged sexual encounter with Donald Trump. The debt stemmed from a loan to a French investor who a year earlier had bought Mr. Cohen out of a Manhattan condominium transaction, producing a large profit for Mr. Cohen, according to three people familiar with the transaction.

title: ‘What’s He Doing Here?’: Inside Trump’s Turbulent Relationship With Michael Cohen
authors: Rebecca Ballhaus,Michael Rothfeld,Joe Palazzolo,Alexandra Berzon,The Wall Street Journal
description: Donald Trump summoned senior aides to his 26th floor office at Trump Tower around 2009 for an unpleasant task: persuade Michael Cohen—a top lawyer at his company—to resign, according to one of the aides. Mr. Trump’s frustration had reached a breaking point, the aide said. Mr. Cohen wasn’t getting things done and Mr. Trump didn’t believe he was a good fit at the Trump Organization, even though he liked him and didn’t want to fire him. “What’s he doing here?” Mr. Trump demanded.

title: Decoding Judge Leon's AT&T-Time Warner Decision
authors: Joe Palazzolo,Ashby Jones,Rebecca Davis O’Brien,The Wall Street Journal
description: Judge Richard J. Leon, in his 172-page opinion Tuesday, allowed AT&T Inc.’s T -1.65% proposed merger with Time Warner Inc., to go through, over objections by the U.S. Justice Department that the deal, if consummated, would have anticompetitive effects and violate the antitrust laws.

title: Stormy Daniels’ Ex-Lawyer Denies Collusion, Files His Own Lawsuits
authors: Michael Rothfeld,Joe Palazzolo,The Wall Street Journal
description: Keith Davidson, the ex-lawyer for former adult-film actress Stephanie Clifford, denied Thursday that he had colluded with a lawyer for President Donald Trump over a hush-money deal, arguing that he tried to fulfill her goal of making money off an alleged sexual encounter with Mr. Trump. Ms. Clifford sued Mr. Davidson in Los Angeles County court on Wednesday, accusing him of being a “puppet” for Mr. Trump and the president’s personal lawyer, Michael Cohen....

title: Stormy Daniels Sues Ex-Lawyer, Saying He Colluded with Michael Cohen
description: Former adult-movie star Stephanie Clifford sued her former lawyer on Wednesday, alleging he served the interests of President Donald Trump’s personal lawyer, Michael Cohen, instead of his client’s when her $130,000 hush-money agreement became public earlier this year.

title: Stormy Daniels’s Lawyer Michael Avenatti Complicates Michael Cohen Probe
description: A lawyer for former adult-film star Stephanie Clifford has frustrated efforts by federal prosecutors to obtain information about a hush-money deal involving President Donald Trump’s personal lawyer, according to people familiar with the matter. In public, Michael Avenatti, Ms. Clifford’s current attorney, has been among the most vocal critics of Michael Cohen, the lawyer who paid her $130,000 in October 2016 to sign a nondisclosure agreement about an alleged 2006 sexual encounter with Mr. Trump.

title: Holder Discusses Trayvon Martin Investigation
description: Attorney General Eric Holder this morning addressed the Justice Department’s investigation of the shooting of 17-year-old Trayvon Martin by neighborhood watch volunteer George Zimmerman. Holder spoke at the annual convention of the National Action Network, a civil rights group founded by the Rev. Al Sharpton, who has called for Zimmerman’s arrest.

title: Michael Cohen’s D.C. Consulting Career: Scattershot, With Mixed Success
authors: Rebecca Ballhaus,Peter Nicholas,Michael Rothfeld,Joe Palazzolo,The Wall Street Journal
description: When Michael Cohen came knocking after the 2016 election, touting himself as the president’s lawyer, a man who could decipher the new administration, Ford Motor Co. said no. So did Uber Technologies Inc. He managed to notch AT&T Inc. and Novartis AG. And Squire Patton Boggs, a law and lobbying firm, hired him for a sizable fee—though he felt it wasn’t enough.

title: How a Firm That Paid Stormy Daniels Hush Money Became Enmeshed in Federal Probes
authors: Joe Palazzolo,Michael Rothfeld,Nicole Hong,The Wall Street Journal
description: From its origins as a conduit to pay hush money, Essential Consultants LLC has evolved into a nexus in federal investigations buffeting the Trump administration. Michael Cohen, President Donald Trump’s personal attorney, set up the Delaware limited liability company to pay former adult-movie actressStephanie Clifford, professionally known as Stormy Daniels.

title: Trump Lawyer Helped Recruit Corporate Client With Ties to Kushner Probe
authors: Erica Orden,Joe Palazzolo,Julie Bykowicz,The Wall Street Journal
description: President Donald Trump’s personal attorney Michael Cohen helped a law and lobbying firm land a corporate client with ties to Kushner Cos., the family company of White House adviser Jared Kushner that is currently the subject of a federal probe.

title: Trump lawyer Cohen helped recruit corporate client with ties to Kushner probe
description: President Donald Trump’s personal attorney Michael Cohen helped a law and lobbying firm land a corporate client with ties to Kushner Cos., the family company of White House adviser Jared Kushner that is currently the subject of a federal probe.

title: Trump’s Payment to Stormy Daniels Raises Campaign-Finance Questions
authors: Julie Bykowicz,Joe Palazzolo,The Wall Street Journal
description: New comments by President Donald Trump and about a payment to a former porn actress who says she had an affair with Mr. Trump place the president at the center of questions about possible campaign-finance violations, two former Federal Election Commission leaders said.

title: ‘Boss, I miss you so much’: The awkward exile of Michael Cohen
description: In the 15 months since Donald Trump shut him out of a White House job, Michael Cohen, the president’s personal lawyer, has made a show of publicly dining with a vocal Trump critic, the billionaire Dallas Mavericks owner Mark Cuban. After lunch at Freds restaurant in New York in April 2017, a gossip item appeared. When they had breakfast at the Time Warner Center in November, paparazzi “somehow” showed up, Cuban said.

When they had breakfast at the Time Warner Center in November, paparazzi “somehow” showed up, Mr. Cuban said.

title: Former Playboy Playmate Karen McDougal and Publisher Settle Lawsuit
authors: Joe Palazzolo,Michael Rothfeld,The Wall Street Journal
description: A former Playboy playmate who sold her story of an extramarital affair with President Donald Trump to the publisher of the National Enquirer settled a lawsuit against the company that releases her from a contract she said was meant to muzzle her during Mr. Trump’s presidential campaign. Karen McDougal reached an agreement with American Media Inc. that “restores to me the rights to my life story and frees me from this contract,” she said in a statement provided by her lawyer, Peter Stris....

title: Cohen Would Turn Against President if Charged, Counselor Warned Trump
authors: Joe Palazzolo,Michael Rothfeld,The Wall Street Journal
description: One of President Donald Trump’s longtime legal advisers said he warned the president in a phone call Friday that Michael Cohen, Mr. Trump’s personal lawyer and close friend, would turn against the president and cooperate with federal prosecutors if faced with criminal charges. Mr. Trump made the call seeking advice from Jay Goldberg, who represented Mr. Trump in the 1990s and early 2000s. Mr. Goldberg said he cautioned the president not to trust Mr. Cohen.

title: Cohen could turn if charged, adviser warned Trump
description: One of President Donald Trump’s longtime legal advisers said he warned the president in a phone call Friday that Michael Cohen, Trump’s personal lawyer and close friend, would turn against the president and cooperate with federal prosecutors if faced with criminal charges. Trump made the call seeking advice from Jay Goldberg, who represented Trump in the 1990s and early 2000s. Goldberg said he cautioned the president not to trust Cohen.

title: Alleged Trump mistress settles with National Enquirer’s publisher
description: A former Playboy playmate who sold her story of an extramarital affair with President Donald Trump to the publisher of the National Enquirer settled a lawsuit against the company that releases her from a contract she said was meant to muzzle her during Trump’s presidential campaign.
