The 2-1 ruling Tuesday by the Second U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Manhattan follows three years of litigation, millions of dollars in legal fees and a bold decision by Apple to challenge the U.S. Department of Justice to a trial, even after all the publishers with which it was accused of colluding...

title: Judges Turn to Risk-Evaluation Tools in Sentencing Decisions
description: Matthew Motley is between the ages of 21 and 29. That is six points against him. He is male. Two points. He has been incarcerated previously but not convicted of a felony. One point. He has been arrested or confined in the past 12 months. Three points. Total risk score: 12 points. Had Mr. Motley scored 15 or higher on an evaluation measure aimed at predicting the likelihood of future criminal behavior, a state judge in...

title: Chief Justice Roberts Drops the L Word
description: If you read Chief Justice John Roberts’s dissent from the Supreme Court’s gay-marriage ruling on Friday, you probably noticed how often he dropped the L Word. No, not love. That word only appears twice in his dissent. We mean Lochner, which appears no less than 16 times in his 29-page opinion. That’s at least one mention every two pages. Lochner refers to both a 1905 Supreme Court decision (Lochner v.

title: Gay Marriage Ruling: What’s Next?
description: The Supreme Court on Friday ruled same-sex partners have a constitutional right to marry. That means, of course, that laws banning gay marriage will melt away. But how quickly? Does the ruling foreshadow other expansions of gay rights? Here is what you need to know about the decision. How many states are affected by the ruling? Before today’s ruling, same-sex marriage was legal in 36 states and the District of Columbia.

title: Majority Ruling on Gay Marriage: Key Excerpts
description: The U.S. Supreme Court has declared that gay Americans have a constitutional right to marry, in a historic ruling penned by Justice Anthony Kennedy, who has several other momentous decisions concerning gay rights to his credit. He was joined by the court’s four liberal justices: Ruth Bader Ginsburg, Stephen Breyer, Sonia Sotomayor and Elena Kagan. Here are some key excerpts, with citations omitted. On Baker v.

title: The Long and Short of the Health Law Ruling
description: It cost Chief Justice John Roberts about 5,700 words (21 pages) to uphold the Affordable Care Act’s health-insurance subsidies on Thursday. He spent three times as many in 2012, when he authored the majority ruling in National Federation of Independent Business v. Sebelius, upholding the law’s individual mandate. The brevity and clarity of Thursday’s ruling is notable.

title: What Legal Challenges Lie Ahead for Obamacare?
description: The Supreme Court on Thursday declared in a 6-3 ruling that health-insurance subsidies are available to Americans in two thirds of the states, marking the conclusion of the justices’ third review of the Affordable Care Act. Could there be a fourth? Or a fifth? “My guess is that this, as a practical matter, is the end,” said Michael Dorf, a constitutional law professor at Cornell University and author of the blog Dorf on Law.

title: Majority Ruling on Health Law Subsidies: Key Excerpts
description: The U.S. Supreme Court on Thursday preserved the ability of low-income Americans in more than two thirds of the states to receive subsidized health insurance. The law’s challengers said the plain language of the Affordable Care Act provides for subsidies in states that created their own exchanges but not in the approximately three dozen states that use the federal government’s marketplace, HealthCare.gov. The text of the Affordable Care Act, the court concluded, is ambiguous on this point.

title: The $370 million, 180,000-carat prize at the center of legal fight
description: The largest uncut emerald ever discovered sits somewhere in Los Angeles County after having been extracted from a Brazilian mine 14 years ago. Now, as a legal dispute over its ownership churns in California court, Brazil wants it back, and it has a powerful ally: the U.S. Justice Department.

title: Prediction Panel: Chief Justice Roberts Will Surprise (Again)
description: As we wait for the Supreme Court to render its decision in the latest challenge to the Affordable Care Act, we asked a panel of experts for their predictions. Our brave participants include Jonathan Adler, a professor at Case Western Reserve University School of Law; Erwin Chemerinsky, dean of University of California, Irvine School of Law; and Richard Pierce, a professor at The George Washington University Law School.

title: Supreme Court’s Ruling on the Affordable Care Act: What to Expect
description: Any day now, the U.S. Supreme Court will issue its third ruling on the Affordable Care Act. The previous two were easy reduce to a sentence: Can the government make people buy health insurance? (Yes, sort of.) Can the government make companies pay for employee insurance coverage of contraceptives, even if their religion forbids the use of contraceptives? (No.)The latest case defies simple reduction.

title: Uber Bans Guns in Its Cars
authors: Doug MacMillan,Joe Palazzolo,The Wall Street Journal
description: Uber Technologies Inc. has become the latest high-profile company to thrust itself into the gun debate with a decision this month prohibiting drivers and passengers from carrying firearms in its fleet. The ride-sharing company added a new policy to its website prohibiting anyone using the service from having “firearms of any kind,” a ban that resonated nationally amid renewed calls for gun restrictions in the wake of last week’s...

title: Justice Department Sets Its Sights on Rare Expungement Order
description: The Justice Department spearheads the federal government’s efforts to help people convicted of crimes return to society after paying their dues, but a case in Brooklyn is putting its views to the test. The U.S. Attorney’s Office for the Eastern District of New York signaled Friday that it will appeal a rare order by a federal judge expunging the fraud conviction of a health-care aide and mother of four who said her efforts to hold down a job have been sabotaged by her criminal record.

title: Remember that Religious Freedom Law?
description: The Religious Freedom Restoration Act emerged from relative obscurity two months ago, when Indiana lawmakers passed a state version of the federal law that critics said would have given private parties the option of wielding their religious beliefs as a defense against claims of discrimination. The furor died down, after Indiana Gov. Mike Pence declined to sign the bill. But the federal law continues to prove itself adept at flattening government obstacles to religious practice.

title: In Federal Appeals Courts, Chivalry Is Not Dead
description: Illustration: Euro RSCG Chivalry is not dead in the U.S. courts of appeal, according to a new study. Typically, gender studies of judicial decision-making focus on how women judges are different from their male counterparts. But a group of researchers from the University of Nevada, Las Vegas, flipped the script: What male qualities, they asked, affect how guy judges decide cases? Professors Rebecca D.

title: Reason Magazine Subpoenaed Over Reader Comments about Silk Road Judge
description: Federal prosecutors have demanded that libertarian news site Reason.com help them identify readers who discussed killing a federal judge, including via wood chipper, in the comments section of an article about Silk Road Founder Ross Ulbricht.

title: Kansas Passes Law Linking Court Funding to Judicial Rulings
description: Kanas Gov. Sam Brownback has signed legislation that would eliminate funding for the state’s courts if they overturn a contentious law passed last year, a move experts described as an unprecedented display of legislative power. The 2014 law, pushed by Republicans, stripped the Kansas Supreme Court of the power to appoint chief judges for the lower courts. A Kansas judge has sued to block it.

title: Federal Judge Expunges 14-Year-Old Fraud Conviction in Rare Ruling
description: A federal judge in Brooklyn has expunged the 14-year-old fraud conviction of a woman who said her criminal record prevented her from holding on to jobs, in what legal experts described as an unprecedented ruling. The May 21 ruling by U.S. District Judge John Gleeson granted the wish of a mother of four and health-care aide by training whose conviction has resulted in her losing a half dozen jobs since 2001. Judge Gleeson, in expunging...

title: Court Rejects Apple’s Bid to Shake Off Corporate Monitor
description: A federal appeals court has rejected Apple Inc.’s efforts to rid itself of a corporate monitor appointed in the wake of a judge’s finding the company liable for conspiring to raise the price of e-books. Michael Bromwich, a former Justice Department inspector general, was appointed to assess Apple’s antitrust compliance policies in October 2013. He was appointed by U.S. District Judge Denise Cote, who held the company liable for a...

title: How Much Do Jails Cost? Probably More Than We Thought
description: Forty years of unrelenting growth in the U.S. prison population, now at about 1.5 million people, has led to annual estimated costs of more than $40 billion. But the growth in the jail population (731,200 in 2013), while less discussed, is no less impressive. The Justice Department’s Bureau Justice Statistics pegged local government expenditures on jails at about $22 billion in 2011, the most recent year available.

title: Kansas Lawmakers’ Budget Links Court Funding to Court Decisions
description: Kansas legislators are threatening to eliminate funding for state courts if a judge strikes down a controversial law passed last year. Republican senators and representatives agreed Monday on a two-year judicial budget that would self-destruct if any court blocks or overturns a 2014 law that stripped the Kansas Supreme Court of some administrative authority, giving local courts control over their own budgets and leadership. A...

title: Copyright Restrictions Spark Disagreement Over ABA Database
description: The number of civil restrictions triggered by criminal convictions, the majority of which exclude ex-offenders from certain jobs, is so vast that it took the nation’s largest organization of lawyers more than four years and $1.6 million to find them and put them in a database. “If we had known going in what this entailed, we would never have done it,” said Stephen Saltzburg, a law professor at George Washington University who oversaw the project on behalf of the American Bar Association.

title: 5 Things to Know About Collateral Consequences
description: Over the past 40 years, as the U.S. prison population grew from fewer than 400,000 inmates to about 1.5 million, states and the federal government enacted thousands of civil sanctions that are triggered by a criminal conviction. They prohibit people with criminal convictions, who now number in the tens of millions, from obtaining a range of professional licenses and jobs in some industries.

title: For Americans Who Served Time, Landing a Job Proves Tricky
description: Hashim Lowndes’s felony conviction for trafficking cocaine earned him three years in an Ohio prison. But there were other consequences for him: more than 500 of them, scattered throughout Ohio’s laws. As a convicted drug felon, he wouldn’t be able to vote, teach preschool, foster a child, operate a racetrack, cut hair, sit on a jury, provide hospice care, protect game, distribute bingo supplies, deal livestock, broker real...

title: New York Weighs Jurisdictional Rule for Foreign Firms
description: New York lawmakers are weighing a bill to make foreign companies submit to the jurisdiction of New York courts as a condition of doing business in the state, a position some lawyers say is at odds with a recent U.S. Supreme Court ruling. The high court decided unanimously last year to put restrictions on lawsuits filed against foreign companies in the U.S. that concern actions that took place abroad. Defense lawyers hailed the...

title: What to Do If Your Expunged Record Won’t Disappear
description: If you discover that an employer or landlord has rejected your application based on criminal records that you had expunged, you have rights under a federal law called the Fair Credit Reporting Act. When declining housing or employment, the landlord or employer has to tell you whether the decision was based, in whole or in part, on a criminal background check, said Matthew A. Dooley, an Ohio lawyer who specializes in claims against...

title: 5 Things to Know About Background Checks and Expunged Records
description: The FTC has brought eight cases against background-screening services since 2009 for allegedly violating the Fair Credit Reporting Act. Private plaintiffs have also filed a handful of lawsuits against background screeners in that time, saying they reported inaccurate information about applicants or otherwise violated the FCRA. The companies have settled these cases without admitting wrongdoing.

title: Fight Grows to Stop Expunged Criminal Records Living On in Background Checks
authors: Joe Palazzolo,Gary Fields,Joe Palazzolo And,The Wall Street Journal
description: Helen Stokes could no longer afford her three-bedroom house in Philadelphia on a fixed income, but her search for a subsidized apartment was haunted by an arrest record that legally didn’t exist. Ms. Stokes, 63 years old, was arrested twice in 2008 and 2010 during rows with her now-estranged husband. Neither resulted in a criminal conviction, and last year she successfully petitioned under Pennsylvania law to have the records...

title: Baltimore Police Case Homes In on Knife Found in Arrest
authors: Joe Palazzolo,Scott And,The Wall Street Journal
description: BALTIMORE—The legality of the knife that police say they found on Freddie Gray, leading to his arrest last month, has emerged as the first battleground in the criminal case against six city police officers in the 25-year-old’s death. The lawyer for one of three officers accused of illegally arresting Mr. Gray filed court papers Monday seeking to inspect the knife. Marc Zayon, who represents Officer Edward Nero, wrote in a motion that...

title: Illegal-Arrest Charge Ripples Beyond Baltimore
authors: Scott Calvert,Joe Palazzolo,Scott And,The Wall Street Journal
description: BALTIMORE—Among the many charges leveled against six city police officers in last month’s death of a man in their custody was an unusual one that many experts said could reverberate among police nationwide. Three of the six officers were charged last week with false imprisonment, after the city prosecutor determined that the April 12 arrest of 25-year-old Freddie Gray was illegal.

title: Six Baltimore Police Officers Charged in Freddie Gray Death
authors: Scott Calvert,Kris Maher,Joe Palazzolo,The Wall Street Journal
description: BALTIMORE—Six city police officers were charged Friday in the death of Freddie Gray, a 25-year-old man who suffered fatal spinal injuries last month while in custody, a swift development in a case that has heightened the national focus on policing in black communities. The announcement by State’s Attorney Marilyn Mosby, the city’s chief prosecutor, surprised many in a city where officials had cautioned for days that the investigation might not come to a quick resolution.

title: Baltimore Police Say Freddie Gray Probe Is Complete
authors: Scott Calvert,Joe Palazzolo,Joe Palazzolo And,The Wall Street Journal
description: BALTIMORE—Baltimore police said Thursday they have concluded their investigation into the death of Freddie Gray and turned the results over to the city’s chief prosecutor. “We have exhausted every lead at this point in time,” Police Commissioner Anthony...

title: After Baltimore Riots, Focus Turns to New Prosecutor
authors: Scott Calvert,Joe Palazzolo,The Wall Street Journal
description: BALTIMORE—Barely 100 days into her tenure as the city’s chief prosecutor, State’s Attorney Marilyn Mosby will soon face a momentous decision: whether to pursue criminal charges against any Baltimore police officers in the high-profile death of Freddie Gray. The case thrusts Ms. Mosby, a 35-year-old former insurance company lawyer who had never before held elected office, into the center of a national maelstrom over race relations and...

title: Baltimore Streets Quiet As Residents Obey Curfew After Riots
authors: Scott Calvert,Joe Palazzolo,The Wall Street Journal
description: BALTIMORE—Baltimore streets previously rocked by riots were quiet early Wednesday as residents obeyed an all-night curfew enforced by 3,000 police and National Guardsmen, the Associated Press reported. However, the curfew—imposed in response to riots and looting on Monday fueled by the recent death of a black man in police custody—was initially challenged by a crowd of about 200 protesters at North and Pennsylvania avenues who tossed bottles at police.

title: As Baltimore Residents Clean Up, National Guard Steps In
authors: Scott Calvert,Joe Palazzolo,Kris Maher,The Wall Street Journal
description: Baltimore police enforced an all-night citywide curfew early Wednesday. Police used pepper balls and smoke grenades to disperse a crowd of about 200 protesters who initially challenged the curfew. Photo: APBALTIMORE—Maryland National Guard troops fanned out here Tuesday and residents began to repair neighborhoods as the city’s mayor defended the response to a previous night of riots and looting fueled by the recent death of a black man in police custody.

title: Mental-Health Treatment for Defendants Dogged by Delays
description: Marilyn Roberts’s son was arrested last year on assault charges after he allegedly flicked a cigarette at a police officer in Olympia, Wash., hitting the rim of his hat. He spent 97 days in a county jail, most of them alone in a cell 23 hours a day. He quickly deteriorated. He refused his medication for bipolar disorder, his mother said, because he believed jail staff were trying to poison him. He lost 30 pounds as he rejected most food.

title: Magistrate Judges Play a Larger Role
description: U.S. magistrate judges are the junior officers of the nation’s 94 federal trial courts, but it is getting harder to tell them apart from their Senate-confirmed peers, especially in court districts buckling under heavy case loads. Parties to civil lawsuits have a right to have their cases heard by federal district judges, who are appointed by the president and confirmed by the Senate for life. But they have to wait in line, sometimes...

title: Which Federal Trial Court Is ‘Most Productive?’
description: Lawyers representing Swiss banking giant UBS leave U.S. district court in Miami. REUTERSThe Administrative Office of the U.S. Courts, the front office of the federal judiciary, has done the legwork to figure out which of the 94 federal trial courts cut through its caseload most efficiently in the fiscal year that ended in September 2014. The AO ranked U.S. district courts by hours on the bench, hours in trial, and number of civil and criminal trials.

title: In Federal Courts, Civil Cases Pile Up
description: The Navy eliminated Ronald Porter’s job in 1999. He is still waiting for his employment-discrimination lawsuit to be heard. Civil cases such as Mr. Porter’s are piling up in some of the nation’s federal courts, leading to long delays in suits involving Social Security benefits, personal injury and civil rights, among others. More than 330,000 such cases were pending as of last October—a record—up nearly 20% since 2004,...

title: U.S. Court Rules That Yoga Is Not Religious
description: The constitutional cordon around public schools has repelled a variety of religious activity in recent history—student prayers at football games, bible readings in class, pictures of Jesus. But does the separation of church and state also render off limits the sun salutations, the downward-facing dog and the lotus?

title: U.S. court rules that yoga is not religious
description: The constitutional cordon around public schools has repelled a variety of religious activity in recent history—student prayers at football games, bible readings in class, pictures of Jesus. But does the separation of church and state also render off limits the sun salutations, the downward-facing dog and the lotus?

title: California Appeals Court Rules Yoga Doesn’t Violate Religious Freedom
description: The constitutional cordon around public schools has repelled a variety of religious activity in recent history—student prayers at football games, bible readings in class, pictures of Jesus. But does the separation of church and state also render off limits the sun salutations, the downward-facing dog and the lotus? A California appeals court ruled last week that a school district in Encinitas could incorporate yoga into...

title: In Madison, Wisc., Nonbelievers Have Religious Rights Too
description: View of Capital, Madison, WisconsinGETTY IMAGESIn Madison, Wis., disbelief in the existence of God is now a religion of sorts. The city council voted earlier this week to erect legal protections around nonreligious people, extending them the same security against discrimination enjoyed by the faithful in the city, a liberal beacon in a state largely controlled by Republicans.

title: Former Peace Corps Volunteer Sues over Malaria Drug
description: SINCLAIR STAMMERSSara Thompson sometimes wakes up in the middle of the night and finds her balance has left her. She stumbles to the kitchen. Or to the bathroom. She suffers spells of dizziness when she tilts her head just so, and sometimes for no reason at all. Ms. Thompson, 32, said the symptoms began during her Peace Corps service in Africa, where she took the antimalarial drug mefloquine.

title: Identity Theft Plagues Prisoners
description: ASSOCIATED PRESSEx-offenders have trouble finding jobs and housing, opening bank accounts and obtaining loans, under the best of circumstances. An increasing number of them have a new worry: Identity theft. We report in The Wall Street Journal that a raft of federal prosecutions has uncovered tax-fraud schemes involving the theft of U.S. prisoners’ social-security numbers, many times stolen by corrections employees.

title: Identity Theft, Tax Fraud Snares Prisoners
description: A raft of federal prosecutions has uncovered tax-fraud schemes involving the theft of Social Security numbers of U.S. prisoners, in many cases by corrections employees.

title: Corruption Currents - WSJ
authors: Samuel Rubenfeld,Joe Palazzolo,The Wall Street Journal
description: Corruption Currents, The Wall Street Journal’s corruption blog, digs into the ever-present and ever-changing world of corporate corruption. It is a source of news, analysis and commentary for those who earn a living by finding corruption or by avoiding it. Corruption Currents is written by Christopher. M. Matthews and Sam Rubenfeld and edited by Nick Elliott. Some posts in Corruption Currents are free but others, denoted by a key symbol, require a subscription.

title: Foreign Firms Often Lose Out on Attorney-Client Privilege
description: Few things in U.S. law are as sacrosanct as the attorney-client privilege. But when foreign companies show up in U.S. courts, they sometimes find it doesn’t apply to them. In a handful of recent lawsuits, U.S. judges have ruled that communications between in-house lawyers and companies in China, India, the Netherlands and Russia enjoyed no protection from disclosure. In their rulings, the judges pointed out that corporate counsel...

title: Jury Notes: A Growing Point for Appeals
description: Eight years ago, 36-year-old Latasha Shaw was beaten and stabbed to death by a mob that prosecutors in Rochester, N.Y., said included more than a dozen people. A witness testified that Terrance Mack hit Ms. Shaw in the head with a bottle and pinned her as others bore down on her.

title: Federal Court Says Alabama Official Must Allow Gay Marriage
description: 5:21 pm ETFeb 12, 2015 Federal Court Says Alabama Official Must Allow Gay Marriage The Law Blog covers the legal arena’s hot cases, emerging trends and big personalities. It’s brought to you by lead writer Jacob Gershman with contributions from across The Wall Street Journal’s staff. Jacob comes here after more than half a decade covering the bare-knuckle politics of New York State.

title: Conflicts Mount Between State and Federal Courts
description: Alabama becomes the 37th state to allow gay marriages, despite an eleventh-hour attempt to block them from the state's chief justice. WSJ's Ashby Jones reports on Lunch Break. Photo: APWhen Alabama Chief Justice Roy Moore ordered probate judges to disregard a federal court order striking down the state’s ban on gay marriage, he said that federal courts have no dominion over state courts.

title: Meet the Qualcomm Lawyers
description: Qualcomm Inc. Chairman and CEO Paul E. Jacobs displays a Snapdragon 800 series chip. Getty ImagesWhat happens when a U.S. company comes under scrutiny by Chinese antitrust authorities enforcing a law that is less than a decade old? They figure it out as they go, according to one lawyer familiar with the legal efforts of Qualcomm Inc., which just inked a historic settlement with Chinese authorities, agreeing to pay $975 million to end the two-year-old antitrust probe.

title: Canada’s Top Court Backs Doctor-Assisted Suicide
authors: Joe Palazzolo,Paul And,The Wall Street Journal
description: OTTAWA—Canada’s top court on Friday said Canadians have a right to end their lives with the help of a doctor, in a ruling that bolsters legal arguments advanced by right-to-die advocates in the U.S. and abroad. In an unanimous 9-0 decision, the Supreme Court of Canada said the country’s criminal ban on physician-assisted suicide “unjustifiably infringes” on Canadians’ constitutional rights.

title: Canada’s High Court Approves Physician-Assisted Suicide
description: Canada’s highest court ruled Friday that citizens have a right to end their lives with the assistance of a doctor.

title: Legal Services Sector Stagnant After a Weak 2014
description: Labor DepartmentThe legal services sector shed 1,400 jobs in January, a small shift that keeps total employment in the 1.1 million range, where it remained throughout 2014, the Labor Department said Friday. The sector includes lawyers, paralegals, legal consultants, process servers, notaries and patent agents, among other occupations. In the wider economy, U.S. nonfarm payrolls grew by a seasonally adjusted 257,000 jobs in January, the Labor Department said Friday.

title: U.S. Prisons Grapple With Aging Population
description: Thomas Maree-Bey was in his 40s when he began his sixth stint in prison in 2007. “I was one of those hardheaded ones who didn’t want to do anything but at the end of a sword,” said Mr. Maree-Bey, now 50 years old, who works as an executive assistant at a nonprofit in Washington, D.C.

title: Justice Names Acting Chief of Public-Corruption Unit
description: 10:23 am ETJan 27, 2015 Justice Names Acting Chief of Public-Corruption Unit The Law Blog covers the legal arena’s hot cases, emerging trends and big personalities. It’s brought to you by lead writer Jacob Gershman with contributions from across The Wall Street Journal’s staff. Jacob comes here after more than half a decade covering the bare-knuckle politics of New York State.

title: Top Corruption Prosecutor at the Justice Department Is Moving On
description: The head of the Justice Department’s public corruption unit, which in recent years prosecuted former Virginia Gov. Bob McDonnell and former Arizona Rep. Rick Renzi, is transferring out of Washington. Jack Smith, who became chief of the Public Integrity Section in 2010, is leaving the post for the U.S. attorney’s office in Nashville, where he will be second-in-command, according to lawyers familiar with the move. His last day in the Justice Department’s headquarters is Jan.

title: More Investigators Go Undercover Online
authors: Joe Palazzolo,Jacob Gershman,The Wall Street Journal
description: Associated PressAs Americans flock to social media such as Facebook , police and prosecutors have followed them—sometimes even impersonating users or setting up fictitious accounts to gather intelligence or evidence for trials. It is unclear how widespread the tactics are, but the undercover activity is turning up in a range of legal cases and has won the blessing of a few courts. Privacy advocates worry that the tactics poses unique threats.

title: Police Online Impersonations Raise Concerns
authors: Joe Palazzolo,Jacob Gershman,The Wall Street Journal
description: As Americans flock to social media such as Facebook, police and prosecutors have followed them—sometimes even impersonating users or setting up fictitious accounts to gather intelligence or evidence for trials. It is unclear how widespread the tactics are, but the undercover activity is turning up in a range of legal cases and has won the blessing of a few courts. Privacy advocates worry that the tactics poses unique threats....

title: Web Sends Lovers Flocking to Private Eyes to Find Out the Truth
description: Private detectives increasingly are helping lovers solve an age-old question: Is my partner marriage material? Investigators across the nation say business has boomed in recent years from clients who want their sweethearts investigated for potentially deal-breaking habits and secrets. "It's worth it to them to spend a little in advance to...

title: Mexican Government Backs Lawsuit Against U.S. Border Patrol Agent
description: A U.S. Border Patrol agent looks out over Tijuana, Mexico, along the old border wall along the U.S.–Mexico borderASSOCIATED PRESSThe Mexican government is throwing its weight behind a U.S. lawsuit filed by the parents of a Mexican teenager who was killed in his country when a U.S. Border Patrol agent fired his weapon across the border.

title: Palestinian Authority Faces Trial in Manhattan
description: Members listen as Palestinian representative to the United Nations, Riyad Mansour, speaks during a meeting of the U.N. Security Council in December. Associated PressThe Palestinian Authority and the Palestinian Liberation Organization go on trial Tuesday in Manhattan federal court, in a civil lawsuit that accuses them of orchestrating terrorist attacks in Israel. The trial, expected to run 12 weeks, will focus on seven shooting and bombing attacks in and around Jerusalem from 2001-2004.

title: U.S. Justice Department Intervenes in Football Redskins Trademark Case
description: Jan. 9, 2015 6:34 p.m. ET The U.S. Justice Department has inserted itself into a legal dispute between the Washington Redskins and a group of Native Americans who want the professional football team to abandon its name. The agency will intervene in the case for the “limited purpose” of defending a federal law that prohibits disparaging trademarks, Justice Department lawyers said in a court filing on Friday.

title: British Cleric Sentenced to Life for Ties to al Qaeda and Taliban
description: Abu Hamza al-Masri, an Egyptian-born British cleric convicted of supporting al Qaeda and the Taliban, was sentenced to life in prison on Friday. U.S. District Judge Katherine B. Forrest in Manhattan said Mr. al-Masri had "conveyed a vision of violence as an obligation" and was remorseless for his crimes, including the 1998 kidnapping of 16...

title: British Cleric Called ‘Evil’ by Judge, Given Life in Prison
description: Abu Hamza al-Masri, an Egyptian-born British cleric convicted of supporting al Qaeda and the Taliban, was sentenced to life in prison on Friday. U.S. District Judge Katherine B. Forrest in Manhattan said Mr. al-Masri had “conveyed a vision of violence as an obligation” and was remorseless for his crimes, including the 1998 kidnapping of 16 Western tourists in Yemen and his attempt to found a jihadist training camp in Oregon.

title: Law-School Program Emphasizes Practical Skills
description: Kristen Blanchette stood outside the courthouse in Concord, N.H., where she was scheduled to present her first arguments before a federal judge, and pleaded for mercy—for herself. “I can’t do this. I just can’t,” Ms. Blanchette recalls telling her superior. It was only later, while watching a video of her performance, she said, that she realized, “Wow, I did an OK job.” The arguments were a simulation, the culmination of...

title: Pay, Pot and Pets: Laws That Take Effect in 2015
description: An employee helps customers with their purchase of marijuana at a store in Denver. BLOOMBERGThe onset of a new year is often marked by restraint. (“In 2015, I’m going to stop texting while walking.) But 2015 will also be a story of more — including more pay and more not-quite-as-illegal pot.

title: Labor, Marijuana and Pets to Get New Laws in 2015
description: In the New Year, the minimum wage will climb in dozens of states, college students in California will test the meaning of “Yes means yes,” recreational pot smokers will gain three more safe havens, and New Yorkers will be banned from piercing or tattooing their pets. Among the many new laws taking effect in 2015, labor laws, in particular, will sprout like weeds.

title: Harvard Law Professor: Feds’ Position on Sexual-Assault Policies Is ‘Madness’
description: 1:35 pm ETDec 31, 2014 Harvard Law Professor: Feds’ Position on Sexual-Assault Policies Is ‘Madness’ The Law Blog covers the legal arena’s hot cases, emerging trends and big personalities. It’s brought to you by lead writer Jacob Gershman with contributions from across The Wall Street Journal’s staff. Jacob comes here after more than half a decade covering the bare-knuckle politics of New York State.

title: AM Roundup: Seattle Police Chafe Under New Orders
description: Seattle officers arrested protesters who tried to enter an interstate highway on foot in November following the Ferguson, Mo., grand-jury decision. SEATTLEPI/ASSOCIATED PRESSLaw Blog rounds up the morning’s legal news:A new approach: After decades of aggressive policing and prosecution practices, combined with tough-on-crime legislation, there is increasing debate over whether those policies need to change.

title: Judge Tosses Sheriff Arpaio’s Obama Immigration Suit
description: Maricopa County, Ariz., Sheriff Joe Arpaio speaks in Phoenix. Associated PressA federal judge dismissed Maricopa County Sheriff Joe Arpaio’s lawsuit challenging the Obama administration’s plan to shield nearly five million people from deportation. U.S. District Judge Beryl Howell in Washington, D.C., said that the lawsuit raised “important questions” but that the courts were an inappropriate forum for answering them.

title: Police Seek Clues in Social Media
authors: Ashby Jones,Joe Palazzolo,The Wall Street Journal
description: Police departments have little legal recourse against people who threaten violence against their officers, but they are aggressively monitoring social media in hopes of identifying dangers and thwarting violence. A warning from Baltimore County Police officials, who learned about an Instagram post that suggested Ismaaiyl Brinsley planned to kill police officers as revenge for the deaths of Michael Brown and Eric Garner, came too late...

title: In These Towns, Being Annoying Is a Criminal Offense
description: Willian Barboza was arrested for being annoying. The 23-year-old Connecticut native was sore about a speeding ticket he got in the Village of Liberty in upstate New York in 2012. And when he sent in payment for the fine, he let the town of 4,400 know exactly how he felt.

title: Binder & Binder Files for Chapter 11
description: In 2010, Binder & Binder scooped up $88 million in fees representing applicants for social security disability benefits. It was the largest firm of its kind, thriving amid an aging workforce, high unemployment and less oversight than in the current environment. On Thursday night, the firm filed for bankruptcy protection.

title: Indiana High Court: Being Drunk and Annoying is Illegal
description: F. Martin Ramin for The Wall Street Journal The Indiana Supreme Court has ruled that it is illegal to be drunk and annoying -- or what a reasonable person would find to be annoying, anyway. The Wall Street Journal previously reported on the case of Rodregus Morgan -- who challenged the state's public-intoxication law as unconstitutionally vague -- in a story about dozens of cities and states that have outlawed annoying conduct.

title: Congress and the Courts Are Learning to Get Along
description: Getty ImagesThe legislative and judicial branches are less neighborly than they once were, but efforts are underway to rekindle a spark in the relationship. The U.S. Supreme Court hasn’t had a member with experience as an elected politician since Justice Sandra Day O’Connor, a former state senator in Arizona, retired nearly a decade ago. Likewise, only seven members of Congress, all in the House, were judges. The past couple years may have marked a low point in inter-branch relations.

title: IBM’s Outgoing General Counsel Looks Back at the Future
description: Robert Weber, IBM’s general counsel, is retiring next year. IBM“Imagine having Watson there with you in the courtroom,” said Robert C. Weber, general counsel for International Business Machines Corp., referring to the company’s problem-solving software of Jeopardy! fame. “There are a lot more cases out there than anybody can keep track of. The facts of cases are sometimes extremely complex.”Watson, in this conceiving, would have all the facts and the cases at his command.

title: Law School Enrollment Continues to Slide
description: We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription. You will be charged $ + tax (if applicable) for The Wall Street Journal. You may change your billing preferences at any time in the Customer Center or call Customer Service. You will be notified in advance of any changes in rate or terms. You may cancel your subscription at anytime by calling Customer Service. Please click confirm to resume now.

title: Wide Racial Divide in Sentencing
description: Prison sentences of black men were nearly 20% longer than those of white men for similar crimes in recent years, an analysis by the U.S. Sentencing Commission found. That racial gap has widened since the Supreme Court restored judicial discretion in sentencing in 2005, according to the Sentencing Commission's findings, which were submitted to...

title: Justice Department Faces Tough Questioning in E-Books Case
description: The U.S. government on Monday faced aggressive questioning from judges reviewing a finding last year that Apple Inc. conspired with publishers to raise the price of electronic books as it prepared to enter the market in 2010. Amazon.com Inc., though not a party in the case, cast a long shadow over the arguments at the Second U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Manhattan.

title: 5 Takeaways from the Insider-Trading Ruling
description: The vast majority of the insider-cases prosecuted by Mr. Bharara’s office were resolved through guilty pleas. Legal experts said defendants in those cases would face an uphill battle in trying to reopen their cases and withdraw their pleas. One case that may be in jeopardy is the conviction of Michael Steinberg, one of the few defendants to go to trial. Mr. Steinberg, a senior employee of SAC Capital Advisors LP, was found guilty last year and his appeal is pending.

title: Read the Ruling: Appeals Court Overturns Two Insider Trading Convictions
description: A three-judge panel of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit overturned two insider-trading convictions and potentially constrained prosecutors’ latitude to pursue such crimes. The ruling narrowed the definition of what constitutes insider trading and determined prosecutors had taken too broad a view of the law in their multi-year crackdown on Wall Street. Read the ruling here:

title: U.S. Courts Order More Companies to Break Foreign Laws
description: Freya Ingrid Morales/BLOOMBERGFederal courts in New York increasingly are ordering companies to break foreign laws. Before trial, parties in U.S. litigation exchange documents relevant to their legal dispute, in a process called discovery. Sometimes, one party demands that another produce documents held in a foreign country whose laws forbid their release. In such cases, a U.S. judge must decide whether to order the party to produce the documents in violation of the foreign law.

title: AM Roundup: FDA Advisers’ Financial Ties Not Disclosed
description: REUTERSLaw Blog rounds up the morning’s legal news:Close ties: The Food and Drug Administration hasn’t disclosed numerous financial ties between medical-device makers and the doctors and other experts who review devices for it, a Wall Street Journal analysis of corporate, state and federal data shows. [WSJ]CIA report: A Senate committee is releasing a report Tuesday on the Central Intelligence Agency’s detention and interrogation program for foreign terrorism suspects.

title: Nine-Year-Old’s Arrest Prompts Call for Change by Federal Judge
description: ASSOCIATED PRESSThe increased involvement of police at schools has led to an increase in schoolchildren arrests, phenomena that make for shocking headlines (8-year-old arrested in school bomb threat) and have led to a new, funny-if-it-weren’t-true formulation: the school-to-prison pipeline. One federal judge is pleading for change. “It is time for a change in our jurisprudence that would deal with petty crimes by minors in a more enlightened fashion,” wrote Judge Carlos F.

title: AM Roundup: Police Race to Overhaul Tactics
description: U.S. Attorney General Eric Holder, at head of table, met in Cleveland with law enforcement, local officials and community leaders after a Justice Department report Thursday said Cleveland police officers use excessive and unnecessary force too often.

title: Civil Rights Investigations: How They Work
description: People participate in a ‘die-in’ protest against the decision of a grand jury not to indict a police officer involved in the death of Eric GarnerEuropean Pressphoto AgencyState grand juries considering whether police officers in New York and suburban St. Louis should be charged in the deaths of Eric Garner and Michael Brown were asked to consider a tricky question: Were the officers’ actions defensible?

title: At Center of Immigration Suit, a Clause with a Funny Name
description: President Barack speaks at the White House Tribal Nations Conference in Washington on Wednesday. ReutersTexas and 16 other states filed a lawsuit on Wednesday challenging President Barack Obama ’s executive action on immigration.

title: A Better Way To Investigate Police Shootings?
description: A woman, who did not want to give her name, places flowers at a memorial for Eric Garner near the site of his death in the borough of Staten Island. SETH WENIG/ASSOCIATED PRESSThe grand jury investigation of Darren Wilson, the Ferguson, Mo., police officer who shot and killed Michael Brown, was unusually elaborate. Jurors heard 70 hours of testimony from more than 60 witnesses before deciding not to charge Mr. Wilson.

title: Wells Fargo Cuts Ties with Prisoner Banking Service
description: Through Prisoner Assistant, Michael Benanti tries to help inmates establish a financial footprint so that ‘they get out with something to lose.’Daryl Peveto for The Wall Street JournalWells Fargo & Co. is severing ties with a company that helps inmates set up bank accounts, establish credit and conduct a variety of services that are difficult to perform from behind bars, the company’s founder said.

title: Uber Hopes for Good News in France, Receives Bad News in Nevada
description: Zuma PressCar-hailing service Uber Technologies Inc. is awaiting a court decision in France that could set the tone for the U.S. firm’s escalating regulatory battles in Europe. The company, reports the WSJ, argued Friday that a new French law governing car-service apps is unconstitutional. A decision in the case is expected on Dec. 12. Uber is accused of flouting the law in France and other countries by using drivers without professional licenses in its low-cost Uberpop service.

title: AM Roundup: Music Publishers Target Cable Industry over Illegal Downloads
description: BMG controls rights to songs by David Bowie, Johnny Cash and Lenny Kravitz, shown, among others. FRANCOIS GUILLOT/AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE/GETTY IMAGESLaw Blog rounds up the morning’s legal news:New target: Two music publishers are taking aim at a new target in the battle against illegal song downloading: the cable industry. [WSJ]Old law, new tricks: The Justice Department is turning to a 225-year-old law to tackle a very modern problem: password-protected cellphones.

title: Ferguson Grand Jury Documents: The Witnesses that Weren’t
description: Days after a grand jury’s decision not to indict police officer Darren Wilson in the shooting of 18-year-old Michael Brown, thousands of pages of testimony and witness interviews released by prosecutors are slowly revealing the contours of the investigation. Grand jurors, it is now clear, had reason to doubt what they heard. Witness accounts diverged from one another in significant ways.

title: AM Roundup: Immigration Plan Ignites Debate over Executive Power
description: President Barack Obama speaks during a news conference in Washington, D.C., on Thursday. BloombergLaw Blog rounds up the morning’s legal news:Executive power: The president’s immigration-overhaul plan has ignited a debate over the legal boundaries of his power, leaving Republicans exploring whether they could litigate claims that his actions violate the law.

title: FCC Lays Groundwork for More Curbs on Prison Call Rates
description: Bethany Fraser, a family member affected by the high telephone rates charged to prison inmates, listens to a Federal Communications Commission hearing in Washington last year. Associated PressRegulators are considering banning payments made by telecommunications companies to states for the exclusive rights to provide call services in their prisons and jails, the latest effort by the Federal Communications Commission to rein in rates for inmates’ telephone calls.

title: Veterans Accuse Six Banks of Aiding U.S. Foes
description: More than 200 veterans and their families filed a lawsuit Monday accusing six major banks of helping Iran move tens of millions of dollars to groups targeting U.S. soldiers in Iraq during the war. The suit, filed in Brooklyn federal court, comes less than two months after the first U.S. jury verdict in a civil terrorism-finance case put banks on notice that they could face civil liability for doing business with certain clients....

title: Kansas Justices Overcome Criticism over Death-Penalty Ruling
description: Kansas Supreme Court Justice Lee Johnson, right, asks questions during a hearing earlier this year. Associated PressTwo Kansas Supreme Court justices who were challenged over their ruling in a death-penalty case won new six-year terms on the high court. Justices Eric Rosen and Lee Johnson weren’t in a contested race. In Kansas, after a justice is appointed by the governor and serves a six-year turn, voters get to decide whether to keep the justice, by checking yes or no.

title: Judicial Elections: Races to Watch
description: Illinois Supreme Court justice Lloyd Karmeier questions an attorney during oral arguments in Chicago. Associated Press/M. Spencer GreenSupreme-court justices in 22 states will face the voters this Election Day, although in 14 they will be running in uncontested, yes-or-no elections. The elections come as the struggle between corporate groups and trial lawyers to influence who sits on state high courts has broadened to include national political groups.

title: Judges to Begin Weighing Shorter Sentences for Thousands of Inmates
description: The U.S. Sentencing Commission estimates that more than 46,000 inmates could receive a shorter sentence — an average of about two years off their total – following a tweak to the sentencing guidelines that altered the formula for calculating penalties for drug-trafficking offenses.

title: These Tricksters Earn Their Treats
description: Not all American kids get their Halloween candy for free. In some haunts, including St. Louis, Mo., and Des Moines, Iowa, trick-or-treaters have to tell a joke before they get candy. The tradition appears to date back to at least the 1930s and, historians say, has roots in Old-World mumming — the practice of people in disguise visiting homes to perform dances, music, jokes or recitations. We encourage you to add some mirth to your Halloween. Tell a joke, or request one. Keep it clean, folks.

title: In St. Louis, Trick-or-Treaters Tell Jokes to Earn Halloween Candy
description: When 7-year-old Jimmy Striler dons his Red Ninja costume this year, he will be armed with a plastic sword. He will also carry something else St. Louis, Mo., children must have with them on Halloween: corny jokes. In certain haunts, such as this city and Des Moines, Iowa, the end of October isn’t just an occasion for children to dress up like a ninja, a ghost or the latest Disney cartoon. It is also a challenge: Make an adult giggle. These Midwesterners don’t parcel out candy...

title: Number of LSAT Takers Continues to Slide
description: LSACPaul Caron, author of the TaxProf Blog, described the downward trend this way: “Law School Carnage Enters Its Fifth Year.”“Carnage” is good word for it. The number of Law School Admission Test takers in June and October of 2014 (52,826) plummeted by more than 43% from the same periods in 2009. As you can see, test takers in 2014-2015 are on pace to reach lows that we haven’t seen since the late 1990s.

title: Being Drunk and Annoying Isn't a Crime, Court Says

title: Ninth Circuit Recognizes Right to Bear Arms Outside the Home
description: The Ninth U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled Thursday that the Second Amendment endows the right to carry a gun outside the home. The opinion comes days before the Supreme Court is expected to decide whether to review two other cases that ask the question of whether the right to “bear arms” extends beyond the home.

There's no guarantee the talks will pan out, but the door-to-door seller of cosmetics and...

title: Holder Is Sworn In as Attorney General
description: Attorney General Eric Holder Jr. was welcomed to his first day on the job by rousing applause, as he spoke of “a new day” in a department that has been tainted by the influence of partisan politics. “It is so good to be home,” said Holder, 58, a former federal prosecutor, D.C. Superior Court Judge, U.S. attorney, and deputy attorney general. The Senate confirmed Holder last evening by a vote of 75 to 21. Vice President Joseph Biden Jr. conducted the swearing in this morning, without incident.

title: Probe Widens Into Dealings Between Finance Firms, Libya
authors: Justin Baer,Michael Rothfeld,Joe Palazzolo,The Wall Street Journal
description: The Justice Department has joined a widening investigation of banks, private-equity firms and hedge funds that may have violated antibribery laws in their dealings with Libya's government-run investment fund, people familiar with the matter said. The criminal investigation, which has intensified in recent months, is proceeding alongside a civil probe by the Securities and Exchange Commission that began in 2011 and initially homed in...

title: Inmate Banking: A Way to Reduce Recidivism or a Recipe for Trouble?
description: Michael Benanti spent 16 years in prison for conspiring to rob a bank. Now he is a banker of sorts for a captive audience. Five years ago, Mr. Benanti launched Prisoner Assistant Inc., a company that helps inmates set up bank accounts, start establishing credit and conduct a variety of services that are difficult to perform from behind bars.

title: First Amendment Doesn’t Distinguish Between Bloggers and Press, Court Says
description: In defamation cases, the First Amendment applies equally to bloggers, dead-tree journalists and anyone else who is speaking to the public, a federal appeals court ruled Friday. The Ninth U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ordered a new trial for Montana blogger Crystal Cox, whom a jury found liable for defaming an investment firm and one of its lead partners.

title: Court Raises Bar on Searches of Laptops at the Border
description: A federal appeals court set a higher bar Friday for U.S. border officials who want to search the laptops or iPads of people crossing into the country. The Ninth U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in San Francisco, considering the case of a man whose laptop was seized at a port of entry in Arizona, ruled that border authorities must show a "reasonable suspicion" of wrongdoing before digging into electronic devices.

title: Jurist Prudence? Candid Judges Speak Out
description: Judges typically confine their opinions to their rulings. But 2013 was a year of exceptions. In Nebraska, U.S. District Judge Richard G. Kopf in February launched Hercules and the umpire, a blog that offers a mix of insights on the judicial process, legal news, personal reflections and wisdom.

title: Top 10 white-collar prison sentences
description: Keith Simmons is not a household name. His Ponzi scheme, which was uncovered in 2009, cost his victims more than $35 million, a much smaller figure than, say, the $20 billion fraud perpetrated by Bernie Madoff (which came to light five years ago Wednesday) or R. Allen Stanford's $7 billion scam. But his conviction was notable outside of North Carolina, where he was prosecuted and received a 50-year prison sentence, one of the longest for a white-collar crime.

title: Curbing Inmate Round Trips
description: Six out of 10 inmates paroled from Pennsylvania prisons were arrested again within three years, a recent state study found. And parolees who were released to the streets were reincarcerated less frequently than those who first spent time in halfway houses-institutions whose goal is preventing such recidivism.

title: Witness: SAC Chief Praised Dell Trade at Center of Insider Case
description: Steven A. Cohen, the billionaire founder of SAC Capital Advisors LP, praised the team of employees that made $1 million on a trade of Dell Inc. stock at the center of the insider-trading trial of a portfolio manager, a former SAC analyst testified in U.S. District Court.

title: Firms Push for Protection Over Preserving Documents
description: At Exxon Mobil Corp., more than 5,000 U.S. employees are under orders not to delete a single file from their computers and devices. Microsoft Corp. employees, hundreds of them, are sitting on millions of old emails, work documents and instant messages.

title: Judge Appears Receptive to Critics of NSA's Collection of Phone Data
description: A federal judge on Friday appeared receptive to the idea that Americans enjoy some level of privacy in their phone records, in the first court challenge to the National Security Agency's bulk collection of data from telecommunications companies. The U.S.

title: Is the Third Party (Doctrine) Winding Down?
description: It may be necessary to reconsider the premise that an individual has no reasonable expectation of privacy in information voluntarily disclosed to third parties. That premise was crystallized in a 1979 case called Smith v. Maryland, in which the U.S. Supreme Court held that Americans have no expectation of privacy in the numbers of those they are calling, because they knowingly give that information to phone companies when they dial a number. The holding became known as the Third-Party Doctrine.

title: More Arrests in Alleged ATM Cybercrime
description: Federal agents arrested five men on allegations they siphoned money out of New York City ATMs, packed it in a suitcase and sent it by bus to a ringleader in Miami. The indictment unsealed Monday shed additional light on an international scheme exposed by federal prosecutors in May, in which thieves allegedly drained $45 million from ATMs in 20...

title: New York Court to Weigh Law License for Illegal Immigrant
description: New York's top court could soon consider whether an illegal immigrant-Cesar Vargas, who moved to the U.S. from Mexico at age 5-can practice law in the state.

title: Appeals Court Blocks Health Law's Contraception Requirement
description: A federal appeals court blocked a provision of the health-care law requiring employers to provide birth-control coverage in employee insurance, ruling it imposed a 'substantial burden' on religious rights of two companies.

title: Plane Maker Embraer Faces Bribery Inquiries
description: U.S. and Brazilian authorities are investigating whether aircraft maker Embraer bribed officials in the Dominican Republic in return for a $90 million contract to furnish the country's armed forces with attack planes.

title: Skakel Retrial Surprises Legal Observers
description: Winning a new trial because of a lawyer's incompetence isn't easy. That is why the legal community is abuzz over a rare decision to grant Kennedy relative Michael Skakel a new trial in a notorious murder case.

title: Court Drops Restriction That Limited Cellphone Wiretaps
description: A federal appeals court withdrew an earlier ruling that law-enforcement officials had warned would hamper efforts to tap the cellphones of suspected criminals.

title: Court Rules Warrant Needed for GPS Tracking of Vehicles
description: A federal appeals court ruled that police must obtain a warrant before attaching a GPS tracker to a suspect's vehicle, in the first case to squarely confront the issue since the Supreme Court's fractured opinion last year on the use of such devices in law enforcement.

title: Health Law Faces New Legal Challenges

title: Facebook 'Likes' Are Protected by First Amendment
description: "Liking" something on Facebook is a form of speech protected by the First Amendment, a federal appeals court held, reviving a lawsuit that explores how much of what people do online is protected by the Constitution. The Fourth U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals on Wednesday sided with a former deputy sheriff in Hampton, Va., who said he was fired for clicking Like on the Facebook page of his boss's opponent in a race for city sheriff.

title: Court: Facebook 'Like' Is Protected By the First Amendment
description: "Liking" something on Facebook is a form of speech protected by the First Amendment, a federal appeals court ruled Wednesday, reviving a closely watched case over the extent to which the Constitution shields what we do online. In doing so, the Fourth U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals sided with a former deputy sheriff in Hampton, Va., who said he was sacked for "liking" the Facebook page of a man running against his boss for city sheriff.

title: Legal Events to Watch This Week
description: This week: The Senate likely votes on a resolution that would authorize the president to use force in Syria; the Justice Department declassifies more secret surveillance court opinions. • The U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit will hear arguments in a suit brought by Verizon Communications Inc. challenging “net neutrality” rules imposed by the Federal Communications Commission in 2011.

title: To Be PC or Not To Be?
description: If a term used to describe a person, place or thing in an old law or a precedent-setting legal ruling has fallen out of favor, should a lawyer writing a brief (or a judge writing an opinion) that incorporates the law or the legal ruling use the current term of preference or stick with the old one for consistency’s sake?

title: Punctures Two Inches of Steel Armor, But Not a Missile
description: Some days, being a judge means picking through a maze of labor regulations. On other days, the job entails deciding whether 40-mm cartridges for a grenade launcher are properly defined as missiles. The question came before the Ninth U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in the case of Arturo Lara, Alfredo Lara, and Yoahjan Lara Flores, who purchased a Colt M203 grenade launcher and three inert 40-mm cartridges from undercover federal agents in 2010.

title: Court Curbs Authority to Issue Wiretap Warrants
description: A recent ruling by the Fifth U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals could put a crimp in federal investigations in the South. In an unsigned opinion, the court ruled Monday that a federal district judge in Mississippi lacked jurisdiction to authorize the wiretap of a cell phone in another state. As a result, the Fifth Circuit suppressed an incriminating call from a suspect in Texas that Drug Enforcement Administration agents had intercepted as part of an investigation of a drug-trafficking organization.

title: ‘Made in Montana’ But Still Subject to Federal Gun Laws
description: Gary Marbut, a Montana man who is trying to shoot down decades of settled law with a rifle he designed, lost his closely watched case in a federal appeals court Friday. When Law Blog reached him, he seemed to be taking it in stride. “We got what we needed out of the Ninth Circuit,” Mr. Marbut said, referring to the San Francisco-based Ninth U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, “and that is the door open to the Supreme Court.”Mr. Marbut wants to be able to make and sell his .22 caliber rifle. . . . . .

title: Appeals Court Says Ex-College Stars Can Sue Videogame Maker Electronic Arts

EA’s videogames are coveted for their attention to detail.

title: Judges Ask Supreme Court to Take On Cell-Phone Searches
description: Federal appeals judges pressed the nation’s top court to resolve a deepening split among their colleagues over whether police need a warrant to search the cell phone of someone under arrest. In a 2-1 decision in May, the First U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals held that Boston police needed a warrant to search the cell phone of a man arrested in 2007 for suspected drug dealing, putting it at odds with several other federal appeals courts as well as the highest state court in Massachusetts.

title: The Unusual Civil Forfeiture Complaint Against SAC
description: The criminal charges against SAC Capital Advisors LP, unveiled Thursday, were accompanied by a civil forfeiture complaint, alleging that the firm dumped the profits of an insider-trading scheme into investment funds, where they mixed with clean money and were laundered through trades based on more inside information.

title: SAC Operating Plan to Be Negotiated
description: Dow Jones Reprints: This copy is for your personal, non-commercial use only. To order presentation-ready copies for distribution to your colleagues, clients or customers, use the Order Reprints tool at the bottom of any article or visit www.djreprints.com

title: Third Circuit: For-Profit Companies Don’t Have Religious Rights
description: Companies can be prosecuted like in-the-flesh people and they have First Amendment rights to free speech. But the next “corporate personhood” question the Supreme Court will likely confront is whether for-profit companies also enjoy religious rights. Federal courts are fractured on the issue.

title: Little Turtles, Once Doomed, Win a Reprieve
description: The Food and Drug Administration has long banned the sale or distribution of little turtles, which, despite their lethargy and charm, are commonly freighted with bacteria on their shells and skin.

title: Do You Know What Violates the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act?
description: The Foreign Corrupt Practices Act is among the statutes most feared by companies with global operations. It can also be one of the most confusing. Since 2008, the U.S. Justice Department and Securities and Exchange Commission have extracted billions of dollars in criminal and civil penalties over alleged violations of the 1977 law, which bars U.S.-based or U.S.-listed companies from bribing foreign officials in exchange for business and requires them to keep accurate books and records.

title: Legal Events to Watch This Week
description: This week: Toyota Motor Corp. goes on trial; the Detroit bankruptcy revs up in court. • Jury selection is set to begin in a trial in California that could determine whether Toyota Motor should be held liable for sudden unintended acceleration in its vehicles. • Rosemarie Aquilina, a circuit judge in Ingham County, Mich., is scheduled to hold a hearing at 9 a.m. to decide whether the Michigan governor has the authority to approve a bankruptcy filing that would affect accrued pension benefits.

title: Does DOMA Decision Mean Green Cards for Gay Spouses?
description: When the Supreme Court struck down part of Defense of Marriage Act last month, granting same-sex couples the same federal benefits enjoyed by married couples of the opposite sex, the justices also fueled a debate over how U.S. immigration laws treats foreign-born spouses of gay Americans.

title: Do ‘Stand-Your-Ground’ Laws Lead to More Homicides?
description: Attorney General Eric Holder said Tuesday that  “stand-your-ground” laws, such as the one Florida authorities initially cited as a reason for not charging George Zimmerman in the death of Trayvon Martin, undermine public safety by encouraging violent situations. Mr. Holder’s remarks, his first public criticism of stand-your-ground laws, came at the NAACP Annual Convention in Orlando, Fla., not far from where Mr. Zimmerman was acquitted last week.

title: When the Right to an Attorney Gets Lost in Translation
description: In the movies, the police officer is a master at reading Miranda rights. The fake cop can spit out the famous warning — enshrined in 1966 Supreme Court case Miranda v. Arizona – while disarming four assailants with a broomstick. Sometimes our hero, or antihero, adds modifications, in service of a cheap laugh.

title: Legal Events to Watch This Week
description: This week: “Fabulous Fab” Tourre goes on trial in Manhattan; Congress takes its first look at the Voting Rights Act since the Supreme Court sliced it up last month. • Jury selection is slated to begin in the civil trial of Fabrice Tourre, a former Goldman Sachs Group Inc. vice president accused by the Securities and Exchange Commission of misleading investors about a complex financial instrument. Opening statements are expected by midday or so. • A bench trial over litigation stemming from the Sept.

title: Apple Ruling Heaps Doubt on 'MFN' Clauses
description: Dow Jones Reprints: This copy is for your personal, non-commercial use only. To order presentation-ready copies for distribution to your colleagues, clients or customers, use the Order Reprints tool at the bottom of any article or visit www.djreprints.com

title: Legal Insights on the Zimmerman Verdict
description: We asked a panel of self-defense experts for reactions to a jury finding George Zimmerman not guilty of all charges in the death of Trayvon Martin. Joshua Dressler, a professor at The Ohio State University Michael E. Moritz College of Law, said the acquittal came as no surprise.

title: Highlights from the Apple Ruling
description: In a stern rebuke to Apple Inc.’s electronic-books sales strategy, a federal judge found the company colluded with five major U.S. publishers to artificially drive up the prices of e-books in the months ahead of its entering the market in 2010.

title: U.S. Judge Rules Apple Colluded on E-Books
authors: Joe Palazzolo,Ian Sherr,Chad Bray,The Wall Street Journal
description: Apple Inc. colluded with five major U.S. publishers to drive up the prices of e-books, a federal judge ruled Wednesday in a stern rebuke that threatens to limit the technology company's options when negotiating future content deals. In her ruling, U.S. District Judge Denise Cote in Manhattan said the evidence was clear that Apple, despite its claims that it negotiated fiercely and separately with each publisher, was at the center of the conspiracy.

title: Is Obesity a Disability?
description: The question is an important one in employment law. If it is, then obesity is covered by the Americans with Disabilities Act. That, in turn, means that obese people are afforded legal protection against discrimination based on their weight, and a sharp tool with which to enforce that protection in a court of law.

title: The AM Roundup: How One Word Empowered the NSA
description: The Law Blog covers the legal arena’s hot cases, emerging trends and big personalities. It’s brought to you by lead writer Jacob Gershman with contributions from across The Wall Street Journal’s staff. Jacob comes here after more than half a decade covering the bare-knuckle politics of New York State. His inside-the-room reporting left him steeped in legal and regulatory issues that continue to grab headlines. Comment or tip? Write to Jacob.Gershman@wsj.com or lawblog@wsj.com

title: Teen Jailed for Facebook Posting About School Shooting
description: Americans were still reeling from the elementary-school massacre in Newtown, Conn., when Justin Carter allegedly committed his crime in New Braunfels, a city in central Texas. "I think I'ma [sic] shoot up a kindergarten and watch the blood of the innocent rain down and eat the beating heart of one of them," the 19-year-old wrote Feb. 13 on a public Facebook page in response to a taunt by one of his friends.

title: Teen Jailed for Facebook Posting About School Shooting
description: Americans were still reeling from the elementary-school massacre in Newtown, Conn., when Justin Carter allegedly committed his crime in New Braunfels, a city in central Texas. "I think I'ma [sic] shoot up a kindergarten and watch the blood of the innocent rain down and eat the beating heart of one of them," the 19-year-old wrote Feb. 13 on a public Facebook page in response to a taunt by one of his friends.

title: Dreier Victim Acquires Fraudster’s Fancy Art Collection
description: Fraud is the dysentery of crime: even after the infection is contained, the unpleasant after-effects linger interminably. Thus it is that even after a confidence man has been convicted, the victims of his fraud are often reduced to fighting among themselves over what assets remain. Judge Rakoff’s words were inspired by one fight in particular — over $33 million worth of artwork by Andy Warhol, Mark Rothko and Roy Lichtenstein, among others, that once belonged to lawyer-cum-swindler Marc Dreier.

title: Legal Events to Watch This Week
description: The Law Blog covers the legal arena’s hot cases, emerging trends and big personalities. It’s brought to you by lead writer Jacob Gershman with contributions from across The Wall Street Journal’s staff. Jacob comes here after more than half a decade covering the bare-knuckle politics of New York State. His inside-the-room reporting left him steeped in legal and regulatory issues that continue to grab headlines. Comment or tip? Write to Jacob.Gershman@wsj.com or lawblog@wsj.com

title: Federal Court: For-Profit Corporations Have Religious Rights Too
description: A divided federal appeals court said Thursday that companies, whether for profit or not, have religious rights. The ruling came in a challenge by arts and crafts chain Hobby Lobby Stores Inc. and Christian bookstore chain Mardel Inc. to a part of President Barack Obama’s 2010 healthcare overhaul — namely, a requirement that employee health insurance plans include free contraceptive coverage.

title: The AM Roundup: Gearing Up for the Next Same-Sex Marriage Battles
description: The path ahead: The Supreme Court’s decisions Wednesday offered neither side in the debate over same-sex marriage a sweeping resolution. With the justices’ ruling on the Proposition 8 gay-marriage ban concerning only California, the path forward nationally on the issue remains winding—and may eventually lead back to the Supreme Court. WSJLosing support: Cutbacks in the legal business aren’t just falling on lawyers.

title: Why Legal Secretaries Can't Find Jobs
authors: Jennifer Smith,Joe Palazzolo,The Wall Street Journal
description: Dow Jones Reprints: This copy is for your personal, non-commercial use only. To order presentation-ready copies for distribution to your colleagues, clients or customers, use the Order Reprints tool at the bottom of any article or visit www.djreprints.com

title: Calif Governor: State Will Issue Marriage Licenses to Same-Sex Couples ASAP
description: After years of struggle, the U.S. Supreme Court today has made same-sex marriage a reality in California. In light of the decision, I have directed the California Department of Public Health to advise the state’s counties that they must begin issuing marriage licenses to same-sex couples in California as soon as the Ninth Circuit confirms the stay is lifted,” said Governor Brown.

title: Gay Marriage Rulings at the Supreme Court: A Cheat Sheet
description: • Can people in gay marriages now receive the same federal benefits as people in opposite-sex marriages? Yes. The Supreme Court struck down as unconstitutional a part of the Defense of Marriage Act that denied federal benefits to gay and lesbian couples in states where such unions are permitted. Here’s a list of the 1,000-plus provisions of U.S. law in which federal benefits are contingent on marital status,  or in which marital status is a factor.

title: Court Arms Supporters of Gay Marriage, Justice Scalia Says
description: The Supreme Court was silent Wednesday on whether state bans on gay marriage are permissible under the U.S. Constitution. But the 5-4 majority, in knocking down a law that denied federal benefits to same-sex couples, did indeed give proponents of gay marriage a lot to work with, as Justice Antonin Scalia notes in his dissent. You can expect to see the language of Justice Anthony Kennedy, who wrote the majority opinion, pop up often in legal challenges to gay marriage bans in the states.

title: New York Law Firm Weil, Gotshal to Lay Off Attorneys, Staff and Cut Pay for Partners
description: Dow Jones Reprints: This copy is for your personal, non-commercial use only. To order presentation-ready copies for distribution to your colleagues, clients or customers, use the Order Reprints tool at the bottom of any article or visit www.djreprints.com

title: Weil Lays Off 60 Associates, 110 Staff
description: New York law firm Weil, Gotshal & Manges LLP plans to cut pay for some partners and lay off dozens of junior attorneys and staff, a firm official said Monday, in the latest example of financial woes facing the legal profession. The 1,200- lawyer firm, which counts General Electric Co. and General Motors Com pany Inc. as clients, will shed 60 associates — or about 7% of its junior ranks — and 110 support staff, executive partner Barry M. Wolf said in a firm-wide email.

title: Legal Events to Watch This Week
description: This week: The trials of James “Whitey” Bulger, George Zimmerman and Bradley Manning continue, and the U.S. Supreme Court is poised to deliver a blockbuster or two. • The U.S. Supreme Court is expected to issue orders and opinions. We’re still waiting for rulings on affirmative action, gay marriage and voting rights in the 2012-13 term, which ends this month.

title: Medical Groups Push Back at Gun-Law Change
