title: Zimmerman Jury Pool Queried on Biases
authors: Arian Campo-Flores,Joe Palazzolo,The Wall Street Journal
description: Dow Jones Reprints: This copy is for your personal, non-commercial use only. To order presentation-ready copies for distribution to your colleagues, clients or customers, use the Order Reprints tool at the bottom of any article or visit www.djreprints.com

title: Legal Events to Watch This Week
description: This week: The trial of George Zimmerman, charged with murdering Trayvon Martin, begins in Florida. • The U.S. Supreme Court is expected to issue orders and opinions. We’re still waiting for rulings on affirmative action, gay marriage and voting rights in the 2012-13 term, which ends this month.

title: George Zimmerman's Trial Over Trayvon Martin Killing Set to Begin
authors: Arian Campo-Flores,Joe Palazzolo,The Wall Street Journal
description: The murder trial of George Zimmerman is set to begin Monday, more than a year after he shot and killed an unarmed black teenager in Sanford, Fla., triggering nationwide protests and acrimonious debate over racial profiling and self-defense laws. Curiosity-seekers, demonstrators and media from around the world are expected to descend on the Seminole County courthouse in Sanford on Monday, when jury selection is set to start.

title: How Many Times Has DOJ Secretly Requested 'Tangible Things'?
description: The chart above shows the number of applications under the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act for business records and “tangible things,” which the law defines to include “books, records, papers, documents, and other items.”Phone records, for instance, are considered tangible things. A secret order by the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court published Wednesday in the Guardian requires Verizon to provide the National Security Agency with “all call detail records” of customers.

title: Prosecutors Accuse Apple Of Helping To Drive Up E-Book Prices As Civil Trial Opens
description: Apple Inc. was the conduit for five major publishers that sought to drive up the price of electronic books as the technology company entered the market in 2010, a Justice Department lawyer told a court on Monday.

title: Prosecutors Accuse Apple of Helping to Drive Up E-Book Prices
description: Apple Inc. was the conduit for five major publishers that sought to drive up the price of electronic books as the technology company entered the market in 2010, a Justice Department lawyer told a federal court on Monday.

title: Apple goes on trial over e-book price-fixing
description: Apple Inc. heads to a U.S. federal court Monday to face civil accusations that it conspired with five publishers to drive up the price of electronic books in the weeks leading up to the 2010 introduction of the iPad. The Justice Department will try to prove during the three-week trial in Manhattan that the publishers seized on Apple’s entrance into the e-book market as an opportunity to shift from low prices set by Amazon.com Inc. to higher ones set by the publishers themselves.

title: Apple Starts E-Book Trial Monday at a Disadvantage
description: Dow Jones Reprints: This copy is for your personal, non-commercial use only. To order presentation-ready copies for distribution to your colleagues, clients or customers, use the Order Reprints tool at the bottom of any article or visit www.djreprints.com

title: Immigration Laws Put New Mexico Judge on Map
description: Dow Jones Reprints: This copy is for your personal, non-commercial use only. To order presentation-ready copies for distribution to your colleagues, clients or customers, use the Order Reprints tool at the bottom of any article or visit www.djreprints.com

title: Ex-Prosecutor Shares Tips on Getting the DOJ Off Your Back
description: Though we don’t know how often it happens, the Justice Department sometimes drops Foreign Corrupt Practices Act cases without bringing charges, even when prosecutors find potential violations of the law.

title: Legal Events to Watch This Week
description: This week: The Lehman Brothers Holding bankruptcy goes before a federal appeals court in Manhattan. • George Zimmerman will return to court for what may be his last pre-trial hearing at which a Florida judge will decide whether to admit a range of evidence. He is charged in the shooting death of Trayvon Martin during a confrontation in Sanford, Fla., last year. • The U.S. Supreme Court is expected to release opinions and orders.

title: Chief Justice, Attorney General Get Cool Swag from Foreign Dignitaries
description: The State Department’s Office of Chief of Protocol has provided a list of the goodies federal government officials received from foreign officials in 2011 and 2010. This being a legal blog, we noted with particular interest the “Soapstone bookends” (estimated value: $414.00) that the chief justice of Canada, Beverley McLachlin, gave to Chief Justice John Roberts Jr. in 2010. That year, he also received a $400 leather document box from Giorgio Napolitano, Italy’s president.

title: Luckless Law Grad Gets Loan Relief. . . 10 Years Later
description: Michael Hedlund graduated from Willamette Law School and took the Oregon bar exam in 1997. He failed. He tried again the next year and failed again. He lost his job at the district attorney’s office as a result. He got a job as a juvenile counselor in Klamath Falls, Ore., and prepared to take the test a third time. Mr. Hedlund locked his keys in his car while stopping to get coffee on the way to the exam and missed it. His goal of becoming a lawyer seemed to vanish. His loans did not.

title: A Quarterback's Lawsuit Over Videogame Likeness Renews Danger to NCAA
description: Dow Jones Reprints: This copy is for your personal, non-commercial use only. To order presentation-ready copies for distribution to your colleagues, clients or customers, use the Order Reprints tool at the bottom of any article or visit www.djreprints.com

title: Court Clears the Way for College Star's Lawsuit
description: In a ruling that is likely to reverberate through the video game industry, a federal appeals court said that Electronic Arts Inc. can be sued by a former college quarterback who alleges the game-maker stole his likeness for its popular “NCAA Football” series. The 2-1 decision by the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit on Tuesday reversed a lower court decision which decided that the depiction of college players in the video game was protected by the First Amendment right to free speech.

title: Legal Events to Watch This Week
description: This week: Former Goldman Sachs Group Inc. director Rajat Gupta will ask a federal appeals court to throw out his insider-trading conviction. • The U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit will hear arguments in the appeal of  former Goldman Sachs Group Inc. director Rajat Gupta, who was convicted last year of sharing corporate secrets. • Apple Inc. CEO Tim Cook is expected to testify at a Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigation’s hearing about the company’s tax practices.

title: Dorms Must Accept 'Emotional Support' Dogs, HUD Says
description: Housing providers must offer people with disabilities a "reasonable accommodation" for emotional support animals under both the Fair Housing Act and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1974, the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development said in a notice to its regional offices late last month. The laws apply to a range of public and private housing, including dwellings "associated with a university or other place of  education," the notice says.

title: Dorms Must Accept 'Emotional Support' Dogs, HUD Says
description: By Joe Palazzolo May 16, 2013 1:31 pm ET Angie, a certified therapy dog, helps students cope with stress during final exams at the University at Buffalo. Associated Press College freshman suffering from separation anxiety, take heart: The federal government says universities have an obligation to admit "emotional support" animals into school housing.

title: Judiciary Asks White House for Emergency Funds
description: The federal judiciary has requested emergency funds from the White House that court officials say are needed to avoid debilitating staff cuts and to cover the legal defense of the Boston Marathon bombings suspect, among others. Courts officials asked for about $73 million in a May 14 letter to the director of the White House Office of Management and Budget, citing “critical needs” resulting from federal budget cuts known as sequestration.

title: Judge: Names in Swartz Case Will Remain Under Seal
description: A federal judge has rejected a request by the family of Aaron Swartz to release the names of those involved in his arrest and federal prosecution. The family pressed for public access to the names after the internet activist’s January suicide, which prompted criticism of the Justice Department for what some viewed as an overzealous prosecution, as well as scrutiny of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where Mr. Swartz was alleged to have committed his crimes.

title: Legal Events to Watch This Week
description: This week: Lawyers for James Holmes, the suspect in the deadly Colorado movie theater shootings, seek to adjust his plea to not guilty by reason of insanity. • Lawyers for James Holmes, accused of killing 12 people last year in an Aurora, Colo., movie-theater rampage, will ask a judge to change his plea from not guilty to not guilty by reason of insanity.

title: You Have the Right to Brew
description: By Joe PalazzoloAssociated PressYou don’t have the right to marry your cousin in all 50 states. Or to wear fake mustaches in church. But suds aficionados may soon be able to brew beer legally in any home in the U.S.The Alabama Legislature voted Tuesday night to lift its prohibition on home brewing. The state is the last in the nation to ban the practice. Gov. Robert Bentley is expected to sign the bill, according to NPR.

title: Legal Events to Watch This Week
description: By Joe PalazzoloAssociated PressTamerlan Tsarnaev, 26, left, and Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, 19This week: The House Homeland Security Committee holds a hearing on the Boston bombings. Monday, May 6• A federal judge in Manhattan will sentence Manssor Arbabsiar, a Texas man who admitted to plotting to kill Saudi Arabia’s ambassador to the United States. Mr. Arbabsiar, 57, pleaded guilty in October to two conspiracy charges and a murder-for-hire count. Prosecutors are seeking a prison term of 25 years.

title: AB InBev Deal With Grupo Modelo Gives Software a Boost
description: Cases involving large companies often require legal counsel to sift through millions of electronic documents. In the past decade, that task has typically fallen on armies of contract, or temporary, lawyers who earn $25 to $40 an hour. Industry experts peg the cost for clients at more than $1 per document.

title: Appeals Court Won’t Re-examine Ban on Gun Sales to People Under 21
description: By Joe PalazzoloGetty ImagesBy a razor-thin margin, a federal appeals court voted to leave undisturbed a ruling upholding a federal law that prohibits people under the age of 21 from purchasing handguns from dealers. The U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, based in New Orleans, voted 8-7 not to rehear the case, according to a Tuesday court filing. In October, a three-judge panel of the Fifth Circuit unanimously ruled that the age restriction, which dates back to 1968. . . . . .

title: The Lawyer, the Wig and the Wardrobe
description: By Joe PalazzoloReutersJudges wearing wigs attend a ceremony to mark the beginning of the new legal year in Hong Kong on Jan. 9, 2012. American lawyers are often curious about the fussier aspects of the British legal system. Wigs, for instance. Who would want to wear horse hair, except maybe to a Constitutional Convention theme party? (Which would be awesome, by the way.)In Hong Kong, a former British colony, the argument is flipped. Who wouldn’t want to wear a white wig?

title: GE Capital cuts off lending to gun shops
description: Want to see how this story relates to your portfolio? Just add items to create a portfolio now: By Joe Palazzolo and Kate Linebaugh General Electric Co. is quietly cutting off lending to gun shops, as the company rethinks its relationship to firearms amid the fallout from the school shooting in Newtown, Conn.

title: GE Capital Cuts Off Lending to Gun Shops
description: Email Newsletters and AlertsThe latest news and analysis delivered to your in-box. Check the boxes below to sign up.

title: Watchdog: Gun Dealers Avoid Regular Inspection
description: By Joe PalazzoloMost licensed gun dealers go more than five years at a time without an inspection by federal authorities, according to a new report by the Justice Department’s watchdog. The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives failed to check 58% of the nation’s 125,481 gun dealers for compliance with firearms laws within that time frame, the report by the office of Inspector General Michael E. Horowitz said, citing a lack of resources at the agency.

title: Legal Events to Watch This Week
description: By Joe PalazzoloAssociated PressSen. Marco Rubio ( R., Fla.) flanked by Sen. Charles Schumer (D., N.Y.), left, and Sen. John McCain (R., Ariz.), discusses immigration legislation by the Senate’s bipartisan “Gang of Eight.”This week: The Senate Judiciary Committee continues its hearings on an immigration bill that would increase border security and create a path to citizenship for an estimated 11 million people living in the U.S. illegally.

title: Pro-Gun Laws Gain Ground
authors: Jack Nicas,Joe Palazzolo,The Wall Street Journal
description: Those laws, along with the long odds for major federal gun-control legislation, show how the march toward expanded gun rights in recent years has hardly slowed since Mr. Obama pledged to use the "full force" of his office to tighten limits after 20 children and six adult staffers were killed at an elementary school in Newtown, Conn.

title: Cities' Gun Laws Hit Roadblock at State Level
authors: Joe Palazzolo,Ashby Jones,Patrick O'Connor,The Wall Street Journal
description: TUCSON, Ariz.—This city, the site of the 2011 mass shooting that nearly killed former Rep. Gabrielle Giffords and sparked a national debate on gun control, is proving how tough it can be for localities to enact new firearms restrictions. The Tucson City Council advanced a measure on Tuesday that would require background checks on the sale of all guns on city property, an attempt to regulate firearms sales at gun shows held at the Tucson Convention Center.

title: US Attorney Statement on the Prosecution of Aaron Swartz
description: The U.S. attorney for Massachusetts, Carmen Ortiz, issued a statement late Wednesday on the prosecution of Internet activist Aaron Swartz, whose suicide last week set off a wave of criticism of her office. January 16, 2013 STATEMENT OF UNITED STATES ATTORNEY CARMEN M. ORTIZ REGARDING THE DEATH OF AARON SWARTZAs a parent and a sister, I can only imagine the pain felt by the family and friends of Aaron Swartz, and I want to extend my heartfelt sympathy to everyone who knew and loved this young man.

title: Quirky Law School Electives Questioned
authors: Susannah Moran,Joe Palazzolo,The Wall Street Journal
description: Students taking Charles Halpern's class at the University of California, Berkeley, start with the ancient Chinese practice of Qi Gong. Standing in the university grounds under towering redwoods and breathing deeply, they are earning credits toward their law degree.

title: Don’t Instagram Your Ballot…You Could Be Breaking the Law
description: Photo courtesy of Instagram By Joe Palazzolo Nov. 6, 2012 3:16 pm ET Our sister site, All Things Digital, has some news you can use. Some states -- Florida, Georgia, Kentucky, Michigan, Nevada and Texas, among them -- prohibit the use of cameras in polling places. In other states, like North Carolina, it's illegal to take pictures of completed ballots. Check your state's laws at the Citizen Media Law Project.

title: Sixth Circuit: Michigan Can Ban Anti-Islam Ads from Buses
description: The group behind the ads is the the American Freedom Defense Initiative, which describes its mission as acting "against the treason being committed by national, state, and local government officials, the mainstream media, and others in their capitulation to the global jihad and Islamic supremacism." The group had sought in 2010 to place the ads on the buses in Michigan’s four southeastern-most counties, but the authority refused, on the grounds that the ads violated a policy against political...

title: Legal Events to Watch This Week
description: Oct 22, 2012 10:32 am ET Bloomberg NewsRajat Gupta, former Goldman Sachs Inc. director and former senior partner at McKinsey & Co., is followed by his lawyer Gary Naftalis as he exits federal court in New York in June. Election Day is near. Congress is out of town. And the Supreme Court isn’t hearing arguments this week. But all is not quiet in the legal world. On Wednesday, a federal judge in New York will sentence former Goldman Sachs director Raj Gupta on insider-trading charges.

title: A New Type of Opinion Is Christened in the Ninth Circuit
description: The U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, sitting en banc, issued a hopelessly split decision in an immigration case on Friday. The Ninth Circuit’s chief judge, the colorful Alex Kozinski, distinguished himself, as usual. Here’s how each opinion began, starting with Judge Jay Bybee’s lead opinion.

title: The Infield Fly Rule and the Law
description: Bottles and cups are seen on the field after they were thrown by fans after the home fans disagree with the infield fly ruling. Getty Images By Joe Palazzolo Oct. 8, 2012 11:07 am ET On Friday, members of LB nation, or at least those baseball fans among us, may have fondly recalled the late William S.

title: Obama Planned to Put Bin Laden on Trial in Civilian Court
description: What if Osama bin Laden had been captured alive? Would he have been shipped to Guantanamo, held overseas indefinitely, tried in a military commission? In the unlikely event that bin Laden surrendered in the 2011 SEAL raid on his hideout, President Barack Obama was prepared to put the al Qaeda leader on trial. That’s what he told author Mark Bowden, for his new book, The Finish. Vanity Fair, which will carry a piece adapted from the book in its November issue, has posted a few highlights.

title: Poll: Most Americans Support Limits on Political Spending
description: DOW JONES, A NEWS CORP COMPANY Home World U.S. Politics Economy Business Tech Markets Opinion Life & Arts Real Estate WSJ.

title: Sixth Circuit: No Expectation of Privacy in Cell Phone GPS Data
description: Drug dealers, beware. Your pay-as-you-go phones probably have GPS. And, according to a federal appeals court in Cincinnati, police can track the signal they emit without a warrant. The U.S. Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit ruled that the Drug Enforcement Administration committed no Fourth Amendment violation in using a drug runner’s cellphone data to track his whereabouts.

title: Judge: There's No First Amendment Right to a Jigsaw Puzzle
description: A good illustration of the rippling boredom that fills a federal prison sentence: Inmates are willing to go to court for a jigsaw puzzle. Lawyer Alan Berkun, who is serving six years in a Miami federal prison for stock fraud, asked his warden for permission to receive a puzzle purchased on Amazon.com. When his request was denied last year, he petitioned a federal judge in Brooklyn, arguing that he had a First Amendment right to, um, jigsaw. Copyright ©2023 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

title: Cyberthieves Hit Small-Business Owners
description: Small-business owners whose bank accounts have been plundered by cyberthieves until recently had no one to blame but themselves. But two recent court rulings are giving those business owners new hope that banks which don't cater to their specific security needs may be held liable for funds stolen by hackers who increasingly have focused on attacking small businesses. Banks typically are responsible for losses when personal accounts are hacked.

title: SCOTUS Springs a Leak (or Several)
description: Getty ImagesSupreme Court Chief Justice John Roberts in 2005The secrecy surrounding Supreme Court deliberations is such that two respectable news outlets can carry stories that don’t agree, and the world may never see a correction. As it stands, we have competing narratives — one from CBS’s Jan Crawford and another from law professor Paul Campos, writing for Salon — about the events leading up to court’s announcement of the health-care ruling.

title: Law Grads Face a Brutal Job Market
description: Members of the law-school class of 2011 had little better than a 50-50 shot of landing a job as a lawyer within nine months of receiving a degree, according to a Wall Street Journal analysis of new data that provides the most detailed picture yet of the grim market for law jobs. Under pressure from disillusioned graduates and some professors, the American Bar Association for the first time released a tally of the previous year's graduates who have secured full-time, permanent jobs as lawyers.

title: Daily Writing Sample: ‘That 1956 Mercury Coupe’
description: Judge Neil Gorsuch of the 10th Circuit Court of Appeals has proven, once again, that there are no mundane legal cases, only mundane legal writers. In most appeals courts, today’s feature case would have ended with a perfunctory ruling, but Judge Gosuch seized the opportunity to tell a quick story to tell about father and son. From an opinion Monday (citations omitted):That 1956 Mercury coupe must be quite a car. Back in 1996, Herbert Buckland made a gift of it to his son, Douglas.

title: Which Federal Appeals Court Cites Wikipedia Most Often?
description: On Friday, the Richmond-based U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit tossed out convictions in a cockfighting case — because a juror used Wikipedia to research an element of the crime. The Fourth Circuit, in arriving at its decision, expressed concerns about Wikipedia’s reliability, given its “open-access nature.”In the opinion, Judge Barbara Milano Keenan rattled off several cases in which federal judges admonished immigration judges or lawyers for citing Wikipedia.

title: So Sirious: iPhone User Sues Apple over Voice-Activated Assistant
description: March 12, 2012 2:55 pm ET Siri, the iPhone 4S's deadpan voice-activated assistant, is imperfect. She's stumped easily. Her command of English is only so so. In the U.K., she's a man. But is Siri a fraud? A New York man represented by Robbins Geller is suing Apple for false advertising, alleging that the company's commercials convey a "misleading and deceptive message" about Siri's capabilities. Resume Subscription We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: UFC Wants To Express Itself In New York
description: Zuffa LLC, which owns the UFC, filed a lawsuit Tuesday in U.S. district court against New York Attorney General Eric Schneiderman and Manhattan District Attorney Cyrus Vance Jr. seeking a declaration that the ban violates the First Amendment. Spokesmen for Schneiderman and Vance declined to comment.

title: The AM Roundup: Foreclosure Flap, Bad Plea Advice, More
description: Photos of the party ran online with a New York Times column about Steven J. Baum PC and included people dressed to look homeless, with one of them holding a sign with a foreclosure-related message; a corner of the office decorated like foreclosed homes; and a sign reading "Baum Estates." Buffalo NewsSCOTUS previews: The Supreme Court this week will revisit the issue of prosecutorial misconduct.

title: State Dept. Lifts Sanctions On Israeli Company That Wasn’t
description: In June, we noted the curious case of Ofer Brothers Group, an Israeli company sanctioned by the State Department for alleged trade with Iran. The sanctions roiled in Israel, where the Ofer family -- among the country's wealthiest -- was branded by some as traitorous. Brothers Sammy and Yuli Ofer, the heads of the Ofer empire, have both died since the sanctions were announced on May 24.

title: Lauren Boebert Tries to Convince New District She’s Not All Drama
description: KIOWA, Colo.—Campaign swag for one of the nation’s most visible and controversial members of Congress has long declared, “This is Boebert Country.”Now, as the congresswoman runs for election in a new district on the opposite side of the state, voters are scrutinizing whether she belongs in their country.

title: What to Know About ‘Significant Failure’ Described in Uvalde Massacre Report

Uvalde Massacre Response Failed at Every Point, Says New Federal Report
Uvalde Massacre Response Failed at Every Point, Says New Federal Report
authors: Elizabeth Findell,Sadie Gurman,The Wall Street Journal
description: UVALDE, Texas—Every aspect of the law-enforcement response to the Robb Elementary shooting and official handling afterward was disorganized, chaotic and ultimately marked by failure, the Justice Department said Thursday in a report.

title: U.S. Claims Texas Is Blocking Border Patrol From Busy Migrant Crossing Area
U.S. Claims Texas Is Blocking Border Patrol From Busy Migrant Crossing Area
description: Texas state officials are blocking federal Border Patrol agents from accessing a busy section of the U.S.-Mexico border, the federal government has alleged in a new legal filing, a move that represents an escalation of a standoff between Texas Gov. Greg Abbott, a Republican, and the Biden administration on authority over the U.S.-Mexico border.

title: This West Texas Outpost Was Remote. Then Airbnb and Instagram Found It.
authors: Elizabeth Findell,Paul Ratje,The Wall Street Journal
description: For decades, Terlingua, a quirky cluster of trailers, hippies and a ghost town, was a lonesome one, in a remote corner of Texas near the Mexico border, on the outskirts of one of the country’s least-visited national parks. Now, the glass of scores of shiny new casitas glitters against rust-brown mountains. Rental villages of tepees, domes, A-frames and shipping containers sprawl across scrub-brush hillsides.

title: U.S. Sues Texas Over Migrant-Arrest Law
description: The suit argues that the Texas law is pre-empted by federal law and asks that it be invalidated and blocked from taking effect. Abbott signed the bill last month, and it is set to take effect in March. “Biden sued me today because I signed a law making it illegal for an illegal immigrant to enter or attempt to enter Texas directly from a foreign nation,” Abbott posted Wednesday night on X, formerly known as Twitter.

title: Biden Administration Asks Supreme Court to Allow Border Patrol to Cut Texas Razor Wire
authors: Jess Bravin,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: In court papers, U.S. Solicitor General Elizabeth Prelogar argued that Congress had given the Border Patrol extensive power to enforce immigration law within 25 miles of the border, including the right to enter private property without a warrant. State governments, she wrote, have no power to displace federal authority the Constitution commits to Washington.

title: Austin Police Officer Is Charged in Killing of Tech Entrepreneur
Austin Police Officer Is Charged in Killing of Tech Entrepreneur
description: A Travis County grand jury Tuesday issued a one-count indictment against Sanchez, District Attorney José Garza said Wednesday in a news release. Austin Police Association President-elect Michael Bullock called the indictment disappointing and said Sanchez acted as he was trained to respond upon hearing gunfire in a neighborhood. Sanchez remains an officer with the department and is on administrative duty, Bullock said. Moonesinghe’s family didn’t immediately return messages for comment.

title: New Law Gives Texas Power to Arrest, Deport Migrants
New Law Gives Texas Power to Arrest, Deport Migrants
description: Texas is set to begin arresting and potentially deporting migrants under a bill Gov. Greg Abbott signed into law Monday, escalating the state’s conflict with the federal government over authority of the U.S. border. The measure, a priority the Republican governor pushed during a special legislative session last month, makes it a state crime for anyone without authorization to be in the U.S. to cross into the country outside of a designated port of entry.

title: New Law Gives Texas Power to Arrest, Deport Migrants
description: The law will allow state and local police to arrest people suspected of such crossings, if they are also suspected of being in the country illegally. Local judges could then order removal of migrants who prefer that to prosecution. The U.S. Department of Justice didn’t immediately say how it plans to respond to the measure, but the American Civil Liberties Union has vowed to challenge it.

title: Austin Tried to Reform Its Policing. Three Years Later, No One Is Happy.
description: Your browser does not support the audio tag. 00:00 / 00:00This article is in your queue. AUSTIN, Texas— In the wake of 2020 social justice protests in the Texas capital, where police officers injured dozens by firing beanbag munitions into crowds, a liberal new district attorney vowed change.  José Garza, elected after the protests on a platform of holding police officers accountable, indicted more than 20 of the officers involved in the protests—an action unlike anywhere else in the nation.

title: Texas Ordered to Remove Buoy Barrier at Southern Border
authors: Alicia A. Caldwell,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: In a September ruling that was later put on hold pending this appeal, U.S. District Judge David Ezra, a Reagan appointee, ordered state officials not to expand the barrier and remove it from the water. Texas authorities installed the string of orange buoys anchored by concrete blocks in the river near Eagle Pass, Texas, in July as part of the state’s broader “Operation Lone Star” border enforcement effort.

title: FBI Arrests Woman Accused of Sending Violent Threats to Uvalde School, Residents
description: Federal officials this week arrested a young woman claiming to be the ex-girlfriend of a gunman who killed 21 people at a Uvalde, Texas, elementary school, after officials say she spent years sending violent threats to the school and others in the community. Victoria Gabriela Rodriguez-Morales, a 19-year-old former resident of Uvalde, was arrested in Puerto Rico on Tuesday and charged with making interstate threats, according to court records.

title: In Texas, Rural School Districts Have Helped Kill School Choice Bills
authors: Elizabeth Findell,Emil Lippe,The Wall Street Journal
description: The opposition to voucher bills in rural, conservative areas comes even though those school districts are unlikely to lose many students to private schools. Rather, districts say any system set up to shift money to private schools eventually will harm all districts, and it is the smallest districts with the thinnest budgets that will feel it most.

title: Texas Bill Gives State Power to Arrest and Deport Migrants
description: AUSTIN, Texas—A bill approved by Texas lawmakers Tuesday will allow the state to begin arresting, jailing and in some cases deporting migrants who cross the U.S.-Mexico border illegally—an unprecedented escalation of the state’s challenge of federal immigration authority.

title: In Texas, Key Opposition to School Vouchers Is Rural and Red
description: CUSHING, Texas—The word spread parent-to-parent during a Little Dribblers basketball game in the school gymnasium. The superintendent had sent emails—several—warning that school-choice efforts under way wouldn’t be good for their East Texas school district of 554 students. The target of Superintendent Brandon Enos’s advocacy was a special session of the Texas Legislature called by Republican Gov.

title: ‘It’s Time to Move On’-Uvalde Mother Loses Mayoral Bid
description: UVALDE, Texas—A year and a half after her daughter was killed in a South Texas classroom massacre, it wasn’t losing a bid for mayor that bothered Kimberly Mata-Rubio. It was a fear that nothing in Uvalde would change. “I’m nervous,” she said. “I don’t want people to forget what happened here.”Tuesday’s mayoral election returned a familiar face to his former post—Cody Smith, senior vice president of First State Bank of Uvalde, who served as mayor from 2008 to 2012.

title: Slow-Boil Refugee Crisis Takes Toll Even in Germany
description: GIESSEN, Germany—The refugee crisis that shook Europe almost 10 years ago never really ended in Germany. Now the country is struggling to cope. More than 322,000 migrants requested asylum here last year, according to the United Nations, numbers second only to the U.S. globally. Germany receives nearly half as many asylum requests as the U.S. despite having just a quarter of the U.S. population and less than 4% of its landmass.

title: Once Inoculated by Its Nazi Past, Germany Is Becoming a Far-Right Stronghold
description: GÖRLITZ, Germany—As evening fell on a recent Monday in this eastern German city of Gothic spires and Renaissance museums, hundreds of protesters began to gather, just as they have nearly every Monday for at least two years. They carried banners calling for Germany to leave the European Union and cheered speakers who demanded that the nearby border with Poland be shut. They are angry about migrants settling in their communities and inflation squeezing their pensions.

title: Texas Trooper's Email Describes Migrant Injuries at Southern Border
description: AUSTIN, Texas—Texas state police troopers and National Guard members patrolling the border with Mexico were ordered to deny water to people at a time when temperatures surpassed 100 degrees, to push an exhausted mother with a nursing baby into the Rio Grande and to prevent a preschooler near razor wire from getting to shore, according to an email from a trooper airing his concerns to his superior.

title: Texas Trooper's Email Describes Migrant Injuries at Southern Border
description: AUSTIN, Texas—Texas state police troopers patrolling the border with Mexico were ordered to deny water to people in over-100 degree heat and to push exhausted mothers with nursing babies into the Rio Grande, according to an email from a trooper airing his concerns to his superior. The email, which was reviewed by The Wall Street Journal, contained allegations of severe injuries to migrants by razor wire that state authorities have placed in the river.

title: El Paso Walmart Mass Shooter to Be Sentenced
description: Nearly four years after a racist rampage in a Texas border Walmart, the gunman who killed 23 people and wounded 22 more is set to be sentenced in coming days for federal hate crimes. Authorities said Patrick Crusius, then 21 years old, traveled from his home near Dallas to the largely Hispanic city of El Paso to kill people in response to what he called “the Hispanic invasion of Texas.” The Aug. 3, 2019, attack was among the nation’s deadliest mass shootings.

title: El Paso Walmart Mass Shooter to Be Sentenced
description: In a courtroom sketch, Patrick Crusius, in black T-shirt, appeared in federal court in El Paso, Texas, in February. title: Men Charged in Deadly Smuggling Knew Truck’s AC Was Broken, Prosecutors Allege
description: A vigil was held last year to honor the victims. Smugglers knew the air conditioning wasn’t working in a tractor trailer where 53 migrants died trapped in the South Texas heat last year, according to charges against four additional men announced on the one-year anniversary of the tragedy.

title: Donor Connected to Texas AG Paxton Impeachment Is Charged
description: George Santos has in recent months become an outspoken supporter of Chinese billionaire Guo Wengui, who was arrested in March and is accused by prosecutors of leading a "complex conspiracy to defraud thousands of his online followers out of over $1 billion dollars." The House Republican was himself arrested last month and charged with 13 counts, including money laundering, wire fraud and the misuse of public funds, all of which he denies.

authors: Elizabeth Findell,Mark Maremont,The Wall Street Journal

AUSTIN, Texas—A Houston lawyer defending Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton in his impeachment proceedings flashed up a bank statement at a press conference Wednesday, intended to disprove allegations that a Paxton donor had paid for extensive renovations at the politician’s Austin home.

title: With Psych Wards Full, Mentally Ill Accused of Crimes Languish in Jail
description: Week after week, Barbara Vassis watches as her daughter sinks deeper into a delusional world while sitting in a Boulder, Colo., jail cell. Vassis can still picture Erin Brown as a gifted artist and chef who bubbled with energy. But last summer the 32-year-old, who had long battled schizoaffective disorder and struggled with meth addiction, was charged with breaking into her mother’s home. Vassis said her daughter stole tools, electronics and other valuables, as well as her pickup truck.

title: Rural America Grows Weary of Waiting for Its Mail
description: Silverthorne, Colo., has reported mail-delivery delays of weeks or months. CRESTED BUTTE, Colo.—Residents of this small mountain town used to get their mail without incident, they said. A few years ago, something changed. Now, those who live in the ski community of 1,600, which has no home delivery of either mail or parcels, say they must wait in line for up to an hour during midday to pick up any package.

title: Rival Colorado Towns Fight Over Frozen Dead Guy…
description: NEDERLAND, Colo.—For more than 20 years, the tiny mountain town of Nederland has enjoyed a macabre claim to fame: a cryogenically immortalized grandfather lying under dry ice in a shed. The annual celebration that honors him, Frozen Dead Guy Days, drew tens of thousands of revelers from around the world. Now Nederland has lost the festival to its more-touristy neighbor, Estes Park. And Grandpa Bredo, as the frozen man is known, appears set to follow.

title: Ohio Train Derailment Contamination Fears Spread Beyond East Palestine
description: Weeks after a train derailment near the Ohio-Pennsylvania border left hazardous chemicals burning from railcars, fears of the potential impacts are being felt in places far from the accident. title: Texas Begins Arresting Migrant Women After Courts Toss Cases Against Men
description: Attorneys have challenged Gov. Greg Abbott’s Operation Lone Star on equal protection grounds; the operation has jailed more than 8,600 menAUSTIN, Texas—Operation Lone Star, the Texas program to exert more control over the border by arresting migrants on state charges, has jailed more than 8,600 men since it started in 2021. Within the past few months, a couple dozen women have begun to join them.

title: El Paso Shooting Came After ‘Random’ Confrontation, Police Chief Says
authors: Elizabeth Findell,Adolfo Flores,The Wall Street Journal
description: Two arrested following incident at mall near location of 2019 Walmart mass shootingBy Elizabeth Findell and Adolfo FloresFeb. 16, 2023 4:45 pm ETThe shooting that killed one and injured three at an El Paso, Texas, mall Wednesday evening, steps from the Walmart where an attacker killed 23 people in 2019, was the result of a random confrontation between two groups who didn’t know each other, the city’s police chief said.

title: Shooting Rattles El Paso Mall Next to Scene of 2019 Rampage
description: One person was killed and three were wounded in a shooting at El Paso’s Cielo Vista Mall Wednesday evening—steps away from the Walmart where an attacker killed 23 people in 2019. Police in the West Texas border city said reports of an active shooter near the mall’s food court came in at 5:05 p.m. local time. An off-duty officer at the mall was at the scene of the shooting within three minutes and detained one suspect, Interim Police Chief Peter Pacillas said.

title: Shooting Rattles El Paso Mall Next to Scene of 2019 Rampage
description: Law enforcement members gather outside the Cielo Vista Mall in El Paso, Texas. One person was killed and three were wounded in a shooting at El Paso’s Cielo Vista Mall Wednesday evening—steps away from the Walmart where an attacker killed 23 people in 2019. Police in the West Texas border city said reports of an active shooter near the mall’s food court came in around 5:10 local time. One suspect was in police custody as police searched for a possible second suspect, said Sgt.

title: Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton Reaches $3.3 Million Whistleblower Settlement
description: Former employees said in a lawsuit that Ken Paxton used his office to stymie an FBI probeAUSTIN, Texas—Texas taxpayers will pay $3.3 million to whistleblowers who reported alleged wrongdoing by their boss, Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton, to law enforcement, under the terms of a mediated settlement agreement filed Friday. The settlement is contingent upon the funds being approved through the Texas Legislature, attorneys said.

title: Texas Inmates Wage Hunger Strikes to Protest Solitary Confinement
description: More than 500 Texas inmates have spent a decade housed aloneFor 17 years, Guadalupe Constante has been alone in a 5-foot-by-9-foot cell, spending hours at a time pacing the small space, he said. The 44-year-old, who is midway through a 35-year sentence for aggravated robbery, is one of the Texas state prisoners held in solitary confinement because of membership in prison gangs. Last month, he and dozens of others stopped eating.

title: Walmart Mass-Shooting Suspect Pleads Guilty to Federal Hate Crimes
description: The Walmart in El Paso, Texas, became home to a makeshift memorial to victims after the killings. The man accused of killing 23 people and wounding 22 more in a racist attack on an El Paso, Texas, Walmart in 2019 pleaded guilty to federal hate crimes charges Wednesday.

title: Suspect Arrested in Dallas Zoo Missing Monkeys Case
description: Davion Irvin faces six animal cruelty counts after two emperor tamarin monkeys found in house in Dallas suburbPolice arrested a man Thursday accused of involvement with the case of two emperor tamarin monkeys that went missing from the Dallas Zoo earlier this week. Davion Irvin, 24, is accused of six counts of animal cruelty not involving livestock, according to a news release.

title: Covid Emergency Orders Live On in Some States, as Biden Winds Down Federal Declarations
description: Governors in eight states have retained emergency powers related to the Covid-19 pandemic, three years after the emergence of the virus. California, Texas, Rhode Island, Delaware, Illinois and New Mexico still have governor-issued Covid emergency or disaster orders in place, which they have continued to renew over the past three years.

title: Alec Baldwin ‘Rust’ Manslaughter Charges Put Spotlight on First-Term Prosecutor
authors: Elizabeth Findell,Katherine Sayre,The Wall Street Journal
description: Before taking office two years ago, Santa Fe District Attorney Mary Carmack-Altwies vowed to target the community’s worst criminal offenders, increase crime diversion programs, build trust with immigrant families, address a rape-kit backlog and crack down on gun crime. She will likely become best known as the woman who prosecuted Alec Baldwin.

title: Rio Grande Water Deal Between Texas and New Mexico Is Opposed by U.S.
description: A decadelong battle between Texas and New Mexico over the future of the water in the Rio Grande might have an end in sight. But the proposed resolution has opponents that include the U.S.A settlement to be considered by the U.S. Supreme Court outlines a new system for managing the division of water between Texas and New Mexico, assuaging objections lodged by New Mexico that Texas was taking more than its share and Texas’ concerns that water measurements were being taken far above its border.

title: 米メキシコ国境コンテナの「壁」 撤去か継続か
description: アリゾナ州は米政府の法的措置を受け、輸送用コンテナの壁を撤去することに同意した Photo: Ross D.

title: U.S. Appeals Sutherland Springs Mass Shooting Verdict
description: U.S. Air Force officials had failed to add the shooter in the 2017 Sutherland Springs shooting to a database that would have prevented him from buying the gun he used in the attack. The U.S. is fighting a court finding that it was largely responsible for a 2017 mass shooting at a church in Sutherland Springs, Texas. A judge in 2021 found that the U.S. Air Force was mostly responsible for the rampage, which killed 26 people and injured 22.

title: Border Wall Made of Shipping Containers Comes Down in Arizona, Rises in Texas
description: Arizona has agreed to dismantle a barrier made of shipping containers after a challenge from the U.S. government. Texas has erected a barrier made of shipping containers along parts of the U.S.-Mexico border, following a similar move by Arizona, which has begun dismantling its makeshift wall after legal threats from the federal government.

title: In Texas, Nothing Says Christmas Like Tamales
description: SAN JUAN, Texas—Preorders for Christmas tamales begin in July at Delia’s, a South Texas chain with a fervent regional following. By mid-December, constables must be on hand to direct lines of cars stretching down the street to get into restaurants. On a recent morning at Delia’s San Juan location, Gabriel Murillo, an IT manager for the local school district, was picking up a cooler with more than a thousand tamales to be served at a holiday staff appreciation luncheon.

title: Entrepreneur’s Death at Hands of Austin Police Prompts Calls for Change
description: AUSTIN, Texas—Rajan Moonesinghe thought there was someone in his house. Mr. Moonesinghe, a 33-year-old tech entrepreneur known as Raj, grabbed a rifle. He told a neighbor there was an intruder and he was going to call 911. Across the street, a private security guard for his neighbor, a technology chief executive, was watching. Within minutes, police would shoot and kill Mr. Moonesinghe on the front porch of his home in an affluent South Austin neighborhood. His Nov.

title: Embattled El Paso District Attorney Yvonne Rosales Resigns
authors: Adolfo Flores,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: The Walmart shooting that the El Paso County, Texas, district attorney’s office is charged with prosecuting is among the deadliest mass shootings in American history. Yvonne Rosales, the El Paso County, Texas, district attorney, resigned Monday amid allegations of mishandling cases and growing efforts to remove her from office.

title: El Paso District Attorney Facing Possible Suspension, Removal
description: “It is unclear who is running the office,” El Paso County Attorney Jo Anne Bernal, an elected Democrat, wrote in an amended petition for removal Monday. Ms. Rosales didn’t respond to requests for comment. She has previously characterized the allegations against her as the work of “a cabal of power brokers and politicians” who supported her opponent in her election.

title: In Lauren Boebert’s Colorado District, Some Voters Grow Tired of Trump-Style Politics
description: PALISADE, Colo.—Bill Heller, a retired oil-field worker on Colorado’s Western Slope and lifelong registered Republican, said he would like to support his party but found he couldn’t vote to re-elect his congresswoman, Rep. Lauren Boebert.

title: Few State Governor Races Result in Change of Control
authors: Elizabeth Findell,Jimmy Vielkind,The Wall Street Journal
description: Democrats also prevailed in the only two states to flip, Maryland and Massachusetts. One of the most hotly contested races in the nation was in Wisconsin, where incumbent Democrat Tony Evers fended off Republican businessman Tim Michels, the AP projected. Mr. Evers ran on a platform of investing in education and infrastructure, opposing gerrymandering and supporting abortion access, while Mr. Michels said he would do more to fight crime and touted his support from former President Donald Trump.

title: Democrats Make Gains in Statehouses, a GOP-Led Territory
authors: Jimmy Vielkind,Jon Kamp,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: Democrats gained ground in state legislatures in the upper Midwest while also adding to their ranks of states in which they maintain control over all branches of government, though Republicans maintained their overall statehouse advantage, early election results show. Key flips for Democrats included both legislative chambers in Michigan and the Senate in Minnesota, according to the nonpartisan National Conference of State Legislatures.

title: Voters to Pick Governors in 36 States, With Many Democrats on Defense
authors: Jimmy Vielkind,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: Voters in three dozen states will choose new governors Tuesday in contests that could bring the number of states led by each party closer—or expand Republicans’ advantage. Most of the nation’s tightest races feature Democratic incumbents on defense, including in Kansas, Nevada and Wisconsin. Those elections are considered tossups by the nonpartisan Cook Political Report, as are the ones to succeed GOP Gov. Doug Ducey in Arizona and Democratic Gov.

title: Rapper Takeoff of Popular Trio Migos Killed in Houston
description: Houston police declined to immediately confirm that Mr. Ball was a victim of the shooting, which occurred at about 2:30 a.m. Tuesday, after a private party at 810 Billiards and Bowling in the city’s downtown. In addition to the victim found dead at the scene, two others were taken in private vehicles to hospitals, police said. No arrests have been announced.

title: In Kansas Governor Race, Even the Democrat Touts Ties to Donald Trump
description: TOPEKA, Kan.—One of the nation’s tightest gubernatorial races is taking place in Kansas, where the incumbent Democrat is focusing on her record against a Republican trying to tie her to President Biden. To win re-election in a state where Donald Trump beat Joe Biden 56% to 41% in 2020, Gov. Laura Kelly is attempting to replicate the coalition of voters she drew four years ago that included Democrats, independents and a slice of defector Republicans.

title: Texas State Trooper Who Responded to Uvalde Shooting Fired
authors: Elizabeth Findell,Ginger Adams Otis,The Wall Street Journal
description: The Uvalde school police force has been widely criticized for its role leading the response to the mass shooting at Robb Elementary School. A Texas state trooper who was among the responding officers to the elementary-school mass shooting in Uvalde was fired Friday, the Texas Department of Public Safety said. Sgt. Juan Maldonado was served with termination papers, a spokesperson for the agency said.

title: WSJ: Ameerika odavaid hotelle kummitab kummaline klient
description: Montana motelliomanik sai paari aasta eest töö juurest kentsaka kõne. Toas 206 olevat roosipilt – tühine trükileht 1990ndate keskelt – punnsilmse kopra fooni omandanud. The Wall Street JournalWSJ: Ameerika odavaid hotelle kummitab kummaline klientThe Wall Street JournalWSJ: Venemaa avalik arvamus Ukraina sõjast halvenebThe Wall Street JournalWSJ: Miks intressid tõusevad kõikjal, sinu säästukonto välja arvatudThe Wall Street JournalWSJ: Kellega sa tegelikult lendad?

title: The Strange Guest Budget Hotels Are Talking About
description: Intrigued, Mr. Burton googled the name scrawled on the back of the picture, and by lunchtime had figured out what happened. Far from being angry, he was delighted. He had been hit by an artist known as T Bang, who has a signature caper: Painting over stodgy hotel room artwork with his own whimsical work. Mr. Burton paid some $600 to have the doctored painting reframed with professional art glass and added a plaque with the artist’s name, room number and the date of the work.

title: Political Feud Mires Case Against Alleged Mass Shooter at Walmart in El Paso
description: The district attorney’s office filed a response to the report Tuesday, calling the report biased and alleging that the evidence contained within it, including audio recordings, were improperly submitted. Ms. Rosales didn’t respond to requests for comment, and Judge Medrano said he was prohibited from commenting. The allegations in the report are the latest twist in a political feud that has emerged around one of the most high-profile criminal cases in Texas history. The Aug.

title: Uvalde, Texas, School Police Department Suspended
description: The Uvalde, Texas, school district is suspending its entire police force, more than four months after a shooting at Robb Elementary School that killed 19 fourth-graders and two teachers. “The District has made the decision to suspend all activities of the Uvalde CISD Police Department for a period of time,” officials said in a statement Friday.

title: Sanibel Island Residents Describe Struggle to Survive Ian and Escape
description: FORT MYERS, Fla—After Hurricane Ian decimated her Sanibel Island home and cut the island’s bridge connection to shore, resident Jacquelyn Semerjian spent Thursday standing outside with a sign with the message “We’re safe” and her mother’s phone number. She hoped a news crew in a helicopter would see it. “We just wanted our parents to know we were alive,” she said.

title: Hurricane Ian Threatens South Carolina After Battering Florida
authors: Elizabeth Findell,Lynn Waddell,Dan Frosch,The Wall Street Journal
description: Hurricane Ian whirled toward the South Carolina coast, where it was expected to make landfall again on Friday as a Category 1 storm after battering Florida. With maximum sustained winds of 85 mph, Ian could gain a little more power before rapidly weakening when it comes ashore and passes over the southeastern U.S., the National Hurricane Center said in an advisory at 5 a.m. ET.

title: Hurricane Ian Survivors in Fort Myers Recount Day of Terror
description: FORT MYERS BEACH, Fla.—As Hurricane Ian crashed ashore Wednesday afternoon, waves cresting above the first floors of buildings, Siegfried Heydrich was standing on furniture feeling the water come up to his neck. He needed to act fast. Mr. Heydrich punched a hole into his drywall roof to reach the rafters, he said. He and his brother and roommate hung from the rafter, water swirling from the necks down, for the duration of the storm, he said.

title: Hurricane Ian Leaves Florida Reeling, Knocks Out Power to Millions
authors: Elizabeth Findell,Dan Frosch,Cameron McWhirter,The Wall Street Journal
description: Some 2.6 million people still had no electricity on Thursday afternoon, according to tracking site poweroutage.us, and energy companies were struggling to restore power as trees and vegetation blocked roads and access to grid infrastructure. By Thursday morning, Ian was gone from the area, tracking northward as it dumped rain over Orlando, and then drifted out over the Atlantic Ocean as a tropical storm. But by later in the afternoon, it had regained strength and become a hurricane again.

title: Hurricane Ian Takes Aim at Fast-Growing Region in Florida
description: As forecasts for the path of Hurricane Ian solidified Wednesday, the storm was poised to hit an area full of newcomers. Projections show the hurricane is likely to make landfall near Port Charlotte, just above Fort Myers and just below Sarasota, before moving inland. It is an area that has seen a rapid influx of people since the start of the Covid-19 pandemic.

title: Latest News, Updates and Storm Path as Storm Strengthens to Category 4
authors: Jon Kamp,Cameron McWhirter,Caitlin Ostroff,Michael Wright,Robert Barba,Thomas Derpinghaus,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: About this pageHurricane Ian Nears Florida, Strengthens to Category 4 Storm: Latest News, Updates and Storm PathLast Updated: Sep 28, 2022 at 8:27 am ETLive coverage as Hurricane Ian approaches Florida's Gulf Coast after hitting Cuba and knocking out the island's powergrid.

title: In Texas Attorney General Race, Democrat Targets Ken Paxton’s Legal Problems as He Courts Conservatives
description: AUSTIN, Texas—Democratic civil-rights lawyer Rochelle Garza is challenging Texas Republican Attorney General Ken Paxton in a race where the incumbent is emphasizing his close ties to former President Donald Trump and counting on the loyalty of the state’s most conservative voters, while his opponent tries to make his legal scandals the focus.

title: Back-to-School Week in Uvalde, Texas, Brings Decisions, Fear
authors: Elizabeth Findell,Ben Chapman,The Wall Street Journal
description: UVALDE, Texas—Zayon Martinez doesn’t like to talk about his last day of second grade, when he hid under his desk at Robb Elementary School and then fled while a gunman killed 21 students and teachers. All the 8-year-old knows, he says, is that he doesn’t want to go back. His father, Adam Martinez, who has been an outspoken critic of the Uvalde school district’s response to the shooting, spent the summer discussing with his wife how to educate Zayon and his sister this school year.

title: Uvalde School Board to Consider Firing Police Chief
description: The school board in Uvalde, Texas, is scheduled Wednesday to consider whether to fire district Police Chief Pete Arredondo, three months after the widely condemned law-enforcement response to a deadly mass shooting at one of the city’s elementary schools. The agenda for Wednesday’s evening meeting says board members will consider terminating Mr. Arredondo for cause. Schools in the district begin classes Sept. 6.

title: Uvalde School Board Fires Police Chief
description: The school board in Uvalde, Texas, voted unanimously Wednesday night to fire district police chief Pete Arredondo, exactly three months after he oversaw the response to a mass shooting in which 19 fourth-graders and two teachers died. The move came after months of calls to remove Mr. Arredondo, whom state officials blamed for failing as commander of the law-enforcement response to the shooting.

title: Uvalde Massacre Prompts New Debate on Guns Among Residents
description: By | Photographs by Lisa Krantz for The Wall Street Journal Aug. 9, 2022 5:30 am ETUVALDE, Texas—On a recent hot evening, in a town that two months ago saw a gunman kill 19 children and two teachers in a school classroom, a few dozen people filtered into an auditorium to look for political solutions to prevent gun deaths. They live in a congressional district that in just five years has been the site of or has neighbored three of the 10 deadliest mass shootings in U.S. history.

title: Uvalde Massacre Prompts New Debate on Guns Among Residents
description: “We need to send a message to every local and state official that supports the sale of AR-15s to children that your days are numbered because we are coming after you in the voting booth,” said Aide Escamilla, a local professor who has called for raising the age for such gun purchases from 18 to 21 or older. Dr. Escamilla said she voted for GOP Gov. Greg Abbott in 2018, but doesn’t plan to vote for him again because of his response to the shooting.

title: In Uvalde, Some Became Numb to Lockdown Alerts Before School Shooting
description: Most of those lockdown alerts were triggered by a nearby bailout, the term for a high-speed chase that ends with a suspect, often a smuggler or immigrant, bailing out of their vehicle and fleeing on foot. Such events are a fact of life in border regions, but lockdowns as a result of bailouts are unusually frequent in Uvalde, officials said. “The series of bailout-related alerts led teachers and administrators to respond to all alerts with less urgency,” the report said.

title: Report Emphasizes Uvalde Shooting Response As A Systemic Failure. How Do We Prevent It From Happening Again?
description: Report Emphasizes Uvalde Shooting Response As A Systemic Failure. How Do We Prevent It From Happening Again? Uvalde Shooting Report 7.18.22 Nearly 400 law enforcement officials rushed to a mass shooting at a Uvalde elementary school, but “egregiously poor decision-making” resulted in more than an hour of chaos before the gunman who took 21 lives was finally confronted and killed, according to a damning investigative report released Sunday.

title: Texas Report Blasts Police Response to Uvalde School Shooting
authors: Elizabeth Findell,Alicia A. Caldwell,The Wall Street Journal
description: Hundreds of law enforcement officers descended on the school but a lack of leadership and communication resulted in costly delays, a state review found July 17, 2022 4:01 pm ET UVALDE, Texas — A review of the Uvalde school massacre by Texas lawmakers found that systemic failures by hundreds of heavily armed law enforcement officers resulted in a delayed confrontation with the shooter that may have cost lives.

title: U.S. Border Agents on Horseback Used Unnecessary Force Against Haitian Migrants, Report Says
authors: Michelle Hackman,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: July 8, 2022 3:25 pm ET WASHINGTON—Border Patrol agents on horseback used unnecessary force against Haitian migrants in Del Rio, Texas, last September, as the agents sought to prevent them from joining more than 15,000 Haitians being held under a bridge there for processing, according to an internal review by U.S. Customs and Border Protection released Friday.

title: Uvalde Residents Press for Answers a Month After School Massacre
description: UVALDE, Texas—Brett Cross has spent the past two weeks trying to get in front of state and local leaders, often wearing a T-shirt bearing his murdered nephew’s photo, determined to show his face as he pushes for bits of information. “I have been doing y’all’s job,” Mr. Cross, who had served as a guardian to 10-year-old Uziyah Garcia, told Uvalde City Council members this week. “I have been demanding answers. That’s not my job—my job is to be a father and a wind technician.”

title: Texas Lawmaker Sues State Police Over Uvalde Records
description: AUSTIN, Texas—A Texas lawmaker sued the state’s Department of Public Safety, claiming the agency was illegally withholding records related to the May 24 fatal shooting of 19 schoolchildren and two teachers in Uvalde, Texas. Sen. Roland Gutierrez, a Democrat who represents Uvalde, said in the lawsuit filed Wednesday that he requested documents including ballistics reports and policy manuals from the police agency May 30 and received no response.

title: 得州公共安全局局长：尤瓦尔迪小学教室的门并未上锁
link: https://cn.wsj.com/articles/得州公共安全局局长-尤瓦尔迪小学教室的门并未上锁-11655855107
description: 得州公共安全局(Texas Department of Public Safety)局长周二表示，上个月在得州尤瓦尔迪的一所小学，没有任何障碍阻止警方进入一个两间相通的教室，当时里面有一名枪手正在枪杀学生和教师。 得州公共安全局局长Steven ...

title: Uvalde Classroom Door Wasn’t Locked, Texas Chief of Public Safety Says
description: AUSTIN, Texas—Officers at an elementary school in Uvalde, Texas, last month had nothing barring them from entering a dual classroom where a shooter was actively gunning down students and teachers, the chief of the Texas Department of Public Safety said Tuesday. The classroom door wasn’t locked, DPS Director Steven McCraw said during a hearing before a Texas Senate committee hearing Tuesday. Police officers armed with rifles and protected by body armor were on the scene within three minutes.

title: Poor Police Radio Reception Caused Confusion in Texas School Shooting Response, Says Official
authors: Alicia A. Caldwell,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: By Alicia A. Caldwell and Elizabeth FindellJune 4, 2022 6:08 pm ETUVALDE, Texas—The police officers who waited more than an hour inside a school in which a mass shooter was barricaded were in a position that received only sporadic and unreliable radio communications, according to two officials with knowledge of the investigation and the system.

title: Uvalde School Security Chief Silent as Post-Shooting Questions Swirl
authors: Elizabeth Findell,Talal Ansari,The Wall Street Journal
description: By Elizabeth Findell and Talal AnsariUpdated June 2, 2022 4:12 pm ETUVALDE, Texas—The man blamed by officials for bungling the response to the deadly elementary-school shooting last week officially became a city council member Tuesday, the same day state police accused him of not cooperating with an investigation into the event.

title: In Uvalde, Funeral Services Begin for Victims of School Shooting
authors: Elizabeth Findell,Joseph Pisani,The Wall Street Journal
description: UVALDE, Texas—Rolando Rodriguez had few words to describe how he was feeling as he turned out Monday to some of the first of the funeral events for the 21 victims, including his grandson, gunned down in their elementary school last week. “I wouldn’t wish this on anyone,” Mr. Rodriguez said, calling his 10-year-old grandson, Jose Manuel Flores Jr., a good boy who loved baseball, fishing and spending time with family.

title: 得州官员称尤瓦尔迪警察未即时攻入枪手所在教室是做了“错误的决定”
link: https://cn.wsj.com/articles/得州官员称尤瓦尔迪警察未即时攻入枪手所在教室是做了-错误的决定-11653701708
description: 得州安全局局长周五表示，回应当地一所小学大规模枪击事件的警察等待了大约一个小时才进入枪手反锁自己的教室，因为现场一名指挥官误认为没有人面临生命危险，尽管里面的孩子反复拨打911电话。 局长Steven McCraw在新闻发布会上说，这是一个错误的决定，目前还不清楚该决定可能造成了多少人死亡。这起事件最终有19名儿童和两名教师丧身。 ...

title: Shooter Fired Outside School 12 Min Before Entering
description: Shooter Fired Outside School 12 Min Before Entering (AP Photo/Dario Lopez-Mills)Local residents voiced anger Thursday about the time it took to end the mass shooting at an elementary school here, as police laid out a fresh timeline that showed the gunman entered the building unobstructed after lingering outside for 12 minutes firing shots. Read Full Article »

title: Texas Parents Angered Over Police Response to Shooting
authors: Elizabeth Findell,Douglas Belkin,Rob Copeland,The Wall Street Journal
description: By Elizabeth Findell, Douglas Belkin and Rob CopelandMay 27, 2022 11:31 am ETUVALDE, Texas—Local residents voiced anger about the time it took to end the mass shooting at an elementary school here, as the National Rifle Association was set to begin its annual meeting in Houston with remarks scheduled from former President Donald Trump and other high-profile Republicans.

title: Uvalde Shooter Fired Outside School for 12 Minutes Before Entering
authors: Douglas Belkin,Rob Copeland,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: UVALDE, Texas—Local residents voiced anger Thursday about the time it took to end the mass shooting at an elementary school here, as police laid out a fresh timeline that showed the gunman entered the building unobstructed after lingering outside for 12 minutes firing shots.

title: 得州枪手曾与学校保安发生冲突，在Facebook发私信称计划实施枪击
link: https://cn.wsj.com/articles/得州枪手曾与学校保安发生冲突-在facebook发私信称计划实施枪击-11653525511
description: 得州官员们周三说，在这里的一所小学杀害了19名学生和两名教师的枪手在进入学校前曾与一名武装保安发生冲突，并在即将开车前往学校时在Facebook上发送了一条私信，表示了他打算实施大规模枪击的意图。 据得克萨斯州州长Greg Abbott和一位了解调查情况的执法官员称，18岁的Salvador Ramos周二上午在Facebook上给一名海外的十几岁女孩发信息写道：“我要开枪打死我奶奶。”在实施之后，他又写道：“我打死了我奶奶。”在到Robb Elementary School前不到15分钟，他写道：“我要去枪击一所小学。” Facebook母公司Meta Platforms Inc.的发言人在Twitter上说，这些通信是发给另一个人的私人信息，不是公开的帖子。 执法官员说，Ramos最后躲在一个有两个房间的四年级教室里，那是所有受害者共用的教室，他在周二与边境巡逻队的精英小组发生枪战后在那里被击毙。...

title: Ken Paxton Defeats George P. Bush in Texas Attorney General Republican Primary
description: Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton won his party’s nomination to keep the seat Tuesday, according to a projection by the Associated Press, defeating state land commissioner George P. Bush. The race illuminated current state Republicans’ allegiance to a Trump-aligned attorney general facing legal problems over the next generation of a family once beloved by the party but now seen in many quarters as too moderate.

title: Texas Attorney General Face-Off Highlights GOP Shift
description: HOUSTON—Diane DeLeonardis, a retired real-estate agent here, walked into a campaign event for Texas attorney general hopeful George P. Bush already planning to vote for his opponent in the Republican primary, incumbent Ken Paxton. She walked out as an undecided voter. “I had been thinking his family sounds so liberal,” Ms. DeLeonardis said of Mr. Bush, a member of the powerful Republican family that has included a senator, two presidents and a governor. “But he speaks like a real conservative.”

title: Texas Supreme Court Clears Way for Transgender Investigations
description: AUSTIN, Texas—Child-abuse investigations against parents of transgender children have been cleared to move forward in Texas, after a state Supreme Court decision Friday struck down an injunction holding them at bay. The state’s Department of Family and Protective Services in February began investigating some families whose transgender adolescents received gender-affirming medical care. The probes followed a February order from Gov. Greg Abbott stating that such care could constitute abuse.

title: Dreams of Inexpensive Texas Barbecue Go Up in Smoke
description: Can’t get to Texas? Try making a coffee-cured brisket at home. Brisket is a challenging cut to cook well; low and slow is the only way. This recipe, from Tim Byres of Smoke, in Dallas, takes some 14 hours in all, but the results are tender and juicy every time. The salt and sugar in the rub cure the exterior of the meat and help form the tasty, charred crust called "bark." Getty

title: Gubernatorial Candidates Seize on Leaked Roe v. Wade Draft Opinion
description: Democratic candidates in competitive gubernatorial races across the country who support abortion rights seized on this week’s leak of a draft opinion overturning Roe v. Wade to rally support from voters who oppose outlawing abortion. Republican incumbents tended to say little about the issue, while those fighting to win the GOP nomination were more outspoken in their enthusiasm to restrict or outlaw abortion.

title: Industries Report Continued Fallout from Texas-Mexico Bridge Slowdowns
description: PHARR, Texas—Industries say they are still grappling with supply-chain fallout after a week of expanded mechanical inspections ordered by Texas Gov. Greg Abbott on transport trucks crossing from Mexico into Texas. Mr. Abbott, a Republican, has dialed back the inspections in recent days, announcing Friday that he would allow the final international bridges in the state to return to normal operations, just over a week after his new policy began.

title: Texas Gov. Reaches Deal With Mexican Officials Over More International Bridges
description: MCALLEN, Texas—Three more Texas international bridges will see relief from state trucking inspections that have disrupted trade with Mexico, Gov. Greg Abbott said on Thursday. Mr. Abbott and Chihuahua Gov. María Campos Galvan said in Austin that they had reached an agreement for Chihuahua to do safety checks on trucks in Mexico.

title: Snarls at Texas-Mexico Bridges Spread to Other Sites
description: By Elizabeth Findell | Photographs by Verónica G. Cárdenas for The Wall Street Journal Apr. 13, 2022 2:11 pm ETREYNOSA, Mexico— More Texas international bridges were grappling Wednesday with problems from state searches of commercial trucks and associated protests, as the blockade of a major U.S.-Mexico entry point entered a third day.

title: Traffic Snarled at Texas-Mexico Border by New Security Measures, Protests
description: PHARR, Texas—Two major international bridges were effectively shut down after Mexican truckers blocked lanes in both directions to protest a new border security initiative from Texas Gov. Greg Abbott that forced them to wait hours or days to bring products into the U.S.At the Pharr-Reynosa International Bridge, which spans the Rio Grande, officials scrambled to react Monday morning as truckers obstructed all lanes on the Mexican side.

title: In Austin, Texas, a Battle Looms Over What Police Did During Protests
description: In Austin, Texas, a Battle Looms Over What Police Did During ProtestsNineteen members of the Austin Police Department were charged criminally for crowd-control tactics in 2020; the officers say they were following orders

title: Ukrainian Pop Star Tries to Make It From War to South by Southwest
description: Oleksandra Zaritska was weaving camouflage nets for soldiers on the western edge of Ukraine, days after her home fell to Russian soldiers, when her phone rang. The voice on the other end of the line was her band’s producer. He thought she should go ahead with a planned concert at Austin’s famed South by Southwest festival—alone, as her two bandmates fought for their lives at home.

title: Texas Judge Halts State Order on Transgender Adolescents
description: AUSTIN, Texas—A Texas judge on Friday temporarily blocked state health authorities from following Gov. Greg Abbott’s order to investigate medical treatments for transgender adolescents as possible child abuse. Judge Amy Clark Meachum, based in Austin, found the directive unconstitutional and that Mr. Abbott passed the order without proper authority.

title: Don’t Mess With Texas Barbecue: Restaurants Confront Rising Meat Prices
description: AUSTIN—Since 1975, Skeeter Miller’s The County Line barbecue restaurants have been dishing out ribs, brisket, turkey and sausage “so good you’ll want to get it all over ya,” their slogan says. Loyalists who have been coming since the beginning remember all-you-can-eat plates for $6.75. Amid the pandemic and the fast-rising cost of meat, Mr. Miller has had to raise prices, including four times in just the past year, he said.

title: Texas Parents of Transgender Teen Win Legal Victory
authors: Laura Kusisto,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: AUSTIN, Texas—Parents scored a narrow victory Wednesday in a lawsuit challenging a new state policy directing child-protection officials to investigate whether transgender youths receiving hormone blockers and other treatments are being subjected to child abuse. A Texas judge granted a request by parents of a 16-year-old transgender girl to temporarily forbid the state from conducting an investigation into whether helping their daughter obtain such medical treatments constituted child abuse.

title: Parents’ Lawsuit Challenges New Texas Transgender Policy
authors: Laura Kusisto,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: The parents of a 16-year-old transgender Texas girl filed a lawsuit Tuesday challenging a new state policy directing child-protection officials to investigate whether transgender youth receiving hormone blockers and other treatments are being subjected to child abuse. The plaintiffs, who brought the case under pseudonyms to protect their privacy, allege the state already is investigating them after Texas Gov. Greg Abbott issued a directive last week outlining the new policy.

title: Texans Kick Off Midterm Elections With Primaries for Governor, Congress
description: AUSTIN, Texas—Voters in Texas head to the polls Tuesday in the first primary of the 2022 midterm elections that will decide many of the matchups for governor, the state’s 38 congressional districts and several statewide offices. Republican Gov. Greg Abbott and former Democratic presidential candidate Beto O’Rourke are favored to win their respective party’s primary in the gubernatorial race.

title: Texans Head to the Polls Under a Tighter Voting Regime
description: AUSTIN, Texas—Rejected mail-in ballots and a drop in mail voting have so far marked the first Texas election since a new voting law went into place, possibly giving a first look at how tightened voting laws in many states may affect the election process. Texans have been casting their ballots in the nation’s first 2022 primary over the past two weeks, either at the polls or by mail.

title: Nineteen Austin Police Officers Charged for Alleged Misconduct During George Floyd Protests
description: We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription. You will be charged $ + tax (if applicable) for The Wall Street Journal. You may change your billing preferences at any time in the Customer Center or call Customer Service. You will be notified in advance of any changes in rate or terms. You may cancel your subscription at anytime by calling Customer Service. Please click confirm to resume now.

title: Texas Church-Shooting Survivors, Families Awarded More Than $230 Million From U.S. Government
authors: Dan Frosch,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: A memorial for some victims in the mass shooting in Sutherland Springs, Texas. Photo: Eric Gay/Associated Press The U.S. government must pay a little more than $230 million to the survivors and families of victims of a 2017 mass shooting at a church in Sutherland Springs, Texas, a federal judge ruled Monday.

title: Texas GOP Governor Faces Backlash Over Problems With National Guard Deployment at Border
description: Texas Republican Gov. Greg Abbott is being blamed by GOP opponents and Democrats for bungling the deployment of thousands of National Guard troops to the border under his signature program Operation Lone Star after a recent spate of suicides among the troops. The deployment was hasty, Guardsmen say. Some stationed on the border say they have little to do, which is leading to low morale. As well, the state has been slow to pay them, Guardsmen say.

title: Texas Congressman Henry Cuellar’s Home Is Searched by FBI
description: U.S. Rep. Henry Cuellar Photo: Kevin Dietsch/Getty Images Federal agents were “conducting court-authorized law enforcement activity” Wednesday afternoon in the area of the Laredo, Texas, home where Rep. Henry Cuellar (D., Texas) resides, according to the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The FBI’s brief statement didn’t say what type of probe was under way, or if the congressman was the subject.

title: Texas Election Law Leads to Increase in Rejected Mail-in Ballot Applications
description: AUSTIN, Texas—Texas counties say confusion stemming from a new state election law is leading them to reject an unusually high proportion of applications for mail-in ballots. Texas Senate Bill 1, passed in August after walkouts by Democrats stymied its progress for months, broadly tightened voting procedures across the state. It is now being tested as the state prepares for its March 1 primary election, the first primary in the country.

title: Small Businesses Struck by Omicron Face Hard Choices Before Holidays
authors: Joe Barrett,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: After nearly two years of dealing with worker shortages, pandemic restrictions and rising prices, many small businesses are suddenly facing a surge of employee illnesses from the Omicron variant that is leading to some hard choices. Steingold’s of Chicago, a deli in the city’s Lakeview neighborhood, had weathered the pandemic without a single case of Covid-19 until last week, when one of 10 employees tested positive. Co-owner Aaron Steingold followed with a positive result a few days later.

title: Au Texas, des citoyens en armes patrouillent le long de la frontière pour traquer les migrants
description: Frontière Par Elizabeth Findell  |  The Wall Street Journal 17 décembre 2021 à 17h45 La loi de l’Etat qui permet d’arrêter les migrants pour intrusion suscite des vocations chez certains groupes de citoyens armés, que les responsables locaux ne voient pas toujours d’un mauvais œil Le shérif du comté de Kinney, Brad Coe.

title: Astroworld Deaths All Due to ‘Compression Asphyxia,’ Examiner Finds
description: Two friends looked on as a third signed a memorial card at the site of the Astroworld Festival in Houston last month, shortly the fatal Travis Scott concert.
