Photo: thomas shea/Agence France-Presse/Getty Images All 10 people who died at a Travis Scott concert last month died after being crushed until they could no longer breathe, a Houston-area medical examiner said Thursday.

title: In a Texas Border Town, Armed Groups Arrive to Look for Migrants
description: BRACKETTVILLE, Texas—As this South Texas border county has seen a jump in illegal border crossings, Sheriff Brad Coe is cooperating with groups of armed private citizens to help patrol the border and arrest migrants for trespassing. The Kinney County sheriff has been in regular contact for months with a group of men donning body armor and rifles while patrolling to look for migrants. Another armed group offered use of a high-tech drone, and went on a patrol along with the sheriff.

title: Sutherland Springs Families, Survivors Seek Bigger Payments From Government
authors: Dan Frosch,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: Lawyers for victims of the 2017 massacre in Sutherland Springs, Texas, argued Monday that the Justice Department was proposing too little in damages, compared with other recent settlements over the government’s failure to prevent mass shootings.

title: SAMSUNG CONFIRMS CHIP PLANT IN TEXAS
authors: Elizabeth Findell,Jinyoug Sohn,The Wall Street Journal
description: ABSTRACTSamsung Electronics Co plans to invest roughly $17 billion in semiconductor-making facility in Taylor, Tex, latest chip-plant commitment this year amid global processor shortage; photo (M)

title: Samsung Picks Texas for $17 Billion Chip-Making Factory
authors: Elizabeth Findell,Jiyoung Sohn,The Wall Street Journal
description: AUSTIN, Texas— Samsung Electronics Co. said Tuesday that it plans to invest roughly $17 billion in a semiconductor-making facility in Taylor, Texas, the latest chip-plant commitment this year amid a global processor shortage. Samsung said the factory would be its largest U.S. investment and produce high-end chips that are used in smartphones and other devices, as well as for artificial-intelligence applications.

title: Travis Scott Concert Latest: Police Dismiss Report of Drugged Security Guard
description: Reports that a security guard was injected with a drug during a Travis Scott concert that turned deadly are false, Houston Police Chief Troy Finner said Wednesday. Police were investigating whether anyone had been maliciously injected with drugs at the show, Mr. Finner said last Saturday, after a report that a security guard had been pricked in the neck. The police chief said at a news conference Wednesday that authorities talked with the guard in question and found the report was inaccurate.

title: Probe of Travis Scott Astroworld Concert Disaster Explores Role of Illegal Drugs
authors: Neil Shah,Elizabeth Findell,Anne Steele,Zusha Ellinson,The Wall Street Journal
description: Investigators probing the tragedy at the Travis Scott concert are looking at whether a bad batch of illegal drugs played a role in some deaths and numerous casualties, people familiar with the investigation said. Police are looking at the possibility of overdoses at Friday’s concert that were caused by counterfeit pills possibly laced with fentanyl, according to one of the people.

title: Texas Jails Fill With Migrants as Border Arrests Overwhelm Courts
authors: Elizabeth Findell,Alicia A. Caldwell,The Wall Street Journal
description: DEL RIO, Texas— Texas Gov. Greg Abbott’s effort to use state law enforcement to enforce immigration law by arresting migrants for trespassing is overwhelming local courts and resulting in few convictions. Just 3% of the about 1,500 people arrested on misdemeanor trespassing charges since July as part of what Mr. Abbott calls Operation Lone Star have been convicted, all via guilty pleas, according to court records.

title: Schools to Distribute Covid-19 Vaccines, Incentives to Kids
authors: Ben Chapman,Lee Hawkins,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: Major U.S. cities are taking the Covid-19 vaccination effort to schools, offering children everything from money to amusement-park tickets to encourage them get the shots. With school districts from Austin, Texas, to Santa Clara, Calif., saying they were set to serve as locations for administering vaccines among students ages 5 and older Thursday, officials around the country are making new pitches urging families to participate.

title: Texas Abortion Law Gives a Glimpse Into a Post-Roe World
description: AUSTIN, Texas—Over nine weeks, a new Texas law effectively banning abortion after six weeks has transformed the state’s abortion climate. The number of abortions performed in clinics has dropped. Some women have carried out their own abortions, such as one woman who took drugs she purchased from overseas. Others, including a 13-year-old assault victim, have fled Texas to other states, where clinics say they are overwhelmed by Texas demand.

title: TEXAS BARS SPORTS FOR TRANSGENDER STUDENTS
description: ABSTRACTTexas lawmakers pass ban on allowing transgender students to participate in interscholastic sports leagues that are designated for gender other than that listed on their birth certificates (M)

title: Texas Passes Sports Ban for Transgender Students
description: Texas state Rep. Jessica González was among Democratic opponents of a Texas bill that banned transgender athletes, saying it invited bullying, though Republicans who supported the measure said it promoted fairness in girls’ sports against competitors who might be stronger or taller.

title: Texas Redistricting Tests Whether Minority Population Gains Will Translate Into Political Clout
authors: Aaron Zitner,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: AUSTIN, Texas—Texas is emerging as a central test of whether the nation’s minority residents, who account for all U.S. population growth over the past decade, will gain additional voting clout as states redraw their U.S. House district lines. Texas added more residents in the past 10 years than any other state, earning two additional seats in Congress. Hispanic, Black, Asian-American and other minority groups accounted for about 95% of the growth, the 2020 census showed.

title: Top Texas employers set to implement vaccine requirements in spite of Republican governor's ban on mandates
description: The move by Texas to bar COVID-19 vaccine mandates by businesses sets up a clash between the state and the Biden administration, leaving employers caught in the middle. On one side, Monday's executive order from Texas Gov. Greg Abbott forbids any private entity to require its employees or customers to get vaccinated. On the other hand, the Biden administration is working on requirements that private-sector workers be vaccinated or tested weekly at businesses with 100 or more employees.

title: Covid-19 Vaccine-Mandate Fight Between Texas and Biden Has Companies Caught in the Middle
authors: David Harrison,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: On one side, Monday’s executive order from Texas Gov. Greg Abbott forbids any private entity to require its employees or customers to get vaccinated. On the other hand, the Biden administration is working on requirements that private-sector workers be vaccinated or tested weekly at businesses with 100 or more employees. Texas is one of a number of Republican-led states with top officials who are opposed to federal vaccine mandates.

title: Texas Governor Bans Covid-19 Vaccine Mandates for Employees
description: Texas Gov. Greg Abbott said the Covid-19 vaccine ‘should remain voluntary and never forced.’ Photo: Bob Daemmrich/Zuma Press AUSTIN—Texas businesses and other private entities are now banned from requiring Covid-19 vaccinations for employees, Gov. Greg Abbott said in an executive order issued Monday.

title: AFTER INJUNCTION, SOME TEXAS SITES RESUME ABORTIONS
description: ABSTRACTNumber of Texas clinics resume performing abortions after judge issued injunction blocking Texas Heartbeat Act banning most abortions; many patients are anxious, knowing injunction may only be in place briefly (M)

title: Texas Abortions Pick Up After Federal Judge Allows Them
description: AUSTIN—Some Texas clinics again began performing abortions later than six weeks Thursday after a federal judge blocked a state law imposing a near ban on the procedure, while others are moving more slowly as legal challenges play out. Whole Woman’s Health, which operates four Texas abortion clinics, said it reached out Wednesday night to women who had been on a waiting list for abortions after being turned away in recent weeks. The Texas Heartbeat Act, also known as SB8, went into effect Sept 1.

title: Texas Aims to Crack Down on Abortion Pills Sent by Mail
description: AUSTIN, Texas—Texas is aiming to stop the use of abortion drugs prescribed remotely and delivered by mail, a practice that ticked up during the pandemic and has surged since the state passed a restrictive new abortion law.

title: Texas Abortion Law Prompts Women to Seek Out-of-State Clinics
description: AUSTIN, Texas—Women’s health clinics in Louisiana, Oklahoma and beyond are reporting an influx of out-of-state patients from Texas looking for abortions and other services, weeks after the U.S. Supreme Court allowed to take effect. Some clinics in neighboring states say they are overwhelmed with out-of-state patients. They are adding hours to try to handle the backlog, administrators said. In Texas, meanwhile, clinics are turning most of their patients away, and losing their staff.

title: Texas Doctor Who Performed Abortion Is Sued in Test of New Law
description: AUSTIN, Texas—A Texas doctor who publicly said he performed an abortion was sued Monday in state court by an Arkansas man, handing Texas a test of its new abortion law. The Texas law bans abortions after about six weeks of gestation when a fetal heartbeat can be detected, and it deputizes private citizens to sue anyone they believe may have aided such a procedure and collect $10,000. It went into effect Sept. 1.

title: Afghans Fleeing Taliban Grow More Desperate as Clock Ticks on U.S. Evacuation
authors: Elizabeth Findell,Erin Delmore,Jim Fanelli,The Wall Street Journal
description: The family of Naqibullah Laghmanai, a former interpreter for the U.S. military, spent days waiting outside Kabul’s airport, hoping to catch a flight out of the country before the Biden administration ends its evacuation operation. People were beaten. The family’s youngest member, a 5-year-old, fell ill in the heat and chaos. The family finally gave up and returned home, says Mr. Laghmanai, a U.S. citizen now living in Houston.

title: IN TEXAS, DEMOCRATS END IMPASSE
description: ABSTRACTSome Democrats return to Texas Legislature after 58-day standoff designed to deprive Republicans of quorum needed for vote on controversial elections bill; other Democrats express dismay with their colleagues; photo (M)

title: Texas Legislature Convenes Quorum, Ending Stalemate on Elections Bill
description: AUSTIN, Texas—A few Democrats in the Texas Legislature, who had helped refuse the House a quorum in an effort to kill an elections bill, returned to the Capitol Thursday after a 38-day standoff. Three Houston-area House Democrats—Garnet Coleman, Ana Hernandez and Armando Walle—returned to the chamber on Thursday evening.

title: Texas Gov. Greg Abbott Tests Positive for Covid-19
description: We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription. You will be charged $ + tax (if applicable) for The Wall Street Journal. You may change your billing preferences at any time in the Customer Center or call Customer Service. You will be notified in advance of any changes in rate or terms. You may cancel your subscription at anytime by calling Customer Service. Please click confirm to resume now.

title: Afghans in America Try to Save Family Members as Options Dwindle
authors: Elizabeth Findell,Sara Randazzo,Jim Fanelli,The Wall Street Journal
description: Desperate and defeated, Naqibullah Laghmanai was calling everyone he could think of Monday morning in Houston, trying to get his family out of Afghanistan. He was on hold with U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services for at least the 10th time in recent weeks, he said. He was crafting a plea to the Canadian Embassy, though his family never worked for the Canadians. He was calling members of Congress.

title: More School Districts in Texas Sue Governor Over Mask-Mandate Ban
authors: Elizabeth Findell,Ben Chapman,The Wall Street Journal
description: AUSTIN, Texas—More school districts in Texas are pushing back against an executive order banning mask mandates, joining districts in other states filing lawsuits over the issue. With most public schools in the country set to begin classes in coming weeks, city and county officials are wrestling with decisions about whether to require masks as the highly-contagious Delta variant causes a surge in Covid-19 cases.

title: Texas Hospitals Are Near Capacity as Covid-19 Surges Again
description: AUSTIN, Texas—Texas Gov. Greg Abbott Monday asked hospitals to delay elective medical procedures, as rising Covid-19 cases bring hospitals in many parts of the nation’s second-largest state to capacity. In Austin, city and county officials used an emergency alert system over the weekend to text and call residents with the warning that the hospital situation is critical, as the number of available intensive care unit beds in a metro area of more than 2 million residents dwindled to single digits.

title: Neighbors’ Deaths From Covid-19 Have an Arkansas Town Reassessing Vaccines
authors: Elizabeth Findell,Kris Maher,The Wall Street Journal
description: GREENWOOD, Arkansas—Michael Lejong fully intended to get vaccinated for Covid-19, his wife said, standing in the pavilion that the prominent architect designed for his hometown. But he was relatively young, very healthy and not overly concerned about the virus. He wanted to get his shots separately from his wife, so he could care for her if she had adverse side effects. She got hers immediately in April and he put his off. In late June, he began feeling sick and tested positive for Covid-19.

title: Biden Administration Sues Texas Over Ban on Transporting Migrants
authors: Sadie Gurman,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: The Biden administration sued Texas on Friday, saying an order from its governor banning the transportation of migrants within the state by anyone other than law enforcement impinges on the federal government’s exclusive control over immigration matters. The Justice Department’s action comes just one day after Attorney General Merrick Garlandwarned Republican Gov. Greg Abbott that the state could face legal action if he didn’t immediately rescind the order.

title: U.S. Threatens to Sue Texas Over Its Latest Challenge to Federal Immigration Authority
authors: Elizabeth Findell,Sadie Gurman,The Wall Street Journal
description: The Biden administration on Thursday threatened to sue Texas over an order from its governor banning the transportation of migrants within the state by anyone other than law enforcement, saying the move impinges on the federal government’s exclusive control over immigration matters. In a letter to Gov.

title: Texas Arrests Migrants Crossing the U.S. Border for Trespassing
description: DEL RIO, Texas—Texas has begun arresting and jailing migrants for trespassing, as Gov. Greg Abbott pursues a new plan aimed at illegal border crossers that is dividing counties in the state. The first three migrants were sent to a state prison Tuesday on the state charges, according to Val Verde County Judge Lewis Owens, whose role is an elected executive akin to a mayor.

title: Republicans, Democrats in Texas Continue Standoff Over Voting Bill
description: AUSTIN, Texas—Democrats and Republicans continued their standoff Wednesday over passing a divisive election bill, even as both sides must now reckon with the challenges of sticking out a 30-day special session. On Monday, scores of House Democrats staged a walkout by chartering two airplanes to Washington, D.C. to keep the Republican-controlled Texas House from having the quorum necessary to pass legislation that would tighten election laws in the state.

title: Texas Senate Expected to Take Up Vote on Election Legislation
description: AUSTIN, Texas—Texas state senators are expected to vote on election legislation Tuesday, and their counterparts in the state House are expected to consider whether to vote to arrest colleagues who fled the state in an effort to kill the legislation. Both chambers of the Republican-controlled Texas legislature, in a special legislative session that began last week, filed similar versions of the bill, which would broadly tighten voting rules across the state. Gov.

title: Texas Democrats to Stage Walkout to Kill Voting Bill
description: AUSTIN, Tex.—At least 59 Texas House Democrats are fleeing the state of Texas Monday to deny the Republican-controlled state legislature the quorum necessary to pass voting legislation during a special session, a source familiar with their plans said. The Democrats were set to head to Washington, D.C., on two chartered airplanes, the person said. The legislators will have to remain out of state for weeks to avoid voting during the 30-day legislative session, which Republican Gov.

title: Texas Weighs Voting Bills in Special Session
description: AUSTIN—The Texas Legislature kicked off a special session Thursday, called by Gov. Greg Abbott, to revive voting legislation that Democrats had killed in May by staging a walkout in the final minutes before a voting deadline. Both the state House and Senate filed bills that are largely similar to the previous bill, which would have set some of the nation’s broadest restrictions on voting.

title: Air Force Found Largely Responsible for Texas Church Shooting
authors: Dan Frosch,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: A federal judge ruled that the U.S. Air Force bears most of the responsibility for the 2017 mass shooting at a church in Sutherland Springs, Texas, because it failed to enter the shooter’s criminal history into a federal background check database used for gun purchases.

title: Austin Boom Spurs Crackdown on Homelessness
description: AUSTIN, Texas—A freeway overpass shaded Elizabeth Contreras’s tent from the hot Texas sun, five years into a stretch of on-and-off homelessness that began when her husband left her, she said. Austin Police Officer Rosie Perez stopped by the tent last week with a written warning for Ms. Contreras: Within weeks, she would need to be gone. Police officers are beginning to enforce new city and statewide bans on public camping, after a two-year battle over Austin homeless policies.

title: Texas Firearms Bill Revives Gun-Rights Strategy Rejected by U.S. Courts in Past
authors: Ben Kesling,Elizabeth Findell,Jacob Gershman,The Wall Street Journal
description: Bill would let residents buy Texas-made gun silencers without a license, which is currently illegal under federal law Resume Subscription We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription. You will be charged $ + tax (if applicable) for The Wall Street Journal. You may change your billing preferences at any time in the Customer Center or call Customer Service. You will be notified in advance of any changes in rate or terms.

title: Texas Governor Says State Will Build a Wall Along Border With Mexico
description: AUSTIN, Texas—The state will begin efforts to build its own wall along its border with Mexico, Texas Gov. Greg Abbott announced Wednesday, saying the state was prompted to take action since President Biden has pulled back on former President Donald Trump’s border wall plans. The state will use an initial $250 million of state funds to explore how to build the wall.

title: ワクチン接種目的で米国旅行、外国人が殺到
authors: Elizabeth Findell,Juan Montes,The Wall Street Journal
description: By Elizabeth Findell and Juan Montes | Photographs by Verónica G.

title: Vaccines Draw Foreigners Looking for Shots and Shops
description: © Verónica G. Cárdenas for The Wall Street Journal McALLEN, Texas—Even before New York City announced plans to offer visitors free vaccines, tourism from Texas to Florida has received a boost as tens of thousands from Mexico and other countries fly to the U.S. for a shot in the arm. “Enjoy Dallas, Includes Covid Vaccine,” said a Mexico travel agency ad. Thai tour companies are selling vaccine packages to California. Northern states in the U.S. are supplying their Canadian neighbors with doses.

title: Covid-19 Vaccines in U.S. Beckon Foreigners Seeking Shots and Shops
authors: Elizabeth Findell,Juan Montes,The Wall Street Journal
description: McALLEN, Texas—Even before New York City announced plans to offer visitors free vaccines, tourism from Texas to Florida has received a boost as tens of thousands from Mexico and other countries fly to the U.S. for a shot in the arm. “Enjoy Dallas, Includes Covid Vaccine,” said a Mexico travel agency ad. Thai tour companies are selling vaccine packages to California. Northern states in the U.S. are supplying their Canadian neighbors with doses.

title: Voting-Rules Bill Passes Texas House
authors: Elizabeth Findell,Jon Kamp,The Wall Street Journal
description: AUSTIN, Texas—The Texas House approved legislation on new election rules early Friday, in a party-line vote that followed an all-night debate. The bill would require adherence to provisions of the state election law that previously had allowed local flexibility, and it would make felonies of many violations. Republicans characterized the bill as a way to protect against voter fraud. Democrats, civil-rights groups and some companies said it would disenfranchise voters.

title: Texas Legislature Set to Vote on Election Bill
description: AUSTIN—Texas lawmakers are poised to vote Thursday on a Republican-sponsored election bill that has received pushback from civil- rights groups and major corporations. The Texas bill comes after voting laws passed in Georgia and Florida that Republicans say will increase election security and Democrats contend will restrict voting access, particularly to minority communities. The House is expected to vote Thursday on a bill that would increase criminal penalties for some voting irregularities.

title: American Airlines, Unilever, Others Oppose Texas Voting Access Laws
authors: Elizabeth Findell,Chip Cutter,The Wall Street Journal
description: State legislature expected to vote on bill in coming days By Elizabeth Findell and Chip CutterUpdated May. 4, 2021 12:17 pm ETAUSTIN, Texas—A group of major companies and business organizations came out Tuesday against a Texas voting bill, after debating how aggressively they should be involved in state legislation.

title: The Pandemic Changed Where Americans Live
authors: Arian Campo-Flores,Paul Overberg,Joseph De Avila,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: The pandemic has spurred a burst of mobility that is accelerating changes in where and how Americans live. Some young people are leaving cities earlier than is typical, while some older people are speeding up retirement moves. Fewer newcomers are giving cities a try, meaning the people moving out aren’t being replaced by fresh residents. Suburbs are emerging as the winners from these changes, marking the end of a decadelong growth trend for big cities.

title: Estados Unidos: la oferta de vacunas va camino a superar la demanda
description: Al ritmo actual, en las próximas semanas la provisión de vacunas contra el Covid de Estados Unidos superará la demanda, según una ONG del área de la salud, y de tener que lidiar con el furor y la avalancha inicial de interesados en vacunarse, ahora las autoridades sanitarias de los distintos distritos tienen que salir a convencer a la gente para que se vacune.

title: Covid-19 Vaccine Supply Set to Outpace Demand
description: The nation’s supply of Covid-19 vaccines is set to outpace demand in the next two to four weeks, according to a national health nonprofit, as state health officials pivot from managing a flood of interest in the shot to persuading people to get it. In Texas, Austin-area leaders held a joint meeting last week to workshop how to increase Covid-19 vaccine outreach efforts as 10,000 local immunization appointments went unfilled.

title: Shootings in Texas and Wisconsin Leave Six Dead, Add to Spate of Gun Violence
description: Gunmen remained at large in Austin, Texas, and Kenosha County, Wis., on Sunday afternoon, after each killed three people in what police described as targeted incidents. In Kenosha County, a confrontation at a bar left three dead and two people injured. Kenosha County Sheriff David Beth said that authorities were still searching for a suspect. “We do not believe this was a random act,” Mr. Beth said.

title: After Georgia, Voting Fight Moves to Texas
description: AUSTIN, Texas—The battle over election security and voting rights has shifted to Texas, following recent legislation in Georgia that led to a backlash from civil-rights groups and some major corporations.

title: For Atlanta Shooting Victims, American Life Was Often a Lonely Struggle
authors: Esther Fung,Elizabeth Findell,Jaewon Kang,The Wall Street Journal
description: ATLANTA—Seven days after Daoyou Feng was shot and killed at the spa where she worked, her body lay unclaimed in a morgue in the Atlanta area. The 44-year-old, originally from China, died alone in a foreign country that knew little about her. Officials here couldn’t find a family member to claim her body, even though her name made international headlines.

title: Miami Beach Declares State of Emergency to Reduce Spring Break Crowds
description: Crowds gathered in Miami Beach on Saturday. Photo: cristobal herrera-ulashkevich/Shutterstock Packs of spring breakers led the city of Miami Beach to declare a state of emergency Saturday as local officials feared the gatherings would impede efforts to drive down Covid-19 cases. The city said in a news release that interim City Manager Raul J.

title: Texas Grocer H-E-B Is Caught in the Middle of Mask Divide
authors: Patrick Thomas,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: KERRVILLE, Texas—When Texas Gov. Greg Abbott said he would lift the statewide Covid-19 mask mandate, he left businesses in charge of setting and enforcing their own policies. H-E-B, a beloved Texas grocer and a stalwart during past crises in the state, waffled. The company, which had experienced a string of altercations in its aisles over mask policy, initially said it would urge customers to wear masks, but require them of employees.

title: A Raid, Deportation and Massacre Hit Two Communities Thousands of Miles Apart
authors: Elizabeth Findell,Juan Montes,José de Córdoba,The Wall Street Journal
description: CARTHAGE, Miss.—Nineteen people, most of them Maya Indian migrants from Guatemala, were killed in Mexico in January, their bodies dismembered and burned 14 miles from the Texas border. Some 800 miles away, this small Mississippi community was left to grieve.

title: Covid-19 Live Updates: U.S. Coronavirus Cases Top 50,000 for Second Day
authors: Peter Loftus,Andrew Restuccia,Sabrina Siddiqui,Elizabeth Findell,Melanie West,Jennifer A. Calfas,David Hall,Laurence Norman,Julie Wernau,Jenny Strasburg,James Hookway,Talal Ansari,Giovanni Legorano,The Wall Street Journal
description: Texas’s attorney general sued the city of Austin Thursday over its attempts to require mask-wearing, the latest in a string of battles between the state and local jurisdictions over Covid-19 health measures. The lawsuit against Austin, its surrounding county and leaders of both argues that the orders of Gov. Greg Abbott supersede any local orders. Mr. Abbott, a Republican, rescinded a statewide mask mandate this week, after it had been in place since summer.

title: Texas Attorney General Sues Austin Over Mask Mandate
description: Texas’s attorney general sued the city of Austin Thursday over its attempts to require mask-wearing, the latest in a string of battles between the state and local jurisdictions over Covid-19 health measures. The lawsuit against Austin, its surrounding county and leaders of both argues that the orders of Gov. Greg Abbott supersede any local orders. Mr. Abbott, a Republican, rescinded a statewide mask mandate this week, after it had been in place since summer.

title: Texas Governor Lifts Mask Mandate, Business Restrictions
description: Volunteers delivered water to local residents at Butler Stadium in Houston on Feb. 21 after a winter storm. Photo: adrees latif/Reuters Texas businesses will be able to operate at full capacity and state residents will no longer be required to wear masks to visit them, Gov. Greg Abbott announced Tuesday. “It is now the time to open Texas 100%,” Mr. Abbott, a Republican, said during an announcement in Lubbock.

title: Covid-19 Vaccine Is a Struggle for Those With No Hospital Connection
description: As Covid-19 vaccines continue to roll out across the country, many hospitals and clinics are giving priority to their own patients, leaving people who lack a primary-care doctor or a doctor affiliated with the right hospital struggling to find doses. Many states chose to distribute the vaccine first to hospitals, which then became the primary deliverer of the shot to their own healthcare workers and others who qualified.

title: Full Death Toll From Texas Storm Could Take Months to Determine
description: The harsh winter storm that hit Texas and other states last week has been blamed for dozens of deaths, though officials said that it would be weeks or months before the human cost of the freezing weather and utility crisis is known and that it might never be fully accurate. So far, nearly 80 people have died a result of the storm and its effects, according to the Associated Press. SHARE YOUR THOUGHTSHave officials responded effectively to the disaster in Texas? Why or why not?

title: Live Question & Answer Event - Ask WSJ: Texas Grapples with Mass Power Outages - WSJ.com
authors: Shayndi Raice,Russell Gold,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: LIVE Q&A Replay | February 18, 2021Ask WSJ: Texas Grapples with Mass Power Outages Texas is experiencing one of its coldest weeks in a generation. Temperatures fell into the single digits this week, leaving thousands of residents desperate to find warmth after the state power grid failed to manage the frigid weather.

title: Texas Cities Under Boil-Water Orders
description: Many Texans are without access to safe drinking water after widespread power outages caused pipes to burst and a major water-treatment plant to lose power, leaving cities like Houston and Austin under boil-water orders. A harsh winter storm crippled Texas’s energy grid earlier this week, leaving millions of residents without electricity or heat in subfreezing conditions for days on end.

title: In Frigid Texas, Desperate Families Take Risks to Stay Warm
description: AUSTIN, Texas—The children played in front of four lighted gas burners in East Austin on Tuesday night as their family tried to warm up during days of subfreezing temperatures, no power, and no relief on the horizon. One-year-old Alex Johnson Jr. toddled, his brother Gabriel Brewster, 3, played with a toy, and their cousin Desiah Fisher, 6, hugged them close, as eight other family members huddled around the light of a single candle.

title: Winter Storm Creates Havoc Across the U.S.
authors: Talal Ansari,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: Millions of Americans were without power Tuesday after a winter storm brought snow, ice, blackouts and record-setting low temperatures to swaths of the U.S. Nearly 75% of the Lower 48 states of the U.S. was under snow cover, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s National Snow Analysis daily report, including many places rarely hit by inclement weather. A week ago, 45% of the Lower 48 was under snow.

title: Fort Worth Crash Leaves Five Dead in Massive Pileup
description: At least five people were killed and dozens more were rushed to hospitals after a massive pileup on a Fort Worth, Texas, freeway. The crash, involving an estimated 70 to 100 vehicles or more, according to police, occurred around 6:30 a.m. Thursday morning, on an unusually cold day, when roadways were icy. Daniel Segura, a Fort Worth police officer, confirmed the fatalities and said first responders are still trying to get others to safety. “We still have a very active scene,” Mr. Segura said.

title: As Biden Decides What to Do With Trump’s Border Wall, Landowners Are in Limbo
authors: Elizabeth Findell,Michelle Hackman,The Wall Street Journal
description: MISSION, Texas—The Trump administration’s border wall now nearly stretches to the riverside retreat where the Cavazos family fishes, barbecues and earns a living on the Rio Grande. To the west, a recently completed stretch of wall stops at their property line. To the east, the bustle of contractors moving dirt continued this past week around a partially built stretch of wall.

title: Covid-19 Vaccine Confusion Leads Volunteers to Create Online Guides
authors: Elizabeth Findell,Alejandro Lazo,The Wall Street Journal
description: Americans have been struggling to figure out where and how to get Covid-19 vaccinations due to glitchy or incomplete online portals and overwhelmed phone hotlines set up by state and local governments. Engineers in California organized a website that lists vaccine availability across the state, relying on hundreds of volunteers to gather the information via daily phone calls to more than 1,500 locations.

title: Samsung Eyes Investing Up to $17 Billion in New U.S. Chip Plant
authors: Elizabeth Findell,Asa Fitch,Elizabeth Koh,The Wall Street Journal
description: South Korea’s Samsung Electronics Co. is considering an investment of as much as $17 billion to build a chip-making factory in Arizona, Texas or New York, according to documents and people familiar with the company’s plans. Samsung is scouting two locations in and around Phoenix, two locations in and near Austin and a large industrial campus in western New York’s Genesee County, according to one of the people.

title: Covid-19 Vaccines Are Getting Stuck at the Last Step
authors: Elizabeth Findell,Jared S. Hopkins,Dan Frosch,The Wall Street Journal
description: In Texas, a man slept in his car for two nights straight to keep his place in a vaccination line. In Kentucky, residents registered online for shots, but found when they arrived that their doses were taken by walk-ins. In New Mexico, state officials scrambled to hire more people after a vaccination hotline was overwhelmed with calls. The biggest challenge in America’s Covid-19 vaccination effort is getting shots into the arms of the right people.

title: Despite Lack of Evidence for Fraud, Trump Supporters Say Election Confidence Shaken
description: Many Trump voters said that, even without proven evidence of wrongdoing, they couldn't shake a general unease that the election was unfair and wanted to see deeper investigations. Some said the sheer volume of accusations convinced them that something was wrong.

title: ‘Startup city’: Accelerated growth strains Austin
description: AUSTIN, Texas—A few years ago, some blocks of Austin’s South Congress Avenue featured a castle-themed wax museum and comic book shop, a neighborhood bar with $1 taco deals, an auto shop and, in season, a Santa Claus on horseback. Then, as at so many other places in Austin, the construction cranes came. Those blocks recently reopened with a strip of modern urban buildings with shops offering national brands from Lululemon to Le Labo perfumes.

title: ‘Startup City’: Accelerated Growth Strains Austin
authors: Elizabeth Findell,Konrad Putzier,The Wall Street Journal
description: AUSTIN, Texas—A few years ago, some blocks of Austin’s South Congress Avenue featured a castle-themed wax museum and comic book shop, a neighborhood bar with $1 taco deals, an auto shop and, in season, a Santa Claus on horseback. Those blocks recently reopened with a strip of modern urban buildings with shops offering national brands from Lululemon to Le Labo perfumes. The $2,000+ private membership club Soho House and an Hermès store are on the way.

title: U.S. Officials Urge Calm Over New Covid-19 Strain Abroad
authors: Ken Thomas,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: Officials across the U.S. urged calm and continued caution Sunday, following the identification of a new strain of Covid-19 in the U.K. Researchers in the U.K. estimate that the variant could be as much as 70% more transmissible than more established strains. Some of the changes are on the spike protein on the surface of the virus, potentially enabling it to more easily cling to and enter human cells. Scientists don’t believe it is any more deadly.

title: Covid-19 Vaccines Are Slow to Reach Rural America
authors: Dan Frosch,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: Five days after Covid-19 vaccines started rolling out across the U.S., rural hospital executives like Cory Edmondson are still waiting, and hoping, that they will receive some doses soon. “How do you tell your staff, your nurses, your doctors, ‘Hey, we’re not going to get the vaccine [yet]?’” said Mr. Edmondson, chief executive of Peterson Health in Kerrville, a town of about 24,000 in the Texas Hill Country.

title: Newly Reported U.S. Coronavirus Cases Back Above 200,000
authors: Brianna Abbott,Alejandro Lazo,Kristina Peterson,Joe Barrett,Jeffrey T. Lewis,Sarah Toy,Jenny Strasburg,Dasl Yoon,Paul Vieira,Rolfe Winkler,Joanna Sugden,Ruth Bender,Felicia Schwartz,Dan Frosch,Andy Duehren,Luciana Magalhaes,Miho Inada,Vipal Monga,Elizabeth Findell,Peter Loftus,The Wall Street Journal
description: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration cleared LabCorp’s mail-in Covid-19 test for use without a prescription on Wednesday, marking the first authorization of a direct-to-consumer test kit. The test enables any individual aged 18 or above to self-swab a sample and ship it to LabCorp for analysis without the signoff from a medical provider. It is currently available online, and the clearance also enables the company to potentially distribute the kit in retail stores.

title: As Covid-19 Vaccines Roll Out, States to Determine Who Gets Shots First
authors: Dan Frosch,Elizabeth Findell,Peter Loftus,The Wall Street Journal
description: The U.S. is about to launch one of the most daunting public-health efforts in generations: swiftly distributing a Covid-19 vaccine across all 50 states, each of which will determine who gets priority. As soon as this weekend, the Food and Drug Administration is expected to grant emergency approval to a Covid-19 vaccine from Pfizer Inc. PFE 3.18% and BioNTech SE. BNTX 1.92% Within 24 hours, 6.4 million doses are set to be sent to every state and the District of Columbia.

title: Texas Attorney General’s Legal Woes Potentially Hinder Google Case
authors: Elizabeth Findell,Keach Hagey,The Wall Street Journal
description: AUSTIN, Texas—Eight high-ranking employees of the Texas attorney general’s office reached out to law-enforcement authorities in September with a bold accusation, according to a lawsuit filed earlier this month. They claimed that their boss, Republican Attorney General Ken Paxton, had illegally used his office to interfere with an FBI investigation into a campaign donor.

title: Coronavirus Surge Doesn’t Keep Holiday Shoppers Away From Malls
authors: Sarah Nassauer,Elizabeth Findell,Nora Naughton,The Wall Street Journal
description: Americans visited malls this weekend saying they wanted to do Christmas shopping before potential lockdown restrictions are implemented or to avoid Black Friday crowds, as the spreading coronavirus looms over the holiday season. Tiffany Lambert and her 15-year-old son hunted for an Xbox Series X, a new hard-to-find videogame console, inside the Best Buy Co. store at Crossgates Mall in Albany, N.Y., on Saturday. “It’s...

title: El Paso Covid-19 Shutdown Blocked by Texas Court as Cases Rise
description: A Texas court ruled that El Paso can’t order residents to stay at home and shut nonessential businesses, throwing out some local efforts to fight Covid-19 cases that are rising so rapidly that local health authorities say morgue trucks and tent hospitals will run out of space. El Paso County had ordered a shutdown after Texas Gov. Greg Abbott had reopened businesses, and the court ruled late Friday that the county can’t go against the wishes of state officials. A...

title: Texas Is First State to Pass One Million Confirmed Covid-19 Cases
description: Texas became the first U.S. state to surpass one million confirmed Covid-19 cases Wednesday, according to data collected by Johns Hopkins University. The nation's second-largest state had a positivity rate of 10.5%, as infections rise nationwide. After an April lockdown, Texas saw confirmed cases rise rapidly in June and July, which led Gov. Greg Abbott to implement a statewide mask mandate and close bars statewide.

title: Fearing Lockdowns South Texas Hispanics Defected to Trump En Masse
description: For decades, no Democratic presidential candidate had won Starr County with less than a 48-point margin. Local lore is that the last Republican who came close to winning a partisan race was a sheriff’s candidate gunned down in a saloon in 1907.

title: Why Democrats Lost So Many South Texas Latinos—the Economy
description: RIO GRANDE CITY, Texas—For decades, no Democratic presidential candidate had won Starr County with less than a 48-point margin. Local lore is that the last Republican who came close to winning a partisan race was a sheriff’s candidate gunned down in a saloon in 1907.

title: Latino Voters Drifted From Democrats in Florida and Texas
authors: Arian Campo-Flores,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: Former Vice President Joe Biden performed more poorly than expected in the presidential election among Latino voters in Florida and Texas, highlighting a weakness for Democrats with an important constituency for the party. In Florida, Hispanic voters shifted markedly toward President Trump this year, compared with 2016, in several counties, including Miami-Dade, a bastion of Cuban-American voters, and Osceola, the heart of the Puerto Rican community in central Florida.

title: Heavy Early Voting in Texas May Mean Fewer Lines on Election Day
description: In Hays County, Texas, a rapidly growing suburban area south of Austin, several voters said they were surprised to see no lines on Election Day morning, speculating that perhaps everyone already voted. Early voting numbers in Texas surpassed the state's overall record 2016 turnout. Hays County, like suburbs of major Texas cities, is particularly competitive and turnout during early voting was more than 130% the total of 2016.

title: Latest Covid-19 Wave Worries Hospitals Even With New Treatments
description: © paul ratje/Reuters Advances in Covid-19 treatment have shortened hospital stays, easing capacity strains. But doctors and health-care disaster experts say the gains are not enough to meet a sustained rise in hospitalizations, particularly in remote pockets of the country that have smaller hospitals and fewer medical professionals. Nationally, a spring surge of Covid-19 hospitalizations peaked in mid-April and was followed by a second wave in late July.

title: Latest COVID-19 wave worries hospitals even with new treatments
description: Advances in Covid-19 treatment have shortened hospital stays, easing capacity strains. But doctors and health-care disaster experts say the gains are not enough to meet a sustained rise in hospitalizations, particularly in remote pockets of the country that have smaller hospitals and fewer medical professionals. Nationally, a spring surge of Covid-19 hospitalizations peaked in mid-April and was followed by a second wave in late July.

title: Covid-19 Is Worse in the Dakotas Now Than It Was in the Spring’s Hot Spots
description: The percentage of tests for Covid-19 coming back positive in South Dakota has soared to 46%. That’s more than eight times the World Health Organization’s recommended 5% threshold for businesses to be open. As Covid cases surge across the U.S. and in Europe, South Dakota and North Dakota hold a distinct position: Each has more new virus cases per capita than any other states have seen since the pandemic began. South Dakota has the most and North Dakota the second-most. “Those...

title: Latest Covid-19 Wave Worries Hospitals Even With New Treatments
authors: Melanie Evans,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: Advances in Covid-19 treatment have shortened hospital stays, easing capacity strains. But doctors and health-care disaster experts say the gains are not enough to meet a sustained rise in hospitalizations, particularly in remote pockets of the country that have smaller hospitals and fewer medical professionals. Nationally, a spring surge of Covid-19 hospitalizations peaked in mid-April and was followed by a second wave in late July.

title: Democrats Seek Gains in State Legislatures During Critical Census Year
authors: Christine Mai Duc,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: In addition to the presidency and U.S. Senate, Democrats have another target in next week’s elections: Evening up control of state legislative chambers for the first time in a decade. At stake isn’t just the ability to craft state laws, but to help shape district boundaries that will influence control of legislatures and the U.S. House after this year’s census.

title: Austin tax rate may mean election as city mulls AISD swap
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Wednesday Aug 9, 2017 at 12:01 AM Sep 22, 2018 at 2:39 AM Austin will consider a maximum tax rate of 46.5 cents per $100 of property value — a 14.4 percent revenue increase that could trigger an election — to facilitate a possible tax swap with the Austin school district. The City Council approved the maximum rate in a 6-4 vote Wednesday, despite council members Ellen Troxclair and Jimmy Flannigan saying they both intended to lead a citywide fight against it....

title: Early Voting in Texas Breaks Records
description: AUSTIN, Texas—Counties across Texas broke their own records for early voter turnout on Tuesday, the first day of in-person voting. The state is in the middle of several ongoing legal fights over early voting and mail-in ballots. Texas this year has nearly three weeks of early voting, which ends on the Friday before the election—this year, Oct. 30. Many polling stations had long lines on Tuesday.

title: In Texas, Fights Over the Ballot as Voting Is About to Start
description: AUSTIN, Tex.—Texas political factions are battling over when voting can begin in the state, what the ballot will look like and where voters can drop off ballots, just 10 days before polls are set to open in America’s second-largest state. Gov. Greg Abbott issued an executive proclamation limiting drop-off locations for mail-in ballots to one per county on Thursday, after some of the state’s largest counties had already sent voters as many as a dozen options.

title: Texas Border Communities Struggle to Rebuild After a Summer of Woes
description: RIO GRANDE CITY, Texas—Delia Perez could barely stomach stepping inside the destroyed shell of her home last month. Her mother was the first Covid-19 fatality in a county that would soon see among the virus’s highest per-capita death rates in the state. Then, as the virus raged across South Texas, Hurricane Hanna arrived, reducing to rubble the mobile home where Mrs.

title: Private Texas Border Wall Will Fall Into Rio Grande, Opponents Say
description: Opponents of a privately funded Texas-Mexico border wall are arguing that land erosion after Hurricane Hanna proves that the wall will fall into the Rio Grande River, citing engineering reports. We Build the Wall, a nonprofit that claimed credit for the project despite having little role in it, recently saw its leaders, including former Trump adviser Steve Bannon, accused of defrauding donors who gave to private border wall efforts. All have pleaded not guilty and are set for trial next year.

title: Dallas Police Chief Resigns Following Concerns Over Transparency and Use of Force
description: Dallas Police Chief U. Reneé Hall speaking to the media about demonstrators protesting in the city in May. Photo: larry w smith/Shutterstock Dallas Police Chief U. Reneé Hall on Tuesday submitted a resignation letter, following a backlash against her department’s handling of protests. Dallas, like other cities, saw widespread demonstrations against police brutality in the wake of the killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis.

title: Laura Weakens as Disaster-Weary Residents Pick Up the Pieces
authors: Valerie Bauerlein,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: PORT ARTHUR, Texas-—A weakened Tropical Depression Laura dumped rain across the mid-Mississippi Valley on Friday, a day after the storm wreaked havoc on the Gulf Coast and left at least six people dead and hundreds of structures destroyed. There were 510,000 people without power in Louisiana and 128,000 in Texas late Friday morning, according to poweroutage.us, which tracks outage reports from utilities. Laura...

title: Hurricane Laura Hits Gulf Coast With More Power Than Katrina
authors: Valerie Bauerlein,Rebecca Elliott,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: BEAUMONT, Texas—Hurricane Laura barreled ashore near the Texas-Louisiana border before dawn Thursday, a vicious Category 4 storm threatening what forecasters described as lethal flooding and widespread wind damage. Laura is a storm of historic proportions, with wind speed at landfall surpassing Hurricane Katrina in 2005.

title: Hurricane Laura Strengthens to Category 4: Live Updates
authors: Valerie Bauerlein,Rebecca Elliott,Talal Ansari,Collin Eaton,Allison Prang,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: Hurricane Laura barreled toward the Texas and Louisiana coasts late Wednesday as a vicious Category 4 storm, threatening what forecasters described as unsurvivable flooding and widespread wind damage. The fast-moving hurricane increased in strength late Wednesday with sustained winds of 145 miles-an-hour, according to the 5 p.m. update from the National Hurricane Center.

title: Hurricane Laura Strengthens in the Gulf of Mexico
description: Hurricane Laura strengthened into a major hurricane Wednesday morning, as it churned north through the Gulf of Mexico toward the Texas and Louisiana coasts, where it is projected to make landfall late Wednesday or early Thursday. The hurricane, currently a Category 3 storm with 115 mile-an-hour winds, is forecast to grow Wednesday to a Category 4 storm and unleash a storm surge as high as 15 feet, causing life-threatening flooding, according to the National Hurricane Center. ...

title: Laura Is Declared a Category 1 Hurricane After Marco Fizzles
description: Tropical Storm Laura has developed into a Category 1 hurricane, according to the National Hurricane Center, and is now projected to strengthen over warm Gulf of Mexico waters before making landfall early Thursday. The National Hurricane Center earlier issued a hurricane watch stretching from an area in Texas near Houston to western Louisiana as the two states prepared for Laura to strengthen to a hurricane before making landfall. ...

title: Hurricane Watch Is Issued for Texas-Louisiana Border Region
description: The National Hurricane Center issued a hurricane watch stretching from an area in Texas near Houston to western Louisiana as the two states prepared for Tropical Storm Laura to strengthen to a hurricane before making landfall later this week. A period of “rapid strengthening” is possible as the storm moves across the Gulf of Mexico, and predictions for its intensity range, with some predicting a major hurricane, the center said in its 5 p.m. update Monday.

title: Austin Produced Willie Nelson and Others. Can Its Music Scene Survive Covid-19?
description: AUSTIN, Texas—Music fans travel from all over the world to Austin to catch a live band any night of the week while having a beer and taco on the patio of a club. But the Covid-19 pandemic is bringing what industry insiders fear could be a debilitating blow to the iconic venues of the self-proclaimed live-music capital of the world.

title: Steve Bannon Charged in Alleged Border-Wall Fundraising Scheme
authors: Corinne Ramey,Rebecca Ballhaus,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: Former senior Trump adviser Steve Bannon was arrested and charged with fraud Thursday in connection with an alleged scheme to siphon hundreds of thousands of dollars from a crowdfunding campaign backing one of the president’s signature promises: building a wall along the southern U.S. border. The We Build the Wall campaign raised more than $25 million, according to prosecutors from the Southern District of New York, which brought the case.

title: Texas Governor Threatens to Freeze Property Taxes of Cities That Defund Police
description: Texas Gov. Greg Abbott threatened Tuesday to permanently freeze the property taxes of any city that defunds its police department, specifically calling out the city of Austin for recent reductions to its police budget. “Any city that defunds police departments will have its property tax revenue frozen at the current level,” said Mr. Abbott, a Republican. “They will never be allowed to increase property tax revenue again.” The governor didn’t say what would qualify as defunding.

title: Austin mayoral candidate banned from Royal Blue Grocery
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Wednesday Aug 29, 2018 at 12:01 AM Sep 26, 2018 at 9:32 AM Be careful what you do in Royal Blue Grocery if you want to be mayor. Inside the Royal Blue Grocery at Fourth and Nueces streets, a photo of Austin mayoral candidate Alexander Strenger hangs on the back of a deli case. It’s not a campaign ad. It’s a warning to employees not to let him in the store. Employees of the store confirmed Monday that Strenger is banned from at least some of its various Austin...

title: Will Texas Shut Down Again Amid Surge in Covid-19 Cases?
description: As he gathered on the White House lawn for an event on deregulation last week, Kevin Roberts, executive director of the powerful Texas conservative group Texas Public Policy Foundation, found that others kept pressing him for news from home. They wanted to know: Would Texas shut down again? In Houston, where booming Covid-19 cases have pushed many hospitals beyond their intensive-care unit capacity for the first time, doctors have been sounding alarms for weeks.

title: In Texas, a Doctor Fights the Surge and Gets Covid-19; ‘I Cry Every Day’
description: We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription. You will be charged $ + tax (if applicable) for The Wall Street Journal. You may change your billing preferences at any time in the Customer Center or call Customer Service. You will be notified in advance of any changes in rate or terms. You may cancel your subscription at anytime by calling Customer Service. Please click confirm to resume now.

title: Why Arizona Wasn’t Ready for Its Coronavirus Surge
authors: Dan Frosch,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: In the state with the highest per-capita rate of Covid-19 cases in America over the past week, Arizonans are waiting up to eight hours in the broiling hot sun to get tested. A metropolitan area of a million people was down to 17 free ICU beds Tuesday. A top health official in the largest county said the coronavirus is now so widespread that contact tracing is almost ineffective.

title: Surge in Covid-19 Cases Tests Austin’s Reopening
authors: Kim Mackrael,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: For months, Nelly Garcia has operated her family’s custom bakery out of her third-floor apartment, working 13-hour days to keep up with an increase in demand. But as Texas eased restrictions on businesses during May and June, Ms. Garcia said she had started to think about returning to the bakery’s storefront in East Austin, which would allow her to rehire some part-time employees. Those...

title: The Coronavirus Surge in Florida, Arizona, Texas Isn’t the Same as New York’s Crisis
authors: Elizabeth Findell,Brianna Abbott,Eliza Collins,The Wall Street Journal
description: PHOENIX—The virus that ravaged Northeastern U.S. cities is surging through Southern and Western states. It’s different this time. Younger people are getting sick with Covid-19. States that had brief coronavirus lockdowns are struggling to encourage social distancing and mask-wearing. Many people appear to have embraced their usual summer rituals. Health officials are sounding alarms about a surge in cases racing not through nursing homes, but bars and house parties.

title: Some Texas Counties Impose Mask Requirement on Businesses
description: HOUSTON—On Monday, the first day that businesses here were required to make their customers wear face coverings, a few walked out of Phoenicia Specialty Foods in protest, said Haig Tcholakian, owner of the Houston grocery chain. He didn’t mind. The store wants everyone to wear masks inside and finally has a reason to enforce that: The county is making them.

title: 「黒人のウォール街」 100年前の虐殺から再起
authors: Elizabeth Findell,Alejandro Lazo,The Wall Street Journal
description: 【タルサ】米南部オクラホマ州タルサの中心街からすぐ北に位置するグリーンウッド地区。ここにリッコ・ライト氏が営むアートギャラリーがある。店内には、地元の美術品や黒人解放運動家アンジェラ・デービス、映画監督スパイク・リー、作家トニ・モリスンの肖像画と並んで、「ブラック・ウォール・ストリート」と書かれたTシャツが展示され、レコードプレーヤーからはジャズが流れていた。 100年前、グリーンウッドの黒人コミュニティーは活気にあふれていた。白人暴徒の焼き打ちに遭い、何百人もが殺害される前、「ブラック・ウォール・ストリート」として知られていたが、現在の姿からは想像もつかない。しかし、この地域は今、暴力的な過去と向き合い、様々な組織が新たな機会創出に取り組む中、地域再生を目指している。 3月にグリーンウッドに移転したギャラリーのオーナーであるライト氏は「私が目指したのは単にアートと音楽、文化をここに集めることだ」と話す。「ブラック・ウォール・ストリートの先達（せんだち）や亡くなった人々、そして再建に努めようとここに残った人々に敬意を表するために、訪問者がやって来ている」...

title: Former ‘Black Wall Street’ Aims to Rebuild as Tulsa Comes Into National Spotlight
description: TULSA—“Black Wall Street” T-shirts were on display alongside local art and images of Angela Davis, Spike Lee and Toni Morrison at Ricco Wright’s art gallery Thursday, as jazz music played on a set of turntables. It is a far cry from what the bustling black community of Greenwood, once known as Black Wall Street, was a century ago, before white mobs burned it to the ground and killed hundreds.

title: Former ‘Black Wall Street’ Aims to Rebuild as Tulsa Comes Into National Spotlight
authors: Elizabeth Findell,Alejandro Lazo,The Wall Street Journal
description: TULSA—“Black Wall Street” T-shirts were on display alongside local art and images of Angela Davis, Spike Lee and Toni Morrison at Ricco Wright’s art gallery Thursday, as jazz music played on a set of turntables. It is a far cry from what the bustling black community of Greenwood, once known as Black Wall Street, was a century ago, before white mobs burned it to the ground and killed hundreds.

title: Covid-19 Hospitalizations Surge in Some States
authors: Eliza Collins,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: Some U.S. states that were largely spared during the early days of the Covid-19 pandemic are now seeing record hospitalizations, causing some experts to fear that loosened restrictions and the approach of summer led many Americans to begin letting down their guard. The post-Memorial Day outbreaks in states come roughly a month after stay-at-home orders were lifted.

title: George Floyd the Athlete, Classmate Remembered at Houston School
description: HOUSTON—Red and gold spanned the Jack Yates High School football field Monday, where hundreds of alumni wore T-shirts bearing the face of their lion mascot and the name of the alumnus whose dying breaths made him famous. Here in Houston’s Third Ward, a low-income, predominantly black area south of downtown, George Floyd, the man killed in Minneapolis after being pinned under a policeman’s knee May 25, wasn’t just a name shouted at a protest.

title: Protesters Gain Backing of Some Lawmakers as George Floyd Movement Rolls On
authors: Jennifer A. Calfas,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: The movement to reform policing appeared to gain traction with some lawmakers after nearly two weeks of protests sparked by the killing of George Floyd and a weekend of some of the largest demonstrations to date. On Monday, House Democrats unveiled an overhaul of policing laws that would make it easier to prosecute officers for misconduct, collect national data and establish new training programs to counter racial bias. In...

title: George Floyd Protests Latest Updates
authors: Jennifer A. Calfas,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: Derek Chauvin, the former police officer charged with second-degree murder in the killing of George Floyd, is facing bail of up to $1.25 millionHouse Democrats unveiled a sweeping overhaul of policing laws aimed at making it easier to prosecute officers for misconduct. New York state lawmakers are set to take up a dozen bills this week in response to recent protests over police violence, including a measure that will make officer disciplinary records more transparent.

title: Wave of protests fuels moves to shift funding from police
description: The largest protests sparked by the killing of George Floyd remained mostly peaceful across the U.S. this weekend, as emboldened organizers said they didn't plan to stop rallying until they saw concrete changes in police policy. From New York to Los Angeles, and in cities of all sizes in between, protesters asked officials to defund police departments and redirect those funds to other programs. They called for banning police chokeholds and revamping law-enforcement training programs.

title: Protests Sparked by George Floyd Killing Set to Resume as Some Leaders Dial Back Enforcement
authors: Andrew Restuccia,Shan Li,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: Protests were expected to resume Sunday across the U.S., while President Trump said he ordered the National Guard to start to withdraw from Washington, D.C., after some of the largest crowds yet gathered peacefully Saturday to demand justice-system overhauls after the killing of George Floyd. Washington authorities said Saturday’s protests near the White House and at places such as the Lincoln Memorial drew more people than on previous days.

title: Appeals Court Blocks Texans’ Access to Mail-In Voting
description: Texans cannot request mail-in ballots based on a fear of catching Covid-19 at the polls, a federal appeals court ruled Thursday, the latest development in a high-stakes fight over voting in the nation’s second-largest state. The Fifth U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals blocked an injunction from a federal judge last month that gave Texans the right to request mail-in ballots during the pandemic.

title: Austin Protester in Critical Condition, Brother Says
authors: Elizabeth Findell,Christopher Mims,Joanna Stern,Julie Jargon,The Wall Street Journal
description: A black college student is in critical condition after he was struck Sunday by a nonlethal round shot by police into a crowd of protesters in Austin, his brother said. Police Chief Brian Manley said the student wasn't the intended target of a bean bag round fired into his head late Sunday night, but was standing near someone who threw a water bottle and backpack at officers. The president of Texas State University on Wednesday identified the victim as Justin Howell, 20.

title: George Floyd’s Hometown of Houston Tries to Unite Through the Tension
description: HOUSTON—In George Floyd’s hometown, tens of thousands gathered downtown Tuesday afternoon with signs protesting his death and police brutality. State and local politicians joined them. Chants resounded in the air. Dancers moved to drumbeats. Children, carried on their parents’ shoulders, clapped. Volunteers passed out water, snacks, masks, and first aid advice. Nearby office buildings were boarded up in anticipation of vandalism.

title: 全米各地で抗議デモ、中小都市にも飛び火 黒人暴行死事件
authors: Elizabeth Findell,Valerie Bauerlein,The Wall Street Journal
description: ユタ州ソルトレークシティーのデモ参加者（5月30日） Photo: Rick Bowmer/Associated Press 米ミネソタ州ミネアポリスで黒人男性が警官に拘束され死亡した事件を巡る抗議デモは、保守的なテキサス州西部からカリフォルニア州の閑静な郊外まで、全米各地に広がりを見せている。 中小の都市でも人々が街頭で平和的または暴力的に、抗議デモを行った。その多くは、過去に警官の残虐な行為に抗議する大規模デモがほとんど起きなかったか、一度もない地域だ。 ノースカロライナ州のウェイクフォレスト大学法科大学院の刑事司法プログラム担当ディレクター、カミ・チェイビス氏は「米国が噴火した」と語り、今回の抗議活動は過去のものより激しいと指摘。「今回はコミュニティーの結束の強さが違うと感じる」と話した。...

title: Protests Spread Beyond Big Cities, From Raleigh to Santa Rosa
authors: Elizabeth Findell,Valerie Bauerlein,The Wall Street Journal
description: In conservative West Texas. In Omaha, Neb. Across the quiet suburbs of California. The rage and despair sparked by the death of George Floyd in police custody has spread far beyond Minneapolis, to communities of all sizes. People took to the streets over the weekend—peacefully and violently—in many small and midsize cities that have seldom, if ever, seen large protests over police brutality. “The...

title: Push to build border wall accelerates in Texas despite coronavirus pandemic
description: LAREDO, Texas -- Tony Medina sat at a desk in his home last week, surrounded by toolboxes and photos of his family. In front of him was a neatly printed four-page statement he had prepared for his virtual hearing to explain to a federal judge why he doesn’t want the property he has owned for more than 40 years to be taken by the U.S. government for a border wall.

title: Push to Build Border Wall Accelerates in Texas
description: LAREDO, Texas—Tony Medina sat at a desk in his home last week, surrounded by toolboxes and photos of his family. In front of him was a neatly printed four-page statement he had prepared for his virtual hearing to explain to a federal judge why he doesn’t want the property he has owned for more than 40 years to be taken by the U.S. government for a border wall.

title: America Is Reopening for Summer, and Tensions Are High
authors: Rebecca Davis O’Brien,Arian Campo-Flores,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: Tricia McIntyre, a 48-year-old emergency-room nurse from southern Wisconsin, donned a mask last Sunday, sat down behind a plexiglass shield at a nail salon, and got her first manicure in two months. “Finally!” Ms. McIntyre said, a few days after Wisconsin’s top court overturned the state’s coronavirus shutdown order.

title: Three Malls in Three States: A Weekend Shopping Trip Under Coronavirus
authors: Sarah Nassauer,Cameron McWhirter,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: On Saturday morning Tracie Giarmo drove 30 minutes to Toledo, aiming to escape Michigan’s store closures and take advantage of just reopened Ohio malls. At the Franklin Park Mall in Toledo about half the stores inside were still closed, including Macy’s, Dillard’s and the Apple Store. The mall’s Pottery Barn closed last year, part of a wider pullback on physical stores as shopping has shifted online. Ms....

title: Texas Businesses Defy Coronavirus Shutdown
description: CONROE, Texas—A Dallas beauty-salon owner was arrested last week for opening before the state lifted its shutdown, sparking national outrage. A bar and gym in Odessa opened, aided by men who drove hundreds of miles to stand outside the businesses with guns. State lawmakers near Houston defied the governor of their own party as they got illegal haircuts on camera and tweeted about it.

title: America Wants to Reopen From Coronavirus But Disagrees About How
authors: Ian Lovett,Elizabeth Findell,Sarah Nassauer,The Wall Street Journal
description: In Oklahoma, hair salons began welcoming back clients this week; next door in Kansas, they remain empty. In Orlando, Fla., retail shops can open to customers again on Monday; in Miami, they must stay closed. And in the Texas capital, Austin, one landmark restaurant resumed serving dine-in customers on Friday; another down the street is still...

title: In Rural Texas, Lone Doctor, Also County Judge, Crafts Coronavirus Policy
description: CLARENDON, Texas—“How many today?” John Howard asked a physician assistant minutes before his clinic opened on April 24, as the staff prepared for another day of treating potential coronavirus patients in the Texas Panhandle. “Two more, both negative,” she replied. Dr. Howard, the only doctor in over 900 square miles, was pleased. That made...

title: States Move to Ease Lockdowns as Global Cases Top 3 Million
authors: Jennifer Calfas,Elizabeth Findell,Newley Purnell,The Wall Street Journal
description: Updated April 27, 2020 8:26 pm ETTexas, Ohio and other states took steps to ease lockdown orders and reopen their battered economies, as reported U.S. coronavirus cases neared one million. Leaders in states hit harder by the pandemic, however, were moving more slowly and urging people to stay home as officials sought to expand testing capacity and create contact-tracing teams. Copyright ©2023 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All Rights Reserved. 87990cbe856818d5eddac44c7b1cdeb8

title: Texas governor lays out plan to reopen some sectors closed by coronavirus
description: The Wall Street Journal Published: April 17, 2020 at 4:30 p.m. ET Stores will be allowed to reopen on a to-go or delivery basis; state parks also reopening Texas Gov. Greg Abbott Getty Images Texas Gov. Greg Abbott set the nation’s second-largest state on a path to reopening Friday, with an announcement that shopping, hiking and some medical procedures may restart as soon as next week.

title: Texas Governor Set to Reopen Some Sectors Closed by Coronavirus
description: Texas Gov. Greg Abbott set the nation’s second-largest state on a path to reopening Friday, with an announcement that shopping, camping and some medical procedures may restart as soon as next week. Stores will be allowed to reopen April 24 on a to-go or delivery basis, similar to restaurants, so employees can run items to customers at the front doors to the shops, at their car windows or at their homes, Mr. Abbott said. “We’ve...

title: Trump Signals He Backs Protests to End Safety Guidelines
authors: Andrew Restuccia,Sabrina Siddiqui,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: President Trump signaled his support for protests in some state capitals against stay-at-home orders designed to slow the coronavirus pandemic, a day after telling governors that they would be the final decision makers about reopening their economies. In a series of tweets on Friday, Mr. Trump highlighted three states—Michigan, Minnesota and Virginia—that have Democratic governors and where protests, organized in part by conservative groups, have taken aim at social-distancing measures.

title: In Texas a Battle Brews Over Voting by Mail Amid Coronavirus
description: Republicans and Democrats in Texas are locking horns over coronavirus-related efforts to expand voting by mail, with Republicans arguing it can fuel voter fraud and Democrats warning that disallowing it could harm turnout and sway results. The Texas Democratic Party has filed two lawsuits against state election officials and Republican Gov. Greg Abbott to extend the state’s limited mail-in eligibility.

title: Photos: Coronavirus Creates Uncertainty for Texas Cattle Dealers
authors: Elizabeth Findell,Christopher Lee,The Wall Street Journal
description: Texas cattle dealers are facing an uncertain future amid the coronavirus pandemic, which has roiled industries big and small. Live cattle futures, which determine sale prices, have plunged. Restaurants are closed. And packing plants have had to slow their processing amid health precautions. Livestock dealers, who buy cattle to finish them...

title: In Laredo, Texans Get Creative With Order to Wear Masks
description: One way or another, Laredoans are following orders to mask up. A few have been able to get their hands on real medical masks. Some are wearing bandannas tied around their noses and mouths, while others are using coverings plucked from their fishing boxes with sports logos and pop culture insignia. One man, spotted by a local pizza-maker, walked through downtown with a towel tied over his face. The...

title: Turmoil at the Austin Zoo: Documenting a zookeepers' revolt
description: How zookeepers came together to question animal care, leadership at private Austin facility Lions Sango and Jelani relax in their enclosure at the Austin Zoo last week. The zoo has been grappling with accusations from some of its zookeepers that management decisions have caused animals to suffer. (RALPH BARRERA/ FOR THE AMERICAN-STATESMAN) By Elizabeth Findell For one zookeeper, a long-suffering monkey's death launched a revolt.

title: Judge Rules Texas Can’t Limit Access to Abortions During Coronavirus Pandemic
description: Planned Parenthood and other abortion providers sued to block the move by Texas. Photo: Godofredo A Vasquez/Associated Press By March 30, 2020 7:24 pm ET A federal judge ruled that Texas isn’t allowed to halt abortions for now amid the new coronavirus pandemic after the state’s governor and attorney general moved last week to halt the procedure.

title: Texas’ Coronavirus Response Is Keep It Local, as More States Move to Lockdowns
description: Texas Gov. Greg Abbott is used to overruling the state’s major cities on a host of issues. With the new coronavirus, he is leaving it to the locals. As a result, some Texans face orders to stay inside for all but essential activities while others are still free to be out and about. Mr. Abbott is resisting calls for a statewide stay-at-home order, while cities and towns this week each make their own call over how to deal with the pandemic.

title: Two States Say Coronavirus Medical Restrictions Should Halt Abortions
authors: Brent Kendall,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: A pair of states are saying their coronavirus restrictions on some medical procedures compel providers to stop performing most abortions, setting up new skirmishes on the issue at a time of national crisis. Governors around the U.S. are ordering elective and nonessential medical procedures be postponed to preserve personal-protective equipment, such as masks and gloves, and critical-care resources for medical workers and facilities responding to the novel coronavirus pandemic. ...

title: For Some Adventurers, National Park Trips Become Ultimate Coronavirus Quarantine
description: LEE’S FERRY, Ariz.— As a pandemic ravaged the world, Mark Malchoff was preparing to drop off it for a while. The Plattsburgh, N.Y., resident’s group of 11 departed Thursday morning for 22 days on rafts, deep in the Grand Canyon, where they would have no contact with the outside world. On the eve of their launch, they weighed excitement and nervousness.

title: Despite Coronavirus, Some Religious Services Continue
authors: Ian Lovett,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: DALLAS—County officials here have banned gatherings of more than 500 people and recommended gatherings of more than 250 be canceled to help halt the spread of the new coronavirus. But on Sunday, crowds streamed into First Baptist Dallas, the downtown megachurch. Hundreds quickly filled the worship center, while more than 250 people went to...

title: Stop the Music: South by Southwest Coronavirus Cancellation Reverberates Through Economy
authors: Elizabeth Findell,Rebecca Elliott,Russell Gold,Alex Scott,The Wall Street Journal
description: AUSTIN, Texas—As South by Southwest approached, tech and cultural leaders from more than a hundred countries were preparing to flock to the festival this weekend to network, build buzz and down a few drinks. Walt Disney Co. rented out a sausages-and-beer restaurant to create an immersive experience promoting its X-Men spinoff movie, “The New Mutants.” DTSQ, a South Korean rock band, was ready to fly halfway around the world to play for 40 minutes on a rooftop bar.

title: Leading Texas School Board Candidate Wants to Teach Pole Dancing, Conspiracy Theories
description: AUSTIN, Texas—He wears a jester hat, frequently tweets photos of women’s breasts and advocates for teaching in schools that Lyndon Johnson assassinated John F. Kennedy. And he was the leading vote-getter for the Republican nomination to a seat on the Texas State Board of Education. Robert Morrow, 55 years old, won nearly 55,000 votes in Tuesday’s...

title: South by Southwest Hit Hard by Coronavirus Cancellation
description: AUSTIN, Texas—The chief executive of South by Southwest said organizers are unsure how they will keep the festival going after the city canceled it because of the novel coronavirus, which he said could cost them millions. Austin officials on Friday pulled the plug on the tech, music and movie event, citing the threat of the coronavirus outbreak.

title: South by Southwest Festival Canceled Over Coronavirus
authors: Rebecca Elliott,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: Austin’s South by Southwest festival has been cancelled due to concerns about the coronavirus, the city’s mayor said Friday, the latest major event to be called off due to fears of the fast-spreading disease. “After consultation with the city manager, I’ve gone ahead and declared a local disaster in the city,” Austin Mayor Steve Adler said in a news conference, adding that the order effectively cancels South by Southwest for this year. ...

title: After Hourslong Waits to Vote, California Considers Changes, Texas Doesn’t
authors: Christine Mai Duc,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: In Santa Monica, volunteers brought cookies, pizza and bottled water. At the University of California, Los Angeles, the co-star of “The Princess Diaries” grabbed a microphone and encouraged students not to give up. Lines to vote in parts of California and Texas on Super Tuesday ran as long as four or five hours, voters reported, leading Golden State officials to call for changes, and a Texas official to call on voters to weigh in earlier. ...

title: Coronavirus Is Devastating the Conference Circuit
authors: Collin Eaton,Rebecca Elliott,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: Leaders of Austin’s South by Southwest festival reassured the public this week that the Texas tech, film and music event would still kick off as planned March 13, despite concerns over the coronavirus epidemic. But behind the scenes, Austin politicians, public health officials and others were meeting with organizers to decide whether the show should go on—and if so, how—as more than 40,000 people signed an online petition calling for its cancellation and Facebook Inc. and Twitter Inc.

title: Long Lines in Houston, and West Hollywood
authors: Elizabeth Findell,Emily Glazer,Christopher Mims,Joanna Stern,The Wall Street Journal
description: In diverse south central Houston, 10 Republican voting machines had seen only 24 voters all day, while the line for the 10 Democrat machines was an hour and a half long. Election judge Carmen Cuneo apologized to voters and said the wait was the longest she'd seen since she started working elections in 2004. Some endured the long wait to log votes even for unlikely candidates.

title: Coronavirus Fears Keep Texas Poll Workers at Home
authors: Elizabeth Findell,Christopher Mims,Joanna Stern,Julie Jargon,The Wall Street Journal
