description: In the Austin, Texas, area, many election judges and poll workers failed to show up to their posts, telling county elections officials they were fearful of coronavirus, according to a statement from Travis County Clerk Dana DeBeauvoir. “Super Tuesday got off to a rocky start due to multiple no-shows,” the clerk said. “To the extent that the Elections Office was given a reason, it seems people were fearful of the Coronavirus.”The office began filling in its own personnel.

title: Texas Latinos, Usually Conservative Democrats, May Swing to Sanders
description: MISSION, Texas—Flor Martinez has spent most afternoons for the past couple of weeks walking the neighborhoods of Texas’ Rio Grande Valley, knocking on doors and asking Democratic voters, mostly in Spanish, to support Bernie Sanders for president. Ms. Martinez spent the weeks leading up to the 2016 presidential primary doing the same thing. But this year is different, she said. More people know who the Vermont senator is. More of them sound interested in his views.

title: Texas Mobilizes for Coronavirus Response
description: By Elizabeth Findell Texas officials are preparing for every possibility as they mobilize for possible public transmission of coronavirus, Gov. Greg Abbott said Thursday. The state activated its crisis State Management Operations Center Jan. 31, which is where Texas Department of State Health Services personnel respond to any local requests for assistance and coordinate activities and data, the governor said. DSHS is also preparing a network of state laboratories to process the coronavirus test.

title: Survivors of Church Shootings Run as Gun-Rights Candidates
description: SEGUIN, Texas—Stephen Willeford was widely hailed by supporters of the Second Amendment as the model “good guy with a gun” in 2017, when he grabbed an AR-15 rifle and pursued and shot at a gunman killing churchgoers in Sutherland Springs, Texas. Two and a half years later, the gregarious plumber has embraced the moniker Good Gun Guy Wille in speeches, church security training and now in a campaign for local county commissioner.

title: Wuhan Evacuees Hunker Down for Weeks in Quarantine
authors: Elizabeth Findell,Brianna Abbott,The Wall Street Journal
description: Tennessee resident David Mayes was in China visiting his girlfriend in Wuhan when officials locked down the city on Jan. 23, aiming to stop a rapidly spreading coronavirus that has killed hundreds there. Overnight, the city turned into a ghost town, Mr. Mayes said. Eight-lane highways were empty. Businesses were shuttered. But some Americans have made it out, on flights chartered by the U.S. State Department from an otherwise-closed airport.

title: Two Dead in Gun Violence at Texas College Dorm
authors: Jennifer A. Calfas,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: Two people were killed and a third injured in a schooling at a Texas A&M University-Commerce residence hall in Commerce, Texas, on Monday. Photo: larry w smith/Shutterstock By Feb. 3, 2020 3:41 pm ET At least two people died and a third was injured in a shooting at a Texas college residence hall Monday morning, the school said.

title: Weslaco, Mercedes land battle heads to the courts
description: Posted: Thursday, September 26, 2013 8:00 am Weslaco, Mercedes land battle heads to the courts By Elizabeth FindellThe Monitor Brownsville Herald An eastern Hidalgo County land tussle turned to the courts Tuesday, as the city of Weslaco obtained a temporary restraining order to stop Mercedes from annexing land between the cities.

title: HED: Recall petition yields opposing harassment claims
description: SAN JUAN— The fight over a recall petition filed in San Juan earlier this month has gotten uglier, with both the city and the petition’s activists making harassment claims against one another. Last Friday evening, city officials found their Christmas party interrupted when they were served with a temporary restraining order.

title: Three More Cases of Coronavirus Confirmed in U.S.
description: The virus has sickened approximately 2,000 people and killed 56, most of them in China. Photo: Kevin Frayer/Getty Images By Jan. 26, 2020 3:59 pm ET Three people in California and Arizona were diagnosed Sunday with the coronavirus that has sparked fears of a fast-spreading outbreak, bringing the total U.S. cases of the China-borne virus to five.

title: Houston Blast Kills at Least Two
description: The blast Friday morning in Houston was felt miles away. Photo: KTRK-TV/Associated Press By Jan. 24, 2020 12:15 pm ET HOUSTON—At least two people were killed in an industrial explosion Friday morning in northwestern Houston. The blast, which occurred around 4:30 a.m. at Watson Grinding & Manufacturing Co., leveled buildings and shook houses for miles. The cause is under investigation.

title: Texas’ Only Home for Matadors Is on Brink of Closing
description: LA GLORIA, Texas—On opening day in Texas’ only bullfighting ring earlier this month, a mariachi version of “The Star-Spangled Banner” played before a matadora dressed in gold sequins waved her cape at a passing bull and the crowd rumbled its first “Olé!” From the announcer’s booth, 83-year-old Fred Renk warned that the bull had spunk. Mr. Renk has hosted bullfights here on his ranch for 20 years, in the traditional Spanish style but with one key difference: No one injures the bulls.

title: Texans Try to Keep Christmas Snow in Their Freezers-For 15 Years
description: EDINBURG, Texas—When the power goes out, the one item in her freezer that Loren Dykes races to save is a 15-year-old snowball. “I don’t know if it’s technically still called snow, but it’s something,” she said. “It looks like a bit of crunchy ice.” Christmas Day 2004 marked the first time snow fell in South Texas’ Rio Grande Valley in 109 years. Residents raced to make their first snow angels, build their first snowmen and have their first snowball fights. Many had never before seen snow.

title: Private Border Wall Construction Can Proceed, Judge Rules
description: Tommy Fisher, president of Fisher Industries, with a section of the border wall he has been building along the Rio Grande. Photo: Elizabeth Findell/The Wall Street Journal By Jan. 9, 2020 6:31 pm ET MCALLEN—Construction of a private border wall in Texas can proceed, a federal judge ruled Thursday, over the objections of the U.S. government, which fears the project could shift the border itself and imperil a treaty with Mexico.

title: One-Year-Old Girl Can Be Removed From Life Support, Texas Court Rules
description: A Texas hospital may be allowed to remove a 1-year-old girl from life support against her mother’s wishes, after a state appeals court judge denied the family’s request for an injunction Thursday. Cook Children’s Medical Center in Fort Worth told the family of 11-month-old Tinslee Lewis in October that it wouldn’t continue treating her because doctors believe she has no chance of recovery and is only suffering, according to a timeline provided by the hospital.

title: Texas Church Shooting Leaves Two Dead, One Wounded
description: Two people were killed and one wounded after a gunman opened fire at a Texas church Sunday morning, according to the Associated Press. The West Freeway Church of Christ in White Settlement, near Fort Worth, Texas, was live streaming the service when the shooting occurred just before 10 a.m. central. Local media who watched the stream before it was made private reported that it appeared a gunman shot two men before an armed person in the church returned fire. ...

title: Private Texas Border Wall Caught in Legal Fight
description: McALLEN, Texas—An effort to build a privately funded wall along the U.S.-Mexico border, as the Trump administration’s efforts progress slowly, is running into trouble over concerns that its design may alter the border itself. Construction of the three-mile section in South Texas was halted last week after a U.S. attorney for Texas’s southern district obtained a temporary restraining order Dec. 5 against its builder, Fisher Industries, a North Dakota-based contractor.

title: Construction of Texas Border Wall Stalls Over Fights With Landowners
description: LAREDO, Texas—Nearly three years into the Trump administration, almost no border wall has been built in Texas. Local property owners ranging from ranchers to a Catholic diocese and institutions have resisted federal efforts to claim their land. The resistance in South Texas, where most land is privately owned, illustrates the challenges in building a border wall, even if funding is available. U.S....

title: District 3 council candidates kick off city-sponsored election forums
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Thursday Aug 30, 2018 at 12:01 AM Sep 26, 2018 at 12:10 PM Six candidates for the Austin City Council’s District 3 seat met on a stage Wednesday night, when incumbent Sabino "Pio" Renteria touted his work on the council, his sister Susana Almanza challenged his record, and four first-time candidates began to hash out their different platforms ahead of Election Day on Nov. 6. While various community organizations are expected to organize forums for the five council...

title: El Paso Walmart to Reopen, With Mixed Emotions, After Mass Shooting
authors: Elizabeth Findell,Sarah Nassauer,The Wall Street Journal
description: EL PASO, Texas—Walmart process supervisor Gilbert Serna tossed and turned with anxiety for two nights before returning to the store where he has worked since 2002, and where he fled a mass shooter in August. His brother, who has worked at the same store 16 years, encouraged him and said they would go together. When he walked in the door, the renovated store looked different, but Mr. Serna also felt his anxiety subsiding. “I was happy to be back home,” he said.

title: Texas Governor to Establish Campground for Homeless in Austin
description: Republican has been feuding with liberal city leaders over who can better manage the issue Gov. Greg Abbott, left, shown with Dennis Bonnen, speaker of the Texas House, plans to let homeless people camp on a plot of state-owned land in southeastern Austin Photo: Jay Janner/Austin American-Statesman/TNS/Zuma Press Escalating his feud with Austin city leaders over how to address the Texas capital’s problem of homelessness, Gov.

title: Texas Begins Clearing Homeless From Austin Underpasses
description: Contractors clean up underneath U.S. Highway 290 West, completing work ordered by Texas Gov. Greg Abbott to clear out homeless areas in Austin. Photo: Bob Daemmrich/Zuma Press By Nov. 5, 2019 5:31 pm ET Texas Gov. Greg Abbott is carrying through on his vow to begin clearing the homeless from Austin underpasses this week, as a standoff between city leaders and the state continues.

title: Victim’s Family Sues Accused El Paso Shooter, His Family and 8Chan
authors: Elizabeth Findell,Erin Ailworth,The Wall Street Journal
description: The family of a victim killed in the August mass shooting at an El Paso, Texas, Walmart Inc. store is suing the accused gunman, his parents and grandparents and the online message board 8chan. Four relatives of Angelina Englisbee filed the lawsuit Tuesday in El Paso District Court. Ms. Englisbee was one of 22 people killed in the rampage.

title: Homeless Becomes More Visible in Austin, Sparking Political Clash
description: AUSTIN, Texas—In 10 years of off-and-on homelessness, Rebecca Wallace has lived in the shadows of Texas’ capital city. Once, while living behind a shopping mall, she said a beating by a group of men put her in intensive care for weeks. Now, Ms. Wallace sleeps on an inflatable mattress under a freeway in the city’s busy tourist district, along with a growing number of other homeless people.

title: Weslaco EDC replaces interim director with city manager
description: WESLACO – Jerry Tafolla didn’t want any discussion about axing the second Economic Development Corporation director in three months. He just wanted to do it. The corporation board member and city commissioner moved Monday to remove Interim Director Alicia Aguilar back to her previous position as director of business retention and marketing and appoint City Manager Leo Olivares in her place.

title: Accused El Paso Shooter Patrick Crusius Pleads Not Guilty
description: A memorial outside the Walmart store in El Paso, where a mass shooting took place in August. Photo: Luis Torres/Zuma Press By Oct. 10, 2019 4:37 pm ET Patrick Crusius, the 21-year-old accused of killing 22 people at an El Paso Walmart, pleaded not guilty Thursday. The brief hearing in an El Paso courthouse was Mr. Crusius’ first since the Aug. 3 rampage, which also left 25 people wounded.

title: Dallas Officer Found Guilty in Shooting of Black Neighbor
authors: Dan Frosch,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: Amber Guyger, who is charged in the killing of Botham Jean in his own home, arrives on the first day of the trial in Dallas on Sept. 23. Photo: jeremy lock/Reuters By Elizabeth Findell Oct. 1, 2019 12:07 pm ET DALLAS—A jury on Tuesday found a former Dallas police officer guilty of murder​for shooting and killing her upstairs neighbor after she mistakenly walked into the wrong apartment.

title: Austin Butts Heads With Texas Leaders Over Abortion Funding
description: The city of Austin is caught in a political and legal feud with Texas Republicans over what constitutes public support for abortion, in the latest clash between the state’s conservative leaders and its overwhelmingly liberal capital. The current fracas began when the GOP-led state legislature earlier this year banned cities from making “any transaction” with an abortion provider.

title: Murder or Mistake? Cop on Trial for Shooting Neighbor in Apartment Mix-Up
description: DALLAS—The trial of a police officer who shot and killed her upstairs neighbor after accidentally walking into his apartment began with prosecutors saying sexual banter between her and her work partner showed that fatigue wasn’t the problem when she failed to recognize it wasn’t her home. Amber Guyger’s attorneys called it a tragic accident that she came home tired from a long day of work on Sept.

title: Deadly Floods in Texas Revive Memories of Hurricane Harvey
description: Darlene Aoch and Pat Blue were rescued from their mobile home as water trapped them Thursday in Vidor, Texas, following flooding from tropical depression Imelda. Photo: Ryan Welch/Associated Press By Elizabeth Findell Sept. 20, 2019 1:25 pm ET HOUSTON—James Revia still hasn’t finished repairing his home from Hurricane Harvey two years ago. But on Thursday, the waters came again.

title: Rain From Tropical Storm Inundates Parts of Texas
description: Two men head off Thursday to rescue a family trapped by floodwaters as rain from Tropical Depression Imelda inundated the area near Patton Village, Texas. Photo: Brett Coomer/Associated Press By Elizabeth Findell Updated Sept. 19, 2019 1:08 pm ET HOUSTON—Rescuers mobilized early Thursday to reach people stranded by flooding around Beaumont, Texas, while forecasters warned of potential danger coming soon to Houston, 80 miles to the west.

title: In Texas, a Surprise Fight for Control of the State House
description: AUSTIN—A scandal at the heart of the Texas House of Representatives has thrown Republicans in the state into turmoil and led to jitters over whether it could be the straw that breaks the party’s longstanding hold on power here. Democrats, who have been gaining in popularity as demographics in the state shift, need to win nine seats to gain a majority in the Texas House for the first time since 2001.

title: Texas Governor Seeks to Plug Law Enforcement Holes After Mass Shootings
description: AUSTIN, Texas—Texas Gov. Greg Abbott issued eight executive orders Thursday in response to a pair of recent mass shootings, while resisting legislative Democrats’ calls for a special session to consider new gun legislation. The order by Mr. Abbott, a Republican, calls for the Texas Department of Public Safety to work with state and local law enforcement agencies to better assess threats and share information more effectively.

title: Texas Shooter Called 911, FBI in Hours Before Rampage
description: Seth Ator, the suspect alleged to have killed seven people in a shooting rampage Saturday, was fired from his job and called 911 and the FBI tip line in the hours before opening fire in and around the West Texas city of Odessa, authorities said Monday. Ator went to work at Journey Oilfield Services on Saturday and was there a short time before he was fired, Odessa Police Chief Michael Gerke said in a news conference.

title: 米テキサス州が銃規制を緩和、携行など容易に
authors: Esther Fung,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: 米テキサス州で今年に入り可決した銃規制の緩和に関する州法が1日、施行された。同法により公共の場で銃を携行することが容易になる一方、学校や地主などは敷地内で銃器の管理や所持について規制をしにくくなる。 ...

title: As Texas Deals with Recent Violence, Looser Gun Laws in State Take Effect
authors: Esther Fung,Elizabeth Findell,The Wall Street Journal
description: A series of laws easing gun regulation in Texas that were passed earlier this year took effect on Sunday as the second-largest state in the U.S. was responding to a second shooting rampage in a month. The Texas Legislature in May and June passed laws making it easier for people to carry guns in public areas and more difficult for landlords and schools to regulate how firearms are stored or carried on their premises. Supporters...

title: Odessa Mayor Says Shooting Death Toll Has Risen to Seven
description: The death toll from a shooting rampage in West Texas rose to seven after two more people died overnight, Odessa Mayor David Turner said Sunday. The gunman, who was killed by police, shot at least 21 people as he tore between Odessa and nearby Midland on Saturday afternoon, firing at random and hijacking a U.S. Postal Service van, authorities said.

title: Panel: Adler aide violated city's ethics rules
description: A former aide to Austin Mayor Steve Adler violated four sections of city code by quietly taking payments from a nonprofit that won city contracts he promoted, the Austin Ethics Review Commission declared Wednesday night. The commission’s vote came a year and a half after an American-Statesman investigation into conflicts of interest between the aide, Frank Rodriguez, and the nonprofit, the Latino HealthCare Forum, which he founded.

title: Amid plans to expand Austin convention center, a battle simmers
description: After years of discussion, the Austin City Council reached a quiet and abrupt consensus last month on what many predicted would be the biggest fight of 2019: They agreed to expand the Austin Convention Center. But don’t start singing "Kumbaya" yet. With a petition drive to force an election on the expansion, opponents mobilizing and both sides amping up their messaging, the fight might be just beginning.

title: Frustration mounts as city says there’s no explanation for water spikes
description: As soon as he saw his September water bill, O.T. Greer knew something was wrong. In the 44 years he’s lived at his house on Aspen Street in North Austin, he’d never seen a water spike like the one this fall when his bill jumped from $22 to $215 in a month. Greer and his neighbors pride themselves on water conservation. His yard is xeriscaped with cacti and rocks.

title: After eight months, Austin Zoo's animal care manager to depart
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Wednesday May 15, 2019 at 5:55 PM May 15, 2019 at 5:55 PM The animal care director hired by the Austin Zoo after a zookeeper revolt last fall is leaving after eight months. The city of Abilene announced Tuesday that Jesse Pottebaum had been hired as the new director of the city-operated Abilene Zoological Gardens. He will begin work there May 28, according to a city news release. Pottebaum moved to Austin from Florida in September to be deputy director at the...

title: Audit: Austin Energy supervisor took favors from city vendor
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Monday May 13, 2019 at 2:55 PM May 13, 2019 at 2:56 PM An Austin Energy supervisor took favors from a city vendor he oversees, including having the company build him a fence with old utility poles and having one employee dig a hole for a mailbox, city auditors concluded in an investigation released Monday. Auditors stated that they found strong evidence the employee, John Wilson, may have billed work at his home to Austin Energy, but they were unable to...

title: Austin throws support behind Green New Deal
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Thursday May 9, 2019 at 5:46 PM The Austin City Council on Thursday formally backed a national “Green New Deal” — a concept from freshman U.S. Rep. Alexandra Ocasio-Cortez, D-N.Y. “The Council recognizes we are already experiencing the adverse consequences of climate change, understands the urgency of creating a blueprint to prepare for and respond to the shocks and stressors of catastrophic climate events, and supports the general tenets of the Green New Deal,”...

title: Eanes voters pass bond, elect board members
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindellLuz Moreno-Lozano @LuzMorenoLozano Thursday May 9, 2019 at 10:15 AM May 9, 2019 at 10:15 AM Eanes school district voters overwhelmingly approved an $80 million bond Saturday. Of 3,277 votes cast, 83% said yes to the bond, which will fund the construction of aquatics, robotics and wrestling facilities as well as upgrades for campus security, buildings, buses and student programs. In the school district’s Place 7 trustee race, incumbent Ellen Balthazar won easily...

title: Good news, state employees: You can book an Airbnb stay
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Thursday May 9, 2019 at 3:25 PM May 9, 2019 at 5:22 PM Texas state employees on business trips and University of Texas students seeking reimbursement for trips may officially stay in Airbnb rentals again. As of Wednesday, the Texas Comptroller's Office no longer listed the online booking giant among companies banned from doing business with Texas because of anti-Israel stances. Airbnb found itself included with Israel boycotters in March, after announcing last...

title: Ethics review against ex-mayoral aide Rodriguez still stalled
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Thursday May 9, 2019 at 2:16 PM May 9, 2019 at 2:52 PM Former mayoral aide Frank Rodriguez saw one more delay to an ethics review of self-dealing allegations against him, after an attempt to dismiss the matter with a resolution agreement failed Wednesday night. A 2017 American-Statesman review of possible conflicts of interest involving Rodriguez, who was an aide to Mayor Steve Adler, and a nonprofit he founded led city auditors to investigate. Auditors ultimately...

title: Council to vote on new home, next steps for Dougherty Arts Center
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Wednesday May 8, 2019 at 5:14 PM May 8, 2019 at 5:14 PM Dougherty Arts Center will be destined for a new home after Thursday, if City Council members sign off on a move for the 41-year-old facility now housed in a 72-year-old former naval reserve facility. Austin voters approved bonds in November and in 2012 to fund the $28.5 million redevelopment of the arts center. The plan that Austin Parks and Recreation staffers have rolled out would move the center from its...

title: Austin water plants are OK, as flooding recalls turbidity crisis
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Monday May 6, 2019 at 1:55 PM May 6, 2019 at 1:55 PM Operations remained normal at Austin's water treatment plants through flooding late last week, but operators are keeping an eye out as more wet weather rolls in, Austin Water spokeswoman Ginny Guerrero said Monday. Austin water plants normally do fine in a region that sees flooding fairly often. Last year, however, flood water that streamed into Austin from the silty Llano River caused such high particle levels,...

title: Eanes school district favoring bond package in early voting
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindellLuz Moreno-Lozano @LuzMorenoLozano Saturday May 4, 2019 at 7:14 PM May 4, 2019 at 7:14 PM Those who voted early in the Eanes school district heavily favored an $80 million bond. With Election Day results not yet tallied, yes votes on the bond were leading no votes 83% to 17%. In the school district's trustee race, incumbent Trustee Ellen Balthazar was ahead of McKennon Rice, a student who decided to make a run for the seat. Balthazar had 79% in early voting to...

title: FINAL RESULTS: Eanes school district approves bond package by wide margin
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindellLuz Moreno-Lozano @LuzMorenoLozano Saturday May 4, 2019 at 7:14 PM May 4, 2019 at 9:54 PM Eanes school district voters have overwhelmingly approved an $80 million bond. With full unofficial results tallied, yes votes on the bond Saturday were leading no votes 83% to 17%. In the school district's trustee race, incumbent Trustee Ellen Balthazar easily won over McKennon Rice, a student who decided to make a run for the seat. Balthazar received 79% of votes to Rice's...

title: Austin joins a neighborhood short-term rental fight
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Friday May 3, 2019 at 3:56 PM May 3, 2019 at 4:23 PM For more than two years, Robert Reeves has been duking out a neighborhood battle on his quiet neighborhood street fronting Lady Bird Lake. Reeves sued two of his neighbors on Edgecliff Terrace in 2016, accusing them of creating a private nuisance on the street by renting their homes illegally short term to bachelor parties and hoards of noisy tourists. One neighbor caved and sold the home. The other dug in and...

description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Wednesday May 1, 2019 at 3:29 PM May 1, 2019 at 3:29 PM Keep it natural.

title: ARCH's revised efforts involve fewer beds but more aid
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Monday Apr 29, 2019 at 6:38 PM Apr 29, 2019 at 6:38 PM Despite an increasing homeless population in Austin, the ARCH shelter downtown hasn't turned away anyone recently, city employees told a City Council committee Monday. Instead, it appears that many of the homeless aren't taking advantage of a lottery system used to distribute beds. “A lot of people outside are not waiting to sleep there,” said Vella Karman, a city public health program manager. “They have a...

title: To upgrade DNA testing, council approves funds, new position
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Thursday Apr 25, 2019 at 5:24 PM Apr 25, 2019 at 5:24 PM Some 1,300 backlogged rape kits tested for DNA are still awaiting a secondary analysis that would allow the results to be entered into a national database, Austin’s police forensic director told City Council members Thursday. Despite the need, those secondary tests won’t be addressed as part of a swath of funding for forensics that council members approved during their latest meeting. Dana Kadavy, who...

title: City Council looks to improve testing of DNA evidence
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Wednesday Apr 24, 2019 at 5:33 PM Austin is preparing this week to bolster its analysis of forensic evidence, amid years of efforts to fix the Police Department's troubled DNA processing. Whether the new moves will help address backlogged cases remains unclear. City Council members Thursday will vote on five items to extend funding for secondary forensic analysis, add a police staff position to deal with sexual assault evidence and extend a contract to process DNA...

title: San Marcos school trustee apologizes after drunken driving arrest
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Saturday Apr 20, 2019 at 3:35 PM Apr 20, 2019 at 3:35 PM A San Marcos school board trustee was arrested on drunken driving charges early Friday morning, he wrote in an apology note posted Saturday on Facebook. Miguel Arredondo, 27, who has served on the school board since 2015, wrote that he had been charged with Driving While Intoxicated after a traffic stop at 12:31 a.m. Friday. Hays County jail records show he was assessed a $2,500 surety bond. Arredondo said...

title: Austin Energy glitches mean darkened holiday for family
description: It was a cold Saturday morning in late December when the lights went out at Ashley Impastato’s North Austin apartment. She put in a call to Austin Energy and learned the outage was limited to her family's apartment. When told that resetting the breaker hadn't fixed the problem, the customer service agent told Impastato a repair crew was on its way.

title: City: Shoal Creek slope still a danger
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Tuesday Apr 16, 2019 at 6:26 PM Apr 16, 2019 at 6:26 PM Nearly a year after a mudslide took out a chunk of hillside above Lower Shoal Creek, the reshaped slope “continues to present a danger to public health and safety,” Austin’s interim director of Watershed Protection wrote in a memo this week. Come June, the department will ask City Council members to ratify emergency contracts already in place and authorize moving forward on reconstruction of the slope,...

title: City may cover shortfall as new homeless shelter stalls
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Thursday Apr 11, 2019 at 4:07 PM Apr 11, 2019 at 6:35 PM City money might fill the gap to make a recently built Salvation Army homeless shelter operational. The $12 million shelter, on the verge of completion in East Austin, is designed for families with children and built to hold 212 people. But the Salvation Army hasn’t been able to raise enough money to cover its operations, which will run about $5.2 million per year, said Andrew Kelly, the Salvation Army area...

title: Tax cap alarm growing louder at Austin City Hall
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Wednesday Apr 10, 2019 at 6:32 PM Apr 10, 2019 at 6:32 PM Before the Austin City Council voted on any agenda items two weeks ago, Mayor Steve Adler was deep into a passionate monologue about a choice subject not on the agenda: The dangers to Austin of a Texas Legislature-proposed tax increase cap. Segueing from talk about a homelessness initiative, Adler said there was something he wanted to mention “while there is a room full of people — a real important...

title: Airbnb reverses policy that landed it on Texas' anti-Israel list
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Tuesday Apr 9, 2019 at 4:33 PM Apr 9, 2019 at 4:33 PM Airbnb is backtracking on a plan to de-list properties in Israeli settlements in the West Bank, after backlash that included being banned from doing business with the state of Texas. “We will continue to allow listings in all of the West Bank,” the home rental booking giant said in a news release Tuesday. “Any profits generated for Airbnb by any Airbnb host activity in the entire West Bank will be donated to...

title: Emotions high as House committee weighs short-term rental rules
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Thursday Apr 4, 2019 at 2:00 PM Apr 4, 2019 at 3:48 PM State representatives heard testimony Thursday about what short-term rentals mean to Texas cities, as the House Urban Affairs Committee took a first look at a proposed bill to overturn local regulations on such rentals. State Rep. Angie Chen Button, R-Richardson, the committee's chairwoman, and state Sen. Pat Fallon, R-Prosper, filed identical bills in both bodies that would prevent cities from limiting...

title: Council ponders whether bigger convention center could better fit Austin
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Tuesday Apr 2, 2019 at 3:47 PM Apr 2, 2019 at 3:47 PM The questions began this week over what the role of the Austin Convention Center should be in a growing and changing downtown, tossed out by city leaders starting to consider possible expansions of the building that occupies six blocks. title: Plans for plant expansion draw suspicion in Weslaco
description: WESLACO — Diggers have moved buildings worth of dirt over the last two years at the quiet plant east of Texas Boulevard and Sugar Cane Drive, where the city’s drinking water is purified. Workers laid thousands of tons of concrete. A house-sized water tank joined the map of structures on the property.

title: UT report outlines convention center expansion pros, cons
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Friday Mar 29, 2019 at 7:22 PM Mar 29, 2019 at 7:23 PM Expanding the Austin Convention Center will cost more than it returns in tax revenue, but the move may be worth it because of the abstract benefits of drawing additional tourists and further branding the city, a University of Texas report on expansion possibilities states. The report, requested by the City Council in late 2017 and made public Friday, took no stance on how or whether the convention center...

title: Austin ethics changes will take employee investigations out of public view
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Thursday Mar 28, 2019 at 6:43 PM Austin will adjust its ethics review process to shield high-level city employees from a public investigation, City Council members decided unanimously Thursday, making the change despite concerns from some transparency watchdogs. Under the new process, employees exempt from civil service representation — a group that includes most city executives — will no longer see ethics complaints against them heard by the Ethics Review...

title: Annual count shows more homeless in Austin
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Tuesday Mar 26, 2019 at 10:15 AM Mar 26, 2019 at 10:15 AM An annual "point in time" count found 2,255 unsheltered homeless people in Austin this year, up five percent from 2018, city and community leaders said at a news conference Tuesday. title: Weslaco water gets expensive
description: WESLACO — Maria Montoya’s family keeps track of every drop they drink. The family of nine shares a small trailer on East 19th Street, where Montoya said they’ve watched their water bill jump from $76 to $130 per month. “It’s too much,” she said in Spanish. “We pay more for water than light.” They were shocked when they saw the first bills after the city of Weslaco raised water rates — first in late 2011 and then again late last year.

title: Proposed change would take some city ethics complaints out of public view
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Friday Mar 22, 2019 at 2:42 PM Some of City Hall’s highest level executives will see future accusations of ethics violations against them handled out of public view, if Austin City Council members pass a proposal offered by Mayor Steve Adler. The changes, outlined in an ordinance after Adler first proposed them in a message board post last week, would remove city employees from the Ethics Review Commission process unless they are the staff member of an elected...

title: Two more hires round out Austin city executive team

Such rentals, facilitated by online booking sites such as Airbnb and Homeaway, have boomed, especially in neighborhoods close to...

title: Ex-employees protest Austin Zoo in wake of animal care controversy
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Sunday Mar 17, 2019 at 4:01 PM Mar 17, 2019 at 4:02 PM Holding photos of animals they say died in agony or were otherwise mistreated at the Austin Zoo, a small group of former zookeepers, board members and their allies lined the road to the zoo’s entrance Sunday. title: Austin PAC admits ethics violation, but intent at issue

title: In pro-Israel move, Texas books boycott of Airbnb
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Wednesday Mar 13, 2019 at 9:54 AM Mar 13, 2019 at 9:54 AM Add a household name to Texas’ relatively obscure list of companies banned from doing business with the state because of their stances on Israel: Airbnb. The Texas comptroller quietly this month named the online home rental giant among companies it says boycott Israel and thus will be boycotted back by Texas. Airbnb does not boycott Israel — it operates more than 20,000 listings there — but it has banned...

title: Is Airbnb anti-Israel? Texas orders boycott
description: Elizabeth Findell, Austin (Texas) American-Statesman Tuesday Mar 12, 2019 at 8:12 AM AUSTIN, Texas — Texas has added Airbnb to its list of companies banned from doing business with the state because of their stances on Israel. The Texas comptroller quietly this month named the online home rental giant among companies it says boycott Israel and thus will be boycotted back by Texas. Airbnb does not boycott Israel — it operates more than 20,000 listings there — but it has banned listings in...

title: Head of Austin Zoo steps down from board, remains director
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Monday Mar 11, 2019 at 7:06 PM Mar 11, 2019 at 7:08 PM Embattled Austin Zoo leader Patti Clark stepped down as president of the non-profit's board of directors but will remain its executive director, the zoo announced Monday in an email to supporters. Clark and the zoo have faced outrage on social media since an American-Statesman story published in January detailed zookeepers' claims of mismanagement and animal mistreatment. The zoo's email Monday said Clark will...

title: Three keepers at Austin Zoo fired in wake of Statesman report
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Wednesday Mar 6, 2019 at 4:18 PM Mar 6, 2019 at 4:22 PM Three Austin Zoo zookeepers were fired in the past two weeks, a month after the American-Statesman reported about zookeepers' allegations of animal mistreatment there. Kris Ledoux, a 9-year keeper at the zoo who spoke to the Statesman for the story, was suspended after it published. She said she was fired by phone Feb. 23 after refusing to meet with the zoo’s lawyer unless she could bring her own legal...

title: 3 keepers at Austin Zoo fired in wake of Statesman report
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Wednesday Mar 6, 2019 at 4:18 PM Mar 6, 2019 at 4:22 PM Three Austin Zoo zookeepers were fired in the past two weeks, a month after the American-Statesman reported about zookeepers' allegations of animal mistreatment there. Kris Ledoux, a 9-year keeper at the zoo who spoke to the Statesman for the story, was suspended after it published. She said she was fired by phone Feb. 23 after refusing to meet with the zoo’s lawyer unless she could bring her own legal...

title: Attorney general: City manager candidates not a competitive secret
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Friday Jan 12, 2018 at 12:01 AM Oct 31, 2018 at 2:34 PM The city of Austin cannot withhold records showing who applied for its city manager position by claiming the information would harm the city competitively in a search for qualified applicants, the Texas attorney general’s office says. Nor is the information a trade secret, a matter that would harm the search firm competitively or “highly intimate and embarrassing,” Matthew Taylor, an assistant attorney...

title: Outcry over report sparks push for changes at Austin Zoo
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Thursday Jan 31, 2019 at 6:40 PM Jan 31, 2019 at 6:40 PM Management at the Austin Zoo responded this week to the outcry that followed an American-Statesman report detailing claims from zookeepers that the zoo disregarded veterinary advice, allowed animals to suffer unnecessarily and retaliated against staffers who raised concerns. The Statesman based its report on interviews with 24 current and former zoo employees, 17 of them zookeepers, after six keepers penned...

title: City Council revises Austin's approach to homelessness
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Thursday Jan 31, 2019 at 5:42 PM Jan 31, 2019 at 5:57 PM Austin took steps Thursday to shift how the city handles homelessness, as the City Council approved a contract refining the role of a downtown homeless shelter and also endorsed a request for a pilot program to provide new short-term housing. Both moves are an attempt to create a pathway to permanent housing for Austin's estimated 7,500 homeless residents, city officials said. The contract extension for the...

title: Caregivers at Texas zoo claim animals are being mistreated
description: For one zookeeper, a long-suffering monkey's death launched a revolt. Annie was a patas monkey, a large species native to Central Africa, who went blind in 2010, forcing the Austin Zoo to separate her from her peers. Categorized as a dangerous animal, she had no contact with other monkeys or humans for years, zookeepers and the zoo's representatives told the Austin American-Statesman.

title: In effort to endure, Cisco's seeks historic designation
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Monday Jan 28, 2019 at 5:34 PM Jan 28, 2019 at 5:34 PM There aren’t many joints left in this town where septuagenarian Austinites can remember pulling up chairs as small children for plates of huevos rancheros and biscuits. The owners of Cisco’s are hoping a historic landmark designation can help keep one in business for the next generation. “With the change in the neighborhood and everything going on, you’re looking at all these things diminishing and going...

title: Turmoil at the Austin Zoo: Documenting a zookeepers' revolt
description: How zookeepers came together to question animal care, leadership at private Austin facility Lions Sango and Jelani relax in their enclosure at the Austin Zoo last week. The zoo has been grappling with accusations from some of its zookeepers that management decisions have caused animals to suffer. (RALPH BARRERA/ FOR THE AMERICAN-STATESMAN) By Elizabeth Findell For one zookeeper, a long-suffering monkey's death launched a revolt.

title: Texas Supreme Court rejects Laura Pressley election contest
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Friday Jan 25, 2019 at 11:14 AM Jan 25, 2019 at 6:14 PM The Texas Supreme Court on Friday ended once and for all former Austin City Council candidate Laura Pressley’s challenge of the 2014 election that put Greg Casar on the council. But the justices found a lower court’s order sanctioning Pressley for filing a frivolous suit went a step too far, leading them to reverse those sanctions. Casar won 64 percent of the vote in the 2014 District 4 council election, the...

title: Who’s moonlighting at Austin City Hall? Most departments don’t know
description: An Austin Energy worker responsible for approving developers’ electric service plans provided consulting services on the side to some of those same companies. An Austin Water spokesman approved a marketing contract with a firm that built him a free website for his real estate business. An information technology analyst used city equipment to send hundreds of emails and scan and print dozens of files related to his rental properties.

title: City of Austin's new moonlighting policy to take effect in March
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Sunday Jan 13, 2019 at 2:50 PM The same week that an employee resigned after auditors said he used his work computer at a second job, the city of Austin announced that its long-awaited new policy on moonlighting would take effect in March. A spokeswoman for the city's human resources department said Friday that a new policy has been finalized and begins March 1. It will require employees to notify supervisors if they work a second job and would require city...

title: Austin poised to get things done as new council members take seats, Adler says
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Monday Jan 7, 2019 at 9:43 PM Jan 7, 2019 at 9:43 PM Two new members officially joined the Austin City Council on Monday evening and four others, including Mayor Steve Adler, returned for second and third terms as they took their oaths of office. Council members also named their colleague Delia Garza mayor pro tem, making her the city's first Latina to hold the position. In that capacity, Garza will serve as mayor when Adler is absent. Amid the pomp and...

title: Smoke from fireworks possibly played role in 32-car crash on New Year's Eve
description: By Elizabeth Findell efindell@statesman.com Wednesday Jan 2, 2019 at 2:15 PM Jan 2, 2019 at 2:15 PM More than 50 people were part of a pileup involving 32 vehicles — two of them semitrucks — just an hour after ringing in the new year in Austin, Texas. Authorities began receiving reports of multiple collisions around 1:09 a.m. Tuesday near southbound Texas 130 and Harold Green Road, where dense fog obscured the road, said Travis County sheriff’s Capt. Craig Smith. Paramedics evaluated 56...

description: By Elizabeth Findell efindell@statesman.com Wednesday Jan 2, 2019 at 1:14 PM Jan 2, 2019 at 1:15 PM More than 50 people were part of a pileup involving 32 vehicles — two of them semitrucks — just an hour after ringing in the new year in Austin, Texas. Authorities began receiving reports of multiple collisions around 1:09 a.m. Tuesday near southbound Texas 130 and Harold Green Road, where dense fog obscured the road, said Travis County sheriff’s Capt. Craig Smith. Paramedics evaluated 56...

title: Austin city worker accused of deer hunting on the job
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Wednesday Jan 2, 2019 at 3:20 PM Austin Energy worker Jody Wood claimed to be checking transmission lines. Instead, city auditors say, he was hunting on city property near Walter E. Long Lake. In a misuse of city resources investigation, auditors said two other city employees saw Wood near a deer blind and feeder close to the lake in March, during time he was being paid for working. An hour and a half later, the employees found the blind and feeder had been moved...

title: Man hospitalized with life-threatening injuries after Austin stabbing
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Tuesday Jan 1, 2019 at 12:14 PM Jan 1, 2019 at 12:17 PM A man is in the hospital with potentially life-threatening injuries after being stabbed Tuesday, Austin-Travis County EMS said on Twitter. Medics responded just before 11 a.m. to a stabbing near 4500 E. Riverside Dr., according to a tweet. They took the injured man to Dell Seton Medical Center. No more details on the victim or what prompted the stabbing were immediately available. Austin police did not return...

title: Nine injured in 20-plus car pile-up
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Tuesday Jan 1, 2019 at 8:43 AM More than 50 people were part of a pile-up involving 20 to 30 cars just over an hour after ringing in the new year in Austin. Austin-Travis County EMS responded about 1:24 a.m. Tuesday to reports of multiple collisions in dense fog near southbound State Highway 130 and Harold Green Road, according to tweets from EMS. Paramedics evaluated 56 people and took nine to the hospital with non-life threatening injuries ranging from mild to...

title: Nine injured in 32-car pile-up
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Tuesday Jan 1, 2019 at 8:43 AM More than 50 people were part of a pile-up involving 20 to 30 cars just over an hour after ringing in the new year in Austin. Austin-Travis County EMS responded about 1:24 a.m. Tuesday to reports of multiple collisions in dense fog near southbound State Highway 130 and Harold Green Road, according to tweets from EMS. Paramedics evaluated 56 people and took nine to the hospital with non-life threatening injuries ranging from mild to...

title: Austinites cast off last year's bad spirits with chilly water
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Tuesday Jan 1, 2019 at 2:51 PM Jan 1, 2019 at 2:51 PM While you were sleeping it off, they were jumping in. They came in coats and in bathrobes. Some came in tank tops and swim trunks as if it were not 40 degrees and cloudy. And they jumped — in pairs, in groups and alone — into the relatively balmy 68-degree water of Barton Springs Pool. "It's so we can wipe off all the bad spirits," said Oakley Krcha, 8. "From last year," added her sister Sawyer, 10, as the...

title: Nine injured in 35-car pile-up
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Tuesday Jan 1, 2019 at 8:43 AM More than 50 people were part of a pile-up involving 20 to 30 cars just over an hour after ringing in the new year in Austin. Austin-Travis County EMS responded about 1:24 a.m. Tuesday to reports of multiple collisions in dense fog near southbound State Highway 130 and Harold Green Road, according to tweets from EMS. Paramedics evaluated 56 people and took nine to the hospital with non-life threatening injuries ranging from mild to...

title: Audit: City mishandles program to fix homes for low-income residents
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Sunday Dec 23, 2018 at 2:41 PM Dec 23, 2018 at 2:41 PM City program fumbles with funds and puts low-income residents at risk, report says The city’s office of Neighborhood Housing and Community Development frequently mishandled programs to help repair homes for low-income residents, an audit found this month. The NHCD failed to properly administer a program to give loans for home repairs, which led to fraud and safety risks, the audit found. The program also...

title: Independent Houston's credo on council: 'You don’t have to be either-or'
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Sunday Dec 23, 2018 at 3:53 PM Dec 23, 2018 at 8:07 PM Socially liberal and fiscally conservative, initial District 1 representative has been happy to be unpredictable Ora Houston’s biggest regret from her four years as a City Council member involves a resolution she doesn’t fully remember. She doesn’t recall exactly when it was discussed, or what the resolution supported or opposed, but it was one of those resolutions involving national politics, something...

title: One new face, one familiar in first Austin executive team hires
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Friday Dec 21, 2018 at 2:02 PM Dec 21, 2018 at 2:02 PM Austin City Manager Spencer Cronk named his first two executive team hires Friday, passing over both interim assistant city managers in favor of one alternate in-house hire and one Austin newcomer. Rodney Gonzales, currently director of Austin’s Development Services Department, will become the assistant city manager overseeing economic opportunity and affordability. Christopher Shorter, director of Washington...

title: Today at Austin City Council: Two members say goodbye
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Thursday Dec 13, 2018 at 11:11 AM Dec 13, 2018 at 11:11 AM Flowers lay at the seats of Austin representatives Ora Houston and Ellen Troxclair Thursday as they marked their final City Council meeting. The council kicked off its last meeting of 2018 by bidding goodbye to Houston and Troxclair, who both opted not to run for second terms this year. Voters Tuesday elected Natasha Harper-Madison to replace Houston in District 1 and Paige Ellis to replace Troxclair in...

title: Amid growing apprehensions at border but no 'caravan,' a quiet Army set to depart Texas
description: HIDALGO COUNTY — Border Patrol agents raced through thick brush along the Rio Grande, then slid down an incline and quickly surrounded a group of immigrants moving north. Once apprehended, the migrants sat dejected, pulling rosaries from around their necks to deposit them with their wallets and other personal belongings in plastic bags. One woman buried her face in her hands. Like most days recently, it had been a busy one for the agents.

title: Incumbent Renteria holds council's District 3 seat, defeating sister
description: East Austin City Council representative Sabino "Pio" Renteria will keep his District 3 seat after a second no-punches-held campaign against his sister. With final but unofficial results tallied, Renteria received 64 percent of the vote to his sister Susana Almanza's 36 percent.

title: Natasha Harper-Madison surges ahead in District 1 City Council race
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Tuesday Dec 11, 2018 at 7:13 PM Dec 11, 2018 at 7:13 PM Austin City Council candidate Natasha Harper-Madison held a nearly 3:1 lead Tuesday evening in a formerly close race to represent northeastern District 1. With election day results for the runoff not yet tallied, Harper-Madison had received 72 percent of the early votes to candidate Mariana Salazar's 28 percent. The two women both ran hard campaigns after narrowly edging out Vincent Harding, a former Travis...

title: Natasha Harper-Madison wins District 1 City Council seat
description: Austin City Council candidate Natasha Harper-Madison defeated Mariana Salazar with a nearly 3:1 margin Tuesday evening, in a formerly close race to represent District 1, which covers the northeastern part of the city. With final but unofficial results tallied, Harper-Madison received 72 percent of the early votes to opponent Mariana Salazar's 28 percent.

title: Council Member Renteria holds strong lead to keep seat over sister
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Tuesday Dec 11, 2018 at 7:16 PM Dec 11, 2018 at 7:16 PM Early voting results showed East Austin representative Sabino "Pio" Renteria well ahead to keep his District 3 City Council seat after a second no-punches-held battle with his sister. With election day results not yet tallied, Renteria had received 65 percent of votes to his sister Susana Almanza's 35 percent. Renteria was elected from a field of 12 candidates in 2014 after a runoff with Almanza. Since then,...

title: Natasha Harper-Madison claims District 1 City Council seat
description: Austin City Council candidate Natasha Harper-Madison defeated Mariana Salazar by a nearly 3:1 margin Tuesday evening in the race to represent District 1, which covers the northeastern part of the city. With final but unofficial results tallied, Harper-Madison received 72 percent of the early votes to opponent Mariana Salazar's 28 percent.

title: Incumbent Renteria holds District 3 seat against sister
description: East Austin City Council representative Sabino "Pio" Renteria will keep his District 3 seat after a second no-punches-held campaign against his sister. With final but unofficial results tallied, Renteria received 64 percent of the vote to his sister Susana Almanza's 36 percent.

title: Water Forward plan including artificial aquifers, graywater reuse gets council nod
description: A 100-year water resiliency plan that calls for massive underground reservoirs and reuse of wastewater is now city policy after gaining the approval of the Austin City Council. The plan, dubbed Water Forward, has been in the works since 2014, when years of drought led council members to call for a look at the city’s long-term water future. It proposes creating artificial aquifers that could store billions of gallons of potable water.

title: Water Forward plan gets council nod
description: A 100-year water resiliency plan that calls for massive underground reservoirs and reuse of city waste water is now city policy with the approval of the Austin City Council Thursday. The plan, dubbed Water Forward, has been in the works since 2014, when years of drought led council members to call for a look at the city’s long-term water future. It proposes creating artificial aquifers that could store billions of gallons of potable water.

title: Water Forward plan to build aquifers, reuse water gets council nod
description: A 100-year water resiliency plan that calls for massive underground reservoirs and reuse of city waste water is now city policy with the approval of the Austin City Council Thursday. The plan, dubbed Water Forward, has been in the works since 2014, when years of drought led council members to call for a look at the city’s long-term water future. It proposes creating artificial aquifers that could store billions of gallons of potable water.

title: 10 in the running for Austin assistant city manager hires
description: Austin City Manager Spencer Cronk announced 10 finalists for his first two assistant city manager hires as he seeks to overhaul his executive team. Cronk made waves a City Hall, with both praise and ire, in July, when he announced he would eliminate all five of the existing assistant city manager positions and create five new ones. The city officials already in those top jobs would have to reapply alongside outside candidates or depart.

title: Austin closes book on one Alamo Drafthouse Wonder Woman’ complaint
description: After a national controversy, cheers from star-spangled Wonder Woman fans, outrage from internet bros and a smackdown by Mayor Steve Adler of a critic, Austin is closing the book on formal discrimination complaints filed against the Alamo Drafthouse for its women-only screenings of "Wonder Woman" last summer. After all the hubbub, the Drafthouse will update its anti-discrimination policies.

title: Amid historic flooding, Austin water systems sank
description: On Oct. 18, two days after historic flooding swept away a concrete bridge on the Llano River upstream from Austin, an operator at Austin Water Treatment Plant 4 noticed something alarming: High levels of silt in the water at a rising Lake Travis were affecting the plant’s operations.

title: City nears settlement on fraudulent water billing
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Friday Nov 23, 2018 at 3:05 PM Nov 23, 2018 at 4:06 PM Austin is closing the book on an investigation of fraudulent water meter readings that caused bills to spike last year. The utility completed a review of the incident this month, and a legal settlement with the former meter reading company is close to completion. The settlement with Corix, the company formerly contracted to read city water meters, should be finalized next week, Monica Joyner, an Austin Energy...

title: Hit-and-run suspect wanted for murder in New Braunfels
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Thursday Nov 22, 2018 at 10:17 AM Nov 22, 2018 at 10:24 AM A Nevada man is wanted for murder in New Braunfels after fleeing a fatal car wreck, police said Thursday morning. Austin Taylor Meade, 26, of North Las Vegas, is accused of killing New Braunfels resident Amber Rachelle Williams, 39, as he raced away from police in a stolen truck near West County Line Road on Wednesday morning. He later threatened a woman with a knife to steal a second car, police said. The...

title: Austin Water leaders look for lessons as water crisis ebbs
description: Three weeks after a water treatment crisis that forced Austinites to boil drinking water for nearly a week, utility administrators are beginning to grapple with whether they could have done anything differently to avoid it. “We came pretty close to working this event without having to do a boil-water notice,” Austin Water Director Greg Meszaros told members of the Water and Wastewater Commission on Wednesday night.

title: Austin's long-term water plan calls for underground reservoirs, local sources
description: Austin’s recent water troubles gave new urgency to the first look at a water resiliency plan, years in the works, that local officials Tuesday said may be unprecedented nationwide. Unlike long-range planning for future growth and droughts in many other cities, the Water Forward plan doesn’t look for new sources of water farther from the city.

title: As Adler talks of mandate, what comes next for Austin?
description: Forty minutes after the polls closed in Austin on Tuesday night, Mayor Steve Adler was at his victory party, declaring that his re-election margin — which eventually settled at 60 percent, despite six challengers — represents a sweeping mandate for him to tackle his favored projects. “I do see the margin in the mayor’s race as an affirmation of what we’ve been doing in this city,” he said.

title: Candidates in three Austin council races ready for runoffs
description: Politicians across the country awoke Wednesday to wins and losses, ready to measure curtains for new offices or to seek new jobs. In Austin, where three of the four contested races for City Council seats will head to Dec. 11 runoffs, six candidates awoke to the prospect of ongoing campaigns. Mayor Steve Adler and District 9 Council Member Kathie Tovo easily won second and third terms, respectively, in Tuesday’s election.

title: Morrison concedes mayor's race after Adler rolls to early lead
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Tuesday Nov 6, 2018 at 7:34 PM Nov 6, 2018 at 10:24 PM Laura Morrison had an early night Tuesday. Mayor Steve Adler's top rival conceded the race to him minutes after early voting results were posted that showed Adler with an insurmountable lead. The early totals had Adler leading Morrison 61 percent to 19 percent. Both candidates assumed final Election Day results would not change the outcome of Adler avoiding a runoff in a field of seven candidates. "I'm excited...

title: FINAL: Siblings Renteria, Almanza will face off in City Council runoff, again
description: District 3 Austin City Council Member Sabino “Pio” Renteria could be headed to a runoff with his sister, Susana Almanza. With early votes and nearly two thirds of Election Day locations reporting, Renteria's remained about 48 percent — short of the majority total he'll need to avoid a runoff. Renteria’s sister, Almanza, a longtime East Austin activist, received nearly 22 percent of the early vote as of 10:45 p.m. Tuesday.

title: Three locked into tight race for City Council District 1
description: If early voting trends hold through Election Day, Northeast Austin could see a runoff between two of three candidates. Natasha Harper-Madison and Mariana Salazar each have received 25 percent of the vote. Vincent Harding has received 24 percent. The top two vote-getters would advance to a Dec. 11 runoff. The crowded race to replace City Council Member Ora Houston in District 1, who opted not to run again, includes seven contenders.

title: FINAL: Salazar, Harper-Madison head to District 1 runoff
description: 10:31 p.m. update: With early votes and nearly two thirds of Election Day precincts reporting, Austin City Council District 1 candidates Natasha Harper-Madison and Mariana Salazar were a single vote apart and the leaders for a potential runoff. Harper-Madison and Salazar both had about 25.5 percent of the vote as of 10:30 p.m. Vincent Harding was just behind them with 24 percent. When all results are tallied, the top two vote-getters will advance to a Dec. 11 runoff.

title: Adler leads Morrison 61 to 19 percent to keep mayor's seat
description: The mayor held a major lead after the release of early voting results, which saw him leading top rival Laura Morrison 61 percent to 19 percent. If the trend remains the same as Election Day results come in, Adler will easily avoid a runoff in a field of seven candidates. Morrison, a former City Council member, sought to challenge Adler largely on the basis of his views on development and support from monied downtown business interests.

title: Update: Morrison concedes mayor's race after strong Adler showing
description: Cheers erupted as Mayor Steve Adler arrived at his election party Tuesday night, minutes after top rival Laura Morrison conceded the election to him based on just the early voting results. Early voting totals saw Adler leading Morrison 61 percent to 19 percent. Both candidates assumed Election Day results would not change the outcomes of Adler easily avoiding a runoff in a field of seven candidates.

title: Ethics complaint about Prop J funding sparks war of words
description: A political action committee that's opposing a proposition to require votes on land-use rewrites in Austin delayed the disclosure of its real estate donors until halfway through early voting, Fred Lewis, one of the proposition’s authors, said in an ethics complaint filed Friday. The No on J PAC received a $10,000 contribution from the Real Estate Council of Austin on Oct. 22. That should have been reported publicly Oct. 25, Lewis said, because the PAC made a direct expenditure the next day.

title: Austin awards new composting contract as competitor cries foul
description: Austin city leaders approved a biosolids removal contract for up to 10 years and $19.3 million Thursday, acting despite the loud of objections of Texas Disposal Systems representatives, who accused city staff members of a conspiracy.

title: Austin assistant city manager Robert Goode to depart
description: Another Austin assistant city manager is out the door, as City Manager Spencer Cronk continues to recruit a new executive team. The Central Texas Regional Mobility Authority (CTRMA) announced Wednesday it has hired Robert Goode to be its new deputy executive director. Goode has been an Austin assistant city manager since 2008, overseeing transportation, waste, public works and the water utility.

title: Adler spends more than $200,000 in closing-weeks push
description: Mayor Steve Adler has spent more than $200,000 campaigning in the past month, burning through more than $705,000 of the $755,000 he’s raised this season, as the 2018 election comes down to its final days. According to campaign finance reports filed Monday, Adler’s top competitor, former City Council Member Laura Morrison, has spent nearly $38,000 in the past month and $135,000 overall. She has raised less than a fifth of Adler’s funds for the race.

title: City Council's Troxclair begins push for reasons behind water crisis
description: As Austin residents wait for water from their taps to become drinkable, three City Council members tried and failed Friday to begin a push for information about what exactly happened to lead to a mandatory boil water notice and how a repeat can be avoided in the future.

title: Austin water fails state standards, making recovery time uncertain
description: AUSTIN, Texas — Austin’s water officially failed state standards in a test Tuesday night, and what began as a precautionary measure urging residents to boil their water is now required by state law.That means Austin Water will have to follow Texas Commission on Environmental Quality procedures to lift the boil notice, but officials remained vague about what that will entail or how it will affect the timeline for when water will be safe to drink.The commission’s website says a water provider...

title: Water crisis dredges up battle over treatment plant
description: Years before the term CodeNext graced the lips of city officials, Austin’s biggest political fight reached an end. Council members approved the construction of Water Treatment Plant 4. For more than three decades, urban planners and environmentalists battled about the need for another water treatment plant, with its intake on Lake Travis. Advocates said it was crucial for projected population growth.

title: Austin water fails state standards, making recovery time uncertain
description: AUSTIN, Texas — Austin’s water officially failed state standards in a test Tuesday night, and what began as a precautionary measure urging residents to boil their water is now required by state law.That means Austin Water will have to follow Texas Commission on Environmental Quality procedures to lift the boil notice, but officials remained vague about what that will entail or how it will affect the timeline for when water will be safe to drink.The commission’s website says a water provider...

title: Austin water fails state standards, making recovery time uncertain
authors: Mary Huber,Elizabeth Findell,The Valdosta Daily Times
description: AUSTIN, Texas — Austin’s water officially failed state standards in a test Tuesday night, and what began as a precautionary measure urging residents to boil their water is now required by state law.That means Austin Water will have to follow Texas Commission on Environmental Quality procedures to lift the boil notice, but officials remained vague about what that will entail or how it will affect the timeline for when water will be safe to drink.The commission’s website says a water provider...

title: Austin water fails state standards, making recovery time uncertain
description: AUSTIN, Texas — Austin’s water officially failed state standards in a test Tuesday night, and what began as a precautionary measure urging residents to boil their water is now required by state law.That means Austin Water will have to follow Texas Commission on Environmental Quality procedures to lift the boil notice, but officials remained vague about what that will entail or how it will affect the timeline for when water will be safe to drink.The commission’s website says a water provider...

title: Adler not hesitant about battles for 'soul of this city'
description: In the summer of 2017, Austin Mayor Steve Adler unveiled a sweeping “Downtown Puzzle” plan that called for tying an expansion of the city’s convention center to increased funding for dealing with homelessness and a cluster of other downtown projects.

title: Austin water fails state standards, making recovery time uncertain
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindellMary Huber @marymhuber Wednesday Oct 24, 2018 at 7:24 AM Oct 25, 2018 at 11:55 AM Austin's water officially failed state standards on Tuesday, and what began as a precautionary measure urging residents to boil their water is now required by state law. That means Austin Water will have to follow Texas Commission on Environmental Quality procedures to lift the boil notice, but officials remained vague about what that will entail or how it will affect the timeline for...

title: In District 8, a tight council race nears an unpredictable end
description: In Southwest Austin, perhaps the most uncertain City Council race is playing out ahead of Election Day. In District 8, which includes the Barton Creek watershed and Edwards Aquifer recharge zones, three environmentally conscious Democrats — Rich DePalma, Bobby Levinski and Paige Ellis — and one conservative, Frank Ward, are squaring off to replace outgoing Council Member Ellen Troxclair.

title: Development at issue as challengers try to unseat Renteria in District 3
description: Supporters of City Council Member Sabino “Pio” Renteria are pushing hard to help Renteria hold his District 3 seat against a slew of challengers as early voting begins next week. Renteria’s sister and his frequent critic, Susana Almanza, is challenging him again, after the two faced off in a high-profile runoff for the East Austin seat in 2014. Another candidate, James Valadez, received strong early support after announcing his candidacy.

title: In District 1 race, seven candidates do best to stand out
description: A busy campaign season is coming down to the wire in northeastern Austin’s District 1, where seven candidates are elbowing to replace outgoing City Council Member Ora Houston. Much of the city’s establishment support former Democratic Party Chairman Vincent Harding, who has raised more than $50,000 since he entered the race. Natasha Harper-Madison, a favorite of city urbanists, has raised nearly $20,000.

title: Austin mayoral candidates spar over soccer, transportation in debate
description: All seven Austin mayoral hopefuls faced off for the first time Thursday, discussing issues from soccer to transportation during a debate hosted by the American-Statesman and KLRU-TV. Only two of the candidates, incumbent Mayor Steve Adler and former City Council Member Laura Morrison, are widely viewed as viable contenders for the seat.

title: LIVE: Austin mayoral candidates face off in debate
description: Candidates for Austin mayor meet today in a debate sponsored by KLRU-TV and the American-Statesman. Mayor Steve Adler, who is running for a second term, and former City Council Member Laura Morrison are considered the two most viable contenders for the seat, though seven names will be on the ballot. Morrison, who was particularly popular among neighborhood groups during her two terms on council, has criticized Adler primarily for being too friendly to development and downtown business interests.

title: Austin City Council Member Ora Houston endorses Laura Morrison for mayor
description: Outgoing Austin City Council Member Ora Houston wants Austinites to vote for Laura Morrison for mayor — not Steve Adler, the mayor she's worked with for four years. Houston cited attempted land-use code rewrite CodeNext, property taxes and neighborhood preservation in her endorsement Wednesday in northeast Austin. She compared CodeNext, as she has in the past, to the 1928 master plan that segregated the city. "Austin's mayor is elected by the entire city," she said.

title: As donations surpass $714,000, Adler continues to eclipse rivals in fundraising
description: Austin Mayor Steve Adler topped off his hefty campaign war chest with an additional $139,804 since July, bringing his total this election season to more than $714,000, according to campaign finance reports filed Tuesday. The fundraising kept Adler well ahead of his biggest rival, former City Council Member Laura Morrison, who has raised a sixth of that amount. Morrison brought in $25,516 from July to the end of September, bringing her total since she entered the race to about $117,800.

title: As donations surpass $714,000, Adler continues to eclipse rivals
description: Austin Mayor Steve Adler topped off his hefty campaign war chest with an additional $139,804 since July, bringing his total this election season to more than $714,000, according to campaign finance reports filed Tuesday. The fundraising kept Adler well ahead of his biggest rival, former City Council Member Laura Morrison, who has raised a sixth of that amount. Morrison brought in $25,516 from July to the end of September, bringing her total since she entered the race to about $117,800.

title: Election might signal end to left-right diversity on Austin council
description: Is there still room for a voice from the right among the leaders of a left-leaning city? Nov. 6 may bring a new answer. Ellen Troxclair, the Austin City Council’s last remaining conservative member, has in the past two years embraced a role that one of her supporters described as “Joan of Arc against these idiots (at City Hall).” Then she announced that she wouldn’t run again for her Southwest Austin seat.

title: As arts groups endure funding cuts, Austin reckons with grant, tax policies
description: Local arts organizations will be taking hits to their funding from the city of Austin for the next two years, but various groups expressed some relief this week that the cuts won’t be as deep as they were told last month. In total, $8.8 million will provide grants to applicants representing hundreds of local arts programs, ranging from theater, dance and musical groups to museums and writers’ groups.

title: Amid changing demographics, will Austin retain a African-American council seat?
description: As Ora Houston prepares to leave behind her District 1 seat, a strong early showing by a Hispanic candidate raised possibility that council might no longer include a black representative.

title: Review of peer cities finds Austin’s legal structure has different look
description: Besides Austin, the only peer city where the city manager appoints the city attorney is Phoenix. Most of Austin’s peer cities have city attorneys who report directly to the City Council as opposed to the city manager, which is how Austin has framed its legal structure. The finding, through a staff review completed last week, has added context to lingering debate about whether Austin should adopt the same setup.

title: Residency questions continue to dog Weslaco commissioner
description: WESLACO— It was February 2011 when Olga Noriega and her allies realized they might have a problem with her bid for District 3 city commissioner.“I did not realize she has stated she does not live in (the) district.

title: How Do You Like Me Now? Toby Keith show costs Pharr $296K
description: Red solo cup, I fill you upLet’s have a party, let’s have a partyI love you red solo cup, I lift you up, Proceed to party, proceed to party      — Toby Keith, “Red Solo Cup” Pharr did just that last month at a heavily touted outdoor concert, where the country superstar belted his hit songs to boot-tapping, beer-swilling fans.But how much did it cost to bring Red Solo Cup to Pharr?More than city leaders hoped, but that won’t deter them from such events in the future, they said.

title: The road ahead for scooters? City weighs safety concerns, new rules
description: Scooter riders logged more than 129,000 trips during the month of July alone, according to city officials. People zipping down sidewalks and tourists wobbling in and out of traffic on rental stand-up scooters has led to grumbling about safety concerns since the dockless devices first appeared in Austin this year. Still, it’s too soon to know whether the scooters are a transportation savior or hazard, staff members told City Council members Tuesday. From May 7 to Sept.

title: Will a homestead exemption across town hurt an Austin council hopeful?
description: Austin officials said they have not received any questions or challenges related to Harper-Madison’s residency. A candidate running to represent East Austin’s District 1 rents a house on East 13th Street but has a homestead exemption — meant to reduce taxes on an owner’s “principal residence” — on a house across town.

title: Woman accused of threatening to shoot men who urinated on fence
description: An Austin woman is accused of pointing a gun at her neighbors and threatening to shoot them after one of them urinated on the side of her apartment complex. Three men identified by pseudonyms in an arrest affidavit were hanging out in front of an apartment building near South Pleasant Valley Road on Saturday night when one of them urinated on the fence of the neighboring building instead of going indoors, police said in an arrest affidavit.

title: Woman accused of threatening to shoot men who urinated on fence
description: An Austin woman is accused of pointing a gun at her neighbors and threatening to shoot them after one of them urinated on the side of her apartment complex. Three men identified by pseudonyms in an arrest affidavit were hanging out in front of an apartment building near South Pleasant Valley Road on Saturday night when one of them urinated on the fence of the neighboring building instead of going indoors, police said in an arrest affidavit.

title: Austin man accused of shooting at police after they tried to stun him
description: A man in a bathrobe, wielding a stick and a liquor bottle, yelled a police who came to his house early Saturday before getting a gun and firing at an officer, police said in an arrest affidavit. Dennis Mahan, 61, is accused of aggravated assault on a peace officer, a first-degree felony. Officers went to his house around 2:30 a.m. after a friend told police he was concerned about Mahan based on alarming social media posts.

title: Austin approves $4.1 billion budget, upping property taxes, fees $77
description: Austin city leaders approved a $4.1 billion budget — the city’s largest — after a day of tweaks that included their consideration of setting aside money to guard against possible tax-increase caps before they changed their minds. The City Council approved the document by a 10-1 vote Tuesday, with Ellen Troxclair opposed. It sets a tax rate of 44.03 cents per $100 of property value, making the city’s portion of the tax bill roughly $1,317 for a median value home, worth $332,366.

title: Austin approves $4.1 billion budget, upping property taxes, fees $77
description: Austin city leaders approved a $4.1 billion budget — the city’s largest — after a day of tweaks that included their consideration of setting aside money to guard against possible tax-increase caps before they changed their minds. The City Council approved the document by a 10-1 vote Tuesday, with Ellen Troxclair opposed. It sets a tax rate of 44.03 cents per $100 of property value, making the city’s portion of the tax bill roughly $1,317 for a median value home, worth $332,366.

title: Austin apartment complexes throwing doors open to short-term rentals
