description: At Corazon, a trendy 2014 complex on the east side of Interstate 35, a studio apartment runs $1,600 a month — or $170 a night. You can live at The Arnold, built in 2016, for $2,000 a month or stay one night for $229. Are these apartment complexes? Or hotels? Many of the newer, nicer apartment complexes cropping up across Austin’s landscape share a new trait.

title: Vexed by licensing, some short-term rental owners fight back
description: It’s been advertised as the Carpe Diem Estate. Eight bedrooms. A pool, water slide and in-ground trampoline in the backyard. A rental price of $1,700 to $4,500 per night, on a quiet block of 18th Street, between Pease Park and the University of Texas.

title: Late entries could change the dynamic of Austin’s mayoral race
description: Mayor Steve Adler and his opponent for the city’s top seat, former City Council Member Laura Morrison, squared off during a downtown forum last week, discussing issues that included homelessness, pro soccer, downtown development and a larger convention center. Other candidates in the seven-way race for mayor sat in the audience.

title: Increasingly, short-term rental boom pits neighbor against neighbor
description: The two houses on West 10th Street are charming and tidy, one yellow, one teal. But ask the neighbors and they’ll tell you some tales, of bachelor parties and noisy barbecues, of inflatable penises in the street and slamming car doors at 3 a.m. They’ll tell you the houses are basically a hotel they can’t get rid of. As Austin code officer Khalid Marshall parked outside the houses one afternoon in mid-July, he was about to catch a break.

title: Increasingly, short-term rental boom pits neighbor against neighbor
description: The two houses on West 10th Street are charming and tidy, one yellow, one teal. But ask the neighbors and they’ll tell you some tales, of bachelor parties and noisy barbecues, of inflatable penises in the street and slamming car doors at 3 a.m. They’ll tell you the houses are basically a hotel they can’t get rid of. As Austin code officer Khalid Marshall parked outside the houses one afternoon in mid-July, he was about to catch a break.

title: Increasingly, short-term rental boom pits neighbor against neighbor
description: According to Airbnb report, city could receive millions in taxes if leaders struck a deal with the company. The two houses on West 10th Street are charming and tidy, one yellow, one teal. But ask the neighbors and they’ll tell you some tales, of bachelor parties and noisy barbecues, of inflatable penises in the street and slamming car doors at 3 a.m. They’ll tell you the houses are basically a hotel they can’t get rid of.

title: Vexed by Austin's licensing, short-term rental owners fight back
description: Some owners complain about delays, hurdles in licensing as city prepares to phase out some short-term rentals. As city tries to regulate ever-growing group of rentals, many owners opt to operate on sly, absent a license. It’s been advertised as the Carpe Diem Estate. Eight bedrooms. A pool, water slide and in-ground trampoline in the backyard. A rental price of $1,700 to $4,500 per night, on a quiet block of 18th Street, between Pease Park and the University of Texas.

title: Austin apartment complexes throwing doors open to short-term rentals
description: As practice grows, concerns surface about its impact on apartment availability, rents and hotel occupancy. Many newer complexes are licensing chunks of units as short-term rentals to be furnished, leased by the night. At Corazon, a trendy 2014 complex on the east side of Interstate 35, a studio apartment runs $1,600 a month — or $170 a night. You can live at The Arnold, built in 2016, for $2,000 a month or stay one night for $229. Are these apartment complexes? Or hotels?

title: District 3 council candidates kick off city-sponsored election forums
description: Six candidates for the Austin City Council’s District 3 seat met on a stage Wednesday night, when incumbent Sabino “Pio” Renteria touted his work on the council, his sister Susana Almanza challenged his record, and four first-time candidates began to hash out their different platforms ahead of Election Day on Nov. 6.

title: Austin mayoral candidate banned from Royal Blue Grocery
description: Inside the Royal Blue Grocery at Fourth and Nueces streets, a photo of Austin mayoral candidate Alexander Strenger hangs on the back of a deli case. It’s not a campaign ad. It’s a warning to employees not to let him in the store. Employees of the store confirmed Monday that Strenger is banned from at least some of its various Austin locations, but otherwise declined to answer questions.

title: UPDATE: Clerk will allow felon candidate to run for City Council seat
description: Austin’s city clerk will allow Lewis Conway Jr.’s run for City Council to proceed, despite his felony conviction, a city spokesman said Tuesday. Conway killed a man in 1991 and was convicted of voluntary manslaughter. He served his prison sentence, had his voting rights restored and is now a community organizer with Grassroots Leadership.

title: Clerk will allow felon candidate to run for Austin City Council seat
description: Austin’s city clerk will allow Lewis Conway Jr.’s run for City Council to proceed, despite his felony conviction, a city spokesman said Tuesday. Conway killed a man in 1991 and was convicted of voluntary manslaughter. He served his prison sentence, had his voting rights restored and is now a community organizer with Grassroots Leadership.

title: Report clears Equity Office leaders of wrongdoing, questions judgment
description: Director of Equity Office, Brion Oaks, disputes report’s findings that his management of the office was poor. Leaders of Austin’s Equity Office did not discriminate or create a hostile work environment, an independent investigation has concluded, though they might have made inappropriate comments about some co-workers and city volunteers.

title: New: Clerk will allow felon candidate to run for Austin City Council
description: Austin’s city clerk will allow Lewis Conway Jr.’s run for City Council to proceed, despite his felony conviction, a city spokesman said Tuesday. Conway killed a man in 1991, served his prison sentence, had his voting rights restored and is now a community organizer with Grassroots Leadership.

title: Austin city election filing draws large field, last-minute surprises
description: Six candidates apiece have filed to run for District 1 and 3 seats on Austin City Council. More than two dozen candidates filed by Monday’s deadline to run in mayoral and other Austin City Council elections Nov. 6, including some last-minute surprises. Lewis Conway Jr., a City Council candidate with a criminal record, might not see his name on November’s ballot after all. On Friday, he received a notice from the city clerk that he needs to prove his eligibility as a candidate.

title: UPDATE: Candidate with criminal record ineligible, city clerk says
description: Lewis Conway Jr., an Austin City Council candidate with a criminal record, may not see his name on November’s ballot after all. Conway killed a man in 1991, served his prison sentence, had his voting rights restored and is now a community organizer with Grassroots Leadership.

title: UPDATE: Candidate with criminal record ineligible, city clerk says
description: Lewis Conway Jr., an Austin City Council candidate with a criminal record, may not see his name on November’s ballot after all. Conway killed a man in 1991, served his prison sentence, had his voting rights restored and is now a community organizer with Grassroots Leadership.

title: Austin candidate Lewis Conway’s run asks when a criminal sentence ends
description: An Austin native, Conway’s life in the years since prison has led him to criminal justice reform. In mid-2017, Lewis Conway Jr. had some political questions. He wanted to understand, really understand, the forces behind people of color slipping away from East Austin neighborhoods. So a black Muslim socialist called the only person he could think of: a white nationalist libertarian tax consultant he had once served time with in prison. “I was like, ‘Dude, tell me about gentrification,’ ” Conway said.

title: Council members set maximum city tax rate at 6 percent
description: Council backs away from typical practice of setting rate at 8 percent — the maximum allowed without an election. During their regular meeting Thursday, Austin City Council members set the maximum tax rate at 44.2 cents per $100 of property value, a rate that will increase taxes 6 percent in 2019. The move doesn’t mean that will be the adopted tax rate, but the rate cannot exceed that figure.

title: Report: Mayor’s aide received cut of nonprofit’s contracts with city
description: Elizabeth Findell @efindell Friday Aug 10, 2018 at 12:01 AM Sep 26, 2018 at 12:18 PM When the nonprofit founded by a former staffer for Austin Mayor Steve Adler won a contract with the city, the aide received a cut, according to an independent investigation. Documents show the aide was paid $37,110 by the nonprofit over the first two years he worked for Adler. Frank Rodriguez served as executive director of the nonprofit Latino HealthCare Forum from 2011 until 2015, when he went to work as...

title: Investigation into Austin’s Equity Office roils City Hall circles
description: An investigation centered on the city of Austin’s Equity Office has sparked strife in City Hall circles, with groups representing minorities strongly weighing in with different viewpoints.

title: NAACP voices discrimination concerns amid city Equity Office inquiry
description: Austin’s NAACP chapter announced Thursday it will investigate “harassment of African American employees at the city of Austin.”Among its concerns is a pending city investigation centered on the city’s Equity Office, which has brought strained relations between groups representing minorities.

title: Report: Mayor’s aide received cut of nonprofit’s contracts with city
description: When the nonprofit founded by a former staffer for Austin Mayor Steve Adler won a contract with the city, the aide received a cut, according to an independent investigation. Documents show the aide was paid $37,110 by the nonprofit over the first two years he worked for Adler. Frank Rodriguez served as executive director of the nonprofit Latino HealthCare Forum from 2011 until 2015, when he went to work as an aide to Adler.

title: Proposed Austin budget increases taxes, but less than it did last year
description: Austin residents will see a tax increase in 2019, but under a proposed city budget unveiled Monday, it could be the smallest in years. The city staff has recommended setting the tax rate to increase revenue just under 5 percent, not the 8 percent maximum allowed by state law, which Austin typically hits. That means an estimated increase to the city’s portion of a property tax bill of $61.48 for a median value home, worth $332,366, with a homestead exemption.

title: Austinites will see a smaller than usual tax bump under draft budget
description: Austin residents will see a tax increase in 2019, but under a proposed 2019 city budget unveiled Monday, it could be the smallest increase in years. City staff have recommended setting the tax rate to increase revenues at just under 5 percent, not the 8 percent maximum allowed by state law that Austin typically hits. That means an estimated increase to the city’s portion of a property tax bill of $61.48 for a median value home, worth $332,366, with a homestead exemption.

title: Rematch: Susana Almanza will again face brother for City Council spot
description: ‘Pio’ Renteria says he’s not surprised by the move, saying sister still ‘hasn’t conceded the first race to me.’Four years ago, siblings topped 10 other candidates to square off in a District 3 council seat runoff. Susan Almanza, director of the advocacy group PODER, will run against her brother, City Council Member Sabino “Pio” Renteria, for East Austin’s District 3 seat — again.

title: Michigan city hires Austin Assistant City Manager Mark Washington
description: Last week, Washington learned that he was one of five Austin assistant city managers whose roles were in flux. Less than a week after new Austin City Manager Spencer Cronk announced a shakeup of his executive team, Assistant City Manager Mark Washington is taking a new job in Michigan. City commissioners in Grand Rapids voted 6-1 Tuesday to hire Washington as city manager, according to MLive. Commissioners there touted him for his experience in Austin, especially involving issues of racial equity.

title: Austin city manager will replace executive team after open recruitment
description: Existing assistant city managers will be free to apply for new positions, which could be filled by winter. Austin’s new city manager, Spencer Cronk, will eliminate the positions that form his executive team and replace those with five new roles oriented to City Council-endorsed goals, he said Friday. As part of the changes, the existing five assistant city managers will have to join other candidates in applying for the new positions.

title: Breaking: Austin city manager will replace executive team positions
description: New Austin City Manager Spencer Cronk will eliminate the city’s existing assistant city manager positions and replace them with assistant city managers targeted to strategic goals, he said in an interview Friday. That means the city’s five existing assistant city managers will have to apply for new roles alongside other candidates, or potentially lose their jobs.

title: Breaking: Austin city manager will replace executive team positions
description: New Austin City Manager Spencer Cronk will eliminate the city’s existing assistant city manager positions and replace them with assistant city managers targeted to strategic goals, he said in an interview Friday. That means the city’s five existing assistant city managers will have to apply for new roles alongside other candidates, or potentially lose their jobs.

title: Mystery conservative, ex-felon and mayor file first for city elections
description: The campaign of Lewis Conway Jr. could challenge state law regarding felons running for elected office. A community organizer with a felony conviction looking to defy Texas law and run for office. A newly minted candidate intent on replacing the only conservative on the Austin City Council. Oh, and the mayor. All three formally applied for a place on the November ballot as filing for the latest municipal election began Monday at City Hall.

title: Who’s the mystery candidate running for Austin City Council?
description: Are you a fiscal conservative hoping to replace City Council Member Ellen Troxclair in District 8? Troxclair announced in a news release Thursday that, though she’s not running for a second term this November, she plans to endorse *someone*. Who? It’s unclear. But it’s a “new candidate”— not one of the three people already in the race.

title: Austin council challengers match incumbents in campaign fundraising
description: Austin’s most senior City Council member may be getting a run for her money this election season. Political newcomer Danielle Skidmore out-fundraised downtown District 9 Council Member Kathie Tovo $47,100 to $41,600, according to campaign finance reports filed Monday. Skidmore, a civil engineer, drew support from several urbanists and LGBT advocates, as well as business owners. Tovo gained contributions from numerous nonprofits and attorneys tied to city issues.

title: Austin Mayor Adler’s fundraising tops $574,000, Morrison raises $92,000
description: Austin Mayor Steve Adler has raised $291,500 for his re-election campaign since January, plus more than $283,000 in late 2017, easily eclipsing rival Laura Morrison’s fundraising. Adler’s latest campaign finance report filed on Monday showed that the mayor’s fundraising has continued unabated since his re-election campaign began last year. Since the start of 2018, his campaign has garnered more than 1,400 contributions. He also had outstanding campaign loans to himself of $449,200.

title: Report: Most donations to 2016 council races from outside districts
description: Most of the money Austin City Council candidates raised for their races in 2016 came from outside their council districts — more than 90 percent for Council Members Delia Garza and Greg Casar — according to a report issued by Texans for Public Justice. The city’s three wealthiest districts accounted for 68 percent of all resident campaign donations, even though two of those three districts didn’t have an election in 2016.

title: Homelessness or infrastructure? New city budgeting targets goal topics
description: New budget process leads some city departments to work together on shared goals. This time, departments’ budget requests are tied to 10 concerns City Council members want to address. Don’t ask how much money the Austin City Council can give your department. This year, ask instead how your department can contribute to the council’s goals. As Austin reaches the budgeting season for fiscal 2019, which begins Oct.

title: Austin mayor claps back at a constituent: Texas’ attorney general
description: Austin Mayor Steve Adler and Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton are exchanging words, as Texas vs. Austin tensions continue to flare. Adler shot back Thursday at an opinion editorial by Paxton calling the city hypocritical and disdainful of the rule of law.

title: Austin mayor claps back at a constituent: Texas’ attorney general
description: Austin Mayor Steve Adler and Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton are exchanging words, as Texas vs. Austin tensions continue to flare. Adler shot back Thursday at an opinion editorial by Paxton calling the city hypocritical and disdainful of the rule of law.

title: Austin Council Member Ellen Troxclair won’t seek re-el
description: Ellen Troxclair, Austin’s only conservative City Council member, will not seek a second term, she said in a news release Wednesday afternoon. “The decision on whether seek another term has been an incredibly difficult one because I believe so passionately in the work with which my constitutents have entrusted me,” she said in the release.

title: Troxclair, Austin council’s lone conservative, won’t seek re-election
description: City Council Member Ellen Troxclair will not seek a second term, she said in a news release issued Wednesday, setting up an open race to replace Austin’s only conservative City Council member. “I can leave knowing that I accomplished what I set out to do — serve as an advocate for my district, a voice of reason, a fiscal watchdog, an unwavering voice for lowering the cost of living and a representative of the average Austinite who often feels overlooked at City Hall,” she said in the release.

title: BREAKING: Austin Council Member Ellen Troxclair won’t seek re-election
description: Ellen Troxclair, Austin’s only conservative City Council member, will not seek a second term, she said in a news release Wednesday afternoon. “The decision on whether seek another term has been an incredibly difficult one because I believe so passionately in the work with which my constitutents have entrusted me,” she said in the release.

title: Teacher will be second challenger to Council Member Kathie Tovo
description: When a campaign volunteer for City Council member Kathie Tovo knocked on Linda O’Neal’s door asking for a signature on a petition to let Tovo run for a third term, O’Neal’s answer was spontaneous. “I told the volunteer: ‘No. I’m going to run against her,'” O’Neal said. “I had no idea if it was too late. I ran to the computer.”The 45 year old U.S. History and Civics high school teacher had flirted with the idea of running for public office before, but hadn’t decided on which office.

title: Union objections slow city’s efforts at second-jobs disclosure policy
description: ‘We feel like what they do on their off hours is their business,’ union official says of city employees. A year after Austin officials said they would create new policies for moonlighting city employees, the process has stalled amid opposition from the employees’ union. In the past two years, a series of city-initiated investigations into issues arising from employees’ second jobs highlighted the potential for conflicts of interest.

title: Austin to pursue Montopolis Negro School through eminent domain
description: Former school one of last surviving structures among 42 segregated, rural schools that county once operated. City has proposed paying $362,000 to owner of .85-acre tract of land, but litigation could be coming. Unable to agree to a purchase price for the site of the former Montopolis Negro School, Austin will move forward with plans to take it through eminent domain proceedings.

title: After complaints, inspectors find bedbugs, code violations at ARCH
description: Austin Fire Department also is working to determine if facility has an occupancy limit. Shelter’s director says pest control efforts have been stepped up in recent months. The Austin Resource Center for the Homeless, or ARCH, will boost pest control efforts after city public health officials documented a list of code violations, including bedbugs, in a recent investigation.

title: After complaints, inspectors find bed bugs, code violations at ARCH
description: The Austin Resource Center for the Homeless (ARCH) is responding after city public health officials documented a list of code violations, including bed bugs, in a recent investigation. City officials were responding to complaints about the facility submitted earlier this year, Austin Public Health Director Stephanie Hayden said in a memo to the City Council late Monday.

title: In Rio Grande Valley, a life-altering limbo as asylum process shifts
description: For some immigrants, pursuit of asylum ends with a trip halfway across an international bridge. Policy of separating children from families — and order to end the practice — sows confusion, fear along border. In shelters in Mexico, in detention facilities in the United States and in consultations with attorneys, they wait in uncertainty.

title: Family reunifications could take months, Cruz, Cornyn told on border
description: Southwest Key says it has gotten no guidance on how to reunite children who were separated from their parents. Immigrant women at Taylor facility are awaiting word on when they will see their children, advocate says. Reuniting immigrant children separated from their parents seeking asylum could take up to four months, a federal official told U.S. Sens. John Cornyn, R-Texas and Ted Cruz, R-Texas, along with local leaders and others meeting at Border Patrol offices on the Texas-Mexico border Friday.

title: Protesters and supporters square off at Southwest Key headquarters
description: Protesters and counter-protesters faced off outside the headquarters of the Austin nonprofit Southwest Key on Thursday, clashing over the organization’s operation of facilities for immigrant children who were separated from their parents at the U.S.-Mexico border.

title: Stormy Daniels’ lawyer at border for parents of separated children
description: As media from around the world clustered in and around an immigrant shelter run by nuns in the Rio Grande Valley Tuesday, the arrival of a familiar face drew a buzz. Michael Avenatti, the Los Angeles-based celebrity lawyer recently known for representing porn star Stormy Daniels in her lawsuit against President Donald Trump, has jumped into the issue of separating asylum-seeking immigrants from their children.

title: Border Patrol opens central processing facility for unaccompanied kids
description: McALLEN — Metal benches, green sleeping pads and chain-link fence enclosures awaited kids picked up by Border Patrol at the Rio Grande Valley’s first central processing center for unaccompanied immigrant children.Border Patrol gave members of the media a tour Thursday of the South McAllen warehouse at 3700 W.

title: BREAKING: Austin City Council member Ora Houston won’t seek reelection
description: East Austin City Council Member Ora Houston will not seek reelection in November, she said in a news release Wednesday. The release said she’d made the decision after “months of personal discernment and conversations with confidants.”“It has been a joy, privilege and a huge responsibility to represent the ‘blended family’ of District #1,” Houston said in the release.

title: Austin City Council member Ora Houston won’t seek re-election
description: East Austin City Council Member Ora Houston will not seek re-election in November, she said in a statement Wednesday. First elected to the council in 2014, Houston said she made the decision to leave after “months of personal discernment and conversations with confidants.”“It has been a joy, privilege and a huge responsibility to represent the ‘blended family’ of District #1,” Houston said in the statement.

title: Austin Council Member Ora Houston won’t run again, Dem party chair will
description: A wide-open City Council election awaits East Austinites as four candidates with civic experience line up to replace outgoing Council Member Ora Houston. Houston said Wednesday that she will not seek a second term in the fall, surprising several colleagues. Only hours after her announcement, Vincent Harding, outgoing chairman of the Travis County Democratic Party, said he would join three others in running for the seat.

title: LIVE: Follow the CodeNext debate at Austin City Council
description: After five years and $8 million, Austin city leaders are beginning to seriously dig into the contentious CodeNext. The rewrite of city land rules aims to increase density along major corridors. It has starkly split neighborhood preservationists from urbanists urging for more housing stock and a more compact city. Last week, Austin City Council members took their first look at CodeNext with a largely high-level discussion of overall goals and broadly agreeable concepts.

title: Jimmy Flannigan, Alison Alter bring sophomore shift to City Council
description: Pair helped shift council dynamics, Flannigan says, ‘but I don’t think they shifted in the way people expected.’A year and a half into their terms, council members have been among the most vocal on the dais. At his first meeting as an Austin City Council member in January 2017, Jimmy Flannigan made it clear he didn’t fear a lack of consensus. Colleagues had asked him to postpone making a nomination to an environmental advisory board so they could study and discuss the nominee in more depth.

title: At Troxclair’s urging, Austin to again weigh hiking homestead exemption
description: Mayor Steve Adler once supported an increase to 20 percent, but he backed away from the idea last year. In 2015, the City Council increased the exemption to 6 percent but spoke about raising it to 20 in the future. Once again, Austin City Council members this week will have to decide whether to move forward on a homestead tax break they once promised property owners before backing away from the idea.

title: At CodeNext session, council talks broad goals, collegial approach
description: City Council Member Delia Garza voices frustration, asks, ‘When are we going to start digging into the weeds?’Mayor Steve Adler passed out “Team Austin” hard hats and reflective vests Tuesday to kick off the City Council’s first CodeNext discussion, making a symbolic plea for unity as the council takes up the city’s most divisive issue. Then the council spent the morning talking about how to talk about the first comprehensive redo of city zoning and building rules in more than three decades.

title: Report envisions Seaholm facility as home to concerts, kayaks and more
description: Austin’s waterfront Seaholm facility should become a multifunctional meeting space, with a coffee shop, food trucks, large yard and kayak docking, according to a recommendation commissioned jointly by the city and outdoor nonprofits. The report, from Studio Gang, included three layouts for the former power plant on the north shore of Lady Bird Lake, and numerous renderings showing yoga classes, art shows and concerts that could happen there.

title: Density, affordability at issue as more Austin council hopefuls emerge
description: In this election cycle, only Council Member Ann Kitchen does not have an opponent so far. Five City Council members and the mayor are up for re-election this year. Two candidates have signaled plans to run against Austin City Council Member Sabino “Pio” Renteria in November, the first to oppose him for East Austin’s District 3 seat. James Valadez, a real estate agent, and Jessica Cohen, a network security administrator, have both appointed treasurers in recent weeks.

title: CodeNext opponents sue to get petition ordinance on November ballot
description: Opponents of CodeNext, Austin’s land use code rewrite, sued the city Friday afternoon to try to force a ballot initiative asking voters to make such land use changes subject to citizen vote. The suit is the expected next step after Austin City Council members last month declined to place a petition-initiated ordinance on November’s ballot. The ordinance would make CodeNext and other measures like it subject to elections.

title: CodeNext opponents sue to get land-use ordinance on November ballot
description: Opponents of CodeNext, Austin’s land use code rewrite, sued the city Friday afternoon to try to force a ballot initiative asking voters to make such land-use changes subject to a vote from residents. The suit is the expected next step after Austin City Council members last month declined to place a petition-initiated ordinance on November’s ballot. The ordinance would make CodeNext and other measures like it subject to elections.

title: Latest debate about merits, demerits of CodeNext hits usual points
description: Low-key input marked the first of two public hearings about Austin’s most contentious political issue, CodeNext, as it moves closer to a vote before the City Council. The comprehensive re-write of Austin’s land use rules and regulations aims to allow more density along major city corridors, and it details how the city will be able to grow in the future.

title: Dog adoption spurs suspensions, outcry at Austin Animal Center
description: The dog-walking volunteers who took to Facebook were furious. Austin Animal Center had proceeded with an adoption they tried to stop — of a dog closely bonded to another one left behind and delivered to a man they distrusted based on a passing conversation — and they weren’t going to let it go. A volunteer told the others of the adoption in the official internal group that animal center employees and volunteers use to communicate. One expressed anger about the news, commenting with an expletive.

title: Austin council to vote on settlement in violent Breaion King arrest
description: Austin City Council members are expected to vote Thursday on a settlement in the civil case filed against the city by Breaion King, an African-American schoolteacher whose violent arrest in June 2015 sparked nationwide outrage when video of the incident became public the following year. The city reached a tentative agreement with King last week, though her lawyers and several council members declined to disclose the proposed amount.

title: What we’re watching at Austin City Council
description: Austin leaders today may close the book on the Breaion King civil case as they consider a settlement agreement with the teacher whom police violently threw to the ground during a 2015 traffic stop. Council members also will weigh actions to address the area’s opiod crisis, and they will consider extending a tax increment finance zone to better fund improvements around downtown Waller Creek. They will consider a move to construct more fire stations, too.

title: City approves $425,000 payment to settle King’s excessive force lawsuit
description: After traffic stop, African-American schoolteacher was thrown to the ground twice by an Austin police officer. Austin will pay $425,000 to an African-American schoolteacher whose violent arrest in 2015 sparked nationwide outrage. On Thursday, City Council members unanimously approved an agreement with Breaion King to settle a lawsuit she filed against the city.

title: Party boat company returns to Lake Austin dock after legal cease-fire
description: At least one Lake Austin party boat company will be able to pick up passengers off of Lake Austin Boulevard this summer, after a reprieve in the legal tussle over the use of a public dock there. Austin Party Cruises sued the city of Austin and Parks and Recreation Department Director Kimberly McNeeley in January after the parks department declined to grant the company a permit to use the Walsh Boat Landing.

title: Jacques Strap who? City employee in hot water for using fake names in email
description: They’re not people who are part of Austin Energy’s Multi-Family Rebate Program. Nor does the utility brass have a sense of humor when it comes to including their names on work assignments, as one Austin Energy employee learned last month. Jaime Gomez, a conservation program coordinator, was placed on disciplinary probation for six months after he wrote 21 naughty names on a work assignment to find people missing from the rebate program’s data.

title: Balance between taxes, city services topic at public budget discussion
description: Are city of Austin taxes too high (meaning services should be cut), too low (meaning services should be improved) or about right (meaning services should be kept as they are now)? The bars on a graph jumped back and forth Tuesday night as about 50 people inside Austin’s Central Library — and participants watching remotely — thumbed in answers to an interactive poll during one of the city’s first public input sessions regarding the 2019 budget.

title: Charter amendments could bring significant shifts in Austin governance
description: Commission proposes eight changes to city charter that could land on November ballot. After months of weighing what needs to change in Austin’s governing structure, a Charter Review Commission has answers. The commission will recommend eight major changes to the city charter that City Council members could add to the general election ballot in November.

title: New festival, event process outlined, but talk on specifics will go on
description: Austin approved new rules for handling festivals and events in the city after six years of discussion Thursday, but watch for the talk to continue. The special events ordinance aims to streamline planning and permitting of Austin happenings big and small, from charity park barbecues and political protests to South by Southwest and Austin City Limits.

title: Companies seek permits in bid to soon peddle rental scooters, bikes
description: Keep an eye out. The rentable scooters that briefly zipped through downtown are on their way back. And they’re bringing dockless bikes with them. Dockless mobility companies were able to begin applying this week for permits to operate in Austin, following a meeting last Friday that drew interest from about 20 companies, said Marissa Monroy, a spokeswoman for the Transportation Department.

title: Foreshadowing CodeNext debate, council splits over planning commission
description: A 1994 Austin charter provision states two-thirds of the body must not be tied to real estate or development. The 13-member commission includes four architects and two leaders of an engineering and planning firm. Foes of the city’s land development rewrite have raised objections to the makeup of the land-use commission.

title: Foreshadowing CodeNext debate, council splits over planning commission
description: A 1994 Austin charter provision states two-thirds of the body must not be tied to real estate or development. The 13-member commission includes four architects and two leaders of an engineering and planning firm. Foes of the city’s land development rewrite have raised objections to the makeup of the land-use commission.

title: Austin nonprofits sue HUD, Carson after changes to fair housing rules
description: Nonprofit official: HUD “sends a message to communities that … they can keep segregating and discriminating.”Local nonprofits sued the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development and HUD Secretary Ben Carson on Tuesday, trying to force the agency to continue recently launched enforcement of some fair housing rules.

title: Delia Garza encourages City Council to take on predatory home flippers
description: City Council will consider asking lobbyists to push for laws to guard against predatory practices. Sometimes they’re letters. Sometimes they’re cards or postcards. Sometimes they’re designed to look personal, with lettering like handwriting. Other times they’re designed to look official or threatening.

title: Austinites mark Cinco de Mayo with conjunto fest
description: Cinco de Mayo recognizes the Battle of Puebla when the Mexican army defeated an invading French army. Cowboy hats and strollers filled Fiesta Gardens in East Austin on a sunny Saturday afternoon. Artists painted the Mexican flag on cheeks. Stands sold tacos, hamburgers, piñatas and quinceañera dresses. Most importantly, couples spun to accordion music in the pavilion in front of an all-day lineup of conjunto bands.

title: Longer live music hours on Red River will remain in place
description: Longer live music hours on Red River Street will stay for good, after a yearlong test that drew widespread praise and support. Austin City Council members agreed unanimously Thursday to permanently allow venues in the Red River Cultural District, between Sixth and 12th streets, to play amplified music until midnight on Thursdays and 1 a.m. on weekends — an hour later than previously allowed.

title: Young singles with pets replacing families in East Austin?
description: Study finds a drop in families with children in at least part of East Austin. “I don’t see many kids around here now,” one resident says. “It’s all people walking their dogs. Olga Hernandez sat on the porch of her East Eighth Street house on a warm April afternoon, offering a few minutes to the latest reporter to come through asking about gentrification in her quickly changing neighborhood. Between pointing out rental units, she called hello to a young man and woman walking dogs down the sidewalk.

title: Races grow more crowded ahead of November Austin city elections
description: Ask Travis Duncan why he’s running for mayor of Austin, and he’ll tell you a tale. Of a city where electricity and food are free and “a network of cooperative projects” pays the bills. Of the city he believes this could be. You probably haven’t heard of Duncan, a drummer and former Tesla worker, and that would be understandable.

title: Does Austin need a new, independent board to police city ethics?
description: The Charter Review Commission said an independent ethics panel is important to its campaign voucher plan. Austin could change the way it handles city ethics violations, beginning with the creation of a new independent board, if a panel drafting potential changes to the city charter has its way. The panel in the coming weeks is expected to recommend that the 11 City Council-appointed members of the Ethics Review Commission be replaced with a five-member board without any ties to elected officials.

title: Austin Energy customer service fail: The tale of a $12,000 water bill
description: For nearly a year, the monthly bills for water on Paul Saustrup’s vacant agricultural lot in Southeast Austin were predictable: $7 here, $6 there. Then came one that made him look twice: $12,111.68. "I just got a literally shocking water bill," he told a customer service representative in a Nov. 22 call to Austin Energy, which handles billing for both utilities.

title: Judge orders new election in Weslaco’s District 5
description: EDINBURG — A judge ordered Weslaco to call a new District 5 City Commission election “as soon as possible” Thursday after weeks of considering arguments in an challenge to last fall’s election results.“This is a victory,” candidate Letty Lopez said after the decision. “The judge called it the best that he could, getting the facts on each voter.”Lopez sued Commissioner Lupe Rivera after she lost the seat by only 16 votes in November.

title: Austin Energy customer service fail: The tale of a $12,000 water bill
description: It took months before the utility discovered that a city water main break had caused the problem. User had hundreds of dollars seized from his bank account over the mistaken bill. For nearly a year, the monthly bills for water on Paul Saustrup’s vacant agricultural lot in Southeast Austin were predictable: $7 here, $6 there. Then came one that made him look twice: $12,111.68. “I just got a literally shocking water bill,” he told a customer service representative in a Nov.

title: Austin city taxes, fees expected to hit $4,032 for average homeowner
description: The city expects to finish this year having spent $4.4 million less than expected on public safety. City of Austin taxes made up only about a fifth of a typical resident’s property tax bills. But Austin will likely end its fiscal year with a tad to spare. Thanks to lower-than-expected spending on public safety, Austin will likely end its fiscal year with a tad to spare and, thanks to growth and tax increases, will have more money to play with next year than it did in 2018.

title: Austin city taxes, fees expected to hit $4,032 for average homeowner
description: Thanks to lower-than-expected spending on public safety, Austin will likely end its fiscal year with a tad to spare and, thanks to growth and tax increases, will have more money to play with next year than it did in 2018. But be careful, city staff warned Wednesday. If state legislators drop the maximum the city can increase taxes from 8 percent to 4 or 5 percent, city finances will be in trouble in a few years.

title: Austin: Meter readers made up reads, causing fall water bill spikes
description: Two former Austin water meter readers made up readings along their routes in late summer, causing thousands of residents’ bills to spike from August to September, city officials said Tuesday. The city expects to seek legal action against former meter-reading company Corix. Kerry Overton, deputy general manager of Austin Energy, which handles billing for both water and electric utilities, said two Corix employees apparently made up reads during the final month Corix worked for Austin.

title: Austin: Meter readers made up reads, causing fall water bill spikes
description: Utility had long insisted that it was impossible for meter readers to have caused the problem. Austin officials now have an answer to the mystery of what caused the water bills of thousands of residents to spike in September — and it’s exactly what residents had suspected and the Austin Water Utility had denied was possible.

title: Austin: Meter readers made up reads, causing fall water bill spikes
description: Two former Austin water meter readers made up readings along their routes in late summer, causing thousands of residents’ bills to spike from August to September, city officials said Tuesday. The city expects to seek legal action against former meter-reading company Corix. Kerry Overton, deputy general manager of Austin Energy, which handles billing for both water and electric utilities, said two Corix employees apparently made up reads during the final month Corix worked for Austin.

title: Austin: Meter readers made up reads, causing fall water bill spikes
description: In this Oct. 12 file photo, Circle C resident Bob Hinman shows his water meter after he and his neighbors got an unpleasant surprise on their September water bills. The city charged them three to five times over the average amount of their water bills. RICARDO B. BRAZZIELL / AMERICAN-STATESMANTwo former Austin water meter readers made up readings along their routes in late summer, causing thousands of residents’ bills to spike from August to September, city officials said Tuesday.

title: Memo details which Austin pools might get funded and which might fail
description: With $120 million, just under the amount a task force recommended for Austin’s aquatic system, the Parks and Recreation Department could keep all the swimming pools in the city functioning, plus add four, city staffers said in a memo this week. With half that amount of money, the department would replace all six pools at imminent risk of closure, with only short-term closures as some fail before construction could occur.

title: Laura Morrison launches her campaign for mayor
description: Austin’s race for mayor is officially on. Laura Morrison launched her campaign Monday night before a room of neighborhood activists who’ve long pushed for her to run. Morrison, a former City Council member, is challenging Mayor Steve Adler largely based on views over growth and development. “Everywhere I go, when I talk to folks in the community now, I hear from them that they feel they’re being written off,” Morrison said, citing traffic, changing businesses and people moving.

title: City: Waller Creek Tunnel works, despite fight over construction flaws
description: Don’t panic, Austin officials said this week. The Waller Creek Tunnel works — just. The American-Statesman broke the news this month that the $161 million project, designed to lift a swath of downtown out of the creek’s flood plain, has severe structural problems that could reduce its ability to control flooding downtown and lessen its lifespan, according to a letter city officials sent to its primary builder, S.J. Louis Construction, Feb. 23.

title: Former Austin police monitor cleared in ethics case
description: Former Austin Police Monitor Margo Frasier, accused of using a city computer for private consulting work, did not violate city policy and will receive no sanctions, the Austin Ethics Review Commission said Wednesday. The 7-2 vote, after lengthy and emotional testimony, sent a statement that could set a precedent for future ethics cases as Austin weighs standards for on-the-clock computer use, employees who work other jobs and standards for executive-level positions, like the police monitor.

title: Misconduct declines at new Central Library compared with former site
description: ‘Different atmosphere’ — with more space, light and staff — may be prompting better behavior, spokeswoman says. Reports of harassment, physical attacks or patrons sleeping have dropped by nearly half in early part of 2018. Before the new Central Library even opened, the online taunts began.

title: Former Austin Police Monitor Margo Frasier cleared in ethics case
description: The Austin Ethics Review Commission said Frasier did not violate city policy and will receive no sanctions. Former Austin Police Monitor Margo Frasier, accused of using a city computer for private consulting work, did not violate city policy and will not receive any sanctions, the Austin Ethics Review Commission said Wednesday.

The 7-2 vote, after lengthy and emotional testimony, sent a statement that could set a precedent for future ethics cases as Austin weighs standards for on-the-clock computer use, employees who work other jobs and standards for executive-level positions, like the police monitor.

title: Council member: After bombings, hire interim police chief for good
description: Interim Austin police Chief Brian Manley speaks at a news conference about Austin bombings Wednesday morning as Mayor Steve Adler and City Manager Spencer Cronk look on. “I ask, in light of recent events, that we as a council put our full support behind two measures,” Garza wrote on the council’s online message board. “1.

title: Elon Musk Says Neuralink Has Implanted Brain Chip in Human
description: 1 min read Join us The announcement represents a potential milestone in the development of “brain-computer interface” technology. Premium Elon Musk said that the first human received a Neuralink brain implant, a potential milestone in the development of “brain-computer interface" technology that could one day help those suffering from debilitating conditions such as paralysis to interact with their surroundings.

title: 马斯克称Neuralink已实施首例人类大脑芯片植入
link: https://cn.wsj.com/articles/马斯克称neuralink已实施首例人类大脑芯片植入-6e06c5a6
description: 图为马斯克。 图片来源：Beata Zawrzel/Zuma Press 马斯克(Elon Musk)表示，首位人类患者已接受Neuralink的大脑植入芯片。这是“脑机接口”技术发展的一个潜在里程碑，有朝一日或将帮助那些患有瘫痪等虚弱病症的患者与周围环境进行互动。 马斯克周一晚间发布推文说，这位病人在前一天接受了植入手术，目前恢复情况良好，这表明手术已经成功完成，没有出现严重的技术问题。马斯克没有透露这名病人的详细情况。NeuraLink去年9月宣布正在招募一名试验参与者，当时该公司表示正在寻找一名四肢瘫痪的患者。 马斯克还表示，初步结果显示，神经元尖峰检测大有前途，进一步表明Neuralink设备正在检测大脑内部单个神经元的信号，这一潜在的进步可以解码更高质量的大脑信号。马斯克没有透露该公司的设备正在检测多少个神经元。 Copyright ©2022 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All Rights Reserved.

title: Matthew Perry’s Death Darkens Ketamine’s Startup Glow
description: Matthew Perry’s death from the effects of ketamine brought new scrutiny to the booming business to prescribe the powerful anesthetic to patients in clinics and online. Perry was receiving ketamine infusions for depression and anxiety before he was found unresponsive in the pool at his Pacific Palisades, Calif., home on Oct. 28.

title: La muerte de Matthew Perry oscurece el brillo inicial de la ketamina
description: Dec. 16, 2023 9:00 pm ETMateo Perry Muerte por los efectos de la ketamina. trajo un nuevo escrutinio a la negocio en auge para prescribir el poderoso anestésico para pacientes en clínicas y en línea. Perry estaba recibiendo infusiones de ketamina para la depresión y la ansiedad antes de nacer. encontrado inconsciente en la piscina en su casa de Pacific Palisades, California, el 28 de octubre.

link: https://cn.wsj.com/articles/下一种热门减肥药获批还需数年-但网上卖家已在兜售-398e4c44
description: 根据《华尔街日报》(The Wall Street Journal)的一项观察，一种还要数年才能获得美国监管部门批准、可能成为畅销药的减肥药目前已在网上销售，这是未经批准的减肥药灰色市场活跃发展的又一例证。 《华尔街日报》发现，有数百家商家出售这种由礼来公司(Eli Lilly)开发的名为retatrutide的新药。其中的大多数似乎都是中国卖家通过Made-in-China.com等网站直接向美国消费者发货。部分网站通已过在Facebook、领英(LinkedIn)和Reddit上发布帖子来推销自己的产品，其中包括一些看起来设在美国的网站。少数网站已在Instagram和谷歌(Google)上投放付费广告。一位健身网红已通过他的简讯出售这种产品。 曾担任美国食品药品管理局(Food and Drug Administration, 简称FDA)刑事调查办公室(Office of Criminal Investigations)主任的律师George...

title: WSJ News Exclusive | This Drug Could Be the Next Ozempic. Bootlegs Are Already Selling Online.
description: By | Photographs by Carolyn Fong for The Wall Street Journal A potential blockbuster weight-loss drug still years away from U.S. regulatory approval is already being sold online, another example of a thriving gray market for unapproved weight-loss medications, according to a Wall Street Journal review. The Journal found hundreds of merchants offering the new drug, which is being developed by Eli Lilly and is called retatrutide.

authors: Micah Maidenberg,Rolfe Winkler,The Wall Street Journal (Japan)

description: SpaceX’s satellite-internet division has outpaced rivals, generated surging revenue and played a pivotal role in Ukraine. The business still has a long way to go before living up to Chief Executive Elon Musk’s ambitions.

title: FDA Warns About Safety of Custom-Made Ozempic
authors: Liz Essley Whyte,Rolfe Winkler,The Wall Street Journal
description: Some people turn to pharmacies to make solution containing active ingredientBy Liz Essley Whyte and Rolfe WinklerJune 1, 2023 12:27 pm ETThe Food and Drug Administration has warned consumers that it can’t guarantee the safety of custom-made forms of Ozempic and other popular weight-loss drugs. So many people have sought Ozempic and Wegovy to slim down that the drugs are in short supply, even for people with diabetes who need them.

title: 《超级马力欧兄弟大电影》成2023年首部票房超10亿美元影片
link: https://cn.wsj.com/articles/超级马力欧兄弟大电影-成2023年首部票房超10亿美元影片-291fa4a1
description: 根据研究公司Comscore的数据，《超级马力欧兄弟大电影》(The Super Mario Bros.)截至周日的全球票房收入估计超过了10亿美元，是2023年第一部突破这一关口的影片。 截至周日，这部电影的本土票房为4.9亿美元，国际票房为5.32亿美元。根据Box Office Mojo的数据，自新冠疫情发生以来，只有五部电影跨越了10亿美元的大关，另外四部为《阿凡达：水之道》(Avatar: The Way of Water)、《蜘蛛侠：英雄无归》(Spider-Man: No Way Home)、《壮志凌云：独行侠》(Top Gun: Maverick)和《侏罗纪世界：统治霸权》(Jurassic World: Dominion)。 这些数字表明，电影观众正回到影院，但仍然没有达到新冠疫情之前的数字。仅在2019年就有九部电影突破了10亿美元大关。...

title: ‘The Super Mario Bros. Movie’ Becomes the First Billion-Dollar-Plus Film of 2023
description: “The Super Mario Bros. Movie” surpassed $1 billion in estimated global box office receipts on Sunday, the first movie to do so in 2023, according to research firm Comscore. Through Sunday the film has grossed $490 million domestically and $532 million internationally.

title: Former Outcome Health executives found guilty of fraud
description: A federal jury convicted three former executives of the once-high-flying startup Outcome Health on several charges they ran a billion-dollar scheme that defrauded customers, including major pharmaceutical companies such as Novo Nordisk A/S and investors including Goldman Sachs Group Inc. The verdict caps the fall of an executive team led by Rishi Shah, who was close to Illinois Gov.

title: Former Outcome Health Executives Found Guilty of Fraud
authors: Rolfe Winkler,John Keilman,Patrick Thomas,The Wall Street Journal
description: Former Outcome Health CEO Rishi Shah had been charged with 22 criminal counts including wire, mail and bank fraud. A federal jury convicted three former executives of the once-highflying startup Outcome Health on several charges that they ran a billion-dollar scheme that defrauded customers including major pharmaceutical companies such as Novo Nordisk A/S as well as investors including Goldman Sachs Group Inc.

title: The $76 Billion Diet Industry Asks: What to Do About Ozempic?
authors: Andrea Petersen,Rolfe Winkler,Sara Ashley O'Brien,The Wall Street Journal
description: By Andrea Petersen, Rolfe Winkler and Sara Ashley O’BrienUpdated April 10, 2023 1:49 pm ETAnnick Lenoir-Peek, a lawyer from Durham, N.C., has struggled with her weight since adolescence. She has tried Atkins and keto and spent thousands of dollars over decades on weight-loss efforts and programs such as Noom, Nutrisystem and WeightWatchers. Since starting Ozempic in late November, she has lost around 30 pounds.

title: Easy Loans, Great Service: Why Silicon Valley Loved Silicon Valley Bank
authors: Katherine Bindley,Rolfe Winkler,Berber Jin,The Wall Street Journal
description: Silicon Valley Bank used financial sweeteners and strategic networking to attract both venture capitalists and their nascent tech companies. That strategy powered spectacular growth for decades—and left the sector extraordinarily vulnerable when the bank collapsed. SVB, founded in 1983, offered banking services to startups that often weren’t profitable, in some cases didn’t even have a product, and would otherwise have a hard time getting a line of credit or a loan from a larger bank.

title: Live Question & Answer Event - What Does the Silicon Valley Bank Failure Mean? - WSJ.com
authors: Dana Cimilluca,Rolfe Winkler,Marie Beaudette,The Wall Street Journal
description: LIVE Q&A | Begins 4:00 PM ET MARCH 13, 2023Silicon Valley Bank collapsed on Friday, becoming the largest bank to fail since the 2008 financial crisis. On Sunday, regulators took control of Signature Bank and rolled out emergency measures to prevent a banking crisis and guarantee depositors access to their money.

title: Silicon Valley Bank collapse forces venture firms to review banking deals
description: Startup founders and investors breathed a collective sigh of relief after the federal government agreed to backstop deposits at Silicon Valley Bank, but they said the lender’s collapse would drive changes in the industry’s financial practices. The decision, announced 12 March afternoon California time, ended a frenzied multiday race to shore up cash and meet payroll needs.

title: Silicon Valley Firms Expect Changes in Financial Methods After SVB Disaster
authors: Berber Jin,Katherine Bindley,Rolfe Winkler,The Wall Street Journal
description: Silicon Valley Bank built up a formidable network in Silicon Valley over its 40 years in business. Startup founders and investors breathed a collective sigh of relief after the federal government agreed to backstop deposits at Silicon Valley Bank, but they said the lender’s collapse would drive changes in the industry’s financial practices. The decision, announced Sunday afternoon California time, ended a frenzied multiday race to shore up cash and meet payroll needs.

title: After Silicon Valley Bank Fails, Tech Startups Race to Meet Payroll
authors: Berber Jin,Katherine Bindley,Rolfe Winkler,The Wall Street Journal
description: Tech startups and other businesses raced to line up sources of cash for payroll and other immediate needs after their deposits in Silicon Valley Bank, long a linchpin of tech financing, were locked up when federal authorities took control Friday morning. The bank’s sudden collapse fueled uncertainty among many founders over the immediate future of their businesses, and further hobbled a startup sector that has struggled with a sharp slowdown in venture funding and broader economic woes.

title: Startup Offering Ozempic Surges With Controversial Ads, Fake Testimonials
description: In eight months, a startup called NextMed has emerged as a growing service among many trying to capitalize on the craze for drugs such as Ozempic, Wegovy and Mounjaro that are often prescribed for weight loss. Run by a founder who graduated from college 14 months ago, the service has web traffic that has surpassed companies like Calibrate Health Inc. and Found Health Inc. that have advertised weight-loss prescriptions for longer.

title: Adderall, OxyContin Prescriptions to Require In-Person Doctor Visit Under Biden Plan
authors: Liz Essley Whyte,Rolfe Winkler,The Wall Street Journal
description: The Biden administration proposed tighter rules for the online prescription of drugs including Adderall and buprenorphine, shrinking the scope of telehealth services that expanded dramatically during the pandemic. The Drug Enforcement Administration on Friday said the telehealth restrictions would take effect after the Covid-19 public-health emergency ends on May 11. The proposed changes affect prescriptions for drugs classified as controlled substances because of their potential for abuse.

title: Health Startups Offer Diabetes Drugs Like Ozempic for Weight Loss With Little Oversight
description: In an Instagram ad for online weight-loss service NextMed, a young woman holds the skin on her stomach and complains about her “little tummy pouch.” In an ad for a similar service—launched by Instacart’s former chief executive—a model wears a yellow bikini and weighs 102 pounds, according to a modeling-agency profile.

title: WSJ News Exclusive | DEA Pressed ADHD-Drug Makers About Impact of Telehealth Firms on Surging Demand
description: The Drug Enforcement Administration told makers of medication for attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder that it was concerned that “aggressive marketing practices” by companies including telehealth providers could be driving excessive prescriptions, according to a letter from the agency. While the letter doesn’t cite specific companies, it reflects the DEA’s concerns about marketing efforts for ADHD treatment by telehealth companies such as Cerebral Inc.

title: Star Gymnast Simone Biles Breaks With Embattled Telehealth Provider Cerebral
authors: Rolfe Winkler,Louise Radnofsky,The Wall Street Journal
description: Star gymnast Simone Biles and the embattled telehealth provider Cerebral Inc. have parted ways, the company said, after announcing a partnership last year that sought to use Ms. Biles’s mental health advocacy to power growth at the startup. “The term of the contract ended earlier this year and wasn’t extended,” said Stephen Cohen, a spokesman for Cerebral. Ms. Biles’s agent declined to comment.

title: Star Gymnast Simone Biles Breaks With Embattled Telehealth Provider Cerebral
authors: Rolfe Winkler,Louise Radnofsky,The Wall Street Journal
description: The gymnast Simon Biles appeared to stop posting ads for Cerebral Inc. to her social media profiles after the spring, when controversy enveloped the company. Star gymnast Simone Biles and the embattled telehealth provider Cerebral Inc. have parted ways, the company said, after announcing a partnership last year that sought to use Ms. Biles’s mental health advocacy to power growth at the startup.

title: The failed promise of online mental-health treatment
description: Heavy advertising and other strategies from Silicon Valley’s playbook boost providers’ growth but not the quality of care. Remote treatment of mental-health problems surged in the pandemic, as in-person treatment became difficult while pandemic-driven isolation increased anxiety and depression. Digital mental-health companies plunged in, promising to provide millions with access to high-quality care by video, phone, and messaging. Many of the businesses, however, put a premium on growth.

title: The Failed Promise of Online Mental-Health Treatment
description: Remote treatment of mental-health problems surged in the pandemic, as in-person treatment became difficult while pandemic-driven isolation increased anxiety and depression. Digital mental-health companies plunged in, promising to provide millions with access to high-quality care by video, phone, and messaging.

title: Telehealth Companies Lobby to Extend Pandemic-Era Rules
authors: Liz Essley Whyte,Rolfe Winkler,Brianna Abbott,The Wall Street Journal
description: Health startups and medical associations are lobbying for permanent permission to prescribe controlled substances remotely, part of a broader debate over the future of telehealth services that boomed during the pandemic. The push comes after some online startups faced scrutiny from lawmakers and pharmacies over their prescription practices.

title: Cerebral to cut jobs amid lower growth targets
description: Telehealth startup Cerebral Inc. told staffers it is cutting jobs and restructuring its operations in moves that will affect about 20% of its employees, shrinking the company to match patient demand and lower growth targets. In a memo to staff on Monday, Chief Executive David Mou said the changes would be spread across all divisions, including headquarters, clinical-care teams and support staff.

title: WSJ News Exclusive | Cerebral to Cut About 20% of Staff as It Shrinks Operations
authors: Khadeeja Safdar,Rolfe Winkler,The Wall Street Journal
description: Telehealth company Cerebral Inc. told staff it is cutting jobs and restructuring its operations in moves that will affect about 20% of its employees, shrinking to match patient demand and lower growth targets. In a memo to staff on Monday, Chief Executive David Mou said the changes would be spread across all divisions, including headquarters, clinical-care teams and support staff.

title: Rolfe Winkler — Reporter at The Wall Street Journal
authors: Rolfe Winkler,Next page,The Wall Street Journal
description: Latest Articles ◆ WSJ News ExclusiveThe agency this summer questioned whether the recent increase in prescriptions reflects “legitimate need” or marketing pressure. Rolfe WinklerDecember 31, 2022 BusinessA contract wasn’t extended between the embattled company and the Olympic champion, who has been open about her own mental-health struggles.

title: WSJ News Exclusive | DEA Investigating ADHD Telehealth Provider Done
description: U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration agents have questioned people about telehealth company Done Global Inc.’s practices for prescribing controlled substances, according to documents reviewed by The Wall Street Journal and people familiar with the inquiries.

title: WSJ News Exclusive | ADHD Specialists Worry Stimulant Drugs Are Overprescribed, Push for Treatment Guidelines
description: A group of specialists in attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder plan to create the first U.S. guidelines for diagnosing and treating the condition in adults, partly due to the proliferation of telehealth companies that they worry are prescribing stimulant medications irresponsibly.

title: Harlan Band’s Descent Started with an Easy Online Adderall Prescription
description: Harlan Band had turned a corner. He was 29 years old and back in school, catching up on algebra and Shakespeare, earning A’s, seeking to put a lost decade behind him and looking ahead to studying medicine. That was the story Mr. Band told his family. He also said it was the reason he sought help from Done Global Inc., an online mental-health company that prescribes stimulants like Adderall in video calls as short as 10 minutes.

title: Harlan Band's Descent Started with an Easy Online Adderall Prescription
description: The 29-year-old man got the amphetamine through a telemedicine startup where some clinicians felt pressure to prescribe the drug

title: 美国FTC对心理健康初创公司Cerebral的商业做法展开调查
link: https://cn.wsj.com/articles/美国ftc对cerebral的商业做法展开调查-11655250307
description: 据《华尔街日报》(The Wall Street Journal)看到的美国联邦贸易委员会(FTC)致心理健康初创公司Cerebral Inc.的一封信显示，该委员会已开始对该公司展开调查。 FTC在6月1日的信中说，正在调查Cerebral是否在心理健康服务的广告或营销方面进行了欺骗或不公平的做法。这封信还要求该公司保存文件。 ...

title: FTC investigating business practices of mental-health startup Cerebral
description: The Federal Trade Commission has begun an investigation into mental-health startup Cerebral Inc., according to a letter the FTC sent the company that was reviewed by The Wall Street Journal. In the letter dated June 1, the FTC said it was investigating whether Cerebral engaged in deceptive or unfair practices related to advertising or marketing of mental-health services. The letter also directed the company to preserve documents.

title: WSJ News Exclusive | Mental-Health Startup Cerebral Investigated by FTC
authors: Rolfe Winkler,Khadeeja Safdar,The Wall Street Journal
description: The Federal Trade Commission has begun an investigation into mental-health startup Cerebral Inc., according to a letter the FTC sent the company that was reviewed by The Wall Street Journal. In the letter dated June 1, the FTC said it was investigating whether Cerebral engaged in deceptive or unfair practices related to advertising or marketing of mental-health services. The letter also directed the company to preserve documents.

title: Tell Us About Your Experience With Telehealth for Treating ADHD
description: The Wall Street Journal is looking at issues related to online mental-health startups, including Cerebral and Done, and their prescribing practices for patients. Use the form below to tell us about your experience.

title: Startup Cerebral Soared on Easy Adderall Prescriptions. That Was Its Undoing.
authors: Rolfe Winkler,Khadeeja Safdar,Andrea Fuller,The Wall Street Journal
description: Startup Cerebral Soared on Easy Adderall Prescriptions. That Was Its Undoing. The online mental health company surged to a $4.8 billion valuation after it started dispensing ADHD medication, but staffers grew concerned that it was pushing the drugs too aggressivelyAdderall prescriptions fueled Cerebral’s rise. Colin Temple/Alamy

title: WSJ News Exclusive | CVS Will Stop Filling Controlled-Substance Prescriptions for Cerebral, Done
description: CVS Health Corp. will stop filling prescriptions for controlled substances ordered by clinicians working for Cerebral Inc. and Done Health starting Thursday, a move that will impact thousands of patients. Cerebral disclosed the change in a statement to The Wall Street Journal. The pharmacy plans to block Done prescriptions for controlled substances as well, according to a person familiar with the matter.

title: Cerebral Replaces CEO Kyle Robertson, a Move He Says is Illegal
description: Cerebral Inc. has replaced Chief Executive Kyle Robertson, according to a statement released by the company, a move Mr. Robertson has called illegal after accusing board members of making him a scapegoat for the company’s troubles. The board said in the statement that it has replaced Mr. Robertson with David Mou, the firm’s president and chief medical officer.

title: WSJ News Exclusive | Cerebral Board Members Agree to Replace CEO Amid Federal Probe Into Prescription Practices
description: Directors who control the board of Cerebral Inc. agreed on a plan to replace Chief Executive Kyle Robertson, sparking leadership tumult at the mental-health startup as it contends with scrutiny over its prescription practices for controlled substances, people familiar with the situation said Tuesday.

title: Cerebral Says It Will Stop Prescribing Most Controlled Substances
description: Online mental-health company Cerebral Inc. said it would stop prescribing almost all controlled substances, expanding an overhaul of its treatment practices in the wake of scrutiny over how it provided stimulants for attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder.

title: Cerebral Receives Subpoena from Federal Prosecutors
description: Cerebral Inc., the online mental-health company, said on Saturday it has been subpoenaed by federal prosecutors as part of an investigation into possible violations of the Controlled Substances Act. Cerebral, one of a group of telehealth startups that have sprung up to treat attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder, said the grand jury subpoena was received on Wednesday from the U.S. attorney’s office for the Eastern District of New York.

title: 远程医疗初创公司Cerebral将停止为新患者开具兴奋剂处方Adderall
link: https://cn.wsj.com/articles/远程医疗初创公司cerebral将停止为新患者开具兴奋剂处方adderall-11651707908
description: Cerebral的高管告诉其临床医生，该公司将从周一起暂停为新病患开具治疗注意力缺陷多动障碍(简称ADHD)的Adderall等受管制药物。 Cerebral的联合创始人兼首席执行官Kyle Robertson在本周发给员工的电邮中宣布了这一消息，并称该公司将继续治疗现有的ADHD患者。 该公司做出上述决定之前，其首选药店Truepill Inc.表示将停止接受Adderall等兴奋剂处方。

title: Cerebral Will Stop Prescribing Adderall for New Patients
description: Cerebral executives told its clinicians that the company will pause prescribing controlled substances like Adderall to treat attention deficit hyperactivity disorder in new patients beginning Monday, the company said. Cerebral’s Co-Founder and Chief Executive Kyle Robertson made the announcement in an email sent to staff this week, adding that the company will continue to treat existing ADHD patients.

title: Cerebral Will Stop Prescribing Adderall For New Patients
description: Cerebral executives told its clinicians that the company will pause prescribing controlled substances like Adderall to treat attention deficit hyperactivity disorder beginning Monday, the company said. Cerebral’s Co-Founder and Chief Executive Kyle Robertson made the announcement to staff in an email sent to staff this week, adding that the company will continue to treat existing ADHD patients.

title: WSJ News Exclusive | Cerebral’s Preferred Pharmacy Truepill Halts Adderall Prescriptions for All Customers
description: Online pharmacy company Truepill Inc. said it is temporarily halting prescriptions for Adderall and other controlled substances used to treat attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder, and partner Cerebral Inc. told its clinicians to direct those orders to patients’ local pharmacies. Cerebral, an online mental-health company based in San Francisco that describes Truepill as its preferred pharmacy, informed its clinicians of Truepill’s decision in a Friday email viewed by The Wall Street Journal.

title: Former Cerebral Executive Alleges Unsafe Prescribing Practices in Lawsuit
description: A former executive of online mental-health company Cerebral Inc. alleged in a labor lawsuit that the company prescribed stimulant medications for “business reasons” to patients seeking treatment for attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder.

title: DRUGSTOIRES BLOCK STARTUPS' ADDERALL ORDERS
authors: Rolfe Winkler,Sarah Nassauer,The Wall Street Journal
description: ABSTRACTWalmart, CVS Health and Walgreen Boots Alliance are among pharmacies sometimes blocking or delaying prescriptions for Adderall by clinicians at telehealth startups Done Health and Cerebral that have sprung up to treat attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder, saying they are writing too many prescriptions for it and other stimulants; graph (M)

title: WSJ News Exclusive | Walmart, CVS Pharmacies Have Blocked or Delayed Telehealth Adderall Prescriptions
authors: Rolfe Winkler,Sarah Nassauer,The Wall Street Journal
description: Some of the nation’s largest pharmacies have blocked or delayed prescriptions over the last year from clinicians working for telehealth startups that have sprung up to treat attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder, according to pharmacies and people familiar with the issue. The pharmacies in certain cases have expressed concerns that clinicians at Done Health and Cerebral Inc. are writing too many prescriptions for Adderall and other stimulants, the people said.

title: Venture firm Sequoia Capital names new leader
authors: Heather Somerville,Rolfe Winkler,Eliot Brown,Private Equity News
description: Venture Captial The appointment of Both comes as Sequoia tries to navigate its increasingly complex relationship with its powerful China affiliate Roelof Botha will take on a new role overseeing the firm's US and European funds Getty Images for TechCrunch By Heather Somerville, Rolfe Winkler and Eliot Brown Monday April 11, 2022 9:16 am Sequoia Capital named a new top leader, a rare transfer of power at one of Silicon Valley’s most storied venture capital firms. Sequoia partner Roelof Botha...

title: Venture Powerhouse Sequoia Capital Names New Leader
authors: Heather Somerville,Rolfe Winkler,Eliot Brown,The Wall Street Journal
description: Sequoia Capital named a new top leader, a rare transfer of power at one of Silicon Valley’s most storied venture-capital firms. Sequoia partner Roelof Botha will take on a new role overseeing the firm’s U.S. and European funds, the company announced. In a concurrent note to investors, exiting Sequoia leader Doug Leone wrote that Mr. Botha “will set the overall tone and oversee the global centralized functions.”

title: Apple wants iPhones to detect car crashes, auto-dial 911
description: Beginning next year, iPhone users in the US who are in a car accident could have their phone dial 911 automatically. Apple Inc plans next year to roll out a product feature called “crash detection” for iPhones and Apple Watches, according to documents reviewed by The Wall Street Journal and people familiar with the feature.

title: WSJスクープ | iPhoneに車衝突時の緊急通報機能　アップル、来年導入か
description: アップルは来年iPhoneとAppleWatchに衝突検知機能を導入する計画だ Photo: Jenny Sathngam/Bloomberg News 米アップルのスマートフォン「iPhone（アイフォーン）」のユーザーが車に乗っているときに衝突事故に遭った場合、来年から自動的に911（日本の110番に相当）に緊急通報されるようになる可能性がある。 アップルはiPhoneと時計型端末「AppleWatch（アップルウオッチ）」に来年、衝突検知機能を導入する計画だ。ウォール・ストリート・ジャーナル（WSJ）が確認した資料と複数の関係者の話で明らかになった。 この機能は衝突時の加速度計のデータなど、アップル端末搭載のセンサーのデータから衝突を検出する。...

title: WSJ News Exclusive | Apple Wants iPhones to Detect Car Crashes, Auto-Dial 911
description: Beginning next year, iPhone users who are in a car accident could have their phone dial 911 automatically. Crash detection uses data from sensors built into Apple devices including the accelerometer to detect car accidents as they occur, for instance by measuring a sudden spike in gravity, or “g,” forces on impact. The feature would mark the latest move by Apple and its competitors to use motion-sensor technology to build safety functions into their devices.

title: Apple studying potential of AirPods as health device
description: Apple Inc. is studying ways to make AirPods into a health device, including for enhancing hearing, reading body temperature and monitoring posture, according to documents reviewed by The Wall Street Journal and people familiar with the plans. The plans further demonstrate Apple’s ambition to add health and wellness features to devices beyond the Apple Watch, where most of the company’s health functions exist today.

title: WSJスクープ | アップル、「AirPods」にも健康管理機能追加か＝関係者
description: AirPodsの2020年の売上高は推定128億ドルに上った Photo: Kenny Wassus/The Wall Street Journal 　米アップルがワイヤレスイヤホン「AirPods（エアポッズ）」に補聴器や体温計、姿勢のモニター機能などを追加し、健康管理に役立つ機器にすることを検討している。ウォール・ストリート・ジャーナル（WSJ）が確認した資料や関係者の話で明らかになった。 　このうち補聴機能については、新たに開発しているのか、既存の聴覚支援機能を「補聴器」として宣伝する計画なのかは分かっていない。上位モデルの「エアポッズ・プロ」には既に、近くにいる人の会話の音量・音質を改善する機能などが備えられている。 　関係者によると、エアポッズへの新機能追加は早くても来年以降となり、時期がずれ込んだり、実現しない可能性もある。 　アップル広報はコメントを控えた。 ※この記事は更新されます。 Copyright ©2021 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

title: WSJ News Exclusive | Apple Studying Potential of AirPods as Health Device
description: Apple Inc. AAPL -0.91% is studying ways to make AirPods into a health device, including for enhancing hearing, reading body temperature and monitoring posture, according to documents reviewed by The Wall Street Journal and people familiar with the plans. The plans further demonstrate Apple’s ambition to add health and wellness features to devices beyond the Apple Watch, where most of the company’s health functions exist today.

title: WSJ News Exclusive | Apple Is Working on iPhone Features to Help Detect Depression, Cognitive Decline
description: Apple Inc. is working on technology to help diagnose depression and cognitive decline, aiming for tools that could expand the scope of its burgeoning health portfolio, according to people familiar with the matter and documents reviewed by The Wall Street Journal.

title: WSJ News Exclusive | Apple Plans Blood-Pressure Measure, Wrist Thermometer in Apple Watch
description: The company is expected to release its seventh version of the Apple Watch in the coming weeks, according to analysts, but most of its more ambitious health-related improvements aren’t expected before 2022. Beyond next year, Apple wants its smartwatch to be able to detect sleep apnea, provide medical guidance when it senses low blood oxygen levels and, perhaps one day, spot diabetes, according to the documents and some of the people.

title: Brain Implant Lets Man ‘Speak’ After Being Silent for More Than a Decade
description: Researchers in California reported Wednesday that they had developed and successfully tested an experimental brain implant that translates brain signals into words on a computer screen. The achievement, described in a paper published in the New England Journal of Medicine, marks a step toward technology that may one day help people speak by thinking. It also offers a glimmer of hope for the thousands of people who each year lose the ability to speak as a result of injury or illness.

title: Robot Bassinet Company Eyes New Funding to Power Growth
description: Harvey Karp turned a bestselling baby book into a robot bassinet that is among the hottest products for yuppie parents. Now he is looking for fresh capital to finance new products and expand to new markets to justify the rich exit he is promising investors. Dr. Karp, a pediatrician, hit it big with his smart bassinet, called the Snoo, that automates some of his popular techniques for calming fussy babies.

title: WSJ News Exclusive | Apple Struggles in Push to Make Healthcare Its Greatest Legacy
description: Apple Inc. AAPL -0.64% Chief Executive Tim Cook has said the company’s greatest contribution to mankind will be in health. So far, some Apple initiatives aimed at broadly disrupting the healthcare sector have struggled to gain traction, according to people familiar with them and documents reviewed by The Wall Street Journal.

title: Walmart Deal Shows Expansion in Telehealth, New Front With Amazon
authors: Sarah Nassauer,Rolfe Winkler,The Wall Street Journal
description: Walmart Inc. said Thursday it purchased telehealth provider MeMD, another sign that the retail behemoth aims to expand its healthcare business.
